Text

TOWARDS the close of last July , when the [London]1-london season was fast dying of the dust , [Otho Laurence]77-otho had invited what [the Morning Post]78-the morning post called ‘ [a select circle of [friends]1669-friends]1668-a select circle of friends , ’[302-a very singular man] to spend a quiet Sunday with [him]298-him at [[his]298-him cool villa by [the sea]300-the sea]299-his cool villa by the sea . [This singular retreat]301-this singular retreat was the work of [a very singular man]302-a very singular man , [[Otho Laurence]77-otho ’s uncle]303-otho laurence ’s uncle , who had squandered on [it]301-this singular retreat an immense fortune , and had designed it as far as possible to embody [his]302-a very singular man own tastes and character . [He]302-a very singular man was a member of [a Tory family of some note]304-a tory family of some note , and had near relations in both [Houses of Parliament]2-houses of parliament ; but [he]302-a very singular man was [himself]302-a very singular man possessed of a deep though quiet antipathy to the two things generally most cherished by those of [his]302-a very singular man time and order , the ideas of Christianity and Feudalism ; and [he]302-a very singular man studiously kept [himself]302-a very singular man clear of all public life . Pride of birth , indeed , [he]302-a very singular man had in no small measure ; but it was the pride of [a Roman of the Empire]305-a roman of the empire rather than of [an Englishman]306-an englishman ; a pride which , instead of connecting [him]302-a very singular man with [prince]307-prince or [people]308-people , made [him]302-a very singular man shun [the one]309-the one as [a Cæsar]310-a cæsar , and forget the other as [slaves]311-slaves . All [his]302-a very singular man pleasures were those of [a lettered voluptuary , who would , as [he]302-a very singular man himself said , have been more in place under [Augustus]79-augustus or [the Antonines]80-the antonines]312-a lettered voluptuary , who would , as he himself said , have been more in place under augustus or the antonines ; and modern existence , under most of its aspects , [he]302-a very singular man affected to regard as barbarous . Next to [a bishop]313-a bishop , the thing [he]302-a very singular man most disliked was [a courtier]314-a courtier ; next to [a courtier]314-a courtier , [a fox - hunting country gentleman]316-a fox - hunting country gentleman . But nothing in [his]302-a very singular man life , perhaps , was so characteristic of [him]302-a very singular man as [his]302-a very singular man leaving of it . During [his]302-a very singular man last hours [he]302-a very singular man was soothed by [a pretty and somewhat educated housemaid]317-a pretty and somewhat educated housemaid , whom [he]302-a very singular man called [Phyllis]81-phyllis , and whom [he]302-a very singular man made sit by [his]302-a very singular man bedside , and read aloud to [him]302-a very singular man [Gibbon]82-gibbon ’s two chapters on Christianity . [Phyllis]81-phyllis had just come to the celebrated excerpt from [Tertullian]3-tertullian , in which [that father]318-that father contemplates the future torments of [the unbelievers]319-the unbelievers , when [the parish clergyman , who had been sent for by [[Mr. Laurence]83-laurence ’s widowed sister - in - law]321-mr. laurence ’s widowed sister - in - law]320-the parish clergyman , who had been sent for by mr. laurence ’s widowed sister - in - law , arrived to offer [his]302-a very singular man services . ‘ How shall [I]0-i admire’—these were the words that , read in a low sweet tone , first greeted [his]302-a very singular man ears when [he]302-a very singular man was shown softly into [the sick chamber]1670-the sick chamber — ‘[0-i] how shall [I]0-i admire , how laugh , how rejoice , how exult , when [I]0-i behold [so many proud monarchs]322-so many proud monarchs , [so many fancied gods]323-so many fancied gods , groaning in the lowest abyss of darkness ; [so many magistrates who persecuted the name of [the Lord]325-the lord , liquefying in a fiercer fire than ever [they]324-so many magistrates who persecuted the name of the lord , liquefying in a fiercer fire than ever they kindled against the christians kindled against [the Christians]326-the christians]324-so many magistrates who persecuted the name of the lord , liquefying in a fiercer fire than ever they kindled against the christians ! ’ [The clergyman]1671-the clergyman was at first much reassured at hearing words so edifying ; but when [he]1671-the clergyman turned to [old Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , [he]1671-the clergyman was dismayed to see on [his]1671-the clergyman pale face , no signs of awe , but only a faint smile , full of sarcastic humour . [He]1671-the clergyman therefore glanced at the book that was lying on [the girl]1672-the girl ’s lap , and discovered to [his]1671-the clergyman horror the work of [the infidel historian]1673-the infidel historian . [He]1671-the clergyman was at first struck dumb ; but , soon recovering [himself]1671-the clergyman , began to say something suitable at once to [his]1671-the clergyman own profession and to [the sick man]1674-the sick man ’s needs . [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence answered [him]1671-the clergyman with the greatest courtesy , but with many thanks declined any assistance from [him]1671-the clergyman ; saying wistfully that [he]0-i knew [he]0-i had not long to live , and that [his]0-i one wish was that [he]0-i could open [his]0-i veins in a bath , and so fade gently into death ; ‘[84-petronius] and then , ’ [he]0-i added , ‘[84-petronius] [my]0-i soul , if [I]0-i have one , might perhaps be with [Petronius]84-petronius , and with [Seneca]85-seneca . And yet sleep would , [I]0-i think , be better than even [their]327-their company . ’ [The poor clergyman]1675-the poor clergyman bade a hasty adieu , and [Phyllis]81-phyllis resumed [her]81-phyllis reading . [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence listened to every word : the smile returned to [his]83-laurence lips that had for a moment left them , and was still upon them when , half - an - hour afterwards , [he]83-laurence died , so quietly that [Phyllis]81-phyllis did not perceive it , but continued [her]81-phyllis reading for some time to ears that could hear nothing . All [his]83-laurence property [he]83-laurence left to [[his]83-laurence nephew]1676-his nephew [Otho]77-otho , including [[his]83-laurence splendid villa]1677-his splendid villa , which was indeed , as [it]1677-his splendid villa was meant to be , a type of [[its]1677-his splendid villa builder]1678-its builder . [It]1677-his splendid villa was [a house of pillars , porticoes , and statues]1679-a house of pillars , porticoes , and statues , designed ambitiously in what was meant to be a classical style ; and though [its]1677-his splendid villa splendours might not be all perhaps in the best taste , nor even of the most strictly Roman pattern , there was yet an air about [its]1677-his splendid villa meretricious stateliness by which the clays of [the Empire]1680-the empire were at once suggested to [one]1681-one , a magnificence that : would at any rate have pleased [Trimalcio]86-trimalcio , though it might have scandalised [Horace]87-horace . [Otho Laurence]77-otho inherited with [[[his]83-laurence uncle]1682-his uncle ’s house]1683-his uncle ’s house something of the tastes and feelings of which it was the embodiment . But , though an epicure by training and by temper , [he]83-laurence had been open to other influences as well . At one time of [his]83-laurence life [he]83-laurence had , as it is expressed by [some]1684-some , experienced religion ; and not religion only , but thought and speculation also . Indeed , ever since [he]83-laurence was twenty - four , [he]83-laurence had been troubled by a painful sense that [he]83-laurence ought to have some mission in life . The only difficulty was that [he]83-laurence could find none that would suit [him]83-laurence . [He]83-laurence had considerable natural powers , and was in many ways [a remarkable man]1685-a remarkable man ; but , unhappily , [one of those who are remarkable because [they]1685-a remarkable man do not become famous , not because [they]1685-a remarkable man do]1686-one of those who are remarkable because they do not become famous , not because they do . [He]83-laurence was one of those of whom it is said till [they]1685-a remarkable man are thirty , that [they]1685-a remarkable man will do something ; till [they]1685-a remarkable man are thirty - five , that [they]1685-a remarkable man might do something if [they]1685-a remarkable man chose ; and after that , that [they]1685-a remarkable man might have done anything if [they]1685-a remarkable man had chosen . [Laurence]83-laurence was as yet only three years gone in the second stage , but such of [[his]83-laurence friends]1687-his friends as were ambitious for [him]83-laurence feared that three years more would find [him]83-laurence landed in the third . [He]83-laurence , too , was beginning to share this fear ; and , not being humble enough to despair of [himself]83-laurence , was by this time taking to despair of [his]83-laurence century . [He]83-laurence was thus hardly [a happy man]1688-a happy man ; but , like [many unhappy men]1689-many unhappy men , [he]83-laurence was capable of keen enjoyments . Chief amongst these was society in certain forms , especially a party in [[his]83-laurence own house]1690-his own house , such as that which [he]83-laurence had now assembled [there]1691-there . To this one in particular [he]83-laurence looked forward with more than usual pleasure , partly because of the peculiar elements which [he]83-laurence had contrived to combine in it , but chiefly because amongst them was to be [[his]83-laurence friend [Robert Leslie]88-leslie , who had been living abroad , and whom [he]83-laurence had not seen for two years]1692-his friend robert leslie , who had been living abroad , and whom he had not seen for two years . [[Laurence]83-laurence ’s aunt]1693-laurence ’s aunt , [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , helped to receive [the guests]1694-the guests , who by dinner - time on Saturday evening had all arrived . [Robert Leslie]88-leslie was the last . The dressing - bell had just done ringing as [he]83-laurence drove up to the door , and [the others]1695-the others had already gone [upstairs]1696-upstairs ; but [he]83-laurence found [Laurence]83-laurence in [the library]1697-the library , sitting with [his]83-laurence head on [his]83-laurence hand , and a pile of menu - cards on the desk before [him]83-laurence . [The two friends]1698-the two friends met with much warmth , and then examined [each other]1699-each other ’s faces to see if either had changed . ‘[328-you] [You]328-you told [me]0-i [you]328-you had been ill , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , having again looked at [Leslie]88-leslie , ‘[328-you] and [I]0-i am afraid [you]328-you do n’t seem quite well yet . ’ ‘[328-you] [You]328-you forget , ’ said [Leslie]88-leslie , whose laugh was a little hollow , ‘[328-you] that [I]0-i was on [the sea]300-the sea six hours ago ; and , as [you]328-you know , [I]0-i am [a wretched sailor]330-a wretched sailor . But the worst of human maladies are the most transient also — love , that is half despairing , and sea - sickness that is quite so . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i congratulate [you]328-you , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , again examining [[his]83-laurence friend]1700-his friend ’s face , ‘[0-i] on [your]328-you true cynical manner . [I]0-i often thought [we]331-we might have [masters in cynicism]332-masters in cynicism just as [we]331-we have [masters in singing]333-masters in singing . Perhaps [I]0-i shall be able to learn the art from [you]328-you . ’ ‘[0-i] Oh ! ’ said [Leslie]88-leslie , ‘[0-i] the theory is simple enough . Find out , by a little suffering , what are the things [you]328-you hold most sacred , and most firmly believe in , and , whenever an occasion offers , deny [your]328-you faith . [A cynic]334-a cynic is a kind of [inverted confessor]335-inverted confessor , perpetually making enemies for the sake of what [he]334-a cynic knows to be false . ’ ‘[334-a cynic] Ah ! ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[334-a cynic] but [I]0-i do n’t want theory . [I]0-i know what is sacred just as well as [you]328-you , and , when [I]0-i am beast enough to be quite out of tune with it , [I]0-i have the good sense to call it [a phantom]336-a phantom . But [I]0-i do n’t do this with sufficient energy . It is skill in cynical practice [I]0-i want — a lesson in the pungent manner — the bitter tone — ’ ‘[0-i] Then please not to take [your]328-you lessons from [me]0-i , ’ said [Leslie]88-leslie . ‘[0-i] [Imitation]90-imitation may be the sincerest flattery , but it is , of all , the most irritating : and [a cynic]334-a cynic , as [you]328-you are good enough to call [me]0-i , feels this especially . For [a cynic]334-a cynic is [the one preacher , remember , that never wants to make converts]339-the one preacher , remember , that never wants to make converts . [His]334-a cynic aim is to outrage , not to convince : to create enemies , not to conquer [them]340-them . The peculiar charm that [his]334-a cynic creed has for [him]334-a cynic , is [his]334-a cynic own peculiarity in holding it . [He]334-a cynic is an acid that can only fizz with an alkali , and [he]334-a cynic therefore hates in [others]341-others what [he]334-a cynic most admires in [himself]334-a cynic . So if [you]328-you hear [me]0-i say a bitter thing , please be good enough to brim over immediately with the milk of human kindness . If [I]0-i say anything disrespectful about friendship , please be good enough to look hurt ; and if [I]0-i happen to say — what is the chief part of [the cynic]342-the cynic ’s stock - in - trade — that [no woman]343-no woman was ever sincere or faithful , [I]0-i trust [you]328-you have [some lady amongst [[your]328-you visitors]344-your visitors who will look at [me]0-i with mournful eyes , and say to [me]0-i , “ Ah , if [you]328-you did but know ! ” ’ ‘[1701-some lady amongst your visitors who will look at me with mournful eyes , and say to me , “ ah , if you did but know ! ” ’ ‘ well , ’ said laurence] Well , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence]1701-some lady amongst your visitors who will look at me with mournful eyes , and say to me , “ ah , if you did but know ! ” ’ ‘ well , ’ said laurence , ‘[1701-some lady amongst your visitors who will look at me with mournful eyes , and say to me , “ ah , if you did but know ! ” ’ ‘ well , ’ said laurence] perhaps [I]0-i have ; but , talking of what [people]308-people are to say , [I]0-i have something here about which [I]0-i want [you]328-you to help [me]0-i . [You]328-you see these cards ; they are all double . Now that second half is for something quite new , and of [my]0-i own invention . [The cook]346-the cook has written [his]346-the cook part already , so [you]328-you need not look so alarmed ; but [he]346-the cook has only provided for the tongue as a tasting instrument ; [I]0-i am going to provide for it as a talking one . In fact , [I]0-i am going to have a menu for the conversation , and to this [I]0-i shall make [everyone]347-everyone strictly adhere . For it has always seemed absurd to [me]0-i to be so careful about what [we]348-we put into [our]348-we mouths , and to leave chance to arrange what comes out of them ; to be so particular as to the order of what [we]348-we eat , and to have no order at all in what [we]348-we talk about . This is the case especially in parties like the present , where [most of [the people]350-the people]349-most of the people know [each other]1699-each other only a little , and if left to [themselves]349-most of the people would never touch on the topics that would make [them]349-most of the people best acquainted , and best bring out [their]349-most of the people several personal flavours . That is what [I]0-i like to see conversation doing . [I]0-i ought to have written these menus before ; but [I]0-i have been busy all day , and , besides , [I]0-i wanted [you]352-you to help [me]0-i . [I]0-i was just beginning without [you]352-you when [you]352-you arrived , as [I]0-i could wait no longer ; but [I]0-i have put down nothing yet : indeed [I]0-i could not fix upon the first topic that is to correspond with the soup — the first vernal breath of discussion that is to open the buds of [the shy and strange souls]353-the shy and strange souls . So come , now — what shall [we]348-we begin with ? What [we]348-we want is something that [anyone]354-anyone can talk easily about , whether [he]354-anyone knows anything of it or not — something , too , that may be treated in any way , either with laughter , feeling , or even a little touch of temper . ’ ‘[0-i] Love , ’ suggested [Leslie]88-leslie . ‘[0-i] That is too strong to begin with , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[0-i] and too real . Besides , introduced in that way , it would be , [I]0-i think , rather common and vulgar . No — the only thing that suggested itself to [me]0-i was religion . ’ ‘[91-bottom] Nothing could be better in some ways , ’ said [Leslie]88-leslie ; ‘[91-bottom] but might not that , too , be rather strong meat for some ? [I]0-i apprehend , like [Bottom]91-bottom , that “ [the ladies]355-the ladies might be afeared of the lion . ” [I]0-i should suggest rather the question , “ Are [you]356-you High - church or [Low - church]357-low - church ? ” There is something in that which at once disarms reverence , and may also just titillate the interests , the temper , or the sense of humour . Quick , ’ [he]0-i said , taking one of the cards , ‘[348-we] and let [us]348-we begin to write . ’ ‘[348-we] Stop , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence ; ‘[348-we] not so fast , let [me]0-i beg of [you]356-you . Instead of religion , or anything connected with it , [we]348-we will have , “ What is the Aim of Life ? ” Is not this the thing of things to suit [us]348-we ? About what do [we]348-we know less or talk more ? There is a Sphinx in each of [our]348-we souls that is always asking [us]348-we this riddle ; and when [we]348-we are lazy or disappointed , [we]348-we all of [us]348-we lounge up to [her]358-her , and make languid guesses . So about this [we]348-we shall all of [us]348-we have plenty to say , and can say it in any way [we]348-we like , flippant , serious , or sentimental . Think , too , how many avenues of thought and feeling it opens up ! Evidently the “ Aim of Life ” is the thing to begin with . ’ [Leslie]88-leslie assented ; and before many minutes [they]348-we had made the menu complete . The ‘[361-you] Aim of Life ’ was to be followed by ‘[361-you] [Town and Country]359-town and country , ’ which was designed to introduce a discussion as to where the Aim of Life was to be best attained . After this , by an easy transition , came ‘[361-you] Society ; ’ next by way of entreés , ‘[361-you] Art and Literature , ’ ‘[361-you] Love and Money , ’ ‘[361-you] Riches and Civilisation ; ’ then ‘[361-you] The Present , ’ as something solid and satisfying ; and lastly , a light superfluity to dally with , brightly coloured and unsubstantial , with the entremets came ‘[361-you] The Future . ’ ‘[361-you] And who is [here]360-here , ’ said [Leslie]88-leslie , as [they]348-we were ending [their]348-we labours , ‘[361-you] to enjoy this feast of reason ? ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i will tell [you]361-you , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘[0-i] In the first place , there is [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , [a woman of a very old but poor family , who has married [a modern M.P.]363-a modern m.p. with more than a million of money]362-a woman of a very old but poor family , who has married a modern m.p. with more than a million of money . [She]92-lady ambrose is very particular about knowing [the right people]364-the right people , and has lovely , large grey eyes . Then there is [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , [a Roman Catholic young lady]365-a roman catholic young lady , [the daughter of [old Sir Ascot Merton]94-old sir ascot merton]366-the daughter of old sir ascot merton , [the horse - racing evangelical]367-the horse - racing evangelical . [I]0-i knew [her]93-miss merton well five years ago , but had not seen [her]93-miss merton since [her]93-miss merton conversion , till to - day . Then [we]368-we have [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , [the great Broad - church divine who thinks that Christianity is not dead , but changed by [himself]95-dr. jenkinson and [his]95-dr. jenkinson followers]369-the great broad - church divine who thinks that christianity is not dead , but changed by himself and his followers in the twinkling of an eye . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i met [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , ’ said [Leslie]88-leslie , ‘[95-dr. jenkinson] just before [I]0-i went abroad , at a great dinner given by [Baron Isaacs]96-baron isaacs , in honour of [[his]96-baron isaacs horse]370-his horse having won the Derby . Well — and who else is there ? ’ ‘[371-two celebrated members of the royal society] [Two celebrated members of the Royal Society]371-two celebrated members of the royal society , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence ; ‘[371-two celebrated members of the royal society] [no less persons than — But , good gracious]372-no less persons than — but , good gracious ! it is time [we]368-we were up - stairs dressing . Come along directly , and [I]0-i will explain [the other people]373-the other people to [you]374-you before dinner . ’ IT was half - past eight , and [the party]1702-the party were fast assembling in [the twilight drawing - room]1703-the twilight drawing - room . [Leslie]88-leslie was lounging in one of the windows , by a large stand of flowers and broad - leaved plants , and was studying the company with considerable interest . [His]88-leslie first impression was of little more than of a number of [men]1704-men ’s dark coats and white shirt - fronts , tables , couches , and gilded chairs , and the pleasant many - coloured glimmerings of female apparel . But before long [he]88-leslie had observed more minutely . There were [men who [he]88-leslie instinctively felt were [celebrities]1706-celebrities , discoursing to [groups of [ladies]1708-ladies]1707-groups of ladies]1705-men who he instinctively felt were celebrities , discoursing to groups of ladies ; there were [ladies who [he]88-leslie at once saw were attractive , being discoursed to by [groups of [men]1704-men]1710-groups of men]1709-ladies who he at once saw were attractive , being discoursed to by groups of men . [He]88-leslie very soon detected [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , [a fine handsome woman of perhaps thirty , with the large grey eyes of which [Laurence]83-laurence had spoken , and a very clear complexion]1712-a fine handsome woman of perhaps thirty , with the large grey eyes of which laurence had spoken , and a very clear complexion . Forming a third in [this group , dropping in a word or two at intervals]1714-this group , dropping in a word or two at intervals , [he]88-leslie recognised [the celebrated Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson — still full of vigour , though [his]95-dr. jenkinson hair was silver — the sharp and restless sparkle of whose eyes , strangely joined with the most benevolent of smiles , [Leslie]88-leslie remembered to have noticed at [Baron Isaacs]96-baron isaacs ’[0-i] festival . [He]375-him had just identified [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose and [the Doctor]376-the doctor , when [Laurence]83-laurence came up to [him]375-him in the window , and began to tell [him]375-him who was who . ‘ [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson is [the only one [I]88-leslie know]1715-the only one i know , ’[88-leslie] said [Leslie]88-leslie , ‘ and , naturally enough , [he]95-dr. jenkinson forgets [me]88-leslie . ’[88-leslie] ‘ Well , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ [that man]1716-that man by [himself]1716-that man , turning over the books on the table — [the man with the black whiskers , spectacles , and bushy eyebrows]1717-the man with the black whiskers , spectacles , and bushy eyebrows — is [Mr. Storks of the Royal Society , who is great on the physical basis of life and the imaginative basis of God]1718-mr. storks of the royal society , who is great on the physical basis of life and the imaginative basis of god . That , too , is [another critic close by [him]99-mr. luke]1731-another critic close by him — the pale creature , with large moustache , looking out of the window at the sunset . [He]1731-another critic close by him is [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , [the pre - Raphaelite]1732-the pre - raphaelite . [He]1731-another critic close by him always speaks in an undertone , and [his]1731-another critic close by him two topics are self - indulgence and art . [The young man there with [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose and [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson]1733-the young man there with lady ambrose and dr. jenkinson , is [Lord Allen]101-allen . [He]101-allen is only two- or three - and - twenty ; still , had [you]1734-you been in [England]4-england lately , [you]1734-you would often have heard [his]101-allen name . [He]101-allen has come early into [an immense property]1735-an immense property , and [he]101-allen yet is conscious that [he]101-allen has duties in life . However — [that redheaded youth]1738-that redheaded youth thinks very differently . [He]1738-that redheaded youth is [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders from [Oxford]5-oxford , supposed to be very clever and advanced . Next [him]1738-that redheaded youth is [Donald Gordon]103-donald gordon , who has deserted deer - stalking and [the Kirk]1739-the kirk , for literature and German metaphysics . ’[83-laurence] ‘ And who is that , ’[88-leslie] said [Leslie]88-leslie , ’ [the young lady with those large and rather sad - looking eyes , and the delicate , proud mouth]1740-the young lady with those large and rather sad - looking eyes , and the delicate , proud mouth ? ’[88-leslie] ‘ Which ? ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘ [The one on the sofa]1741-the one on the sofa , ’[88-leslie] said [Leslie]88-leslie , ‘ who looks so like a [Reynolds]104-reynolds portrait — like [a duchess of the last century]1742-a duchess of the last century — [the lady in the pale blue dress]1743-the lady in the pale blue dress , talking to [that man with such a curiously attractive smile and the worn melancholy look]1744-that man with such a curiously attractive smile and the worn melancholy look ? ’[88-leslie] ‘ That , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ is [Miss Merton]93-miss merton . [He]1744-that man with such a curiously attractive smile and the worn melancholy look is almost [the only man of these days for whom [I]83-laurence feel a real reverence]1745-the only man of these days for whom i feel a real reverence — almost [the only one of [[our]1747-our teachers]1748-our teachers who seems to [me]83-laurence to speak with the least breath of inspiration .
