And now , as the years come , it seems that hope is more and more leaving [him]1744-that man with such a curiously attractive smile and the worn melancholy look , and things look darker to [him]1744-that man with such a curiously attractive smile and the worn melancholy look than ever . That is [Herbert]88-leslie . ’[83-laurence] ‘ [Herbert]88-leslie ! ’[88-leslie] exclaimed [Leslie]88-leslie , ‘ so it is . [I]88-leslie thought [I]88-leslie recollected the face . [I]88-leslie have heard [him]1744-that man with such a curiously attractive smile and the worn melancholy look lecture several times at [the Royal Institution]1749-the royal institution ; and that singular voice of [his]1744-that man with such a curiously attractive smile and the worn melancholy look , which would often hold all the theatre breathless , haunts [me]88-leslie still , sometimes . There was something strange and aërial in its exquisite modulations , that seemed as if it came from a disconsolate spirit , hovering over the waters of [Babylon]6-babylon , and remembering [Sion]105-sion . [I]88-leslie ca n’t tell exactly why it was that — but , ah!—my dear [Laurence]83-laurence — who is this , that is coming into [the room]1750-the room now — this lovely creature , with a dress like a red azalea ? What speaking eyes ! And what hair , too — deep dead black , with those white starry blossoms in it . [I]88-leslie do n’t think [I]88-leslie ever saw [anyone]354-anyone move so gracefully ; and how proudly and piquantly [she]354-anyone poises On [her]354-anyone neck the small head buoyant , like a bell - flower on its bed ! ’[88-leslie] ‘ That , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , when [Leslie]88-leslie had done , ‘ is [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , who has published a volume of poems , and is a sort of fashionable [London]1-london Sappho . But come,—we shall be going into dinner directly . [You]83-laurence shall have [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose on one side of [you]83-laurence , and shall take in [Miss Merton]93-miss merton . ’[83-laurence] [LAURENCE]83-laurence , though [he]83-laurence had forewarned [[his]83-laurence guests]377-his guests of [his]83-laurence menu before [they]377-his guests left [the drawing - room]378-the drawing - room , yet felt a little anxious when [they]377-his guests sat down to dinner ; for [he]83-laurence found it not altogether easy to get the conversation started . [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , who was the first to speak , began somewhat off the point . ‘ What a charming change it is , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , ’[92-lady ambrose] [she]92-lady ambrose said , ‘ to look out on [the sea]300-the sea when [one]1681-one is dressing , instead of across [South Audley Street]7-south audley street ! ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Hush ! ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence softly , with a grave , reproving smile . ‘ Really , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose beg [your]83-laurence pardon . [I]92-lady ambrose thought [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson had said grace . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ If [he]95-dr. jenkinson has , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ it is very good of [him]95-dr. jenkinson , for [I]83-laurence am afraid [he]95-dr. jenkinson was not asked . But what [I]83-laurence mean is , that [you]83-laurence must only talk of what is on the cards ; so be good enough to look at [your]83-laurence menu , and devote [your]83-laurence attention to the Aim of Life . ’[83-laurence] ‘ Really , this is much too alarming , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘ How is [one]1681-one to talk at so short a notice on a subject one has never thought about before ? ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Why , to do so , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ is the very art of conversation ; for in that way , one ’s ideas spring up fresh like young roses that have all the dew on them , instead of having been kept drying for half a lifetime between the leaves of a book . So do set a good example , and begin , or else [we]1755-we shall never be started at all ; and [my]83-laurence pet plan will turn out a fiasco . ’[83-laurence] There was , indeed , as [Laurence]83-laurence said this , something very near complete silence all round the table . It was soon broken . ‘ Are [you]83-laurence [High - church]1756-high - church or [Low - church]357-low - church ? ’[83-laurence] was a question suddenly uttered in [a quick eager girl]379-a quick eager girl ’s voice by [Miss Prattle]107-miss prattle , [a young lady of eighteen]380-a young lady of eighteen , to the astonishment of [the whole company]381-the whole company . It was addressed to [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson who was sitting next [her]107-miss prattle . Had a pin been run into [the Doctor]376-the doctor ’s leg , [he]83-laurence could not have looked more astounded , or given a greater start . [He]83-laurence eyed [his]83-laurence fair questioner for some time in complete silence . ‘ Can [you]376-the doctor tell [me]83-laurence the difference ? ’[83-laurence] [he]83-laurence said at last , in a voice of considerable good humour , yet with just a touch of sharpness in it . ‘ [I]93-miss merton think , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , who was sitting on the other side of [him]83-laurence , ‘ that [my]93-miss merton card is a little different . [I]93-miss merton have the “ Aim of Life ” on [mine]93-miss merton , and so [I]93-miss merton believe has [everybody else]1758-everybody else . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ Well , ’[376-the doctor] said [the Doctor]376-the doctor , laughing , ‘ let [us]1759-us ask [Miss Prattle]107-miss prattle what is [her]107-miss prattle aim in life . ’[376-the doctor] ‘ Thank [Heaven]108-heaven , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson has begun . [I]83-laurence hope [we]1759-us shall all now follow . ’[83-laurence] [Laurence]83-laurence ’s hope was not in vain . The conversation soon sprang up everywhere ; and [the company]384-the company , though in various humours , took most of [them]384-the company very kindly to the solemn topic that had been put before [them]384-the company . [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , who was sitting by [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , was heard in a loudish voice saying that [his]99-mr. luke own favourite Muse had always been [Erato]109-erato ; [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose had taken a crimson flower from a vase on the table , and , looking at it [himself]100-mr. rose with a grave regard , was pointing out its infinite and passionate beauties to [the lady next [him]100-mr. rose]385-the lady next him ; and [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton was explaining that [the Alps]111-the alps looked grander , and the sky bluer than ever , to [those who truly realised the atomic theory]386-those who truly realised the atomic theory . [No one]387-no one , indeed , was silent except [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert and [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks , the former of whom smiled rather sadly , whilst [the latter]388-the latter looked about [him]110-mr. stockton with an inquisitorial frown . [Laurence]83-laurence was delighted with the state of things , and surveyed the table with great satisfaction . Whilst [his]83-laurence attention was thus engaged , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose turned to [Leslie]88-leslie , and began asking [him]88-leslie if [he]88-leslie had been in [town]389-town much this season . [She]92-lady ambrose was taken with [his]88-leslie look , and wished to find out if [he]88-leslie would really be [a nice person]390-a nice person to like . ‘ Please , ’[92-lady ambrose] interposed [Laurence]83-laurence pleadingly , ‘ do try and keep to the point — please , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose want to find out [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie ’s aim in life by asking [him]114-leslie where [he]114-leslie has been , ’[92-lady ambrose] [she]92-lady ambrose answered . ‘ [I]114-leslie have been in a great many places , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘ but not to pursue any end — only to try and forget that [I]114-leslie had no end to pursue . ’[114-leslie] ‘ This is a very sad state of things , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose ; ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose can always find something to do , except when [I]92-lady ambrose am quite alone , or in [the country]1760-the country when [the house]1761-the house is empty . And even then [I]92-lady ambrose can make occupation . [I]92-lady ambrose draw , or read a book , or teach [[my]92-lady ambrose little boy]1762-my little boy some lessons . But come — what do [you]83-laurence think is the real aim of life?—since that is what [I]92-lady ambrose must ask [him]114-leslie , is it not , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence ? ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Do n’t ask [me]114-leslie , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie ; ‘ [I]114-leslie told [you]83-laurence [I]114-leslie had n’t a notion ; and [I]114-leslie do n’t suppose [we]1763-we any of [us]1763-we have . ’[114-leslie] ‘ That ca n’t be true , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘ for just listen how [everyone]347-everyone is talking . [I]92-lady ambrose wish [we]1763-we could hear what [they]347-everyone are saying . [You]83-laurence might learn something then , perhaps , [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie , since [you]83-laurence are so very ignorant . ’[92-lady ambrose] It happened that , as [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose said this , the conversation suddenly flagged , and [Laurence]83-laurence took advantage of the lull to ask if any satisfactory conclusions had been come to during the past five minutes , ‘ because [we]1763-we up here , ’[83-laurence] [he]83-laurence said , ‘ are very much in the dark , and want to be enlightened . ’[83-laurence] ‘ Yes , ’[113-mr. storks] said [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks gruffly , ‘ has [any one]1765-any one found out what is the aim of life ? ’[113-mr. storks] As [he]83-laurence said this [he]83-laurence looked about [him]83-laurence defiantly , as though [all the others]391-all the others were butterflies , that [he]83-laurence could break , if [he]83-laurence chose , upon [his]83-laurence wheel . [His]83-laurence eye at last lit upon [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , who , considering this a challenge to [himself]102-mr. saunders , immediately took up the gauntlet . [The young man]392-the young man spoke with the utmost composure , and , as [his]392-the young man voice was high and piercing , [everybody]393-everybody could hear [him]392-the young man . ‘ The aim of life , ’[392-the young man] [he]392-the young man said , adjusting [his]392-the young man spectacles , ‘ is progress . ’[392-the young man] ‘ What is progress ? ’[95-dr. jenkinson] interrupted [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson coldly , without looking at [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , and as though any answer to [his]95-dr. jenkinson question was the last thing [he]95-dr. jenkinson expected . ‘ Progress , ’[102-mr. saunders] replied [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders slowly , ‘ has been found , like poetry , somewhat hard to define . ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ Very true , ’[376-the doctor] said [the Doctor]376-the doctor drily , and looking straight before [him]102-mr. saunders . [His]392-the young man accents were of so freezing a sharpness that [he]392-the young man seemed to be stabbing [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders with an icicle . [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , however , was apparently quite unwounded . ‘ But [I]392-the young man , ’[392-the young man] [he]392-the young man continued with the utmost complacency , ‘ have discovered a definition which will , [I]392-the young man think , meet with general acceptance . There is nothing original in it — it is merely an abstract of the meaning of [all [our]1767-our great liberal thinkers]1766-all our great liberal thinkers — progress is such improvement as can be verified by statistics , just as education is such knowledge as can be tested by examinations . That , [I]392-the young man conceive , is a very adequate definition of the most advanced conception of progress , and to persuade [people in general]1768-people in general to accept this is at present one of the chief duties of [all earnest men]1769-all earnest men . ’[392-the young man] ‘ Entirely true ! ’[112-mr. herbert] said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , with ironical emphasis ; ‘ an entirely true definition of progress as [our]1767-our age prizes it . ’[112-mr. herbert] [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders was delighted , and , imagining [he]102-mr. saunders had made [a disciple]395-a disciple , [he]102-mr. saunders turned to [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert and went on . ‘ For just let [us]1767-our , ’[392-the young man] [he]392-the young man said , ‘ compare [a man]1770-a man with [a gorilla]1771-a gorilla , and see in what [the man]1772-the man ’s superiority lies . It is evidently not in [the man]1772-the man ’s ideas of [God]115-god , and so forth — for in [his]1772-the man presumable freedom from these [the gorilla]1774-the gorilla is [the superior of [the man]1772-the man]1775-the superior of the man — but in the hard and verifiable fact , that [the man]1772-the man can build [houses]1778-houses and [cotton - mills]1779-cotton - mills , whereas [the highest monkey]1780-the highest monkey can scarcely make the rudest approach to [a hut]1781-a hut . ’[392-the young man] ‘ But can [you]112-mr. herbert tell [me]112-mr. herbert , ’[112-mr. herbert] said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘ supposing [men]1704-men some day come to a state in which no more of this progress is possible , what will [they]1704-men do then ? ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ [Mr. Mill]116-mr. mill , whom in almost all things [I]102-mr. saunders reverence as a supreme authority , ’[102-mr. saunders] said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ‘ asked [himself]116-mr. mill that very question . But the answer [he]116-mr. mill gave [himself]116-mr. mill was one of the few things in which [I]102-mr. saunders venture to dissent from [him]116-mr. mill . For , when all the greater evils of life shall have been removed , [he]116-mr. mill thinks [the human race]1783-the human race is to find its chief enjoyment in reading [Wordsworth]117-wordsworth ’s poetry . ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ Indeed ! ’[112-mr. herbert] said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert ; ‘ and did [Mill]116-mr. mill come to any conclusion so sane as that ? ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ [I]102-mr. saunders , on the contrary , believe , ’[102-mr. saunders] [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders went on , ‘ that as long as [the human race]1783-the human race lasts , [it]1783-the human race will still have some belief in [God]115-god left in it , and that the eradication of this will afford an unending employment to [all enlightened minds]1785-all enlightened minds . ’[102-mr. saunders] [Leslie]114-leslie looked at [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , expecting to see [her]92-lady ambrose smile . On the contrary [she]92-lady ambrose was very grave , and said , ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose think this is shocking . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Well , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence in a soothing tone to [her]92-lady ambrose , ‘ it is only the way of [these young men]1786-these young men in times of change like [ours]1787-ours . Besides , [he]116-mr. mill is very young — [he]116-mr. mill has only just left [Oxford]5-oxford — ’[83-laurence] ‘ If these irreligious views are to be picked up at [Oxford]5-oxford , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose shall be obliged to send [[my]92-lady ambrose little boy]1762-my little boy , when [he]116-mr. mill grows up , to [Cambridge]8-cambridge . And as for what [you]1789-you say about “ times of change ” — [I]92-lady ambrose am not [a conservative]1790-a conservative , as [you]1789-you know — indeed , [I]92-lady ambrose quite go in for reform , as [[my]92-lady ambrose husband]1791-my husband does : but [I]92-lady ambrose do n’t think religion ought to be dragged into the matter . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Well , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ let [us]1792-us listen to what [Lord Allen]101-allen is saying . ’[83-laurence] ‘ [He]101-allen is sure , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘ not to say anything but what is nice . ’[92-lady ambrose] [Allen]101-allen was speaking in a low tone , but [his]101-allen voice was so clear that [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose was quite able to hear [him]101-allen . ‘ To [me]101-allen it seems , ’[101-allen] [he]101-allen was saying , blushing a little as [he]101-allen found suddenly how many [people]308-people were listening to [him]101-allen , ‘ that the aim of life has nearly always been plain enough in a certain way — always , and for [all men]1793-all men — ’[101-allen] ‘ Indeed ? ’[102-mr. saunders] said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , raising [his]102-mr. saunders eyebrows . ‘ Yes , ’[101-allen] said [Allen]101-allen , slightly turning towards [him]102-mr. saunders , and raising [his]101-allen voice somewhat . ‘ It has been , [I]101-allen think , as [a single magnet , acting on all , though upon many by repulsion]1794-a single magnet , acting on all , though upon many by repulsion . It is quite indescribable in words . But there are two things by which [you]1795-you can tell [a man]1770-a man ’s truth to it — a faith in [God]115-god . and a longing for a future life . ’[101-allen] ‘ [Lord Allen]101-allen , ’[112-mr. herbert] exclaimed [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , and the sound of [his]112-mr. herbert voice made [everyone]347-everyone at once [a listener]398-a listener , ‘ that is very beautifully put ! And it is , indeed , quite true , as [you]101-allen say , that the real significance of life must be for ever indescribable in words . But , in the present day , [I]112-mr. herbert fear also that for most of [us]1797-us it is not even thinkable in thought . [The whole human race]1798-the whole human race , ’[112-mr. herbert] [he]112-mr. herbert went on in measured melancholy accents , ‘ is now wandering in [an accursed wilderness]1799-an accursed wilderness , which not only shows [us]1797-us no hilltop whence [the promised land]1800-the promised land may be seen , but which , to [most of [the wanderers]1802-the wanderers]1801-most of the wanderers , seems [a promised land itself]1803-a promised land itself . And [they]1798-the whole human race have [a God of [their]1798-the whole human race own]1804-a god of their own too , who engages now to lead [them]1798-the whole human race out of it if [they]1798-the whole human race will only follow [him]1804-a god of their own : who , for visible token of [[his]1804-a god of their own Godhead]1805-his godhead , leads [them]1798-the whole human race with a pillar of cloud by day , and a pillar of fire by night — the cloud being the black smoke of [[their]1798-the whole human race factory chimneys]1806-their factory chimneys , and the fire the red glare of [[their]1798-the whole human race blast - furnaces]1807-their blast - furnaces . And so effectual are [these modern divine guides]1808-these modern divine guides , that if [we]1809-we were standing on the brink of [Jordan]9-jordan itself , [we]1809-we should be utterly unable to catch , through the fire and the smoke , one single glimpse of [the sunlit hills beyond]1810-the sunlit hills beyond . ’[112-mr. herbert] [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert said these last words almost fiercely ; and they were followed by a complete hush . It was almost directly broken by [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose . ‘ To [me]100-mr. rose , ’[100-mr. rose] [he]100-mr. rose said , raising [his]100-mr. rose eyebrows wearily , and sending [his]100-mr. rose words floating down the table in a languid monotone , ‘ [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert ’s whole metaphor seems misleading . [I]100-mr. rose rather look upon life as [a chamber]1811-a chamber , which [we]1809-we decorate as [we]1809-we would decorate [the chamber of [the woman]1813-the woman or]1812-the chamber of the woman or [the youth that [we]1809-we love]1814-the youth that we love , tinting the walls of [it]1812-the chamber of the woman or with symphonies of subdued colour , and filling it with works of fair form , and with flowers , and with strange scents , and with instruments of music . And this can be done now as well — better , rather — than at any former time : since [we]1809-we know that so many of the old aims were false , and so cease to be distracted by them . [We]1809-we have learned the weariness of creeds ; and know that for [us]1809-we the grave has no secrets . [We]1809-we have learned that the aim of life is life ; and what does successful life consist in ? Simply , ’[100-mr. rose] said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , speaking very slowly , and with a soft solemnity , ‘ in the consciousness of exquisite living — in the making [our]1809-we own each highest thrill of joy that the moment offers [us]1809-we — be it some touch of colour on [the sea]300-the sea or on [the mountains]1816-the mountains , the early dew in the crimson shadows of a rose , the shining of [a woman]1817-a woman ’s limbs in clear water , or — ’[100-mr. rose] Here unfortunately a sound of ‘ ’[100-mr. rose] Sh ’ broke softly from several mouths . [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose was slightly disconcerted , and a pause that would have been a little awkward seemed imminent . [Laurence]83-laurence , to prevent this , did the first thing that occurred to [him]83-laurence , and hastily asked [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson what [his]95-dr. jenkinson view of the matter was . [The Doctor]376-the doctor ’s answer came in [his]95-dr. jenkinson very sharpest voice . ‘[100-mr. rose] Do any of [us]399-we know what life is ? ’ [he]95-dr. jenkinson said . ‘[100-mr. rose] Had n’t [we]399-we better find that out first ? ’ ‘[100-mr. rose] Life , ’ continued [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , who had now recovered [himself]100-mr. rose , ‘[100-mr. rose] is a series of moments and emotions . ’ ‘[100-mr. rose] And a series of absurdities too , very often , ’ said [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson . ‘[100-mr. rose] Life is a solemn mystery , ’ said [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks , severely . ‘[100-mr. rose] Life is a damned nuisance , ’ muttered [Leslie]114-leslie to [himself]114-leslie , but just loud enough to be heard by [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , who smiled at [him]114-leslie with a sense of humour that won [his]114-leslie heart at once . ‘[100-mr. rose] Life is matter , ’ [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks went on , ‘[100-mr. rose] which , under certain conditions not yet fully understood , has become self - conscious . ’ ‘[101-allen] [Lord Allen]101-allen has just been saying that it is the preface to eternity , ’ said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders . ‘[101-allen] Only , unfortunately , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[101-allen] it is a preface that [we]399-we can not skip , and the dedication is generally made to [the wrong person]400-the wrong person . ’ ‘[400-the wrong person] All [our]399-we doubts on this matter , ’ said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ‘[400-the wrong person] are simply due to that dense pestiferous fog of crazed sentiment that still hides [our]399-we view , but which [the present generation]401-the present generation has sternly set its face to dispel and conquer . Science will drain the marshy grounds of [the human mind]402-the human mind , so that the deadly malaria of Christianity , which has already destroyed two civilisations , shall never be fatal to a third . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i should rather have thought , ’ said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , in [her]106-mrs. sinclair soft clear voice , and casting down [her]106-mrs. sinclair eyes thoughtfully , ‘[0-i] that passion and feeling were the real heart of the matter : and that religion of some sort was an ingredient in all perfect passion . There are seeds of feeling in every soul , but these will never rise up into flowers without some culture — will [they]403-they , [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke ? And this culture is , surely , ’ [she]106-mrs. sinclair said dreamily , ‘[106-mrs. sinclair] the work of Love who is [the gardener of the soul]404-the gardener of the soul , and of Religion , [the under - gardener]405-the under - gardener , acting as [Love]118-love bids it . ’ ‘[403-they] Ah , yes ! ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , looking compassionately about [him]99-mr. luke . ‘[403-they] Culture ! [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair is quite right ; for without culture [we]399-we can never understand Christianity , and Christianity , whatever the vulgar may say of it , is the key to life , and is co - extensive with it . ’ [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose was charmed with this sentiment . ‘[99-mr. luke] Quite so , [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , [I]0-i quite agree with [you]99-mr. luke , ’ [she]106-mrs. sinclair said , in [her]106-mrs. sinclair most cordial manner . ‘[0-i] But [I]0-i wish [you]99-mr. luke would tell [me]0-i a little more about Culture . [I]0-i am always so much interested in those things . ’ ‘[0-i] Culture , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘[0-i] is the union of two things — fastidious taste and liberal sympathy . These can only be gained by wide reading guided by sweet reason ; and when they are gained , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , [we]399-we are conscious , as it were , of a new sense , which at once enables [us]399-we to discern the Eternal and the absolutely righteous , wherever [we]399-we find it , whether in an epistle of [St. Paul]119-st. paul ’s or in a comedy of [Menander]120-menander ’s . It is true that culture sets aside the larger part of the New Testament as grotesque , barbarous , and immoral ; but what remains , purged of its apparent meaning , it discerns to be a treasure beyond all price . And in Christianity — such Christianity , [I]0-i mean , as true taste can accept — culture sees the guide to the real significance of life , and the explanation , ’ [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke added with a sigh , ‘[0-i] of that melancholy which in [our]399-we day is attendant upon all clear sight . ’ ‘[0-i] But why , ’ said [Allen]101-allen , ‘[0-i] if [you]99-mr. luke know so well what life ’s meaning is , need [you]99-mr. luke feel this melancholy at all ? ’ ‘[406-the world] Ah ! ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘[406-the world] it is from this very knowledge that the melancholy [I]0-i speak of springs . [We]399-we — the cultured — [we]399-we indeed see . But [the world]406-the world at large does not . [It]406-the world will not listen to [us]399-we . [It]406-the world thinks [we]399-we are talking nonsense . Surely that is enough to sadden [us]399-we . Then , too , [our]399-we ears are perpetually being pained and deafened by the din of the two opposing Philistinisms — science and orthodoxy — both equally vulgar , and equally useless . But [the masses]407-the masses can not see this . It is impossible to persuade some that science can teach [them]407-the masses nothing worth knowing , and others that the dogmatic utterances of the gospels are either ignorant mistakes or oriental metaphors . Do n’t [you]99-mr. luke find this , [Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson ? ’ [he]0-i added , addressing [the Doctor]376-the doctor across the table in a loud mournful voice . ‘[99-mr. luke] [Laurence]83-laurence , ’ said [the Doctor]376-the doctor , apparently not hearing the question , ‘[99-mr. luke] have n’t [we]399-we talked of this quite long enough ? [Town]10-town and [Country]11-country — let [us]399-we go on to that ; or else [we]399-we shall be getting very much behind - hand . ’ These words of [the Doctor]376-the doctor ’s caused a rapid change in the conversation . And as it appeared impossible to agree as to what the aim of life was , most turned eagerly to the simpler question of where it might be best attained . At first there seemed to be a general sense on all sides that it was a duty to prefer [the country]1760-the country . There , the voices of [Nature]121-nature spoke to the soul more freely , the air was purer and fresher ; the things in life that were really valuable were more readily taken at their true worth ; foolish vanities and trivial cares were less likely to degrade the character ; [one]1681-one could have flowers ; [one]1681-one could listen to the music of birds and [rivers]1825-rivers ; [a country house]1826-a country house was more comfortable than [a town]1827-a town one ; and few prospects were so charming as [an English park]1828-an english park . But the voice of [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders was soon heard proclaiming that progress was almost entirely confined to [towns]1829-towns , and that [the modern liberal]1830-the modern liberal could find little scope for action in [the country]1760-the country . ‘[408-he] If [he]408-he does anything there , ’ [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders said , ‘[408-he] [he]408-he can only make [[his]408-he tenants]409-his tenants more comfortable and contented ; and that is simply attaching [them]409-his tenants more to the existing order of things . Indeed , even now , as matters stand , [the healthy rustic]410-the healthy rustic , with [his]410-the healthy rustic fresh complexion and honest eye , is absolutely incapable of appreciating the tyranny of religion and society . But [the true liberal]411-the true liberal is undeceived by [his]411-the true liberal pleasing exterior , and sees [a far nobler creature in the pale narrow - chested operative of [the city]413-the city]412-a far nobler creature in the pale narrow - chested operative of the city , who at once responds to the faintest cry of insurgence . ’ Slight causes often produce large results ; and these utterances of [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders turned the entire torrent of opinion into a different channel . [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , who had a moment before been talking about ‘[412-a far nobler creature in the pale narrow - chested operative of the city] liberal air , ’ and ‘[412-a far nobler creature in the pale narrow - chested operative of the city] sedged brooks , ’ and ‘[412-a far nobler creature in the pale narrow - chested operative of the city] meadow grass , ’ now admitted that [one ’s country neighbours]1832-one ’s country neighbours were sure to be [narrow - minded sectarians]1833-narrow - minded sectarians , and that it was better to live amongst cultured society , even under a [London]1-london fog , than to look at all the splendour of provincial sunsets , in company with [a parson who could talk of nothing]1834-a parson who could talk of nothing but [[his]408-he parishioners]1835-his parishioners and justification by faith . [Others]341-others , too , followed in the same direction ; and the verdict of [the majority]1837-the majority soon seemed to be that , except in [a large country house]1838-a large country house , country life , though it might be very beautiful , was still very tiresome . But the voice of [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders was again heard , during a pause , laying it down that [no true liberal]1839-no true liberal could ever care to live in [the country]1760-the country now ; and [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , who highly disapproved of [him]411-the true liberal and [his]411-the true liberal views in general , saw here a fitting opportunity for contradicting [him]411-the true liberal , asserting that , though [she]92-lady ambrose and [[her]92-lady ambrose husband]1841-her husband were both advanced , [liberals]1842-liberals , yet the pleasantest part of [their]414-their year was that spent upon [[their]414-their moor in [Scotland]12-scotland]1843-their moor in scotland . ‘[412-a far nobler creature in the pale narrow - chested operative of the city] And then , too , ’ [she]92-lady ambrose added , turning to [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i am devoted to [[our]414-their place in [Gloucestershire]13-gloucestershire]415-our place in gloucestershire , and [I]0-i would not miss for anything such things as [[my]0-i new dairy]416-my new dairy , and [[my]0-i cottages]417-my cottages , with [the old women]418-the old women in [them]417-my cottages . ’ ‘[122-sir george] And yet , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , smiling , ‘[122-sir george] [Sir George]122-sir george would never go near [the place]419-the place if it were not for the shooting . ’ ‘[122-sir george] Indeed [he]122-sir george would , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , a little indignantly . ‘[122-sir george] [He]122-sir george likes the life so much , and is so fond of [[his]122-sir george gardens]420-his gardens , and [greenhouses]421-greenhouses , and — ’ But [she]92-lady ambrose was here interrupted by [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , who , mistaking [the Sir George Ambrose]122-sir george mentioned for [another Baronet of the same name]1844-another baronet of the same name — [a gentleman of [a very old but impoverished Catholic family]1846-a very old but impoverished catholic family]1845-a gentleman of a very old but impoverished catholic family — broke in as follows , somewhat to the consternation of [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , whose husband was [a great cotton - spinner , of the most uncertain origin]1847-a great cotton - spinner , of the most uncertain origin . ‘[122-sir george] [Sir George]122-sir george , ’ [he]0-i said , ‘[122-sir george] is , as [I]0-i know well , [an entirely honest gentleman of ancient lineage]422-an entirely honest gentleman of ancient lineage . [He]122-sir george is indeed a perfectly beautiful type of what [the English Squire]423-the english squire properly ought to be . For [he]122-sir george lives upon [[his]122-sir george own land]424-his own land , and amongst [[his]122-sir george own people]425-his own people ; and is a complete and lovely example to [them]425-his own people of a life quite simple indeed , but in the highest sense loyal , noble , and orderly . But what is one amongst so many ? To most of [his]122-sir george own order [Sir George Ambrose]122-sir george appears merely as [a madman]426-a madman , because [he]122-sir george sees that it is altogether a nobler thing for [a man]1770-a man to be brave and chivalrous than it is to be fashionable ; and because [he]122-sir george looks forward on [his]122-sir george dying day to remembering the human souls that [he]122-sir george has saved alive , rather than the pheasants that [he]122-sir george has shot dead . ’ Now , [the husband of [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose]1848-the husband of lady ambrose being known to most present for [[his]122-sir george magnificent new country house]1849-his magnificent new country house , [[his]122-sir george immense preserves]1850-his immense preserves , and [[his]122-sir george yacht of four hundred tons that never went out of [the Solent]14-the solent]1851-his yacht of four hundred tons that never went out of the solent , there was naturally some wonder excited by [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert ’s words , since the thought of any other [Sir George]122-sir george never came for an instant into [anyone]354-anyone ’s head . [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose [herself]92-lady ambrose was in utter amazement . [She]92-lady ambrose could not tell what to make of it , and [she]92-lady ambrose was as near looking confused as [she]92-lady ambrose had ever been in [her]92-lady ambrose life . The awkwardness of the situation was felt by [many]1853-many : and to cover it a hum of conversation sprang up , with forced alacrity . But this did not make matters much better ; for in a very short time [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert ’s voice was again audible , uttering words of no measured denunciation against [the great land - owners of [England]4-england]1854-the great land - owners of england , ‘[428-a nobility] who were once , ’ [he]112-mr. herbert said , ‘[428-a nobility] in some true sense [a Nobility]428-a nobility , but are now the portentousest Ignobility that [the world]406-the world ever set eyes upon . ’ [Everyone]347-everyone felt that this was approaching dangerous ground : nor were [they]347-everyone at all reassured when [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , who was , it appeared , quoting from a letter which [he]112-mr. herbert had received , [he]112-mr. herbert said , that morning from [the greatest of [modern thinkers]1857-modern thinkers]1856-the greatest of modern thinkers , concluded amidst a complete silence with the following passage , ‘[430-they] Yes , here [they]430-they come , with coats of the newest fashion , with pedigrees of the newest forging , with [their]430-they moors in [Scotland]12-scotland , with [their]430-they rivers in [Norway]15-norway , with [their]430-they game preserves in [England]4-england , with some thousands of [human beings]431-human beings calling [them]430-they [masters]432-masters , somewhere — [they]430-they probably forget where — and with the mind of [a thinking man]433-a thinking man , or with the heart of [a gentleman]434-a gentleman , nowhere . Here [they]430-they come , [[our]435-our cotton - spinning [plutocrats]437-plutocrats]436-our cotton - spinning plutocrats , bringing in luxury , and vulgarity , and damnation ! ’ These last words came like a thunderclap . [Laurence]83-laurence hardly knew where to look . The result , however , was more satisfactory than could have been expected . There are some emotions , as [we]435-our all know , that can be calmed best by tears . [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose did not cry . [She]92-lady ambrose did something better — [she]92-lady ambrose laughed . ‘[437-plutocrats] What would [poor Sir [George]122-sir george]438-poor sir george say ? ’ [she]92-lady ambrose whispered to [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘[122-sir george] [He]122-sir george is fishing in [Norway]15-norway at this very moment . But do [you]439-you really think , ’ [she]92-lady ambrose went on , being resolved not to shirk the subject , ‘[439-you] that Society is really as bad as [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert says ? [I]0-i was looking into the the other day , and [I]0-i am sure nothing goes on in [London]1-london now so bad as what [he]112-mr. herbert describes . ’ ‘[112-mr. herbert] Do [you]0-i know , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ’ said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , who concluded that [he]112-mr. herbert had given [her]92-lady ambrose much pleasure by [his]112-mr. herbert late remarks , ‘[92-lady ambrose] [I]0-i think the state of [London]1-london at the present day infinitely worse than anything [Grammont]123-grammont or [[his]123-grammont biographer]440-his biographer could have dreamt of . ’ ‘[123-grammont] Quite so , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke ; ‘[123-grammont] the bulk of [men]1704-men in [our]442-our days are just as immoral as [they]443-they were in [Charles]124-charles [the Second ’s]444-the second ’s ; the only difference is that [they]443-they are incomparably more stupid ; and that , instead of decking [their]443-they immorality with the jewels of wit , [they]443-they clumsily try to cover it with the tarpaulin of respectability . This has not made the immorality any the better ; it has only made respectability the most contemptible word in the English language . ’ ‘[124-charles] The fop of [Charles]124-charles ’s time , ’ said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘[124-charles] aimed at seeming a wit and [a scholar]445-a scholar . The fop of [ours]442-our aims at being [a fool and a dunce]446-a fool and a dunce . ’ ‘[446-a fool and a dunce] Yes , ’ said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘[446-a fool and a dunce] society was diseased then , it is true , and marks of disease disfigured and scarred [its]447-its features . Still , in spite of this , it had some sound life left in it . But now the entire organism is dissolving and falling asunder . All the parts are refusing to perform [their]443-they functions . How , indeed , could this possibly be otherwise , when [the head itself]448-the head itself , [the aristocracy]449-the aristocracy , the part whose special office is to see and think , has now lost completely both [its]448-the head itself brains and eyes , and has nothing head - like left it except the mouth ; and that can not so much as speak . [It]448-the head itself can only eat and yawn . ’ ‘[448-the head itself] Society , [you]450-you see , [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , who felt bound to say something , ‘[112-mr. herbert] is so much larger now than it was . ’ ‘[112-mr. herbert] Oh , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , shrugging [his]0-i shoulders , ‘[112-mr. herbert] in that sense , [I]0-i really think there is almost no society now . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t see how there can be , ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘[0-i] when what is called society is simply one great scramble after fashion . And fashion is such a delicate fruit , that it is sure to be spoilt if it is scrambled for . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i am glad , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[450-you] [you]450-you do n’t abuse fashion as [some people]451-some people do . [I]0-i look on it as the complexion of [good society]452-good society , and as the rouge of bad ; and when society gets sickly and loses its complexion , it takes to rouge — as it is doing now ; and the rouge eats into [its]447-its whole system , and makes [its]447-its health worse than ever . ’ ‘[0-i] [You]0-i are [the last person]453-the last person , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[453-the last person] [you]0-i who go out so much , that [I]0-i should have expected to hear talking against society like that . ’ ‘[0-i] Ah ! ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[0-i] [we]454-we can not escape from [our]454-we circumstances : [I]0-i only wish [we]454-we could . [I]0-i go into the best society [I]0-i can get , but [I]0-i am not blind to the fact that it is very bad . Of course there are a number of [the most delightful people in it]455-the most delightful people in it : [I]0-i am not denying that for a moment . But not only is society not made up out of a few of [its]447-its parts , but [even the best parts suffer from the tone of the whole]456-even the best parts suffer from the tone of the whole . And taking society as a whole , [I]0-i honestly doubt if it was ever at any time so generally bad as it is now . [I]0-i am not saying that [it]447-its has forgotten [its]447-its duties — that [it]447-its can not even conceive that it ever had any ; that is of course quite true : but [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert has said that already . [I]0-i am not complaining of its moral badness , but of its social badness — of its want of practical skill in life as a fine art — a want that [it]447-its often feels [itself]447-its , and yet has not the skill to remedy . Think for a moment how barbarous are its amusements ; how little culture there is in its general tone ; how incapable it is of any enlightened interest ! ’ ‘[457-you] Really , ’ said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , ‘[457-you] [I]0-i think [you]457-you are doing society a great injustice . It seems to [me]0-i that enlightened interest is the very thing that is everywhere on the spread . The light of intellect is emerging from [the laboratory]458-the laboratory and [the dissecting - room]459-the dissecting - room , where it had its birth , and is gilding , with its clear rays , the dinner - table , and even the ball - room . A freer , a truer , and a grander view of things , seems to [me]0-i to be rapidly dawning on [the world]406-the world . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i fear , [[my]0-i dear sir]461-my dear sir , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘[457-you] that these pleasing opinions of [yours]457-you will not bear testing . ’ ‘[457-you] Do [you]457-you mean , ’ said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , ‘[457-you] that society as a rule is not infinitely better informed now than it was thirty years ago ? Has [it]447-its not infinitely fewer prejudices and infinitely more knowledge ? ’ ‘[462-our] [We]462-our should look to the effects of the knowledge , not to the knowledge itself , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke . ‘[462-our] [We]462-our can not test the health of [a society]463-a society from looking over [its]463-a society examination papers in physical science . ’ ‘[457-you] How would [you]457-you test it ? ’ said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , with a slight curl of the lip . ‘[457-you] There are many tests , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke . ‘[457-you] Here is one , amongst the very subjects that [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence has ordered [us]462-our to talk about — art and literature . ’ ‘[83-laurence] [I]0-i accept the test , ’ said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton . ‘[0-i] What , then , can be nobler than much modern poetry ? There is some that [I]0-i look upon as quite of the highest order . ’ ‘[0-i] When [I]0-i spoke of [our]462-our literature , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke loftily , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i was not thinking of poetry . [We]462-our have no poetry now . ’ ‘[462-our] Indeed ? ’ said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton ; ‘[462-our] [I]0-i imagined [you]0-i had written some [yourself]0-i . ’ ‘[0-i] Ah ! ’ exclaimed [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , drawing a long sigh , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i once knew what [Goethe]125-goethe calls “ the divine worth of tone and tears . ” But [my]0-i own poems only prove the truth of what [I]0-i say . They could only have been written in evil days . They were simply a wail of pain ; and now that [I]0-i am grown braver , [I]0-i keep silence . Poetry in some ages is an expression of the best strength ; in an age like [ours]462-our it is the disguise of the worst weakness — or , when not that , it is simply a forced plant , an exotic . No , [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , [I]0-i was not speaking of [our]462-our poetry , but of the one kind of imaginative literature that is the natural growth of [our]462-our own day , the novel . Now , the novel itself is a plant which , when it grows abundantly and alone , [you]464-you may be sure is a sign of a poor soil . But do n’t trust to that only . Look at [our]462-our novels [themselves]465-themselves , and see what sort of life it is [they]465-themselves image — the trivial interests , the contemptible incidents , the absurdity of [the virtuous characters]466-the virtuous characters , the viciousness of [the characters who are not absurd]467-the characters who are not absurd . [Spain]17-spain was in some ways worse in [Cervantes]126-cervantes ’ time than [England]4-england is in [ours]462-our ; but [you]464-you may search all [our]462-our novels for [one character that has one tithe of [Don Quixote]127-don quixote ’s heroism]1858-one character that has one tithe of don quixote ’s heroism , for [one of [[our]462-our sane men]1860-our sane men that [breathed in so healthy and pure an atmosphere as the inspired madman]1861-breathed in so healthy and pure an atmosphere as the inspired madman]1859-one of our sane men that breathed in so healthy and pure an atmosphere as the inspired madman . And this is not from want of ability on [the novelist]1862-the novelist ’s part . Some of them have powers enough and to spare ; but the best novels only reflect back most clearly the social anarchy , and the bad ones are unconscious parts of it . ’[126-cervantes] ‘ And as for [our]462-our painting , ’[112-mr. herbert] said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘ that reflects , even more clearly than [our]462-our literature , [our]462-our hideous and [our]462-our hopeless degradation . The other day , when [I]112-mr. herbert walked through [the Royal Academy]1863-the royal academy , [my]112-mr. herbert mind was literally dazzled by the infernal glare of corruption and vulgarity that was flashed upon [me]112-mr. herbert from every side . There were , indeed , only two pictures in the whole collection that were not entirely abominable ; and these were , one of them three boulders in [the island of [Sark]18-sark]1864-the island of sark , the other a study of pebbles on [the beach at [Ilfracombe]19-ilfracombe]1865-the beach at ilfracombe . ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ [I]110-mr. stockton know little about the technicalities of art , ’[110-mr. stockton] said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , ‘ so [I]110-mr. stockton will not presume to dispute this point with [you]112-mr. herbert . ’[110-mr. stockton] ‘ Well , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘ here is another test quite as good as art and literature — love and money , and [their]1866-their relations in [our]462-our days . ’[114-leslie] [He]114-leslie would have continued speaking ; but [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert allowed [him]114-leslie no time . ‘ The very things , ’[112-mr. herbert] [he]112-mr. herbert said , ‘ [I]112-mr. herbert was about to touch upon — the very things the pictures the other day suggested to [me]112-mr. herbert . For , seeing how the work of [the painter]1867-the painter becomes essentially vile so soon as it becomes essentially venal , [I]112-mr. herbert was reminded of the like corruption of what is far more precious than the work of [any painter]1868-any painter — [[our]462-our own English girls , who are prepared for the modern marriage - market on precisely the same principles as [our]462-our pictures for [the Royal Academy]1863-the royal academy]1869-our own english girls , who are prepared for the modern marriage - market on precisely the same principles as our pictures for the royal academy . There is but one difference . The work of [the modern painter]1871-the modern painter is vile from its very beginning — in its conception and execution alike ; but [[our]462-our girls]1872-our girls [we]462-our receive , in the first instance , entirely fair and sacred from the hands of [God]115-god [himself]115-god , clothed upon with a lovelier vesture than any lilies of the field — ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ Really , ’[92-lady ambrose] whispered [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose to [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ [Providence]128-providence has done so very little for [us]462-our , as far as vesture goes . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ — And [we]462-our , ’[112-mr. herbert] [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert went on , ‘ with unspeakable profanity presume to dress and to decorate them , till the heavenly vesture is entirely hidden , thinking , like a modern [Simon Magus]129-simon magus , that the gifts of [God]115-god are to be purchased for money , and not caring to perceive that , if they are to be purchased with the devil ’s money , [we]462-our must first convert them into the devil ’s gifts . ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ Yes , ’[106-mrs. sinclair] said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , with a faint smile , ‘ the day for love - matches is quite gone over now . ’[106-mrs. sinclair] But [her]106-mrs. sinclair words were drowned by [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , who exclaimed at the top of [his]102-mr. saunders voice , and in a state of great excitement , ‘ Electric telegraphs — [railways]1873-railways — steam printing presses — let [me]102-mr. saunders beg of [you]112-mr. herbert to consider the very next subject set for [us]462-our — riches and civilisation — and to judge of [the present generation]401-the present generation by the light of that . ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ [I]112-mr. herbert have considered them , ’[112-mr. herbert] said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘ for the last thirty years — and with inexpressible melancholy . ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ [I]102-mr. saunders conceive , ’[102-mr. saunders] said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ‘ that [you]112-mr. herbert are somewhat singular in [your]112-mr. herbert feelings . ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ [I]112-mr. herbert am , ’[112-mr. herbert] replied [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert ; ‘ and that in most of [my]112-mr. herbert opinions and feelings [I]112-mr. herbert am singular , is a fact fraught for [me]112-mr. herbert with the most ominous significance . Yet , how could [I]112-mr. herbert — who think that health is more than wealth , and who hold it a more important thing to separate right from wrong than to identify [men with monkeys]1875-men with monkeys — how could [I]112-mr. herbert hope to be anything but singular in a generation that deliberately , and with its eyes open , prefers [a cotton - mill]1876-a cotton - mill to a Titian ? ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ [I]102-mr. saunders hold it , ’[102-mr. saunders] said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ‘ to be one of the great triumphs of [our]462-our day , that it has so subordinated all the vaguer and more lawless sentiments to the solid guidance of sober economical considerations . And not only do [I]102-mr. saunders consider [a cotton - mill]1876-a cotton - mill , but [I]102-mr. saunders consider even [a good sewer]1878-a good sewer , to be a far nobler and a far holier thing — for holy in reality does but mean healthy — than [the most admired Madonna ever painted]1879-the most admired madonna ever painted . ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ [A good sewer]1878-a good sewer , ’[112-mr. herbert] said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘ is , [I]112-mr. herbert admit , an entirely holy thing ; and would all [[our]462-our manufacturers]1881-our manufacturers and [men of science]1882-men of science bury [themselves]1881-our manufacturers underground , and confine [their]1881-our manufacturers attention to making [sewers]1883-sewers , [I]112-mr. herbert , for one , should have little complaint against [them]1883-sewers . ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ And are railways , telegraphs , gas - lamps — is [the projected Channel tunnel]1884-the projected channel tunnel , nothing in [your]112-mr. herbert eyes ? Is it nothing that all the conditions of life are ameliorated , that mind is daily pursuing farther its conquest over matter ? ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ Have [we]462-our much to thank [you]102-mr. saunders for , ’[112-mr. herbert] said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘ that [you]102-mr. saunders have saved [us]462-our from an hour of sea - sickness , if in return [you]102-mr. saunders give [us]462-our a whole lifetime of heart - sickness ? [Your]112-mr. herbert mind , [[my]112-mr. herbert good sir]1885-my good sir , that [you]112-mr. herbert boast of , is so occupied in subduing matter , that it is entirely forgetful of subduing itself — a matter , trust [me]112-mr. herbert , that is far more important . And as for [your]112-mr. herbert amelioration of the conditions of life — that is not civilisation which saves [a man]1770-a man from the need of exercising any of [his]1770-a man powers , but which obliges [him]1770-a man to exert [his]1770-a man noble powers ; not that which satisfies [his]1770-a man lower feelings with the greatest ease , but which provides satisfaction for [his]1770-a man higher feelings , no matter at what trouble . ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ Other things being equal , ’[102-mr. saunders] said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ‘ [I]102-mr. saunders apprehend that [the generation that travels sixty miles an hour is at least five times as civilised as the generation that travels only twelve]1887-the generation that travels sixty miles an hour is at least five times as civilised as the generation that travels only twelve . ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ But the other things are not equal , ’[112-mr. herbert] said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert : ‘ and the other things , by which [I]112-mr. herbert suppose [you]112-mr. herbert mean all that is really sacred in the life of [man]1888-man , have been banished or buried by the very things which [we]1889-we boast of as [our]1889-we civilisation . ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ That is [our]1889-we own fault , ’[102-mr. saunders] said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ‘ not the fault of civilisation . ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ Not so , ’[112-mr. herbert] said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert . ‘ Bring up [a boy]1890-a boy to do nothing for [himself]1890-a boy — make everything easy for [him]1890-a boy — to use [your]112-mr. herbert own expression , subdue matter for [him]1890-a boy — and [that boy]1891-that boy will never be able to subdue anything for [himself]1890-a boy . [He]1891-that boy will be weak in body , and [a coward in soul]1892-a coward in soul — ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ Precisely , ’[102-mr. saunders] said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders . ‘ And that is really , if [you]112-mr. herbert look dispassionately at the matter , a consummation devoutly to be wished . For why do [we]1889-we need [our]1889-we bodies to be strong?—To overcome obstacles . Why do [we]1889-we need to be brave?—To attack [enemies]1893-enemies . But by and by , when all [our]1889-we work is done by machinery , and [we]1889-we have no longer any obstacles to overcome , or any hardships to endure , strength will become useless , and bravery dangerous . And [my]102-mr. saunders own hope is that both will have ere long vanished ; and that weakness and cowardice , qualities which [we]1889-we now so irrationally despise , will have vindicated their real value , by turning universal civilisation into universal peace . ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ Yes , ’[112-mr. herbert] said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘ that is exactly what the modern world is longing for — a universal peace ; which never can nor will mean anything else than peace with the devil . ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ Really , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose to [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘ do [you]114-leslie think [we]1889-we are in such a bad way as all this ? [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , [I]92-lady ambrose must ask [you]114-leslie — [you]114-leslie always know these things — do [you]114-leslie think [we]1889-we are so very bad ? ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Yes — yes , ’[376-the doctor] said [the Doctor]376-the doctor , turning towards [her]92-lady ambrose with a cheerful smile , ‘ there is a great deal that is very bad in [our]1889-we own days — very bad indeed . [Many thoughtful people]1894-many thoughtful people think that there is more that is bad in the present than there has ever been in the past . [Many thoughtful people in all days]1895-many thoughtful people in all days have thought the same . ’[376-the doctor] ‘ Whenever [wise men]1896-wise men , ’[112-mr. herbert] said [Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘ have taken to thinking about [their]1896-wise men own times , it is quite true that [they]1896-wise men have always thought ill of [them]1896-wise men . But that is because the times must have gone wrong before [the wise men]1897-the wise men take to the business of thinking about [them]1896-wise men at all . [We]1889-we are never conscious of [our]1889-we constitutions till they are out of order . ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ Ah ! yes , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke ; ‘ how true that is , [Herbert]112-mr. herbert ! But it is the gold of [the autumn woods]1898-the autumn woods , that soon falls , and leaves the boughs of [the nation]1899-the nation naked . ’[99-mr. luke] ‘ Yes , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘ leaving nothing but Bare ruined choirs , where late the sweet birds sang . ’[114-leslie] ‘ Thank [you]114-leslie , [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie , ’[112-mr. herbert] exclaimed [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert across the table , ‘ thank [you]114-leslie — an exquisitely apt quotation . ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ Then [you]114-leslie , [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose in a disappointed voice , ‘ [you]114-leslie are one of [these desponding people]1900-these desponding people too , are [you]114-leslie ? [I]92-lady ambrose never heard anything so dismal in [my]92-lady ambrose life . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ [I]114-leslie certainly think , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘ that [our]1901-we age in some ways could not possibly be worse . [Nobody]1902-nobody knows what to believe , and [most people]1903-most people believe nothing . Do n’t [you]114-leslie find that ? ’[114-leslie] ‘ Indeed [I]92-lady ambrose do not , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , with some vigour , ‘ and [I]92-lady ambrose am very sorry for those who do . That [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ’[92-lady ambrose] [she]92-lady ambrose added , lowering [her]92-lady ambrose voice , ‘ is the first person [I]92-lady ambrose ever heard express such views . [We]1901-we were dining only the other day with the Bishop of — — , and [I]92-lady ambrose ’ll tell [you]114-leslie what [he]102-mr. saunders said , [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie . [He]102-mr. saunders said that the average number of churches built yearly during the last ten years was greater than it had ever been since the Reformation . That does not look as if religion was on the decline , does it ? [I]92-lady ambrose know [the Bishop]1904-the bishop spoke of a phase of infidelity that was passing over [the nation]1899-the nation : but that , [he]102-mr. saunders said , would soon have drifted by . Indeed , [he]102-mr. saunders told [us]1901-we that all the teachings of modern irreligious science were simply reproductions of — [you]114-leslie must not laugh at [me]92-lady ambrose if [I]92-lady ambrose say the names wrong — [Epicurus]130-epicurus and Democritus — which had been long ago refuted . And that was no peculiar crotchet of [his]102-mr. saunders own mind ; for [a very clever gentleman who was sitting next [me]92-lady ambrose]1906-a very clever gentleman who was sitting next me said that that was the very thing which [all the bishops]1907-all the bishops agreed in saying — almost the only thing indeed in which [they]1907-all the bishops did agree . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Ah ! ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘ materialism once came to [the world]406-the world like [a small street boy]1909-a small street boy throwing mud at [it]406-the world ; and [the indignant world]1910-the indignant world very soon drove it away . But it has now come back again , dirtier than ever , bringing [a big brother]1911-a big brother with it , and [Heaven]108-heaven knows when [we]1901-we shall get rid of it now . ’[114-leslie] ‘ In every state of transition , ’[95-dr. jenkinson] said [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson to [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘ there must always be much uneasiness . But [I]95-dr. jenkinson do n’t think , ’[95-dr. jenkinson] [he]95-dr. jenkinson said , with a little pleased laugh , ‘ that [you]93-miss merton will find these times really much worse than those that went before [them]1912-them . No — no . If [we]1901-we look at [them]1912-them soberly , they are really a great deal better . [We]1901-we have already got rid of a vast amount of superstition and ignorance , and are learning what Christianity really is . [We]1901-we are learning true reverence — that is , not to dogmatise about subjects of which [we]1901-we can not possibly know anything . ’[95-dr. jenkinson] ‘ Just so , [Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke ; ’ that is the very thing [I]99-mr. luke am trying to teach [the world]406-the world [myself]99-mr. luke . Personal immortality , for instance , which forms no part of the sweet secret of authentic Christianity — ’[99-mr. luke] ‘ Yes — yes , ’[376-the doctor] said [the Doctor]376-the doctor hastily ; ‘ [the Church]20-the church had degraded the doctrine . It needed to be expressed anew . ’[376-the doctor] ‘ Of course , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘ [I]93-miss merton , as [a Catholic]1914-a catholic — ’[93-miss merton] ‘ Dear ! dear ! ’[376-the doctor] exclaimed [the Doctor]376-the doctor , in some confusion , ‘ [I]376-the doctor beg [your]93-miss merton pardon . It is so difficult to shape [one]1681-one ’s course in life . [One]1681-one has nowhere any work cut out for one . There is a want of — well — ’[93-miss merton] [she]93-miss merton said , smiling , ‘ of what perhaps , when religion has been analysed by science , will be called moral ozone in the air . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ Such a feeling is not unnatural , ’[376-the doctor] said [the Doctor]376-the doctor ; ‘ but [you]93-miss merton will find it vanish if [you]93-miss merton just resolve cheerfully to go on doing the duty next [you]93-miss merton — even if this be only to order dinner . And , ’[376-the doctor] [he]376-the doctor said , turning to [her]93-miss merton rather abruptly , ‘ do n’t despond over the times : that only makes [them]1920-them worse . Besides , they are not really at all bad . There is no need for desponding at all . ’[376-the doctor] ‘ But there is at least excuse , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ when [we]1921-we see all the old faiths , the old ideas , under which [the world]406-the world has so long found shelter , fading Like the baseless fabric of a vision , rapidly and for ever away from [us]1921-we . ’[83-laurence] ‘ [I]376-the doctor do n’t think so , ’[376-the doctor] said [the Doctor]376-the doctor , as if that settled the question . ‘ Christianity , ’[110-mr. stockton] said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , ‘ is only retiring to make way for something better . Religions are not quickened unless they perish . Look forward at the growing brightness of the future , not at the faded brightness of the past . ’[110-mr. stockton] ‘ Why not look at the present ? ’[95-dr. jenkinson] said [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson . ‘ Depend upon it , it is not wise to be above one ’s times . There ’s plenty of religion now . The real power of Christianity is growing every day , even where [you]93-miss merton least expect it . ’[95-dr. jenkinson] ‘ In what part of Christianity , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘ [its]1923-its real power lies , it would be unbecoming in [me]114-leslie to profess that [I]114-leslie know . But this [I]114-leslie do know , that if [you]93-miss merton take [four out of five of [the more thoughtful and instructed men of the day]1925-the more thoughtful and instructed men of the day]1924-four out of five of the more thoughtful and instructed men of the day , [you]93-miss merton will find that not only have [they]1924-four out of five of the more thoughtful and instructed men of the day no faith in [a personal God]1926-a personal god or a personal immortality , but the very notions of such things seem to them absurdities . ’[114-leslie] ‘ Yes , ’[112-mr. herbert] said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘ it was once thought a characteristic of [the lowest savages]1927-the lowest savages to be without a belief in a future life . It will soon be thought a characteristic of [the lowest savages]1927-the lowest savages to be with [one]1681-one . ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ Really now — ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , in a voice whose tone seemed to beseech [everyone]347-everyone to be sensible , ‘ personal immortality and a personal Deity are no doctrines of Christianity . [You]376-the doctor , [Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , [I]99-mr. luke know agree with [me]99-mr. luke . ’[99-mr. luke] There was nothing [the Doctor]376-the doctor so disliked as these appeals from [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke . [He]99-mr. luke made in this case no response whatever . [He]99-mr. luke turned instead to [Miss Merton]93-miss merton . ‘ [You]93-miss merton see , ’[99-mr. luke] [he]99-mr. luke said to [her]93-miss merton in a very quiet but very judicial way , ‘ the age [we]1930-we live in is an age of change . And in all such ages there must be many things that , if [we]1930-we let [them]1931-them , will pain and puzzle [us]1930-we . But [we]1930-we must n’t let [them]1931-them . There have been many ages of change before [our]1930-we time , and there are sure to be many after it . [Our]1930-we age is not peculiar . ’[99-mr. luke] Here [he]99-mr. luke paused , as [he]99-mr. luke had a way of doing at times between [his]99-mr. luke sentences . This practice now , as it had often been before , was of a disservice to [him]99-mr. luke ; for it gave a fatal facility for interruption when [he]99-mr. luke could least have wished it . In this case [Leslie]114-leslie entirely put [him]99-mr. luke out , by attacking the very statement which [the Doctor]376-the doctor least of all had designed to bear question . ‘ But in some ways , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘ this age is peculiar , surely . It is peculiar in the extraordinary rapidity of its changes . Christianity took three hundred years to supplant polytheism ; atheism has hardly taken thirty to supplant Christianity . ’[114-leslie] [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson did not deign to take the least notice of this . ‘ [I]93-miss merton suppose , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton to [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘ that [you]114-leslie think [Catholicism]131-catholicism quite a thing of the past ? ’[93-miss merton] ‘ [I]114-leslie ’m[114-leslie] afraid , ’ said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘[93-miss merton] that [my]0-i opinion on that is of very small importance . But , however that may be , [you]476-you must admit that in the views of [the world]406-the world at large there have been great changes ; and these , [I]0-i say , have come on [us]478-us with so astonishing a quickness that [they]479-they have plunged [us]478-us into a state of mental anarchy that has not been equalled since mental order has been known . There is no recognised rule of life any where . The old rules only satisfy [those who are not capable of feeling the need of any rule at all]480-those who are not capable of feeling the need of any rule at all . [Every one who does right at all only does what is right in [his]481-every one who does right at all only does what is right in his own eyes own eyes]481-every one who does right at all only does what is right in his own eyes . All society , it seems , is going to pieces . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i , ’ said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ‘[0-i] look upon social dissolution as the true condition of the most perfect life . For the centre of life is [the individual]482-the individual , and it is only through dissolution that [the individual]482-the individual can re - emerge . All the warrings of endless doubts , all the questionings of matter and of spirit , which [I]0-i have [myself]0-i known , [I]0-i value only because , remembering the weariness of [them]479-they , [I]0-i take a profounder and more exquisite pleasure in the colour of a crocus , the pulsations of a chord of music , or a picture of [Sandro Botticelli]132-sandro botticelli ’s . ’ [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose ’s words hardly produced all the effect [he]100-mr. rose could have wished ; for the last part was almost drowned in the general rustle of [the ladies]355-the ladies rising . ‘[132-sandro botticelli] Before [we]478-us go , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[83-laurence] will [you]83-laurence be good enough to tell [me]0-i the history of [these salt - cellars]484-these salt - cellars ? [I]0-i wanted to have asked [you]83-laurence at the beginning of dinner , but [you]83-laurence made [yourself]83-laurence so very appalling then , that [I]0-i really did not venture . ’ ‘[83-laurence] Well , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[83-laurence] no doubt [they]484-these salt - cellars surprise [you]83-laurence . [They]484-these salt - cellars were a present made to [me]0-i the other day by [a friend of mine]485-a friend of mine — [an eminent man of science]486-an eminent man of science , and are models of a peculiar kind of retort [he]485-a friend of mine has invented , for burning human bodies , and turning them into gas . ’ ‘[485-a friend of mine] Good gracious ! ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[485-a friend of mine] how horrible ! [I]0-i insist , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , on [your]83-laurence having another set to - morrow night — remember . ’ ‘[0-i] There , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , when [the gentlemen]1933-the gentlemen had resettled [themselves]1933-the gentlemen , and had begun [their]1933-the gentlemen wine , ‘[0-i] there is the new version of the skeleton at the banquet - board — the two handfuls of white dust , to which [we]487-we , the salt of [the earth]488-the earth , shall one day crumble .
