Is not that so , [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks ? ’ ‘[83-laurence] [Laurence]83-laurence , ’ said [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson briskly , ‘[83-laurence] the conversation has n’t kept pace with the dinner . [We]487-we have got no farther than “ The Present ” yet . [The ladies]355-the ladies are going to talk of “ The Future ” by [themselves]355-the ladies . See — there [they]355-the ladies are out on [the terrace]491-the terrace . ’ [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks here drew [his]113-mr. storks chair to the table , and cleared [his]113-mr. storks throat . ‘[355-the ladies] It is easier , ’ [he]113-mr. storks said , ‘[355-the ladies] to talk about the present now [we]487-we are alone — now [they]355-the ladies , ’ [he]113-mr. storks nodded [his]113-mr. storks head in the direction of [the party outside]1934-the party outside , ‘[355-the ladies] are gone out to talk about the future in the moonlight . There are many things which even yet it does not do to say before [women]492-women — at least , before [all women]493-all women . ’ ‘[1726-my aunt] [[My]0-i aunt]1726-my aunt , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[1726-my aunt] is [a great authority on [woman]496-woman ’s education and true position]495-a great authority on woman ’s education and true position ; and [she]1726-my aunt has written an essay to advance the female cause . ’ ‘[1726-my aunt] Indeed ? ’ said [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks ; ‘[0-i] [I]0-i was not aware of that . [I]0-i shall look forward with much pleasure to some conversation with [her]1726-my aunt . But what [I]0-i was going to say related to the present , which at dinner was on all sides so mercilessly run down . [I]0-i was going to claim for the present age , in thought and speculation ( and it is these that give their tone to its entire conduct of life ) , as its noble and peculiar feature , a universal , intrepid , dogged resolve to find out and face the complete truth of things , and to allow no prejudice , however dear to [us]487-we , to obscure [our]487-we vision . This is the only real morality : and not only is it full of blessing for the future , but it is giving [us]487-we “ manifold more in this present time ” as well . The work of science , [you]497-you see , is twofold ; it enlarges the horizon of the mind , and improves the conditions of the body . If [you]497-you will pardon [my]0-i saying so , [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , [I]0-i think [your]497-you antipathy to science must be clue to [your]497-you not having fully appreciated its true work and dignity . ’ ‘[0-i] The work of science is , [I]0-i know , twofold , ’ said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘[0-i] speculative and practical . ’ ‘[0-i] Exactly so , ’ said [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks approvingly . ‘[0-i] And all it can do for [us]487-we in speculation , ’ said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘[0-i] is to teach [us]487-we that [we]487-we have no life hereafter : all it can do for [us]487-we in practice , is to ruin [our]487-we life here . It enervates [us]487-we by providing [us]487-we with base luxury ; it degrades [us]487-we by turning [our]487-we attention to base knowledge . ’ ‘[112-mr. herbert] No — no , ’ said [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , with one of [his]95-dr. jenkinson little laughs , ‘[112-mr. herbert] not that . [I]0-i do n’t think , [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks , that [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert always quite means what [he]112-mr. herbert says . [We]487-we must n’t take [him]112-mr. herbert at [his]112-mr. herbert word . ’ ‘[487-we] [[My]0-i dear [sir]499-sir]461-my dear sir , ’ said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , turning to [the Doctor]376-the doctor , ‘[487-we] [you]499-sir are [a consecrated priest of [the mystical Church of Christ’—Dr]501-the mystical church of christ’—dr]500-a consecrated priest of the mystical church of christ’—dr . [Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson winced terribly at this—‘and let [me]0-i ask [you]499-sir if [you]499-sir think it the work of [Christ]134-christ to bring into [men]1704-men ’s minds eternal corruption , instead of eternal life — or , rather , not corruption , [I]0-i should say , but putrefaction . For what is putrefaction but decomposition ? And at the touch of science all [our]487-we noblest ideas decompose and putrefy , till [our]487-we whole souls are strewn with dead hopes and dead religions , with corpses of all the thoughts [we]487-we loved Quickening slowly into lower forms . [You]503-you may call it analysis , but [I]0-i call it death . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i wish [we]487-we could persuade [you]499-sir , ’ said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , very temperately , ‘[487-we] to take a fairer view of things . Surely truth can not in the long run be anything but life - giving . ’ ‘[499-sir] Let [us]487-we take care of facts , ’ said [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks , ‘[499-sir] and fictions — [I]0-i beg [your]499-sir pardon , religion — will take care of itself . ’ ‘[499-sir] And religion , ’ said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , ‘[499-sir] will take care of itself very well . Of course [we]487-we do n’t waste time now in thinking about personal immortality . [We]487-we shall not live ; but the mind of [man]1888-man will ; and religion will live too , being part of the mind of [man]1888-man . Religion is , indeed , to [the inner world]506-the inner world what the sky is to the outer . It is the mind ’s canopy — the infinite mental azure in which the mysterious source of [our]487-we being is at once revealed and hidden . Let [us]487-we beware , then , of not considering religion noble ; but let [us]487-we beware still more of considering it true . [We]487-we may fancy that [we]487-we trace in the clouds shapes of real things ; and , as long as [we]487-we know that this is only fancy , [I]0-i know of no holier occupation for [the human mind]402-the human mind than such cloud - gazing . But let [us]487-we always recollect that the cloud which to [us]487-we may seem shaped like [a son of man]508-a son of man , may seem to [another to be backed like a weasel]509-another to be backed like a weasel , and to another to be very like a whale . What , then , ’ [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton added , ‘[115-god] can be a nobler study than the great book of Nature , or , as [we]487-we used to call it , the works of [God]115-god ? ’ ‘[510-this generation] Pray do not think , ’ said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘[510-this generation] that [I]0-i complain of [this generation]510-this generation because it studies Nature . [I]0-i complain of it because it does not study [her]511-her . Yes , ’ [he]110-mr. stockton went on , as [he]110-mr. stockton saw [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton start , ‘[512-you] [you]512-you can analyse [her]511-her in [your]512-you test tubes , [you]512-you can spy at [her]511-her through [your]512-you microscopes ; but can [you]512-you see [her]511-her with [your]512-you own eyes , or receive [her]511-her into [your]512-you own souls ? [You]512-you can tell [us]513-us what [she]511-her makes [her]511-her wonders of , and how [she]511-her makes them , and how long [she]511-her takes about it . But [you]512-you can not tell [us]513-us what these wonders are like when they are made . When [God]115-god said , “ Let there be light , and light was , and [God]115-god saw that it was good , ” was [he]115-god thinking , as [he]115-god saw this , of the exact velocity it travelled at , and of the exact laws it travelled by , which [[you]512-you wise men]514-you wise men are at such infinite pains to discover ; or was [he]115-god thinking of something else , which [you]512-you take no pains to discover at all — of how it clothed the wings of the morning with silver , and the feathers of the evening with gold ? Is water , think [you]512-you , a nobler thing to [the modern chemist]515-the modern chemist , who can tell [you]512-you exactly what gases it is made of , and nothing more ; or to [Turner]135-turner , who could not tell [you]512-you at all what it is made of , but who did know and who could tell [you]512-you [what it is made — what it is made by the sunshine , and the cloud - shadow , and the storm - wind]516-what it is made — what it is made by the sunshine , and the cloud - shadow , and the storm - wind — who knew how it paused in [the taintless mountain trout - pool]517-the taintless mountain trout - pool , a living crystal over stones of flickering amber ; and how it broke itself turbid , with its choirs of turbulent thunder , when the rocks card it into foam , and where the tempest sifts it into spray ? When [Pindar]136-pindar called water the best of things , was [he]136-pindar thinking of it as the union of oxygen and hydrogen — ’ ‘[136-pindar] [He]136-pindar would have been much wiser if [he]136-pindar had been , ’ interposed [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson . ‘[137-thales] [Thales]137-thales , to whose theory , as [you]512-you know , [Pindar]136-pindar was referring — ’ But [the Doctor]376-the doctor ’s words were utterly unavailing to check the torrent of [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert ’s eloquence . [They]1937-they only turned it into a slightly different course . ‘[136-pindar] Ah ! [You]512-you can , no doubt , explain to [us]519-us all about sunsets ; but the smoke of [[your]512-you towns]522-your towns and [[your]512-you factories]523-your factories has made it impossible for [us]519-us to see one . However , [each generation]524-each generation is wise in [its]524-each generation own wisdom ; and [ours]519-us would sooner look at a fœtus in a bottle , than at a statue of [the god Apollo]525-the god apollo , from the hand of [Phidias]138-phidias , and in the air of [Athens]21-athens . ’ During all this speech [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks had remained with [his]113-mr. storks face buried in [his]113-mr. storks hands , every now and then drawing in [his]113-mr. storks breath through [his]113-mr. storks teeth , as if [he]113-mr. storks were in pain . Mere automata as science shows [we]519-us are — clockwork machines , wound up by meat and drink — ’ ‘[524-each generation] As for that , ’ broke in [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks , who had by this time recovered [himself]113-mr. storks — and [his]0-i weighty voice at once silenced [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ‘[524-each generation] [I]0-i would advise [[our]519-us young friend]526-our young friend not to be too confident . [We]519-us may be automata , or [we]519-us may not . Science has not yet decided . And upon [my]0-i word , ’ [he]0-i said , striking the table , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t [myself]0-i care which [we]519-us are . Supposing [the Deity]527-the deity — if there be one — should offer to make [me]0-i [a machine]528-a machine , if [I]0-i am not one , on condition that [I]0-i should always go right , [I]0-i , for one , would gladly close with the proposal . ’ ‘[0-i] But [you]529-you forget , ’ said [Allen]101-allen , ‘[0-i] that in the moral sense there would be no going right at all , if there were not also the possibility of going wrong . If [your]529-you watch keeps good time [you]529-you do n’t call it virtuous , nor if it keeps bad time do [you]529-you call it sinful . ’ ‘[529-you] Sin , [Lord Allen]101-allen , ’ said [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks , ‘[101-allen] is a word that has helped to retard moral and social progress more than anything . Nothing is good or bad , but thinking makes it so ; and the superstitious and morbid way in which a number of entirely innocent things have been banned as sin , has caused more than half the tragedies of [the world]406-the world . Science will establish an entirely new basis of morality ; and the sunlight of rational approbation will shine on many a thing , hitherto overshadowed by the curse of [a hypothetical God]531-a hypothetical god . ’ ‘[102-mr. saunders] Exactly so , ’ exclaimed [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders eagerly . ‘[102-mr. saunders] Now , [I]0-i ’m not at all [that sort of man]1938-that sort of man [myself]0-i , ’[0-i] [he]0-i went on , ‘ so do n’t think it because [I]0-i say this . ’[0-i] [Everyone]347-everyone stared at [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders in wonder as to what [he]102-mr. saunders could mean . ‘ [We]1939-we think it , for instance , ’[0-i] [he]0-i said , ‘ a very sad thing when [a girl]1940-a girl is as [we]1939-we call it ruined . Luckily this brought about a pause . [Laurence]83-laurence took advantage of it . ‘ See , ’[83-laurence] [he]83-laurence said , ‘ [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson has left [us]1943-we . Will [no one]387-no one have any more wine?—Then suppose [we]1943-we follow [him]95-dr. jenkinson . ’[83-laurence] IT was a calm , lovely evening . The moon was rising over [the sea]300-the sea , and [the sea]300-the sea was slowly silvering under it . A soft breeze breathed gently , full of the scents of flowers ; and in the low sky of the west there yet lingered a tender peach - colour . [The ladies]355-the ladies were sitting about on chairs , grouped together , but with [several little groups within [the group]537-the group]536-several little groups within the group ; and amongst [them]536-several little groups within the group all was [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , making [himself]95-dr. jenkinson particularly agreeable to [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair . When [the gentlemen]1933-the gentlemen emerged there was a general stir , and [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , shutting up a volume of [St.-Simon]139-st.-simon ’s Memoirs , said , ‘ Well , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , [we]1943-we have been talking most industriously about the future . ’[92-lady ambrose] [Laurence]83-laurence was standing with [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke on the step of the dining - room window , and [both]539-both were looking out gravely on the tranquil scene . ‘ Do [you]83-laurence remember , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ that it was here , three years ago , that [you]83-laurence composed the lines that stand last in [your]83-laurence published volumes ? ’[83-laurence] ‘ [I]99-mr. luke remember , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke dreamily . ‘ What an evening that was ! ’[99-mr. luke] ‘ [I]83-laurence wish [you]83-laurence would repeat them , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘ What is the good ? ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke ; ‘ why rouse again the voices that haunt About the mouldered lodges of the past ? ’[99-mr. luke] ‘ [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose appealingly , ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose do so wish [you]99-mr. luke would . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Is [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke going to recite poetry ? ’[106-mrs. sinclair] said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , coming languidly up to [them]540-them . ‘ How delicious ! ’[106-mrs. sinclair] [She]106-mrs. sinclair was looking lovely in the dim light , with a diamond star shining in [her]106-mrs. sinclair dark hair ; and for [a mortal bard]541-a mortal bard there was positively no resisting [her]106-mrs. sinclair appeal . [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , with a silent composure , pressed [his]99-mr. luke hands for a moment against [his]99-mr. luke forehead ; [he]99-mr. luke gave one hem ; and then in a clear melodious voice began as follows : — ‘ Thank [you]99-mr. luke , [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , so much , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘ How charming ! [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke stood apart , and surveyed [the party]1702-the party with a look of pensive pity . On [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks , however , whose last remark [he]99-mr. luke had overheard , [his]113-mr. storks eyes rested with an expression somewhat more contemptuous . The brightening moonlight fell softly on the group before [him]113-mr. storks , giving it a particularly picturesque effect , as it touched the many colours and folds of [the ladies]355-the ladies ’ dresses , and struck here and there a furtive flash from a gem on wrist or throat . The tranquil hour seemed to have a tranquillising effect on nearly [everyone]347-everyone ; and the conversation reached [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke ’s ears as a low murmur , broken only by the deep sound of [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks ’s voice , and the occasional high notes of [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , who seemed to [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , in [his]99-mr. luke present frame of mind , to be like a shrill cock crowing to [the world]406-the world before the sunrise of universal philistinism . [Laurence]83-laurence meanwhile had caught [Miss Merton]93-miss merton ’s eyes looking at [him]83-laurence with a grave regard ; and this had brought [him]83-laurence instantly to [her]93-miss merton side , when [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke had ended [his]99-mr. luke recital . ‘[544-we] [We]544-we did n’t spare the times [we]544-we live in , to - night , did [we]544-we ? ’ [he]83-laurence said slowly to [her]93-miss merton in a low voice . ‘[544-we] Well , well — [I]0-i wonder what it is all coming to — [we]544-we and [our]544-we times together ! [We]544-we are certainly [a curious medley]545-a curious medley here , all of [us]544-we . [I]0-i suppose no age but [ours]544-we could have produced one like it — at least , let [us]544-we hope so , for the credit of the ages in general . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i must say , ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , smiling , ‘[0-i] that [you]0-i seem to take to the age very kindly , and to be very happy amongst [[your]0-i friends]546-your friends . But [you]0-i did not tell [us]544-we very much of what [you]0-i thought [yourself]0-i . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t often say what [I]0-i think , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[0-i] because [I]0-i do n’t often know what [I]0-i think ; but [I]0-i know a great many things that [I]0-i do n’t think ; and [I]0-i confess [I]0-i take a pleasure in saying these , and in hearing [others]341-others say them ; so the society that [I]0-i choose as a rule represents not the things [I]0-i think [I]0-i approve , but the things [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i repudiate . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i confess , ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t quite understand that . ’ ‘[0-i] Shall [I]0-i tell [you]0-i , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[0-i] why [I]0-i live so much in society — amongst [[my]0-i friends]548-my friends , as [you]0-i call [them]548-my friends ? Simply because [I]0-i feel , in [my]0-i life , as [a child]549-a child does in [a dark room]550-a dark room ; and [I]0-i must have [some one]551-some one to talk to , or else [I]0-i think [I]0-i should go mad . What [one]1681-one says is little matter , so long as [one]1681-one makes a noise of some sort , and forgets the ghosts that in one ’s heart one is shuddering at . ’ [Miss Merton]93-miss merton was silent for a moment , and looked up into the sky in which the stars were now one by one appearing . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i suppose , ’ [she]93-miss merton said presently , ‘[0-i] [you]0-i think it is a very poor affair — life ’s whole business . And yet [I]0-i do n’t see why [you]0-i should . ’ ‘[0-i] Not see why [I]0-i should ? ’ repeated [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘[0-i] Ah , that shows how little [you]0-i , from [your]0-i position , can sympathise with [ours]554-we . [I]0-i am not surprised at it . Of course , it is out of the question that [you]0-i should . [You]0-i , happy in some sustaining faith , can see a meaning in all life , and all life ’s affections . [You]0-i can endure — [you]0-i can even welcome its sorrows . The clouds of ennui themselves for [you]0-i have silver linings . For [your]0-i religion is a kind of philosopher ’s stone , turning whatever it touches into something precious . But [we]554-we — [we]554-we can only remember that for [us]554-we , too , things had a meaning once ; but they have it no longer . [Life]140-life stares at [us]554-we now , all blank and expressionless , like the eyes of [a lost friend]555-a lost friend , who is not dead , but who has turned [an idiot]556-an idiot . Perhaps [you]0-i never read [Clough]141-clough ’s Poems , did [you]0-i ? Scarcely a day passes in which [I]0-i do not echo to [myself]0-i [his]141-clough words : — ‘ And do [you]0-i think , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton in a low tone , ‘ that belief in these days brings no painful perplexities too ? Do [you]0-i think that [we]554-we can look out on the state of [the world]406-the world now , and think about its future , without anxiety ? But really , ’[93-miss merton] [she]93-miss merton went on , raising [her]93-miss merton voice , ‘ if [I]93-miss merton , like [you]0-i , thought that Christianity was not true , [I]93-miss merton should not waste [my]93-miss merton time in lamenting over it . [I]93-miss merton should rather be glad that [I]93-miss merton had got free from a gigantic and awful imposition . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ What ! ’[83-laurence] exclaimed [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ should [we]554-we rejoice at [[our]554-we old guide]1949-our old guide dropping dead amongst [the mountains]1816-the mountains , even though [he]1949-our old guide had lost [his]1949-our old guide way ; if so [we]554-we are left hopeless , and without [any guide]1951-any guide at all ? ’[83-laurence] ‘ [You]0-i have [your]0-i consciences , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , with some decision in [her]93-miss merton voice ; ‘ [you]0-i surely do n’t mean to say that [you]0-i have lost [them]1952-them ? ’[93-miss merton] ‘ As for [our]554-we consciences , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie , who was standing close by , ‘ [we]554-we revere [them]1952-them so much that [we]554-we fancy [they]1952-them possess some power . But conscience , in most souls , is like [an English Sovereign]1953-an english sovereign — it reigns , but it does not govern . [Its]1953-an english sovereign function is merely to give a formal assent to the Bills passed by the passions ; and [it]1953-an english sovereign knows , if it opposes what those are really bent upon , that ten to one it will be obliged to abdicate . ’[114-leslie] ‘ Let [us]554-we hope that the constitutions of [most souls]1954-most souls are more stable than that , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton . ‘ As far as morality goes , [I]93-miss merton expect [you]0-i have quite enough to guide [you]0-i ; and if [you]0-i think religion false , [I]93-miss merton do n’t see why its loss should trouble [you]0-i . And life itself , remember , has plenty of pleasures . It is full of things worth living for . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ Is it ? ’[114-leslie] exclaimed [Leslie]114-leslie with sudden emphasis , and [he]114-leslie looked into [Miss Merton]93-miss merton ’s face with an expression half absent and half wondering . ‘ Is there anything in life that [you]0-i really think is , for its own sake , worth living for ? To [me]114-leslie it seems that [we]554-we are haunted with the power of imagining that there might be , and are pursued with the knowledge that there never is . Look at [that lovely water before [us]554-we]1955-that lovely water before us , with its floods of moonlight — how it ripples , how it sparkles away into the distance ! What happiness sights like these suggest to [one]1681-one ! How happy they might make [us]554-we — might , but [they]1957-they never do ! [They]1957-they only madden [us]554-we with a vague pain , that [I]114-leslie is like the sense of something lost for ever . ’[114-leslie] ‘ Still , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘ life is not all moonlight . Surely friendship and affection are worth having ? ’[93-miss merton] ‘ Let [me]114-leslie beg [you]0-i , [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie , replying to [her]93-miss merton tone rather than to [her]93-miss merton words , ‘ not to think that [I]114-leslie am always pining and bemoaning [myself]114-leslie . Fortunately the deeper part of one ’s nature will often go to sleep , and then the surface can enjoy itself . [We]554-we can even laugh with [our]554-we lips at the very things that [our]554-we hearts in silence are breaking for . But as for happiness , that is always like prophecy , it is only fulfilled in the future ; or else it is a miracle — it only exists in the past . The actual things [we]554-we wish for [we]554-we may very likely get , but they always come too late or too soon . When [the boy]1958-the boy is in love , [he]1958-the boy tries to feel like [a man]1770-a man ; when [the man]1772-the man is in love , [he]1772-the man tries to feel like [a boy]1890-a boy ; and both in vain . ’[114-leslie] ‘ Ah , ’[83-laurence] exclaimed [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ [I]83-laurence think very differently from that . [I]83-laurence know , ’[83-laurence] [he]83-laurence said , turning to [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘ that friendship and affection are things worth having ; and if only pain and anxiety would leave [me]83-laurence , [I]83-laurence could enjoy the taste of happiness . ’[83-laurence] ‘ Could [you]83-laurence ? ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie . ‘ When [I]83-laurence look at what [we]554-we are and what [the world]406-the world is , [I]83-laurence can fancy no more melancholy spectacle than [a happy man]1688-a happy man ; though [I]83-laurence admit , ’[83-laurence] [he]83-laurence added as [he]83-laurence moved slowly away , ‘ that there is none more amusing than [a man who tries to be melancholy]1964-a man who tries to be melancholy . ’[83-laurence] ‘ [Leslie]114-leslie is oddly changed , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ since [I]83-laurence saw [him]114-leslie last . [I]83-laurence am distressed with life because [I]83-laurence can not find out its worth . [He]114-leslie is indignant at it , it seems , because [he]114-leslie thinks [he]114-leslie has found out its worthlessness . And yet — [I]83-laurence envy [him]114-leslie [his]114-leslie temperament . [He]114-leslie never lets any melancholy subdue [him]114-leslie . [He]114-leslie can always laugh it down in a moment ; and [he]114-leslie will trample bravely on any of [his]114-leslie sentiments if [he]114-leslie is on the road to anything [he]114-leslie is proud of aiming at . ’[83-laurence] [Laurence]83-laurence was silent for a moment , and then said abruptly : — ‘ [I]83-laurence dare say [you]1965-you think [me]83-laurence very morbid ; but perhaps [you]1965-you can hardly realise the intense restless misery that [a man]1770-a man endures when [he]1770-a man can find nothing to do which [he]1770-a man really feels worth doing . Could [I]83-laurence only find some one thing — one great cause to labour for — one great idea — [I]83-laurence could devote [my]83-laurence whole self to it , and be happy : for labour , after all , is the only thing that never palls on [a man]1770-a man . But such a cause , such an idea — [I]83-laurence can find it nowhere . Politics have turned into a petty , weary game ; religion is dead . [[Our]1968-us new prophets]1969-our new prophets only offer [us]1968-us Humanity , in place of the God of which [they]1969-our new prophets have deprived [us]1968-us . And [Humanity]142-humanity makes [a very poor Deity]1970-a very poor deity , since it is every day disgracing itself , and is never of the same mind from one week ’s end to another . And so here [I]83-laurence am utterly alone — friendless , and with nothing to help [me]83-laurence ; feeling that , were it not for the petty contemptible interests [I]83-laurence manufacture for [myself]83-laurence from day to day , life would be quite unbearable . ’[83-laurence] ‘ And yet , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘ [you]83-laurence have much to make [you]83-laurence happy — much that [you]83-laurence would be sorry to lose . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ [I]83-laurence have a certain position , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ and a certain amount of wealth , and [I]83-laurence would not willingly lose anything of either of these ; but that is not because , in [my]83-laurence heart , [I]83-laurence value them ; but because , if [I]83-laurence lost them , [I]83-laurence might in [my]83-laurence heart cease to despise [them]1971-them . ’[83-laurence] ‘ Surely , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘ there is a better way of looking at the matter . [You]83-laurence came into [the world]406-the world with all [your]83-laurence lower ambitions satisfied for [you]83-laurence . The ground therefore is quite clear for the higher ambitions . That is why [I]93-miss merton think [an aristocracy]1973-an aristocracy , as a rule , must always be [the best governors of [men]1704-men]1974-the best governors of men , for [their]1704-men ambitions , as a rule , are the only genuine ones . Think , too , what an advantage mere wealth is . The highest labour will never produce money , but generally requires it . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ That is just the difficulty , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘ What shall [I]83-laurence labour for ? [I]83-laurence am almost maddened sometimes , as [I]83-laurence sit all the day idle , and seem to hear the hateful wasted moments slipping away from [me]83-laurence . And [I]83-laurence could do something , [I]83-laurence am sure . [I]83-laurence feel [I]83-laurence have powers . ’[83-laurence] ‘ [I]93-miss merton think , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘ that all [I]93-miss merton should say to [you]83-laurence is , find something to do . The power to find or make an object is , [I]93-miss merton think , a great part of genius . However , ’[93-miss merton] [she]93-miss merton said , with some sympathy in [her]93-miss merton voice , ‘ if [you]83-laurence are in difficulties , [I]93-miss merton am sure [I]93-miss merton wish [I]93-miss merton could help [you]83-laurence . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ Well , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence in a subdued voice , ‘ [I]83-laurence ’m[83-laurence] sure [I]0-i beg [your]557-you pardon for [my]0-i egoism . [I]0-i never talked so long about [myself]0-i in [my]0-i whole life before ; and [I]0-i promise never to do so again . ’ [Leslie]114-leslie meanwhile had moved away towards [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , who , looking particularly fascinating , was still commanding the attentions of [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson . [The Doctor]376-the doctor was standing by [her]106-mrs. sinclair , all deferent gallantry , and , to [Leslie]114-leslie ’s surprise , was saying something to [her]106-mrs. sinclair about [Sappho]143-sappho . ‘[0-i] And now , ’ said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , with a little appealing dainty smile , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i want to ask [you]557-you something about the Greek Anthology too . [I]0-i ca n’t read much Greek [myself]0-i : but [a gentleman who used to be rather kind to [me]0-i]558-a gentleman who used to be rather kind to me , translated [me]0-i a good deal of Greek poetry , once upon a time — when [[my]0-i husband]1791-my husband , ’ [she]106-mrs. sinclair said , with a little shrug of the shoulders , ‘[558-a gentleman who used to be rather kind to me] used to go to sleep after [his]1791-my husband dinner . ’ [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson here glanced suspiciously at [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair . ‘[558-a gentleman who used to be rather kind to me] Now , what [I]0-i want [you]557-you to tell [me]0-i , ’ [she]106-mrs. sinclair said , ‘[0-i] is something about some little — ahem — little love songs , [I]0-i think they were—ἐρωτικ - something or other — [I]0-i really ca n’t pronounce the name . ’ [The Doctor]376-the doctor started . ‘[0-i] And , [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , please , ’ [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair went on in a voice of plaintive innocence , ‘[0-i] not to think [me]0-i a terrible blue - stocking , because [I]0-i ask [you]557-you these questions ; for [I]0-i really hardly know any Greek [myself]0-i — except perhaps a verse or two of the New Testament ; and that ’s not very good Greek , [I]0-i believe , is it ? But [the gentleman who translated so much to [me]0-i , when [he]560-the gentleman who translated so much to me , when he came to these little poems i speak of came to these little poems [I]0-i speak of]560-the gentleman who translated so much to me , when he came to these little poems i speak of , was continually , though [he]560-the gentleman who translated so much to me , when he came to these little poems i speak of was [a very good scholar]561-a very good scholar , quite unable to translate them . Now , why should that have been , [I]0-i want to know ? Are Greek love - poems very hard ? ’ ‘[562-your friend] Well , ’ said [the Doctor]376-the doctor , stammering , yet re - assured by [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair ’s manner , ‘[562-your friend] they were probably — [[your]0-i friend]562-your friend perhaps — well — they were a little obscure perhaps — much Greek is — or — ’ ‘[106-mrs. sinclair] Corrupt ? ’ suggested [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair naively . The word was a simple one : but it sufficed to work a miracle on [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson . For the first time in [his]95-dr. jenkinson life to [a lady who united the two charms of beauty and fashion]1979-a lady who united the two charms of beauty and fashion , to both of which [he]95-dr. jenkinson was eminently susceptible , [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson was rude . [He]95-dr. jenkinson turned abruptly away , and staring hard at the moon , not at [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , said simply , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t know , ’ with the most chilling intonation of which those words are capable . [He]95-dr. jenkinson then moved a pace away , and sat down on a chair close to [Miss Merton]93-miss merton . [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair turned to [Leslie]114-leslie , with a flash in [her]106-mrs. sinclair eyes of soft suppressed laughter . ‘[0-i] How lovely the evening is ! ’ murmured [Leslie]114-leslie , responding to the smile . ‘[0-i] Yes , ’ said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , looking out dreamily over [the sea]300-the sea , ‘[0-i] it almost realises [one]1681-one ’s idea of perfect beauty . ’ ‘[0-i] Really , [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , ’ said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘[106-mrs. sinclair] [you]106-mrs. sinclair are certainly most [Hellenic]144-hellenic . First [you]106-mrs. sinclair talk of [Sappho]143-sappho , now of Ideas of Beauty . Are [you]106-mrs. sinclair [a Platonist]564-a platonist ? ’ ‘[106-mrs. sinclair] [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie , of course [I]0-i am , ’ said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , somewhat misapprehending [his]114-leslie meaning . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i never heard such an impertinent question . Platonism , however , is a very rare philosophy in these days , [I]0-i ’m afraid . ’[0-i] ‘ Ah , and so [you]106-mrs. sinclair too think [we]1981-we are all of [us]1981-we very bad , do [you]106-mrs. sinclair ? ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie . ‘ It may be so , of course ; and yet [men]1704-men at least often generalise very hastily and very wrongly , [I]114-leslie am sure . How often , for instance , do [we]1981-we say that [all wives]1983-all wives nowadays are inconstant , simply because such are the only ones [we]1981-we remember , not because [they]1983-all wives are the only ones [we]1981-we know . ’[114-leslie] This speech was quite in [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair ’s own manner , and [she]106-mrs. sinclair looked at [Leslie]114-leslie with a smile of appreciation half humorous and half sentimental , ‘ Ah , ’[106-mrs. sinclair] [she]106-mrs. sinclair began to say , in a voice that had just a touch of sadness in it , ‘ if [we]1981-we could but all of [us]1981-we love only when [we]1981-we ought , and where [we]1981-we ought — ’[106-mrs. sinclair] But here [she]106-mrs. sinclair paused . [Her]106-mrs. sinclair voice died away , and [she]106-mrs. sinclair leaned [her]106-mrs. sinclair head upon [her]106-mrs. sinclair hand in silence . [Leslie]114-leslie was going to have spoken ; but [he]114-leslie was suddenly arrested by the sound of [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , close beside [him]114-leslie , talking to [Miss Merton]93-miss merton in a tone of unusual earnestness . ‘ [I]114-leslie do n’t wonder , ’[114-leslie] [he]114-leslie was saying , ‘ that [you]1984-you should feel in perplexity sometimes ; whichever way [we]1981-we look at things there will be perplexities . But there is such a thing as goodness ; and goodness in the end must triumph , and so in this large faith let [us]1981-we rest . ’[114-leslie] ‘ And , ’[103-donald gordon] said [Donald Gordon]103-donald gordon in [his]103-donald gordon soft deferential voice , which always sounded as if [he]103-donald gordon was saying something deeply devotional , ‘ do n’t [you]1984-you think it is a higher thing to be good for good ’s own sake than for [God]115-god ’s ? and , whatever [men]1704-men may believe about having another life , and a beautiful heaven , with [gold streets]1986-gold streets , and with [jewelled fortifications]1987-jewelled fortifications , do n’t [you]1984-you think that morality really is after all its own reward ? ’[103-donald gordon] ‘ But what of [those poor people]1988-those poor people , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘ who can not be moral — whom circumstances have kept from being ever anything but brutalised ? [I]93-miss merton dare say , ’[93-miss merton] [she]93-miss merton said , turning to [the Doctor]376-the doctor , quite forgetting [his]376-the doctor sacred character , ‘ that [I]93-miss merton shall hardly be able to make [you]376-the doctor understand such a notion as that of living for [God]115-god ’s glory . But still , if there be not [a God for whose glory [we]1990-us can live , and who in [his]115-god turn will not leave [us]1990-us all to [ourselves]1990-us]1989-a god for whose glory we can live , and who in his turn will not leave us all to ourselves , what then ? Think of [all those who , in spite of hard surroundings , have just had strength enough to struggle to be good , but to struggle only — whose whole moral being has been left writhing in the road of life]1991-all those who , in spite of hard surroundings , have just had strength enough to struggle to be good , but to struggle only — whose whole moral being has been left writhing in the road of life , like an animal that a cart - wheel has gone over , just lifting its eyes up with a piteous appeal at [us]1990-us who will not help it — ’[93-miss merton] [Miss Merton]93-miss merton looked at [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson and paused . The moon shone tenderly on [his]95-dr. jenkinson silver hair , and [his]95-dr. jenkinson keen eyes had something very like moisture in them . ‘ Yes , ’[95-dr. jenkinson] [he]95-dr. jenkinson said ; ‘ these are great , great difficulties . But there is another life in store for [us]1990-us — another life , and [a God]1992-a god . And do n’t think that [the world]406-the world is growing to disbelieve in these . Remember how [many intelligent laymen]1994-many intelligent laymen count [themselves]1994-many intelligent laymen [members of [the Church of]20-the church [England]1996-england]1995-members of the church of england , simply because [they]1994-many intelligent laymen believe in these two doctrines . ’[95-dr. jenkinson] ‘ It has always been inexplicable to [me]113-mr. storks , ’[113-mr. storks] said [Mr. Storks , who had been]113-mr. storks [attracted by the sound of the Doctor]566-attracted by the sound of the doctor ’s voice , ‘ whence this longing for a future life could have arisen . [I]113-mr. storks suppose there are few things the very possibility of which science so conclusively disproves . ’[113-mr. storks] ‘ And yet , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , who had been speaking for a moment to [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , ‘ [I]83-laurence ca n’t help thinking at certain times that there may be a whole world of things undreamed of by [our]1997-our scientific philosophy . Such a feeling is touched by the sight of an “ Ora pro animâ mea , ” or a “ Resurgam , ” on [a quiet tombstone]1998-a quiet tombstone , or the sign of the cross made by [a mother]1999-a mother in hope and in sorrow on the forehead of [[her]1999-a mother dead child]2000-her dead child . ’[83-laurence] [Miss Merton]93-miss merton looked at [Laurence]83-laurence with some wonder in [her]93-miss merton large expressive eyes , [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks snorted , and [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson blinked . ‘ See , ’[95-dr. jenkinson] said [Donald Goidon]145-donald goidon , ’ the moonlight grows brighter and brighter every moment . It is almost bewildering in its dazzling paleness . ’[145-donald goidon] ‘ And there , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ do [you]2001-you catch it?—that is the light - ship on the horizon , like a large low star . ’[83-laurence] [Laurence]83-laurence seated [himself]83-laurence on the balustrade , and , leaning on [his]83-laurence elbow , looked up into the clear hollow skies . ‘ World upon world , ’[83-laurence] [he]83-laurence exclaimed at last , ‘ and each one crowded , very likely , with [beings like [ourselves]1997-our]2002-beings like ourselves , wondering what [this whole great universe]2003-this whole great universe is ! ’[83-laurence] ‘ And [the vast majority of [them]2002-beings like ourselves]2004-the vast majority of them believing in [a wise and just God]2005-a wise and just god , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘ for [I]114-leslie see no reason why [ours]1997-our should be [the stupidest world in all creation]2006-the stupidest world in all creation . ’[114-leslie] ‘ Yes , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ and in [each world]2007-each world [a small select band , that has pierced through such a husk of lies]2008-a small select band , that has pierced through such a husk of lies , and has discovered the all - golden truth , that [the universe]2009-the universe is aimless , and that for good and evil the end is all one . ’[83-laurence] [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson had a sensible horror of the stars : and as soon as [they]567-they were mentioned , [he]95-dr. jenkinson turned round in [his]95-dr. jenkinson chair , giving [his]95-dr. jenkinson back to [the group]537-the group , [Miss Merton]93-miss merton included ; whilst [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks walked away , not without dignity , ‘ [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair is going to sing in a moment , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence ; ‘ [some one]551-some one is gone to fetch [her]106-mrs. sinclair guitar . ’[83-laurence] ‘ Hush ! ’[93-miss merton] exclaimed [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘ do just listen to this . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ Good gracious ! ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence in a whisper , ‘ [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks is at [[my]83-laurence aunt]1726-my aunt at last . ’[83-laurence] [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks had been watching ever since dinner for an opportunity of discussing with [Lady Grace]89-lady grace the true position of [woman]496-woman , as settled by modern science . [He]113-mr. storks was peculiarly full of this subject just now , having received only that morning a letter from [a celebrated American physician , who stated very strongly as [his]95-dr. jenkinson opinion , that the strain of what is called the higher education]570-a celebrated american physician , who stated very strongly as his opinion , that the strain of what is called the higher education was most prejudicial to the functions of maternity , and that the rights of [woman]496-woman might very probably be fatal to the existence of [man]1888-man . As soon as [he]113-mr. storks got hold of [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , [he]113-mr. storks led up to this point with startling rapidity ; having been perfectly charmed at starting to find that [she]89-lady grace fully agreed with [him]113-mr. storks that the prejudices of the present day were doing more harm to [woman]496-woman ’s true interests than anything else . ‘ It is a pleasure , ’[113-mr. storks] said [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks , ‘ to discuss these matters with [a person so thoroughly enlightened as [yourself]2012-a person so thoroughly enlightened as yourself]2012-a person so thoroughly enlightened as yourself . [You]2012-a person so thoroughly enlightened as yourself will of course see from what [Dr. Boston]146-dr. boston says how entirely suicidal is the scheme of turning [woman]496-woman into [a female man]2014-a female man . [Nature]121-nature has marked out [her]121-nature mission for [her]121-nature plainly enough ; and so [[our]2015-our old friend [Milton]147-milton]2016-our old friend milton was right in [his]147-milton meaning after all , when [he]147-milton says that [man]1888-man is made for [God]115-god , and [woman]496-woman for [God]115-god through [him]1888-man , though of course the expression is antiquated . ’[113-mr. storks] ‘ Surely , ’[89-lady grace] said [Lady Grace]89-lady grace with animation , ‘ not only the expression is antiquated , but the meaning also is contrary to all true fairness and enlightment . ’[89-lady grace] ‘ [I]113-mr. storks confess , [I]113-mr. storks do n’t see that , ’[113-mr. storks] said [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks with a look of smiling deference . ‘ What ! ’[89-lady grace] cried [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , ‘ is it not contrary to reason — let [me]89-lady grace put it to [your]113-mr. storks own candour — for [a man who knows that [[his]2019-a man who knows that his wife , ages hence wife]2020-his wife , ages hence]2019-a man who knows that his wife , ages hence , will be [a seraph singing before the throne of [God]115-god]2021-a seraph singing before the throne of god , to consider [her]2020-his wife only made for [God]115-god through [him]2019-a man who knows that his wife , ages hence — to consider [her]2020-his wife , indeed , as a thing made simply for [[her]2020-his wife husband]1841-her husband ’s use ? ’[89-lady grace] This answer of [Lady Grace]89-lady grace ’s took [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks quite aback . [He]113-mr. storks knew not how to comport [himself]113-mr. storks . [His]113-mr. storks jaw fell — [he]113-mr. storks stared — [he]113-mr. storks said nothing . [He]113-mr. storks felt as though [he]113-mr. storks had been assassinated . But luckily at this very moment , liquid and clear , and exquisitely modulated , were heard the sounds of [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair ’s voice , singing the following song — ‘ What a lovely voice ! ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence to [Miss Merton]93-miss merton . ‘ [I]83-laurence wonder how [she]106-mrs. sinclair will sound singing before the throne . ’[83-laurence] ‘ [She]106-mrs. sinclair will be obliged to take lessons in a rather different style , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , unable to suppress a smile ; and then [she]93-miss merton suddenly checked [herself]93-miss merton , and looked grave . ‘ [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair has always interested [me]93-miss merton , ’[93-miss merton] [she]93-miss merton said . ‘ [I]93-miss merton often come across [her]106-mrs. sinclair in [London]1-london , but [I]93-miss merton hardly know [her]106-mrs. sinclair . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , ’[106-mrs. sinclair] said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , ‘ [you]83-laurence must now make [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie sing , for [I]106-mrs. sinclair discover that [he]114-leslie can play the guitar too . ’[106-mrs. sinclair] [Leslie]114-leslie was of course pressed , and with some reluctance consented . ‘ [I]114-leslie suppose , ’[114-leslie] [he]114-leslie said , ‘ [we]2023-we are all of [us]2023-we more or less moon - struck to - night , so [I]114-leslie had best sing the silliest thing [I]114-leslie know ; and as [I]114-leslie do n’t think anything can be sillier than a song [I]114-leslie once wrote [myself]114-leslie , [I]114-leslie will sing that . ’[114-leslie] [He]114-leslie touched a few chords carelessly , and yet with the manner of [a practised player]574-a practised player ; paused for a moment , and then again striking the instrument began to sing . [He]114-leslie was watched at first with merely a languid curiosity ; and [Miss Prattle]107-miss prattle whispered to [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose that [his]114-leslie attitude was very affected ; but curiosity and criticism were both lost in surprise at the first sound of [his]114-leslie rich and flexible voice , and still more so at the real passion which [he]114-leslie breathed into the following words , rude and artless as they were : — [Leslie]114-leslie received loud thanks from many voices , especially from [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . [Some]1684-some , however , were almost silent from surprise at the feeling , which [he]114-leslie seemed quite unconsciously to have betrayed . [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair held out [her]106-mrs. sinclair hand to [him]114-leslie , when [no one]387-no one was looking , and said quietly , ‘ Thank [you]114-leslie so much , [I]106-mrs. sinclair ca n’t tell [you]114-leslie how [I]106-mrs. sinclair like [your]114-leslie song . ’[106-mrs. sinclair] ‘ Well , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , as [the party]1702-the party moved indoors into [the lighted drawing - room]578-the lighted drawing - room , ‘ [we]1702-the party have been all of [us]1702-the party very sentimental to - night , and if [we]1702-the party ca n’t get better now , [I]83-laurence hope [we]1702-the party shall sleep it off , and wake up well and sane to - morrow morning . ’[83-laurence] This being Saturday night , there sprang up some vague mention of [church]579-church . [The nearest church]580-the nearest church however was some miles distant , and a rumour arose amongst [the guests]1694-the guests that [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson would perform the service and preach a sermon in [the private chapel]582-the private chapel . On the following morning [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose awoke somewhat out of spirits . Last night , whilst [[her]92-lady ambrose maid]583-her maid was brushing [her]92-lady ambrose hair , [she]92-lady ambrose had pondered deeply over much that [she]92-lady ambrose had heard during the evening ; and [her]92-lady ambrose thoughts having been once started in such a direction , the conviction quickly dawned upon [her]92-lady ambrose that [the world]406-the world was indeed becoming very bad , and that society was on the point of dissolution . This was quite a new view of things to [her]92-lady ambrose , and it had all the charm of novelty . Still , however , [she]92-lady ambrose would probably have found by the morning that [she]92-lady ambrose had successfully slept it off , if the post had not failed to bring [her]92-lady ambrose an invitation to the Duchess of — — — ’s garden - party at — — — House , which [she]92-lady ambrose was expecting with some anxiety . As it was , therefore , [her]92-lady ambrose spirits failed to recover themselves , and whilst [she]92-lady ambrose was being dressed [her]92-lady ambrose thoughts wandered wistfully away to the promised morning service in [the chapel]585-the chapel . At breakfast , however , another blow awaited [her]92-lady ambrose . How [a private chapel]586-a private chapel had come to be mentioned last evening was not clear . Certainly there was no such appendage to [[Laurence]83-laurence ’s villa]587-laurence ’s villa , and the susceptibilities of [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose received a severe shock , as [she]92-lady ambrose learnt that the ministrations of [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , the comfort of which [she]92-lady ambrose was looking forward to , were to take place in [the theatre which adjoined [the house]1761-the house]588-the theatre which adjoined the house . [She]92-lady ambrose bore up , however , like [a brave woman]590-a brave woman , and resolving that nothing , on [her]92-lady ambrose part at least , should be wanting , [she]92-lady ambrose appeared shortly before eleven o’clock , in full Sunday costume , with [her]92-lady ambrose bonnet , and [her]92-lady ambrose books of devotion . [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair looked at [her]92-lady ambrose in dismay . ‘ [I]106-mrs. sinclair had thought , ’[106-mrs. sinclair] [she]106-mrs. sinclair said plaintively to [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ that , as this was only a morning performance , [I]106-mrs. sinclair need not make a toilette . And as for a prayer - book , why , [dear Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , [I]106-mrs. sinclair have not had one since [I]106-mrs. sinclair was confirmed . ’[106-mrs. sinclair] ‘ Not when [you]114-leslie were married ? ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie . ‘ Perhaps , ’[106-mrs. sinclair] said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair pensively , ‘ but [I]106-mrs. sinclair have forgotten all about that — now . ’[106-mrs. sinclair] At this moment the gong sounded , and [the whole party]591-the whole party , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose and [her]92-lady ambrose bonnet amongst [them]591-the whole party , adjourned to [the place of worship]592-the place of worship , which was connected with [the house]1761-the house by [a long corridor]594-a long corridor . When [the party]1702-the party entered [they]591-the whole party found [themselves]591-the whole party in a complete miniature theatre , with the gas , as there were no windows , fully burning . It had been arranged beforehand that [the guests]1694-the guests should occupy the boxes , the gallery being appropriated to [the servants]597-the servants , whilst [the stalls]598-the stalls were to remain completely empty . [The congregation]599-the congregation entered with great decorum and gradually settled [themselves]599-the congregation in [their]599-the congregation places with a subdued whispering . [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose buried [her]92-lady ambrose face in [her]92-lady ambrose hands for a few moments , and [several of [the younger ladies]601-the younger ladies]600-several of the younger ladies followed [her]92-lady ambrose example . [Everyone]347-everyone then looked about [them]347-everyone silently , in suspense and expectation . The scene that met [their]347-everyone eyes was certainly not devotional . The whole little semicircle glittered with heavy gilding and with hangings of crimson satin , and against these the stucco limbs of a number of gods and [goddesses]603-goddesses gleamed pale and prominent . [The gallery]604-the gallery rested on the heads of [nine scantily - draped Muses]605-nine scantily - draped muses , who , had [they]605-nine scantily - draped muses been two less in number , might have passed for the seven deadly sins ; round the frieze in high relief reeled a long procession of Fauns and Bacchanals ; and [half the harem of [Olympus]148-olympus]606-half the harem of olympus sprawled and floated on the azure ceiling . Nor was this all . The curtain was down , and , brilliantly illuminated as it was , displayed before the eyes of [the congregation Faust on the Brocken]607-the congregation faust on the brocken , with a long plume , dancing with [the young witch , who could boast of no costume at all]608-the young witch , who could boast of no costume at all . The scene was so strange that [everyone]347-everyone forgot to whisper or even to smile . There was a complete silence , and the eyes of all were soon fixed upon the curtain in wonder and expectation . Presently a sound was heard . A door opened , and [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , in [his]95-dr. jenkinson ordinary dress , entered [the stalls]598-the stalls . [He]95-dr. jenkinson looked deliberately round [him]95-dr. jenkinson for a moment , as though [he]95-dr. jenkinson were taking stock of [those present]611-those present ; then , selecting the central stall as a kind of prie - dieu , [he]95-dr. jenkinson knelt down facing [[his]95-dr. jenkinson congregation]612-his congregation , and after a moment ’s pause began to read the service in a simple , earnest voice . [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , however , though [she]92-lady ambrose knew [her]92-lady ambrose prayer - book as well as [most women]613-most women , could not for the life of [her]92-lady ambrose find [the place]419-the place . The reason was not far to seek . [The Doctor]376-the doctor was opening the proceedings with the following passage from the Koran , which [he]376-the doctor had once designed to use in [Westminster Abbey]23-westminster abbey as the text of a missionary sermon . ‘ Be constant in prayer , ’[376-the doctor] [he]376-the doctor began , in a voice tremulous with emotion , ‘ and give alms : and what good [ye]2024-ye have sent before for [your]2024-ye souls , [ye]2024-ye shall find it with [God]115-god . Surely [God]115-god seeth that which [ye]2024-ye do . [They]2025-they say , Verily [none]2026-none shall see [Paradise]149-paradise except [they]2025-they be [Jews]2027-jews or [Christians]2028-christians . This is [their]2025-they wish . Say [ye]2024-ye , Produce [your]2024-ye proof of this if [ye]2024-ye speak truth . Nay , but [he]2029-he who resigneth [himself]2029-he to [God]115-god , and doeth that which is right , [he]2029-he shall have [his]2029-he reward with [[his]2029-he Lord]2030-his lord ; there shall come no fear on [them]2025-they , neither shall [they]2025-they be grieved . ’[376-the doctor] [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson then went on to the Confession , the Absolution , and a number of other selections from the English morning service , omitting , however , the creed , and concluded the whole with a short prayer of [St. Francis Xavier]150-st. francis xavier ’s . But it was discovered that [his]95-dr. jenkinson voice , unless [he]95-dr. jenkinson made an effort , was unhappily only partly audible from the position which [he]95-dr. jenkinson occupied ; and [Laurence]83-laurence , as soon as the Liturgy was over , went softly up to [him]95-dr. jenkinson to apprise [him]95-dr. jenkinson of the fact . [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson was very grateful for being thus told in time . It was fortunate , [he]95-dr. jenkinson said , that the prayers only had been missed ; the question was , where should [he]95-dr. jenkinson go for the sermon . [Laurence]83-laurence in a diffident manner proposed the stage ; but [the Doctor]376-the doctor accepted the proposal with great alacrity , and [Laurence]83-laurence went immediately out with [him]95-dr. jenkinson to conduct [him]95-dr. jenkinson to [[his]95-dr. jenkinson new pulpit]617-his new pulpit . In a few moments the curtain was observed to twitch and tremble ; two or three abortive pulls were evidently being made ; and at last [Faust]151-faust and [the young witch]618-the young witch rapidly rolled up , and discovered first the feet and legs , and then [the entire person of [Doctor Jenkinson]152-doctor jenkinson , standing in the middle of [a gorge in [the Indian Caucasus]24-the indian caucasus]620-a gorge in the indian caucasus]619-the entire person of doctor jenkinson , standing in the middle of a gorge in the indian caucasus — the remains of a presentation of Prometheus Bound which had taken place last February . [The Doctor]376-the doctor was not [a man to be abashed by incongruities]622-a man to be abashed by incongruities . [He]376-the doctor looked about [him]376-the doctor for a moment : [he]376-the doctor slightly raised [his]376-the doctor eyebrows , and then , without the least discomposure , and in a clear incisive voice , began : — ‘ In the tenth verse of the hundred and eleventh Psalm , it is said , “ The fear of [the Lord]2031-the lord is the beginning of wisdom . ” The fear of [the Lord]325-the lord , ’[376-the doctor] [he]376-the doctor again repeated , more slowly , and with more emphasis , surveying the theatre as [he]376-the doctor spoke , ‘ is the beginning of wisdom . ’[376-the doctor] [He]376-the doctor then made a long pause , looking down at [his]376-the doctor feet , as if , although [he]376-the doctor held [his]376-the doctor sermon - book in [his]376-the doctor hand , [he]376-the doctor were considering how to begin . As [he]376-the doctor stood there silent , the footlights shining brightly on [his]376-the doctor silver hair , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose had full time to verify the text in [her]92-lady ambrose prayer - book . At last [the Doctor]376-the doctor suddenly raised [his]376-the doctor head , and with a gentle smile of benignity playing on [his]376-the doctor lips , shook open [his]376-the doctor manuscript , and thus proceeded : — ‘ The main difficulty that occupied [the early Greek Philosophers]2033-the early greek philosophers , as soon as philosophy in its proper sense can be said to have begun , was the great dualism that seemed to run through all things . Matter and mind , the presence of imperfection , and the idea of perfection , or the unity and plurality of being , were amongst the various forms in which the two contradictory elements of things were presented to [them]2033-the early greek philosophers , as demanding reconcilement or explanation . This manner of viewing things comes to a head , so to speak , amongst [the ancients]2034-the ancients , in the system of [Plato]153-plato . With [him]153-plato the sensible and the intelligible worlds stand separated by a great gulf , the one containing all good , the other of itself only evil , until [we]2035-we recognise its relation to the good , and see that it is only a shadow and a type of it . The world of real existence is something outside , and virtually unconnected with , [this world of mere phenomena]2036-this world of mere phenomena ; and the Platonic prayer is that [we]2035-we should be taken out of [the world]406-the world , rather than , as [Christ]134-christ says , with a fuller wisdom , that [we]2035-we should be delivered from the evil . [Plato]153-plato had , however , by thus dwelling on this antagonism in things , paved the way for a reconciliation — some say [he]153-plato even [himself]153-plato began it . At any rate , it was through [him]153-plato that it was nearly , if not quite , accomplished by [[his]153-plato disciple]2038-his disciple [Aristotle]154-aristotle . [Aristotle]154-aristotle first systematised the great principle of evolution , and transformed what had appeared to [former thinkers as the dualism of mind]2039-former thinkers as the dualism of mind and matter into a single scale of ascending existences . Thus what [Plato]153-plato had conceived of as [two worlds]2040-two worlds , were now presented as opposite poles of the same . The πρώτη ὕλη , [the world]406-the world “ without form and void , ” receiving form , at length culminated in the soul of [man]1888-man ; and in the soul of [man]1888-man sensation at length culminated in pure thought . ’[376-the doctor] A slight cough here escaped from [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair . ‘ [You]106-mrs. sinclair will perhaps think , ’[376-the doctor] [the Doctor]376-the doctor went on , ‘ that a sermon is not the place in which to discuss such differences of secular opinion ; or [you]106-mrs. sinclair will perhaps think that such differences are of no very great moment . But if [you]106-mrs. sinclair look under the surface , and at the inner meaning of them , [you]106-mrs. sinclair will find that [they]626-his audience bear upon questions which are , or ought to be , of the very highest moment to each of [us]2044-us — questions indeed , ’[376-the doctor] [the Doctor]376-the doctor added , suddenly lowering [his]376-the doctor manuscript for a moment , and looking sharply round at [[his]376-the doctor audience]626-his audience , ‘ which [we]2044-us all of [us]2044-us here have very lately — very lately indeed — either discussed [ourselves]2044-us , or heard discussed by [others]341-others . ’[376-the doctor] This produced an immediate sensation , especially amongst the feminine part of [the listeners , to whom the discourse thus far had seemed strange , rather than significant]627-the listeners , to whom the discourse thus far had seemed strange , rather than significant . ‘ The question , ’[376-the doctor] [the Doctor]376-the doctor continued , ‘ is one of the relations of the spiritual to the natural ; and the opposition between the views of [these two ancient philosophers]2046-these two ancient philosophers is by no means obsolete in [our]2044-us own century . There is even now far too prevalent a tendency to look upon the spiritual as something transcending and completely separate from the natural ; and there is in the minds of [many well - meaning and earnest persons]2047-many well - meaning and earnest persons a sort of alarm felt at any attempt to bring [the two]2048-the two into connection . This feeling is experienced not by [Christians]2028-christians only , but by [a large number of [[their]2028-christians opponents]2051-their opponents]2050-a large number of their opponents . There is , for instance , no doctrine more often selected for attack by those who oppose Christianity upon moral grounds , than that of which [my]376-the doctor text is an expression , [I]376-the doctor mean the doctrine of a morality enforced by rewards and punishments . Such morality , [we]2044-us hear it continually urged by [men who set [themselves]2052-men who set themselves up as advanced thinkers up as [advanced thinkers]2053-advanced thinkers]2052-men who set themselves up as advanced thinkers , is no morality at all . No action can be good , [they]2052-men who set themselves up as advanced thinkers tell [us]2044-us , that does not spring from the love of good . Virtue is no longer virtue if it springs from fear . The very essence of it is to spring from freedom . Now , these arguments , though specious at the first blush of the thing , are really , if [we]2044-us look them honestly in the face , to the utmost shallow and unphilosophical . They are really but so many denials of the great doctrine of evolution — so many attempts to set up again that absolute antagonism between good and evil which it has been the aim of [all the higher thinkers]2054-all the higher thinkers , and of [Christ]134-christ [himself]134-christ , to do away with . If , then , [these modern critics of Christianity]2055-these modern critics of christianity come to [us]2044-us with such objections , let [us]2044-us not try to disguise the truth that the morality of [our]2044-us religion is based on fear . Let [us]2044-us rather boldly avow this , and try to point out to [them]2052-men who set themselves up as advanced thinkers that it is [they]2052-men who set themselves up as advanced thinkers , and not [the Psalmist]2056-the psalmist , that are out of harmony with modern thought . For what is it that the sacred Scripture says ? “ The fear of [the Lord]325-the lord is the beginning of wisdom . ” The beginning , [you]2058-you will please to observe — the beginning only . It is not perfect wisdom , it is not perfect virtue ; but it is the beginning of both of these . It is , if [I]376-the doctor may be allowed the expression , the moral protoplasm — it is that out of which [they]2052-men who set themselves up as advanced thinkers are both evolved . It is , as [Aristotle]154-aristotle would call it , [their]2052-men who set themselves up as advanced thinkers potentiality . The actuality is different from the potentiality ; for “ perfect love ” as [St. John]155-st. john says , “ casteth out fear . ” Putting together , then , the ideas of [these two good men]2059-these two good men , [St. John]155-st. john and [Aristotle]154-aristotle , [we]2060-we may say that the love of [God]115-god — that is , true wisdom — is the actuality of the fear of [Him]115-god . ‘[376-the doctor] This account of the origin of the true wisdom may not , indeed , be applicable to each individual case . [Some persons]629-some persons ’ — [the Doctor]376-the doctor ’s voice here grew very soft , and seemed as though it would almost break with feeling — ’[376-the doctor] [some persons]629-some persons may have been so fortunate as to have received the truest wisdom into [their]629-some persons hearts by education , almost with [[their]629-some persons mother]631-their mother ’s milk . But there are [those not so fortunate , who may have needed the discipline of a godly fear to lead [them]632-those not so fortunate , who may have needed the discipline of a godly fear to lead them upwards front a “ wallowing in the sensual sty ” towards the higher life upwards front a “ wallowing in the sensual sty ” towards the higher life]632-those not so fortunate , who may have needed the discipline of a godly fear to lead them upwards front a “ wallowing in the sensual sty ” towards the higher life . And just as this is true of many of [us]633-us individually , so it is still more deeply true of [the human race as a whole]634-the human race as a whole . All study of history , and of social science , and of philosophy , is teaching this to [us]633-us every day with increasing clearness . [The human race]1783-the human race , as soon as [it]1783-the human race became [human]636-human , feared [God]115-god before [it]1783-the human race loved [Him]115-god . [Its]1783-the human race fear , as the Scripture puts it , was the beginning of [its]1783-the human race wisdom ; or as modern thought has put it , in slightly different words , the love of justice sprang out of the fear of suffering injustice . Thus the end is different from the beginning , and yet springs out of it . Ethics , as it has been well said , are the finest fruits of humanity , but they are not its roots . [Our]633-us reverence for truth , all [our]633-us sacred family ties , and the purest and most exalted forms of matrimonial attachment , have each [their]637-their respective origins in self - interest , self - preservation , and animal appetite . ‘ There is , [I]0-i admit , in this truth something that may at first sight repel [us]633-us , and perhaps even prompt some of [us]633-us to deny indignantly that it is a truth at all . But this is really a cowardly and unworthy feeling , fatal to any true comprehension of [God]115-god ’s dealings with [man]1888-man , and arising from a quite mistaken conception of [our]633-us own dignity , and [our]633-us own connection with [God]115-god . It is some such mistaken conception as this that sets so many of [us]633-us against the discoveries of modern science as to the origin of [our]633-us own species , and , what is far worse , prompts [us]633-us to oppose such discoveries with dishonest objections . How is it possible , some of [us]633-us ask , that [man]1888-man with [his]1888-man sublime conceptions of duty and of [God]115-god , and [his]1888-man fine apparatus of reason , and so forth , should be produced by any process of evolution from a beastly and irrational ape ? But to ask such questions as these is really to call in question the power of [God]115-god , and so to do [Him]115-god dishonour . It is true that [we]633-us can not trace out , as yet , all the steps of this wonderful evolution ; but let [us]633-us not be found , like doubting [Thomas]156-thomas , resolved not to believe until [we]633-us have actually seen . And yet , if [our]633-us faith does indeed require strengthening , [we]633-us have only to look a little more attentively at the commonest facts before [us]633-us . For is it not , let [me]0-i ask [you]2064-you — to take , for instance , [a man]1770-a man ’s sublime faculty of reasoning and logical comprehension — far more wonderful that [a reasoning man]2066-a reasoning man should have the same parents as [a woman]1817-a woman , than that [they]2068-they both should have [the same parents as a monkey]2069-the same parents as a monkey ? Science and religion both alike teach [us]633-us that with [God]115-god all things are possible . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i just touch in passing upon this doctrine that [we]638-we popularly call Darwinism , because it is the most familiar example to [us]638-we of the doctrine of evolution . But the point which [I]0-i am wishing to emphasize is not the outward evolution of [man]1888-man , but the inward , of which , however , the former is an image and a likeness . This theory of moral evolution , [I]0-i wish to point out to [you]640-you , is alike the Christian and the scientific theory ; and [I]0-i thus wish [you]640-you to see that the very points in which science seems most opposed to Christianity are really those in which it most fundamentally agrees with it . [I]0-i will therefore just ask [you]640-you to notice how foolish and short - sighted [those persons are who think that a great result is lessened if it can be proved to have had small beginnings]641-those persons are who think that a great result is lessened if it can be proved to have had small beginnings . Is a state less truly a state because [we]638-we know that it has sprung out of the germ of [the family]642-the family ? Surely not . Neither is [man]1888-man less truly [man]1888-man if [he]1888-man have sprung from an ape ; nor is love less truly love if it has sprung from fear . ‘ And so now , since [we]638-we have seen how science and Christianity are at one as to the rise of the moral sentiments , [I]406-the world will pass on to a wider point , the character and the history of Christianity itself , both of which have been misunderstood and misinterpreted for at least eighteen hundred years ; and when [I]406-the world have pointed out how this great subject is being now explained by the methods of modern science , [I]406-the world will pass on to an issue that is wider yet . ‘[406-the world] [The world]406-the world has hitherto failed to understand Christianity , because [it]406-the world studied it upon a false method — a method based upon that old dualistic theory of things of which [I]0-i have already spoken . Just as [Plato]153-plato looked upon mind as entirely distinct from matter , so used [Christians]2028-christians to look upon things sacred as entirely distinct from things secular . But now this middle wall of partition is being broken down by science , and by scientific criticism , and by a wider view of things in general . The primary way in which all this has affected Christianity , is by the new spirit in which it has led [us]638-we to study the Bible . [We]638-we used to look upon the Bible as a book standing apart by itself , and to be interpreted by a peculiar canon of criticism . But [we]638-we have now learnt that it is to be studied just like all other books ; and [we]638-we are now for the first time coming to understand what , in its true grandeur , a real revelation is . [We]638-we are learning , in fact , that just as no single scripture “ is of any private interpretation ; ” still less is the entire body of the Scriptures . They , too , must be interpreted by [their]2028-christians context . [We]638-we must inquire into [their]2028-christians origin ; [we]638-we must ask diligently under what circumstances they were written and edited , and for what ends . Nor must [we]638-we ever again fall into such quaint and simple mistakes as did commentators like [Origen]157-origen , or [Augustine]158-augustine , or [Tertullian]3-tertullian , or even [Paul]119-st. paul [himself]119-st. paul , whose discoveries of Messianic prophecies in writings like the Psalms for instance , are really much the same as would be a discovery on [our]638-we part in [Mr. Tennyson]160-mr. tennyson ’s line on the death of [the Duke of [Wellington]25-wellington]647-the duke of wellington , “ [The last great Englishman]648-the last great englishman is low , ” a prophecy of [the late Chancellor of the Exchequer]649-the late chancellor of the exchequer . But to understand the meaning of any text , [we]638-we must try to see what , from [his]650-i position and education , [the writer]651-the writer could have meant by it ; not what this or [that Father]318-that father , living long afterwards , fancied that [he]650-i meant . [Our]638-we motto in religion , as in science , should be , “ Vere scire est per causas scire . ” ‘ If [we]638-we study Christianity reverently and carefully upon these principles , [we]638-we shall see that it was not a thing that sprang up , as [we]638-we used to fancy , without any human antecedents , but that its roots reach back with many ramifications into the western and oriental thought of preceding centuries . [We]638-we shall see how it absorbed into [itself]2070-itself all that was highest in Hebraistic Theism and in Hellenic thought — something too , let [us]638-we admit , of the failings of both . [I]650-i can not here enter into any of the details of this , what may be truly termed pre - Christian Christianity . [I]650-i can only briefly point out its existence , and its double origin , commenting on these by the following few lines from [a great German writer]2071-a great german writer . “ The yearning after a higher revelation ” [he]2071-a great german writer tells [us]638-we , “ was the universal characteristic of the last centuries of [the ancient world]2072-the ancient world . This was in the first place but a consciousness of the decline of [the classical nations]2073-the classical nations and [their]2073-the classical nations culture , and the presentiment of the approach of a new era ; and it called into life not only Christianity , but also , and before it , Pagan and Jewish Alexandrianism , and other related developments . ” ‘[650-i] This , then , is the great point to be borne in mind — viz . that [God]115-god had been preparing the way for the coming of [Christ]134-christ long before [he]115-god sent “ [Elias]161-elias , which was for to be . ” Neither [John Baptist]162-john , no , nor One greater than [John]162-john , was left by [God]115-god ( as [the children of [Israel]26-israel]653-the children of israel were left by [Pharaoh]163-pharaoh ) to gather straw [himself]115-god to make bricks . The materials were all prepared ready to [their]654-their hands by [[their]654-their Heavenly Father]655-their heavenly father . And so , let [us]656-we be especially and prayerfully on [our]656-we guard against considering Christianity as having come into [the world]406-the world at once , ready - made , so to speak , by [[our]656-we Saviour]658-our saviour , as a body of theological doctrines . Any honest study of history will show [us]656-we that [the Apostles]659-the apostles received no such system ; that [[our]656-we Lord [Himself]660-our lord himself]660-our lord himself never made any claim to the various characters with which subsequent thought invested [Him]660-our lord himself ; and that to attribute such claims to [Him]660-our lord himself , would be an anachronism , of which [He]660-our lord himself would [Himself]660-our lord himself have scarcely understood the meaning . If [we]656-we only clear [our]656-we eyes of any false theological glamour , a very slight study of [the inspired writers]661-the inspired writers will at once show [us]656-we this . [We]656-we shall see how uncertain and shifting at first everything was . [We]656-we shall see what a variety of conflicting opinions [the early Church]662-the early church entertained even upon the most fundamental subjects — such , for instance , as the identity of [the God of the Old Testament]663-the god of the old testament with [the God of the New , which was denied by [a large number of [the early Christians]666-the early christians]665-a large number of the early christians]664-the god of the new , which was denied by a large number of the early christians : [we]656-we shall see how widely divergent were the systems of Jewish and Pauline Christianity , and how discrepant and tentative are the accounts given by [St. Paul]119-st. paul and by [the author of the Fourth Gospel of the mystical nature of [Christ]134-christ , whom [they]668-they tried to identify with different mysterious potencies supposed by [the Jewish - Alexandrian philosophers]669-the jewish - alexandrian philosophers to be coexistent with [God]115-god]667-the author of the fourth gospel of the mystical nature of christ , whom they tried to identify with different mysterious potencies supposed by the jewish - alexandrian philosophers to be coexistent with god . And if [we]656-we pursue the history of [the Church]670-the church a little farther , [we]656-we shall find many more things to startle [us]656-we .
