[We]656-we shall find , for instance , [the most renowned apologist of early Catholic times]671-the most renowned apologist of early catholic times , a materialist , holding the materiality not of the soul of [man]1888-man only , but of [God]115-god also . “ Nihil enim”—these are [this father]673-this father ’s words—“si non corpus . Omne quod est , corpus est . ” Thus [we]656-we see , ’ said [the Doctor]376-the doctor cheerfully , looking round [him]0-i with a smile of benignant triumph , and blinking with [his]0-i eyes , ‘[673-this father] that difference of opinion about the dogmas of religion is nothing new . It existed in the Jewish Church ; the phenomenon was only prolonged by Christianity . Later Judaism and [primitive Christianity]674-primitive christianity were both made up of a variety of systems , all honestly and boldly thought out , differing widely from each other , and called by the honourable appellation of heresies : and of these , let [me]0-i remind [you]675-you , it is the glory of [the Church of [England]4-england]676-the church of england to be composed likewise . ‘ Nor is this all , ’[0-i] [he]0-i went on in a softer and more appealing tone ; ‘ not only are all these things so confused and doubtful ; but [we]656-we now see that , in the face of recent criticism , [we]656-we can not even be quite sure about any of the details of the divine life of [[our]656-we Lord]2075-our lord . But in all [this’—the Doctor]2076-this’—the doctor ’s voice here became still more aërial , and [he]0-i fixed [his]0-i eyes upon the painted ceiling of [the theatre]2077-the theatre , as though [he]0-i were gazing on some glorious vision—‘in all this there is nothing to discompose [us]677-we . [We]677-we can be quite sure that [He]0-i lived , and that [He]0-i went about doing good , and that in [him]0-i [we]677-we have , in the highest sense , everlasting life . ‘[0-i] Let [us]677-we then no longer fight against the conclusions of science and of criticism , but rather see in [them]678-them the hand of [God]115-god driving [us]677-we , even against [our]677-we will , away from beliefs and teachings that are not really those of [[His]115-god son]679-his son . If [we]677-we do not do this — if [we]677-we persist in identifying the false Christianity with the true — the false , when it is at last plucked widely away from [us]677-we , as it must be , will carry away a part of the true with it . And as long as [we]677-we are in this state of mind , [we]677-we are never for a moment safe . [We]677-we can never open a philological review , or hear of a scientific experiment , without trembling . Witness the discussions now engaging so much public attention on the subject of animal automatism , and the marvellous results which experiments on [living subjects]680-living subjects have of late days revealed to [us]677-we ; a frog with half a brain having destroyed more theology than [all the doctors of [the Church]670-the church]681-all the doctors of the church with [their]681-all the doctors of the church whole brains can ever build up again . Thus does [God]115-god choose the “ weak things of [this world]1737-this world to confound the wise . ” Seeing , then , that this is the state of the case , [we]677-we should surely learn henceforth not to identify Christianity with anything that science can assail , or even question . Let [us]677-we say rather that nothing is or can be essential to the religion of [Christ]134-christ which , when once stated , can be denied without absurdity . If [we]677-we can only attain to this conception , [we]677-we shall see truly that this [our]677-we faith is indeed one “ that [no man]684-no man taketh away from [us]677-we . ” ‘ If [we]677-we be thus once “ stablished in the faith ” all human history , and the history of Christianity especially , will assume for [us]677-we a new sacredness and a new significance . [We]677-we shall recognise gladly its long struggles of growth , and its struggles for existence , and see how in all these were at work the great principles of evolution . [We]677-we shall see how Christian perfection emerged gradually out of imperfection — nay , that it was only through imperfection that this perfection was possible . For although , as [we]677-we now know , all the various theological systems that have sprung up about Christianity , and have been so long current , are not Christianity , are most of them , indeed , not even sense — yet it was through these that true Christianity made its way , and extended itself in a corrupt and ignorant world . For [the world]406-the world has been given from age to age just so much of the truth as it has been able to bear , and it is only , let [us]677-we remember , from receiving it tempered in this wise proportion , that [it]406-the world has been able to receive it at all . But these times of [the world]406-the world ’s probation are now passing away . It is now at length ceasing to be under “ [tutors]2080-tutors and [governors]2081-governors ; ” it is learning to “ put away childish things . ” It is coming to a sense that it is now fitted to receive [Christ]134-christ ’s truth pure , and without any admixture or wrappage of falsehood . And so , as it looks back over all the various opinions once so fiercely agitated about religion , it recognises in all of [them]2082-them a common element of good , and it sees that [all theologians]2083-all theologians and [all sects]2084-all sects have really agreed with [one another]489-one another , and been meaning the same thing , even when [they]2082-them least suspected or wished it . Nor is it , as modern study is showing [us]677-we , varieties of Christianity only that this deeper unity underlies , but all other religions also . It has been well observed by [a great Roman Catholic writer now living]2086-a great roman catholic writer now living , that whenever any great saintliness of life is to be observed amongst [infidels]2087-infidels and [heretics]2088-heretics , it is always found to be due to the presence of certain beliefs and rules which belong to [the Catholics]2089-the catholics . And in like manner , [we]686-we may say too , that whenever any great saintliness of life is to be observed amongst [Catholics]2090-catholics , it is due to the presence of certain beliefs and rules that belong to [the infidels]2091-the infidels and [the heretics]2092-the heretics — and indeed to [all good men]2093-all good men , no matter what [their]2093-all good men religion is . ‘[684-no man] Such are the views that [all the most enlightened men of [our]686-we own day]685-all the most enlightened men of our own day are coming to . But the process is gradual ; and meanwhile let [us]686-we not rebuke [[our]686-we weaker brethren]687-our weaker brethren , if for the present “ [they]687-our weaker brethren follow not after [us]686-we ; ” let [us]686-we rather bear with [them]687-our weaker brethren , and make all allowance for [them]687-our weaker brethren ; for [we]686-we must remember , as [I]0-i have said before , that those evils to which [they]687-our weaker brethren still cling , but from which [we]686-we , under [God]115-god ’s mercy , are trying to free [ourselves]686-we , have done good service in [their]687-our weaker brethren time ; and that even such doctrines as those of eternal punishment , or of sacerdotal absolution , or the subtleties of sacramental systems , or the mystical paradoxes of the Athanasian Creed , have assisted in the evolution of the good — have been , in some sense , “ [schoolmasters]688-schoolmasters to bring [men]1704-men to [God]115-god . ” And even if [we]686-we do occasionally come across some incident in the history of [our]686-we religion — some doctrine or body of doctrines , which seems , humanly speaking , to subserve no good end at all — such as [our]686-we own Thirty - nine Articles — let [us]686-we not suffer such to try [our]686-we faith , but let [us]686-we trust in [God]115-god , believing that in [His]115-god secret councils [He]115-god has found some fitting use even for these ; because [we]686-we know how many things there are , in every branch of inquiry , that [we]686-we can not explain , and yet [we]686-we know that nothing happens but by those immutable and eternal laws which [[our]686-we Heavenly Father]690-our heavenly father has [Himself]690-our heavenly father ordained , and of which [He]690-our heavenly father is [Himself]690-our heavenly father the highest synthesis . ‘ And now , ’[376-the doctor] said [the Doctor]376-the doctor , with a fresh briskness in [his]376-the doctor voice , ‘ [I]376-the doctor shall pass on to that wider point to which [I]376-the doctor have already alluded , which is indeed that which [I]376-the doctor wish chiefly to impress upon [you]2094-you , and to which all that [I]376-the doctor have hitherto said has been preparatory . [We]686-we have come to see how genuine Christianity has been enabled to grow and extend itself only through an admixture of what [we]686-we now recognise as evil . And seeing this , [we]693-we shall be led on to a conclusion that is much wider . It has been said that it is the part of [the devil]2095-the devil to see in good the germs of evil . Is it not also the part of [the devil]2095-the devil not to recognise in evil the germs of good ? May [we]693-we not indeed say with [St. Augustine]158-augustine , that absolute evil is impossible , because , if [we]693-we look at it rightly , it is always rising up into good ? And so , may [we]693-we not recognise in all things the presence and the providence of [God]115-god ? ‘[376-the doctor] Perhaps this view may at first sight seem difficult . [Some of [us]693-we]692-some of us may find that [we]693-we have a certain amount of pride to swallow before [we]693-we can cheerfully acquiesce in it . It is not an uncommon thing to find [persons who secretly flatter [their]694-persons who secretly flatter their vanity by cherishing a gloomy view of the world and of mankind vanity by cherishing a gloomy view of [the world]406-the world and of [mankind]696-mankind]694-persons who secretly flatter their vanity by cherishing a gloomy view of the world and of mankind . But if [we]693-we can only get free from these littlenesses , and attain to that view which [I]0-i have indicated , it will enlarge and ameliorate [our]693-we own philosophy of things , and bring life and trust to [us]693-we , in the place of doubt and despondency . Evil will then appear to [us]693-we simply as undeveloped good — as something which [we]693-we may acquiesce in without complaining — as something that has assisted in the development of whatever is good in the present , and which will itself one day become good in the future . Indeed it is not too much to say that all things , in a certain sense , existed first in the form of evil . It was not till after the Spirit of [God]115-god had worked on the primeval matter that [God]115-god pronounced [the world]406-the world to be “ very good . ” ‘ And so , if [we]693-we consider the subject thus , [we]693-we shall learn to put a stop to all those fretful wailings over the badness of [our]693-we own times of which [we]693-we hear so much — wailings over the unbelief of [[our]693-we neighbours]2097-our neighbours , the corruption of society , the misery of [the poor]2098-the poor , the luxury of [the rich]2099-the rich , or the decline of commercial morality . The present is an age of change , and is therefore at every turn presenting to [us]693-we some new feature . But if these come to [us]693-we in the apparent guise of evils , let [us]693-we not uselessly bemoan them ; but let [us]693-we believe that [they]2100-they are , even if [we]693-we can not see that it is so , but the beginnings , the embryos of new good . Indeed , by the eye of faith , even in the present day , may be discerned the beautiful spectacle of good actually shining through evil . May [we]693-we not , for instance , discern the well - being of [the rich]2099-the rich through the misery of [the poor]2098-the poor ? and again , the honest industry of [the poor]2098-the poor through the idleness of [the rich]2099-the rich ? ‘[115-god] If , then , these things be so , surely [we]698-us may look on unmoved at the great changes and commotions that are going on around its , and the new forms that society , and thought , and politics are assuming , even although for the moment they may appear threatening . And if in this great storm [[our]698-us Master]699-our master have fallen asleep , and no longer speak audibly to [us]698-us , let [us]698-us not be of little faith and fearful , and try to awaken [Him]699-our master with [our]698-us foolish clamours ; but let [us]698-us trust all to [Him]699-our master , and follow [His]699-our master example . For really , if [we]698-us do but trust in [God]115-god , there is no ground for fear , but “ all things work together for good to [him]699-our master that believeth . ” And , however the matter may strike [us]698-us at first sight , the times [we]698-us live in are really the times that are best fitted for [us]698-us ; and [we]698-us shall see , if [we]698-us will but think soberly , that [we]698-us could not , as [a whole]700-a whole , alter anything in them for the better . [I]0-i do not mean that [we]698-us have not each of [us]698-us [his]699-our master own work marked out for [him]699-our master to do ; but all this work is strictly in relation to things as they are . [God]115-god has given to [us]698-us the general conditions under which [we]698-us are to serve [Him]115-god , and these are the best and indeed the only conditions for [us]698-us . Doubtless , if [we]698-us each do the duty that lies before [us]698-us , these conditions will be slowly and insensibly changed by [us]698-us ; but [we]698-us shall [ourselves]698-us change also , as well as the conditions ; what [I]0-i mean is , that supposing by a sudden act of will [we]698-us could do what [we]698-us pleased with the conditions of the age , [we]698-us , being as [we]698-us are , should not be really able to make the age better . [We]698-us should not be really able to make it different . Any Utopia [we]698-us might imagine would , if it were [a thinkable one]701-a thinkable one , be only [our]698-us own age in a masquerading dress . For [we]698-us can not escape from [our]698-us age , or add , except in a very small degree , anything that is really new to it . Nor need [we]698-us wish to do so . [Our]698-us age is for [us]698-us the best age possible . [We]698-us are [its children]702-its children , and it is [[our]698-us only true parent]703-our only true parent . But though [we]698-us can not alter [our]698-us time at a stroke , so to speak , no , not even in imagination , [we]698-us can all of [us]698-us help to do so little by little , if [we]698-us do cheerfully the duties that are set before [us]698-us . And if [we]698-us do this , which is what [Christ]134-christ bids [us]698-us to do , then is [Christ]134-christ made manifest in [us]698-us , and lives in the hearts of [every one of [us]698-us]704-every one of us ; and in a far higher sense than [any mere physical one]705-any mere physical one , [He]134-christ is risen from the dead . And if [He]134-christ be not so risen in and for [us]698-us , then are [we]698-us indeed , as [the Apostle]706-the apostle says , “ of [all men]1793-all men most miserable ! ” ‘ Let [us]698-us therefore , with a large hope for the future , and a cheerful contentment with the present , be willing to leave [the world]406-the world in the hands of [God]115-god , knowing that [He]115-god has given [us]698-us what conditions and what circumstances are best for [us]698-us . Let [us]698-us see all things in [God]115-god , and let [us]698-us become in [Him]115-god , as [Plato]153-plato says , “ [spectators of all time , and of all existence]2106-spectators of all time , and of all existence . ” And thus , in spite of the difficulties presented to [us]698-us by “ all the evil that is done under the sun ” [we]698-us shall perceive that all things will , nay must , come right in [God]115-god ’s own time ; and the apparent dualism of good and evil at last become a glorious unity of good . But let [us]698-us remember also that “ [the Kingdom of [God]115-god]2107-the kingdom of god cometh not with observation ; ” and [I]706-the apostle would conclude [my]706-the apostle sermon with certain memorable words spoken by [Christ]134-christ [Himself]134-christ , though unfortunately not to be found in the Gospels , but preserved to [us]698-us by [[Clement]164-clement of [Alexandria]27-alexandria]2108-clement of alexandria . “ [The Lord]2109-the lord , ” [Clement]164-clement tells [us]698-us , “ being asked when [His]2109-the lord kingdom should come , said , When two shall be one , and that which is without as that which is within , and the male with the female — neither male nor female . ” ‘[706-the apostle] — And now — ’ ( at the sound of this word [the whole congregation]2110-the whole congregation rose automatically to [their]2110-the whole congregation feet),‘I will ask [you]2111-you , ’[376-the doctor] [the Doctor]376-the doctor went on after a pause , ‘ to conclude this morning ’s service by doing what [I]376-the doctor trust [I]376-the doctor have shown that [all here]2112-all here may sincerely and honestly do . [I]376-the doctor mean , [I]376-the doctor will ask [you]2111-you to recite after [me]376-the doctor the Apostles ’[376-the doctor] Creed . ’ This appeal took [the whole congregation]2110-the whole congregation quite aback . But there was no time for wonder . [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson at once began ; nor was [his]95-dr. jenkinson voice the only sound in [the theatre]2077-the theatre . [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , pleased , after all that [she]92-lady ambrose had heard the night previous , to make public profession of [her]92-lady ambrose faith , especially in a place where it could not be called in question , followed [the Doctor]376-the doctor audibly and promptly ; [Miss Prattle]107-miss prattle followed [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose ; [Lady Violet Gresham]98-lady violet gresham , who was busy with one of [her]98-lady violet gresham sleeve - links , followed [Miss Prattle]107-miss prattle ; [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , from quite another part of [the house]1761-the house , followed [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson on [her]89-lady grace own account ; [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton repeated the first clause in a loud voice , and then relapsed into marked silence ; [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke only opened [his]99-mr. luke lips to sigh out audibly in the middle a disconsolate ‘[376-the doctor] Heigh ho ! ’ [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks blew [his]113-mr. storks nose with singular vigour through the whole proceeding ; [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , just towards the end , tapped [Leslie]114-leslie ’s arm gently with [her]106-mrs. sinclair fan , and said to [him]709-him in a whisper , ‘[376-the doctor] Do [you]709-him really believe all this ? ’ When all was over , when [the Doctor]376-the doctor had solemnly pronounced the last ‘[709-him] Amen , ’ [he]376-the doctor looked about [him]376-the doctor nervously for a moment , as if the question of how to retire becomingly suddenly dawned upon [him]376-the doctor . Luckily [he]376-the doctor perceived almost directly [a servant standing in readiness by the curtain]2118-a servant standing in readiness by the curtain . [The Doctor]376-the doctor frowned slightly at [the man]1772-the man ; made a slightly impatient gesture at [him]1772-the man ; and [Faust]151-faust and [the young witch]618-the young witch again covered [the preacher]2122-the preacher from the eyes of [[his]376-the doctor congregation]612-his congregation . The blinds were half - down at luncheon in [the dining - room]2124-the dining - room , to keep out the brilliant summer sun . [The guests]1694-the guests dropped in by [ones and twos]2126-ones and twos , somewhat tired and exhausted by the divine service of the morning ; and the sight of the table was not a little refreshing to [them]1694-the guests , as it shone whitely in the soft gloom , with its flowers and ferns , and [its]2127-its day - lit glimmer of glass and silver . Soon , however , a piece of news was circulated that was even more refreshing than the luncheon . [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , owing to [his]95-dr. jenkinson late exertions , and the gas - light , and the draughts upon the stage , was suffering from a headache , which inclined [him]95-dr. jenkinson to keep [[his]95-dr. jenkinson room]2128-his room ; and accordingly an unhopedfor prospect of freely discussing the sermon dawned brightly upon [the whole party]591-the whole party . [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , who had been much struck with the strictly prosaic style of [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson ’s discourse , and who had been secretly contrasting this with the more impassioned character of [his]110-mr. stockton own mind , was the first to begin . ‘[709-him] The sermon was perhaps ingenious , ’ [he]110-mr. stockton said , turning to [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[0-i] but [I]0-i ’m afraid [[our]2130-us friend]2131-our friend ’s forte is certainly not poetry . ’[103-donald gordon] ‘ Surely , ’[103-donald gordon] said [Donald Gordon]103-donald gordon with extreme solemnity of manner and only a slight twinkle in [his]103-donald gordon eye , ‘ [his]95-dr. jenkinson forte is something far better . Poetry can only make [us]2130-us happy for a little while . Such doctrines as [we]2130-us have heard this morning ought to make [us]2130-us happy always . ’[103-donald gordon] As for [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , to whom both these remarks were addressed , [she]92-lady ambrose was in doubt what altogether to think of the matter . More than half [her]92-lady ambrose heart inclined [her]92-lady ambrose to look upon [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson as [a valuable ally]710-a valuable ally ; but there was yet , all the while , a fatal something that whispered to [her]92-lady ambrose a vague distrust of [him]95-dr. jenkinson . [She]92-lady ambrose was therefore waiting anxiously to hear what would be said by [others]341-others , before taking any side [herself]92-lady ambrose ; [her]92-lady ambrose mind all the while being busy with the profoundest questions . This suspense of judgment produced a certain gravity and depression in [her]92-lady ambrose , which was visible on [her]92-lady ambrose face , and which seemed to communicate itself to [nearly everyone at [her]92-lady ambrose end of the table]712-nearly everyone at her end of the table . For [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose was [a communicative woman]713-a communicative woman . [Her]92-lady ambrose spirits , good or bad , were generally caught by those near [her]92-lady ambrose . As for [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , however , [no one else]714-no one else seemed needed to depress [him]112-mr. herbert . Low , slow , and melancholy , [his]112-mr. herbert accents at once caught the ear of [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘ [I]112-mr. herbert have heard to - day , ’[112-mr. herbert] [he]112-mr. herbert said to [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , who was sitting next [him]112-mr. herbert , ‘ an entirely new and in every way memorable doctrine , which [I]112-mr. herbert never heard before from the mouth of [man]1888-man , [woman]496-woman , or [child]1723-child ; nor can [I]112-mr. herbert tell by what steps [any human being]2135-any human being could have arrived at it . [I]112-mr. herbert have heard that [the world]406-the world — [the world]406-the world as it is — could not be better than it is ; that there is no real sorrow in it — no real evil — no real sin . ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ [Poor Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson ! ’[106-mrs. sinclair] said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , also in a melancholy voice ; ‘ [I]106-mrs. sinclair suppose [he]95-dr. jenkinson has never loved . ’[106-mrs. sinclair] ‘ Ah , ’[715-mr. stockton,—his] exclaimed [Mr. Stockton,—his]715-mr. stockton,—his voice was melancholy as well—‘the whole teachings of [that school]716-that school have always seemed to [me]0-i nothing more than a few fragments of science imperfectly understood , obscured by a few fragments of Christianity imperfectly remembered . ’ ‘[112-mr. herbert] [You]717-you forget , ’ said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘[112-mr. herbert] that [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson ’s Christianity is really [a new firm trading under an old name , and trying to purchase the goodwill of [the former establishment]719-the former establishment]718-a new firm trading under an old name , and trying to purchase the goodwill of the former establishment . ’ [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , who had not liked [Leslie]114-leslie so much on further acquaintance as [she]92-lady ambrose had at first expected [she]92-lady ambrose should , was very indignant at [him]112-mr. herbert for so flippant a speech as this — [she]92-lady ambrose felt sure it was flippant , though [she]92-lady ambrose did not quite understand its meaning — but once again [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert ’s grave accents arrested [her]92-lady ambrose . ‘[113-mr. storks] It is simply , ’ [he]112-mr. herbert was saying to [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , evidently alluding to the same subject—‘it is simply [our]2138-our modern atheism trying to hide its own nakedness , for the benefit of the more prudish part of [the public]2139-the public , in the cast grave - clothes of [a Christ who , whether [he]2140-a christ who , whether he be risen or no , is very certainly , as the angel said , not here be risen or no , is very certainly , as [the angel]2141-the angel said , not here]2140-a christ who , whether he be risen or no , is very certainly , as the angel said , not here . ’[113-mr. storks] ‘ All discussion of such matters seems to [me]100-mr. rose but a diseased activity , ’[100-mr. rose] said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , raising languidly a white deprecating hand . [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks too , though for different reasons , was apparently of the same opinion . ‘ In [his]112-mr. herbert main points , ’[113-mr. storks] [he]113-mr. storks said with a severe dogmatism that seemed designed to end all further controversy , ‘ and putting aside [his]112-mr. herbert quasi - religious manner of expressing it — which considering [his]112-mr. herbert position may be pardoned — [I]113-mr. storks conceive [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson to have been entirely right . ’[113-mr. storks] Hitherto [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose ’s views had been wavering to and fro , in a sad uncertainty . But now [her]92-lady ambrose mind at once cleared . [Her]92-lady ambrose worst suspicions of [the Doctor]376-the doctor were confirmed by this fatal commendation . The gloom on [her]92-lady ambrose face deepened , and [she]92-lady ambrose had a look almost of distress about [her]92-lady ambrose as [she]92-lady ambrose turned to [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘ [You]92-lady ambrose look tired , ’[113-mr. storks] [he]113-mr. storks said to [her]92-lady ambrose . ‘ No , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose wearily : ‘ at least , perhaps [I]92-lady ambrose am a little . Do [you]83-laurence know , [I]92-lady ambrose always think [one]1681-one feels rather dull if [one]1681-one does n’t get the letters [one]1681-one expects . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Perhaps [you]92-lady ambrose do n’t know , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ that the letters [you]92-lady ambrose got this morning were only those of last night ’s post . [Our]2144-we Sunday letters [we]2144-we are obliged to send for , and they do n’t generally come till later on in the day . ’[83-laurence] ‘ Really ! ’[92-lady ambrose] exclaimed [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , with surprise , as a smile slowly spread over [her]92-lady ambrose face , and [her]92-lady ambrose frank eyes lit up again . ‘ [The Duchess]2145-the duchess could n’t have forgotten it , ’[92-lady ambrose] [she]92-lady ambrose said to [herself]92-lady ambrose half - consciously . Strangely enough , a new warmth , it seemed , had dawned upon [her]92-lady ambrose , and [her]92-lady ambrose ice - bound gloom began to thaw — to thaw only , however , not to evaporate . It did not go ; it only became voluble . ‘ Do [you]721-you know , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , ’[92-lady ambrose] [she]92-lady ambrose began , ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose have been thinking over and over again about many of the things that were said last night ; and [I]92-lady ambrose really am afraid that [the world]406-the world is getting very bad . It is very sad to think so ; but , with all this infidelity and wickedness of which [we]2144-we hear so much , [I]92-lady ambrose ’m[92-lady ambrose] afraid it is true . For [my]0-i own part , [you]721-you know , there is nothing [I]0-i dislike so much as to hear the Bible profanely spoken about ; though , of course , [I]0-i know one is tempted sometimes to make jokes out of it [oneself]722-oneself . And then , ’ [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose added — [her]92-lady ambrose ideas did not always follow [one another]489-one another in the strictest order—‘hardly a week passes without some new scandal . [I]92-lady ambrose had a letter only this morning , telling [me]92-lady ambrose all the particulars about [Colonel Eardly]165-colonel eardly and [poor Lady Arthur]166-poor lady arthur . And [that man]1716-that man , [you]721-you know — just fancy it!—it will not be very long before [we]2149-we shall be obliged to receive [him]1716-that man again . However , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , with a slightly more cheerful accent , ‘ that sort of thing , [I]92-lady ambrose believe , is confined to [us]2149-we . [The middle classes]2150-the middle classes are all right — at least , [one]1681-one always hears so . ’[92-lady ambrose] At this moment [Lord Allen]101-allen ’s voice was heard . ‘ But now , ’[92-lady ambrose] [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose went on to [Laurence]83-laurence , very slightly moving [her]92-lady ambrose head in the direction of [Lord Allen]101-allen , and speaking in a low tone , ‘ how different [he]101-allen is ! ’[92-lady ambrose] [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose had the greatest admiration for [Lord Allen]101-allen , though [her]92-lady ambrose acquaintance with [him]101-allen had hitherto been of the slightest ; and [Laurence]83-laurence , not knowing how to respond to all [her]92-lady ambrose late remarks , was glad that [her]92-lady ambrose attention was thus called elsewhere . ‘ Do n’t [you]83-laurence think , ’[101-allen] [Allen]101-allen was saying , half addressing [himself]101-allen to [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , half to [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘ that though at the present moment things as they are may be worse than they have ever been before , there are yet ideas amongst [us]2152-us of things as they might be , that are in advance of what has ever been before ? [I]101-allen know quite well how society is falling to pieces , and how all [our]2152-us notions of duty are becoming confused or lost . [I]101-allen know too how utterly without any religion [we]2152-us are’—(Lady [Ambrose]92-lady ambrose started ) — ‘[101-allen] at least , any religion that [one man]723-one man can express to another , and that can enable [men]1704-men to act in concert . But still , [I]0-i ca n’t help feeling that , in spite of all this , a higher class of conceptions both of religion and morality , and social relations also , is forming itself in the minds of [thinking men]725-thinking men . ’ ‘[727-you] Perfectly true , [Lord Allen]101-allen , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘[727-you] perfectly true ! It is indeed the very essence of [the cultured classes]726-the cultured classes to be beyond [their]726-the cultured classes time — to have , indeed , every requisite for making everything better , except the practical power . As [you]727-you say , what [man]1888-man ’s life ought to be — what true morality is — what is true sense , and what is true nonsense — these are matters never at any time distinguished so truly as by some of [us]729-we in the latter half of the nineteenth century . Only , unfortunately , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , sighing slowly , and looking round the table , ‘[731-such men as these] the dense ignorance of [the world]406-the world at large hampers and hinders [such men as these]731-such men as these , so that all that [their]731-such men as these teaching and [their]731-such men as these insight can do , is only to suggest a Utopia in the future , instead of leading to any reality in the present . ’ ‘[727-you] All [my]0-i happiness is in a kind of Utopia , ’ sighed [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair . ‘[727-you] Yes — yes , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke wearily ; ‘[727-you] so in these days must be the happiness of all of [us]729-we — except that of [the world]406-the world at large . ’ [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks was here heard clearing [his]113-mr. storks throat . With an ominous pugilistic smile [he]113-mr. storks turned towards [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke . ‘[727-you] Are [you]727-you quite sure , ’ [he]113-mr. storks said , ‘[727-you] that the reason why [[your]727-you friends]546-your friends do nothing practical is not because [they]546-your friends will build [Utopias]28-utopias ? [I]0-i , as [I]0-i have already said , entirely hold with [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson that [the world]406-the world is as good as it can be — has , indeed , been always as good as it could have been — has , that is , been always persistently progressing by one constant course of evolution . [I]0-i do n’t [myself]0-i profess to be [a student of history]735-a student of history ; but , as far as [I]0-i at all understand its teachings , the one thing it most clearly shows to [us]729-we is , that what strikes [a superficial observer]736-a superficial observer as simply the decadence of old orders of things , is really , under the surface , the birth of the new . Indeed , ’ said [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks , shrugging [his]113-mr. storks shoulders , ‘[121-nature] of course it must be so . [We]729-we are all part of [Nature]121-nature ; and , little as [we]729-we think it , [we]729-we are all working together by invincible and inviolable laws . [Nature]121-nature will have [her]121-nature own way ; and those who have studied [her]121-nature carefully know that [her]121-nature way is always the best . Even supposing [we]729-we could transplant [ourselves]729-we into some different , some more advanced state of society , [[my]0-i dear sir]461-my dear sir , do [you]461-my dear sir think [we]729-we should be any happier [there]1691-there ? As much happier , [I]0-i suppose , as [you]461-my dear sir or [I]0-i should be if [we]729-we were translated into the heaven [[our]729-we nurses]739-our nurses used to tell [us]729-we of , where nothing was done but to sing Tate and [Brady]167-brady ’s psalms with the angels to all eternity . The air of [our]729-we own age is the only air fit for [us]729-we . In any other [we]729-we should languish . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i languish in this , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , looking up to the ceiling . Scarcely were the words out of [his]99-mr. luke mouth than [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders exclaimed , in [his]102-mr. saunders most excited and shrillest voice , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i deny it — [I]0-i entirely deny it ! ’ [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke was thunderstruck . Even [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks was taken aback by the audacity of the contradiction ; and as for [the rest of [the company]384-the company]2153-the rest of the company , [they]2153-the rest of the company could not conceive where on [earth]2155-earth [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders had left [his]102-mr. saunders manners . [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks , however , was still more astonished , and still less pleased , when [he]113-mr. storks discovered , as [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders proceeded , what was the real meaning of [his]102-mr. saunders speech . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i entirely deny , ’ [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders went on , ‘[0-i] that the ways of Nature are the best ways . The belief that [they]740-they are so is of all faiths the one that most obviously contradicts experience . Did [I]0-i accept this , [I]0-i could accept anything — Transubstantiation even . [I]0-i should literally feel that [I]0-i had no right to condemn any doctrine because it was groundless , gratuitous , and absurd . This faith in the goodness of Nature — why , that it is a faith , is not that enough to condemn it ? What but faith , let [me]0-i ask , has enslaved and stunted [the world]406-the world hitherto ? And this particular faith , [I]0-i would remind [you]742-you , which [you]742-you flatter [yourself]742-you will oppose religion , has been in most cases [its]743-its child , and is always ready to be its parent . [I]0-i on the contrary maintain that , far from being the best , Nature is the most odious of things — that the whole universe is constructed on the most hateful principles ; in fact , that out of the primordial atoms only one thing has developed itself in which the good outweighs the evil ; and that is the one thing that is usually opposed to Nature — [man]1888-man , and the reason of [man]1888-man . ’ [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks turned sharply round , and , with an awful look in [his]113-mr. storks eyes of contemptuous indignation , stared [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders into silence . [He]0-i held [him]742-you fixed in this way for a few moments , and then said to [him]742-you in a voice of grim unconcern , ‘[0-i] May [I]0-i trouble [you]742-you for the mustard . ’ Then again turning to [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘[0-i] [You]742-you see , ’ [he]0-i proceeded , ‘[0-i] what [I]0-i take to be civilisation — indeed , the whole duty of [man]1888-man — is the gradual self - adaptation of [the human organism]747-the human organism to [its]747-the human organism environment — an adaptation which must take place , and any attempts to hinder which are simply neither more nor less than disease . Progress , which it is [our]748-our highest life to further , is a thing that will continue despite the opposition of [individuals]749-individuals . Its tendencies are beyond the control of [individuals]749-individuals , and are to be sought in the spirit of the age at large,—not — if [you]751-you will forgive [me]0-i the word — in the crotchets of this or [that thinker]752-that thinker . And it seems to [me]0-i to be the hopeful and distinguishing feature of the present day , that [men]1704-men are learning generally to recognise this truth — that [they]1704-men are learning not to cry out against progress , but to investigate its grand and inevitable laws , and submit [themselves]1704-men willingly to [them]1704-men . And the tendency of [our]748-our own day is , [I]0-i am proud to say , a tendency towards firm , solid , verifiable knowledge , and as a result of this , towards the acquisition of a firm and solid happiness also . ’ ‘[0-i] To [me]0-i , ’ said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘[0-i] it seems rather that the only hope for the present age lies in the possibility of [some individual]754-some individual wiser than the rest getting the necessary power , and in the most arbitrary way possible putting a stop to this progress — utterly stamping out and obliterating every general tendency peculiar to [our]748-our own time . [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks will perhaps think [me]0-i very foolish . Perhaps [I]0-i am . [I]0-i freely own that [I]0-i could more easily tell a good action , if [I]0-i saw it , than a good piece of protoplasm , and that [I]0-i think the understanding of a holy moral law , by which [an individual]755-an individual may live , of infinitely more importance than the discovery of all the laws of progress in [the world]406-the world . But let [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks despise [me]0-i , and not be angry with [me]0-i — ’ ‘[113-mr. storks] [[My]0-i dear sir]461-my dear sir , ’ interposed [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks , with a gruff courtesy , ‘[113-mr. storks] why should [I]0-i do either the one or the other ? ’ ‘[0-i] Because , ’ said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , slightly waving [his]112-mr. herbert hand , and speaking with great emphasis , ‘[0-i] had [I]0-i only the power , [I]0-i would [myself]0-i put a forcible stop to all this evolution . [I]0-i would make a clean sweep of all the improvements that the present day so much vaunts . [I]0-i would collect [an army of [strong , serviceable , honest workmen]759-strong , serviceable , honest workmen]758-an army of strong , serviceable , honest workmen , and send [them]758-an army of strong , serviceable , honest workmen to blow up [Manchester]29-manchester , and [Birmingham]30-birmingham , and [Liverpool]31-liverpool , and [Leeds]32-leeds , and [Wolverhampton]33-wolverhampton — ’ ‘[0-i] And [all the artisans in [them]758-an army of strong , serviceable , honest workmen]760-all the artisans in them ? ’ asked [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks . ‘[760-all the artisans in them] Well , ’ said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , smiling , ‘[760-all the artisans in them] [I]0-i would , perhaps , give [the artisans]761-the artisans notice of this gunpowder plot of [mine]0-i . And yet [their]761-the artisans existence has always presented a painful difficulty to [me]0-i . For if there is no other life , [I]0-i think [they]761-the artisans have a very bad time of it here ; and if there is another life , [I]0-i think that [they]761-the artisans will all certainly be damned . But it is not only [Manchester]29-manchester and [Birmingham]30-birmingham that [I]0-i would blow up . [I]0-i would blow up also [every anatomical museum in [the land]763-the land]762-every anatomical museum in the land , save such as were absolutely necessary for the use of [professional doctors]764-professional doctors , that the foul sights in [them]762-every anatomical museum in the land should not taint [men]1704-men ’s imaginations , and give [them]1704-men an appetite for beastly knowledge . [I]0-i would destroy [every railway]766-every railway , and nearly every steam - engine ; and [I]0-i would do a number of other things of a like sort , by way of preparing the ground for a better state of society . Indeed , so far am [I]0-i from believing that an entirely different and better state of society is unthinkable , that [I]0-i believe it to be not impracticable ; and [I]0-i am at the present moment collecting money , from such as will here and there confide in [me]0-i , for the purpose of purchasing land , and of founding [a community]767-a community upon what seem to [me]0-i to be true and healthful principles — a Utopia , in fact — in which [I]0-i trust may be once again realised upon earth those two things to which [we]768-we are now such strangers — order and justice . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i once began a book about justice , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[153-plato] on the model of [Plato]153-plato ’s Republic . ’ ‘[153-plato] What is [Plato]153-plato ’s Republic ? ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘[0-i] Tell [me]0-i . ’ ‘[0-i] It is a book , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[0-i] which describes the meeting of a party of [friends]1669-friends , who fell discussing high topics just as [we]768-we are doing , and , amongst others , What is justice ? ’ ‘[0-i] What ! ’ exclaimed [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘[0-i] Did not [they]770-they know that ? ’ ‘[770-they] [You]771-you forget , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ’[770-they] that this was very long ago . ’ ‘[770-they] To be sure , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose ; ‘[770-they] and [they]770-they were of course [all heathens]772-all heathens . Well — and what conclusions did [they]770-they come to as to the nature of justice ? ’ ‘[770-they] At first , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ’[770-they] though [Socrates]168-socrates [himself]168-socrates was amongst [them]770-they , [they]770-they were all completely at a loss how to define it . But at last [they]770-they hit upon the notion of constructing an ideal perfect state , in which of course justice would be lurking somewhere . Now there are in life , [Plato]153-plato says , four great virtues — wisdom , courage , temperance , and justice ; and no sooner has the ideal state been constructed , than it appears that three of these virtues are specially illustrated and embodied , each in a particular class of [citizens]773-citizens . Thus , wisdom is specially embodied in [the theoretical politicians]774-the theoretical politicians and [religious speculators of the day]775-religious speculators of the day ; courage is embodied in [the practical men who maintain and execute the regulations and orders of the philosophers]776-the practical men who maintain and execute the regulations and orders of the philosophers ; and temperance is embodied in the commercial and industrial classes , who loyally submit [themselves]777-them to [their]777-them betters , and refrain from meddling in matters that are too high for [them]777-them . And now , where is justice ? In what class is that embodied specially ? ’ ‘[778-the judges] In [the judges]778-the judges and [the magistrates]779-the magistrates and [the policemen]780-the policemen , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘[778-the judges] No , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence ; ‘[778-the judges] it is peculiar to [no class]781-no class . It resides in all . It is that virtue which enables [the others]1695-the others to exist and to continue . ’ ‘[778-the judges] But surely , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[778-the judges] all that is not what [we]783-we mean by justice now ? ’ ‘[778-the judges] Certainly not , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence ; ‘[778-the judges] and [my]0-i book was designed to investigate what justice is , as it exists now . [I]0-i , like [Plato]153-plato , constructed a state , making it , however , a real rather than an ideal picture . But when [I]0-i had done this , [I]0-i could find [no earnest thinking class]784-no earnest thinking class to represent wisdom ; [no class of practical politicians that would carry out even the little wisdom]785-no class of practical politicians that would carry out even the little wisdom [they]777-them knew , and so represent courage ; and certainly no commercial or industrial class that would refrain for a single day from meddling in matters that were too high for [them]777-them , and so represent temperance . So [I]0-i analysed life in a somewhat different way . [I]0-i divided it into happiness , misery , and justice . [I]0-i then at once discovered that [the rich]2099-the rich represented all the happiness of which [we]783-we are now capable , and [the poor]2098-the poor all the misery ; and that justice was that which set this state of things going and enabled it to continue . ’ ‘[83-laurence] Ah , [Laurence]83-laurence , ’ exclaimed [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , clapping [his]0-i hands gently in sad applause , ‘[83-laurence] [I]0-i like that . [I]0-i wish [you]83-laurence had worked out this idea more fully . ’ ‘[83-laurence] Suppose , ’ exclaimed [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘[83-laurence] that [we]783-we try this afternoon to construct a Utopia [ourselves]783-we . Let [us]783-we embody [our]783-we notions of life as it ought to be in [a new Republic]788-a new republic . ’ ‘[1790-a conservative] Well , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[1790-a conservative] [I]0-i am not [a Conservative]1790-a conservative ; [I]0-i do n’t object . [I]0-i ’m sure at any rate that there is much [we]783-we could all of [us]783-we alter , if [we]783-we only had [our]783-we own way . ’[0-i] ‘ Much , ’[89-lady grace] said [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , with severe briskness . ‘ Much , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , with a soft , half - serious smile . ‘ Much , ’[101-allen] said [Lord Allen]101-allen , catching eagerly at the idea . ‘ Well , then , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ let [us]783-we all do [our]783-we best to give those airy somethings , [our]783-we aspirations , a local habitation and a name . ’[83-laurence] [The majority of [the company]384-the company]790-the majority of the company took very kindly to the proposal . [Lady Grace]89-lady grace was especially pleased , as it seemed to provide at once a whole afternoon ’s occupation for the party ; and it was arranged accordingly that as soon as luncheon was over [they]792-we should adjourn for [castle - building]793-castle - building to a shady spot in [the garden]794-the garden . GUIDED by [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , [the guests]1694-the guests gradually converged after luncheon towards [the appointed spot]796-the appointed spot , straggling thither by various ways , and in desultory groups ; passing down broad flights of steps flanked by gods and goddesses , and along [straight terraces set with vases and Irish yews]797-straight terraces set with vases and irish yews ; while busts of [orators]798-orators , [poets]799-poets , and [philosophers , with Latin inscriptions]800-philosophers , with latin inscriptions , glimmered to right and left of them in groves of laurels ; and scaly Tritons , dappled with green lichens , spouted up water in the middle of gleaming basins . Everything was today looking at its loveliest . There was an unusual freshness in the warm summer air . Beyond the green shrubs [the sea]300-the sea shone bright and blue ; and through the shrubs the sea - breeze moved and whispered . [Laurence]83-laurence strolled slowly on behind with [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , choosing a path which [none of the others]802-none of the others had taken . ‘ How delicious this is ! ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , lifting [her]93-miss merton hat to enjoy the breeze upon [her]93-miss merton forehead . ‘ [Nobody]1902-nobody could be in bad spirits in a place like this . There is something so fresh and living everywhere , and even when [we]792-we lose sight of [the sea]300-the sea [we]792-we still hear it . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ Yes , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘ [I]93-miss merton believe [these gardens]2158-these gardens are like [Keats ’s island]34-keats ’s island . There is no recess in [them]2158-these gardens Not haunted by the murmurous sound of waves . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ And how perfectly everything is kept ! What [gardeners]2159-gardeners [you]83-laurence must have ! ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , as [they]803-they turned up a narrow winding - walk , thickly set on either side with carefully - trimmed laurels . [The whole place]804-the whole place was , indeed , as [Miss Merton]93-miss merton said , kept perfectly . Not a weed was on the grey gravel ; not a single twig called for pruning . Every vase [they]803-they passed was full of the most delicious flowers . Overhead the branches of limes and of acacia - trees murmured gaily . Everything seemed to be free from care , and to be laughing , light of heart , in the bright weather . ‘ [I]83-laurence am taking [you]93-miss merton this way , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ because [I]83-laurence want to show [you]93-miss merton what [I]83-laurence think may perhaps interest [you]93-miss merton . ’[83-laurence] As [he]83-laurence spoke these words , a sudden bend in the walk brought [them]803-they face to face with something that gave [Miss Merton]93-miss merton a sudden sensation of surprise . It was [a small classical portico]805-a small classical portico built in a style of the most severe simplicity , through which by an iron gate one passed into [an open space beyond]806-an open space beyond . What surprised [Miss Merton]93-miss merton on seeing this was the singular sense of desolation and dreariness that seemed all at once to come over [her]93-miss merton . The iron gates before [her]93-miss merton were a mass of rust ; [the portico]807-the portico , which had once been white , was weather - stained into a dismal grey ; the stone , too , [it]808-it was built of was scaling off in almost every place , and the fragments lay unheeded as they had fallen upon the ground . Here , amongst everything that spoke of the utmost care , was one object that spoke of entire forgetfulness and neglect . [They]803-they approached in silence , and [Miss Merton]93-miss merton looked in through the bars of the rusty gate . The scene that met [her]93-miss merton eyes was one of greater desolation still . [It]809-it was a circular plot of ground , fenced round by a low stone wall that was surmounted by spiked railings . [It]809-it looked as though [it]809-it might have been once [a flower garden]810-a flower garden , but [it]809-it was now [a wilderness]811-a wilderness . Outside [its]809-it boundary rose the rare and beautiful trees of [the happy tended shrubberies]812-the happy tended shrubberies . Inside were nettles , brambles , and long weedy grass . Nothing else was visible in [this melancholy enclosure]813-this melancholy enclosure but three cypresses , apparently of various ages , the two smaller planted near together , [the third]814-the third , and by far the largest , standing apart by [itself]809-it . [Miss Merton]93-miss merton was quite at a loss what to make of [the strange spot]815-the strange spot ; and , as [Laurence]83-laurence was feeling in [his]83-laurence pocket for the key , [she]93-miss merton asked [him]83-laurence if it had anything to do with breeding pheasants . ‘ Do [you]93-miss merton see what is written above the gate ? ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , as [he]83-laurence pointed to a dim inscription whose letters still retained a glimmer of fading gold ; ‘ can [you]93-miss merton read it ? Neque harum , quas colis , arborum Te , præter invisam cupressum , “ Of all these trees which [you]93-miss merton love so , the hated cypress only shall follow [its master]2160-its master , and be faithful to [him]2160-its master in [[his]2160-its master narrow house]2161-his narrow house . ” But come — let [us]816-us go inside , if [you]93-miss merton are not afraid of the long grass . ’[83-laurence] [They]816-us passed through the gate , which gave a low wail upon [its]817-its hinges , and [Miss Merton]93-miss merton followed [Laurence]83-laurence , knee - deep in grass and nettles , to the smallest of the three cypress - trees . There [Laurence]83-laurence paused . At the foot of the tree [Miss Merton]93-miss merton saw a flat slab of marble , with something written upon it ; and for the first time [she]93-miss merton felt certain that [she]93-miss merton must be in [a place of graves]818-a place of graves . ‘ This , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , pointing to the little cypress , ‘ was planted only five years ago , ten clays before [the poor old man]2162-the poor old man died who now sleeps under it . This is [[[my]83-laurence uncle]2163-my uncle ’s grave]2164-my uncle ’s grave . Do [you]93-miss merton see the inscription ? Omnis moriar , nullaque pars mei “ [I]83-laurence shall wholly die , and there is no part of [me]83-laurence that will escape the Venus of death . ” That , and that alone , [he]2162-the poor old man chose to have written over [him]2162-the poor old man . ’[83-laurence] [Laurence]83-laurence spoke with some feeling , but [Miss Merton]93-miss merton was so much surprised that [she]93-miss merton hardly knew what response to make . ‘ And does [nobody]1902-nobody take any care of [this place]2166-this place ? ’[93-miss merton] at last [she]93-miss merton said . ‘ No , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘ By [his]2162-the poor old man own last orders , [nobody]1902-nobody . But come — [you]93-miss merton must look at this too . ’[83-laurence] And [he]83-laurence motioned [her]93-miss merton towards the neighbouring cypress . At the foot of this , almost hidden by the long grass , [Miss Merton]93-miss merton saw something that surprised [her]93-miss merton still more strangely . It was the statue of [a woman half reclining in a languid attitude on a block of hewn marble]819-a woman half reclining in a languid attitude on a block of hewn marble . [The figure]820-the figure was full and beautiful , and the features of the face were singularly fine ; but there was something in the general effect that struck [one]1681-one at the first moment as not pleasing . What slight drapery there was , was disposed meretriciously over the rounded limbs ; on the arms were heavy bracelets ; one of the hands held a half - inverted wine - cup , and the other was laid negligently on a heap of coins . But what jarred most upon the feelings was the face , with its perfect features . For a cold sneer was fixed upon the full mouth and the fine nostrils ; and the eyes , with a leer of petulant sensuality , seemed to be fixed for ever upon the flat neighbouring gravestone . ‘ This cypress , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ is much older than the other . It was planted twenty years ago ; and twenty years ago the original of that statue was laid beneath it . [She]93-miss merton was one of those many nameless ladies — for , as [you]2168-you know , [he]83-laurence completely exiled [himself]83-laurence from society all the latter part of [his]83-laurence life — who from time to time shared [his]83-laurence fortunes at [the house here]2169-the house here . [She]93-miss merton was , too , by far the loveliest . [She]93-miss merton was at the same time the hardest , the most selfish , the most mercenary as well . And [he]83-laurence knew it too . In spite of the distraction [he]83-laurence found in [her]93-miss merton companionship , [he]83-laurence was never for a moment deceived about [her]93-miss merton . At last , having made a fortune out of [him]83-laurence , [she]93-miss merton was thinking of leaving [him]83-laurence . But one day , suddenly , [she]93-miss merton caught a chill and died . [She]93-miss merton died [here]360-here , and here [she]93-miss merton was buried . That statue , as [you]2168-you may imagine , is [his]83-laurence design not [hers]93-miss merton . The attitude , the drapery , the wine - cup held in one hand , and the money in the other , are according to [his]83-laurence express direction ; and by [his]83-laurence direction , too , that face , with its lovely features , leers and sneers at [him]83-laurence for ever , as [he]83-laurence rests in [[his]83-laurence neglected grave]2171-his neglected grave . See , too , there is the epitaph which [he]83-laurence chose for [her]93-miss merton : — Lusisti satis , edisti satis , atque bibisti ; “ [You]822-you have wantoned enough with [me]83-laurence — [you]822-you have eaten enough of [my]83-laurence substance — [you]822-you have drunk enough of [my]83-laurence champagne ; ’[83-laurence] tis high time for [you]822-you to go . ” And now , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[83-laurence] let [us]823-us come to the third tree , and [you]822-you shall see what is overshadowed by it . ’ [They]823-us passed across [the enclosure]2172-the enclosure to the largest of the three cypresses , and at the foot of that [Miss Merton]93-miss merton discovered a third gravestone , also with a poetical inscription . ‘[83-laurence] That , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[83-laurence] [you]822-you can read without help of [mine]824-mine . ’ [Miss Merton]93-miss merton looked ; and the lines were not new to [her]93-miss merton : — ‘[83-laurence] Here , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[83-laurence] is the oldest grave of all . [Its]825-its date is that of the tree that stands beside it , and that was planted forty years ago . Under that stone lies [the only woman]826-the only woman — except [myself]0-i , almost the only thing — that [the old man]827-the old man ever really loved . This was in [his]827-the old man young days . [He]827-the old man was only thirty when [she]826-the only woman died ; and [her]826-the only woman death was the great turning - point of [his]827-the old man life . [She]826-the only woman lived with [him]827-the old man for two years , in [a little cottage that stood on the very spot where [he]827-the old man afterwards built [the villa]829-the villa]828-a little cottage that stood on the very spot where he afterwards built the villa . [She]826-the only woman has no name , [you]822-you see , on the grave - stone , and [I]0-i had best not give [her]826-the only woman any . [She]826-the only woman was [[some one]551-some one ’s wife]831-some one ’s wife , but not [his]827-the old man . That is [her]826-the only woman story . [I]0-i have [her]826-the only woman miniature somewhere , which one day [I]0-i should like to show [you]822-you . It is a lovely dark face , with liquid , spiritual eyes , and under it are written two lines of [Byron]169-byron ’s , which might have been composed for [her]826-the only woman : — [She]826-the only woman walks in beauty like the night Well , there [she]826-the only woman lies now ; and [the old man]827-the old man ’s youth lies buried with [her]826-the only woman . It was [her]826-the only woman death that made [him]827-the old man [a philosopher]833-a philosopher . [He]827-the old man built [this great place]834-this great place [here]360-here , and laid out [these gardens]2158-these gardens half to kill [his]827-the old man grief for [her]826-the only woman , and half to keep alive [her]826-the only woman memory ; and here , as [you]822-you see , [he]827-the old man buried [her]826-the only woman . [She]826-the only woman gave up all that was best in [her]826-the only woman for the love of [him]827-the old man . [He]827-the old man gave up all that was best in [him]827-the old man for the loss of [her]826-the only woman . ’ ‘[827-the old man] And is this place left quite uncared for ? ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , looking around [her]93-miss merton . ‘[827-the old man] [It]837-it is left , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[827-the old man] as [he]827-the old man wished it should be . It was one of [his]827-the old man most special orders that , when [he]827-the old man was dead and buried , no further care of any kind should be spent on it . The grass and weeds were to be left to grow wild in it , the rails to rust , the portico to decay and crumble . “ Do [you]822-you think , ” [he]827-the old man said to [me]0-i , “ that [I]0-i know so little of life as to flatter [myself]0-i that [any single creature]838-any single creature will regret [me]0-i when [I]0-i am gone , or even waste a thought upon [me]0-i ? [I]0-i do not chose , as [Christians]2028-christians do , to rest for ever under a lie ; for [[their]2028-christians tombs]840-their tombs are lying monuments that [they]2028-christians are remembered ; [mine]0-i shall be a true one that [I]0-i am forgotten . Yes , ” [he]827-the old man said , “ it makes [me]0-i laugh to think of [myself]0-i — [me]0-i , who have built [this house]841-this house and planted [these gardens which [others]341-others will enjoy — rotting in the midst of it all]842-these gardens which others will enjoy — rotting in the midst of it all . under thorns and brambles , in [a little dismal wilderness]844-a little dismal wilderness . And then perhaps , [Otho]77-otho , ” [he]827-the old man would say to [me]0-i , “ some of [[your]0-i friends who will walk about [these gardens]2158-these gardens]845-your friends who will walk about these gardens in a year or two — [Christians]2028-christians , no doubt , with the devil knows what of fine sentiments about faith and immortality — will look in through the bars of the gate , and be shocked at [that honest wilderness]848-that honest wilderness , that unconcealed neglect , which is the only real portion of those that have been . ” But during [his]827-the old man last illness [he]827-the old man softened just a little , and admitted that [I]0-i , [he]827-the old man did believe , cared for [him]827-the old man , and might , when [he]827-the old man was dead , every now and then think of [him]827-the old man . “ And so , ” [he]827-the old man said , “ if [you]0-i like to do it , come every now and then , and scrape the moss from [my]0-i inscription , and from the two others . But that is all [I]0-i will have [you]0-i do — that , and nothing more . That will express all that it is possible that [you]0-i should feel for [me]0-i . ” [I]0-i promised [him]827-the old man to do no more than that , and that [I]0-i do . [Poor old man]849-poor old man ! ’ [Laurence]83-laurence went on meditatively , as [they]2173-they passed out of the gates , and were again in [the bright trim garden]2174-the bright trim garden . ‘[827-the old man] [He]827-the old man thought that [he]827-the old man belonged to times before [his]827-the old man own ; but [I]0-i think that in reality [he]827-the old man belonged to times after [them]850-them . If [he]827-the old man was [Roman]170-roman at all , as [he]827-the old man always fancied [himself]827-the old man , [he]827-the old man was [Roman]170-roman only in that sombre ennui that through all [his]827-the old man later years oppressed [him]827-the old man ; and which seems to [me]0-i to be now settling down upon [the world]406-the world — an ennui that always kept [him]827-the old man seeking for pleasures , and that turned the pleasures into ashes as soon as [he]827-the old man possessed them . [His]827-the old man pleasures were high and low ; but the higher made [him]827-the old man despise [the lower]852-the lower ; and the lower [he]827-the old man sought simply that [he]827-the old man might drown [the higher]853-the higher . Two things only during [his]827-the old man last years never palled upon [him]827-the old man : one was , saying a sharp thing neatly ; the other , detecting some new weakness in human nature . In this [he]827-the old man seemed really to revel . On the littlenesses and the pretences of [men]1704-men , especially when they turned out failures , [he]827-the old man seemed to look with a passionate contemptuous fondness , like [a wicked prince on a peasant - girl]855-a wicked prince on a peasant - girl . See — here was [[his]827-the old man summer study]856-his summer study — [this stone pavilion]857-this stone pavilion . Let [us]858-us go in for a moment , and [I]0-i will show it to [you]859-you . ’ [They]858-us were in front of [a small quasi - classical building of white marble , embowered behind in arbutus and in myrtles , and commanding from [its]2175-a small quasi - classical building of white marble , embowered behind in arbutus and in myrtles , and commanding from its large windows a full view of the sea large windows a full view of [the sea]300-the sea]2175-a small quasi - classical building of white marble , embowered behind in arbutus and in myrtles , and commanding from its large windows a full view of the sea . [Laurence]83-laurence unlocked the door , and [he]83-laurence and [Miss Merton]93-miss merton entered . Inside there was a faint musty smell , and a general sense that [the place]419-the place had been long disused . The walls were completely lined with books in splendid bindings , whose gilded backs glimmered temptingly through the network of the bookcase doors . In the centre stood a table , covered with a cloth of faded crimson velvet ; nothing on it but a tarnished ormolu inkstand , in the shape of a Roman temple , across the columns of which spiders had woven dusty webs . Placed stiffly before the table stood a gilded arm - chair , with cushions of crimson damask , and under it a foot - stool to match , which had been worn quite bare by [the old philosopher]2178-the old philosopher ’s feet . ‘[0-i] Here , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[0-i] [he]827-the old man would sit day after day amongst [his]827-the old man books , drawing , or reading , or writing , or looking out at [his]827-the old man flowers or at [the sea]300-the sea . Look ! these two folios , bound in red morocco , are a collection of [his]827-the old man verses , letters , essays and so on , that [he]827-the old man had had privately printed . They are not all , [I]0-i ’m afraid , quite fit to read . But this first volume is all right . [I]0-i should like to take it out and show it to [you]2179-you by - and - by . But come — [I]0-i have nothing more to exhibit now . [We]861-they had better join [the others]1695-the others . [They]1695-the others will not be far off , ’[0-i] [he]0-i said , as [they]861-they left [the pavilion]862-the pavilion ; ‘ indeed , [I]0-i think [I]0-i can hear [them]1695-the others talking . ’[0-i] In another moment [they]861-they had passed through an arch of evergreens , and found [themselves]861-they on the spot where nearly all the rest of [the party]1702-the party had already assembled , disposed in an easy group upon the grass . [The place]419-the place was [an amphitheatre of velvet turf , set round with laurels and all kinds of shrubs]865-an amphitheatre of velvet turf , set round with laurels and all kinds of shrubs ; in [the arena of which]866-the arena of which — if one may so speak — a little fountain splashed cool and restless in [a porphyry basin]867-a porphyry basin . Overhead the blue summer sky was screened by the whispering shade of tall trees ; and above the dark laurel - leaves [the fresh sea]868-the fresh sea was seen in the distance , an azure haze full of sparklings . The whole scene , as [Miss Merton]93-miss merton and [Laurence]83-laurence , with [his]83-laurence gorgeous folio under [his]83-laurence arm , came upon [it]869-it , was curiously picturesque . The various dresses made against the green turf a soft medley of colours . [The ladies]355-the ladies were in white and black and pale yellow , green and crimson and dove - colour . [All the men]871-all the men , except [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , were in shooting coats ; and [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , who wore knickerbockers , had even pink stockings . And here , as the lights and shades flickered over [them]861-they , and the gentle air breathed upon [them]861-they , [they]861-they seemed altogether like a party from which [an imaginative on - looker]872-an imaginative on - looker might have expected a new Decameron . Already , under [Lady Grace]89-lady grace ’s vigorous guidance , a certain amount of talk had begun àpropos of [the new Republic]873-the new republic ; [all the ladies]874-all the ladies , with the exception of [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , having fallen to discussing the true position of [women]492-women , or rather of [woman]496-woman , and [their]874-all the ladies opinions on this point being a little various . But besides this , the post had arrived ; and that too had created some excitement . [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose in particular had become delightfully radiant , on receiving a large envelope that was stiff as [she]92-lady ambrose handled it ; and which [she]92-lady ambrose saw contained , as [she]92-lady ambrose just peeped into it , a card , on the top of which was printed , ‘ To have the honour to meet—. ’[92-lady ambrose] [She]92-lady ambrose had , too , just extracted from [Lord Allen]101-allen a promise to come and stay with [her]92-lady ambrose , next autumn , in [the country]1760-the country ; and [her]92-lady ambrose measure of good spirits was quite full . ‘ Now , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , ’[92-lady ambrose] [she]92-lady ambrose exclaimed , dangling [her]92-lady ambrose hat in [her]92-lady ambrose hand , ‘ do come and put a stop to this . [You]83-laurence see what [a woman]1817-a woman ’s parliament would be if [we]2182-we ever have one , which [[my]92-lady ambrose husband]1791-my husband says is not at all impossible . Here is one of [us]2182-we who thinks that everything will go well if [women]492-women can only learn to paint flowers on white dessert plates , and get fifteen shillings apiece for [them]492-women . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ And [I]89-lady grace , ’[89-lady grace] said [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , smiling good - naturedly , ‘ was just saying that [they]492-women all ought to be taught logic . ’[89-lady grace] ‘ Perfectly true , ’[102-mr. saunders] exclaimed [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , putting up [his]102-mr. saunders spectacles to see who had spoken . ‘ And [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘ thinks that [we]2182-we should all be taught to walk [the hospitals]2185-the hospitals , or be [sick - nurses]2186-sick - nurses . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ [I]106-mrs. sinclair should not so much mind that , ’[106-mrs. sinclair] said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , ‘ in war time , if [one]1681-one had anyone fighting in whose life [one]1681-one really took an interest . [I]106-mrs. sinclair once thought , [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie , that that might be [my]106-mrs. sinclair mission , perhaps . ’[106-mrs. sinclair] ‘ But , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘ how are [we]2182-we to build a castle in the air together , if [we]2182-we are all at cross purposes like this ? ’[92-lady ambrose] There did indeed seem little prospect of [their]878-we getting to work at all ; until [Leslie]114-leslie exclaimed at last that [he]114-leslie thought [he]114-leslie had found a way . ‘ See , ’[106-mrs. sinclair] said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , ‘ [I]106-mrs. sinclair told [you]114-leslie a little while ago [you]114-leslie would be wanted to talk cleverly . And now , [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie , do n’t [you]114-leslie think [you]114-leslie would be more comfortable if [you]114-leslie sat a little farther off ? or [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , of whom [I]106-mrs. sinclair am already afraid , will begin to think [we]878-we ’re[106-mrs. sinclair] flirting . ’ ‘[106-mrs. sinclair] Well , ’ said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘[106-mrs. sinclair] in spite of all [our]878-we differences , [I]0-i think [I]0-i see a way in which [we]878-we shall all be able to set to work together . [We]878-we want to imagine a state that shall be as nearly perfect as [we]878-we can make it . Well and good . Now , [we]878-we shall all admit , [I]0-i suppose , that in a perfect state all the parts will be perfect , and each part will imply and involve all the others . Given one bone , [we]878-we shall be able to construct the entire animal . Let [us]878-we then take one part , and imagine that first . Let [us]878-we take the highest class in [[our]878-we state]879-our state , and see what [we]878-we think that ought to be , looking on it in the first place not as a corporate body of [superiors]880-superiors , but as [an assembly of [equals]882-equals]881-an assembly of equals . Let [us]878-we , [I]0-i mean , to put it in other words , begin with seeing what [we]878-we really wish [society]883-society to be — what [we]878-we really think that the highest and most refined life consists in , that is possible for [the most favoured classes]884-the most favoured classes ; and then let [us]878-we see afterwards what is implied in this . ’ [Leslie]114-leslie ’s proposal was welcomed eagerly by [everyone]347-everyone . ‘[878-we] Well , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[878-we] and so [we]878-we are each of [us]878-we to say , are [we]878-we , what [we]878-we think is the essence of [good society]452-good society ? Come then , who knows ? ’ ‘[878-we] Art , ’ murmured [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose . ‘[878-we] Reason , ’ said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders . ‘[878-we] Unworldliness , based on knowledge of [the world]406-the world , ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton . ‘[878-we] Wait a moment , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[878-we] [we]878-we are going too fast . This is not what [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie means . ’ ‘[114-leslie] No , no , ’ said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders . ‘[114-leslie] Let [us]878-we get rid of what is evil before [we]878-we introduce what is good . [I]0-i should begin by getting rid of every belief that is not based upon reason , and every sentiment whose existence can not be accounted for . ’ ‘[0-i] Here [we]878-we are , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[0-i] all over [the place]419-the place . Now if [I]0-i might be allowed to say what [I]0-i thought was the essence of [good society]452-good society , [I]0-i should say that a great part of it , at least , was the absence of [dull and vulgar people]889-dull and vulgar people . ’ ‘[889-dull and vulgar people] Excellent ! ’ exclaimed [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘[889-dull and vulgar people] and a capital exclusion with which to begin [[our]878-we new Republic]890-our new republic . ’ ‘[0-i] YES , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke still more solemnly , ‘[0-i] if [we]878-we only follow this out — this idea of the exclusion from [our]878-we society of all vulgar and extraneous elements , [we]878-we shall find [we]878-we have done a great deal more than [we]878-we may at first think . [We]878-we shall have at once a free , and liberal , and untainted social and intellectual atmosphere , in which [our]878-we thoughts , and feelings , and refinements , and ways of living , may develop themselves to the utmost , unimpeded . [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose has certainly begun with hitting the right nail on the head . ’ Could [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose have been told , when [she]92-lady ambrose left [London]1-london the afternoon before , that in another twenty - four hours [she]92-lady ambrose would be taking the lead in the construction of a Utopia , or ideal state of society , suggested by the writings of [a Greek philosopher]2190-a greek philosopher , [she]92-lady ambrose would have been utterly at a loss to know what the prophecy meant ; and had [she]92-lady ambrose known what it meant , [she]92-lady ambrose would certainly not have believed it . Indeed , as it was , [she]92-lady ambrose could hardly imagine that [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke was serious , and that [he]99-mr. luke was not laughing at [her]92-lady ambrose ; so [she]92-lady ambrose said quickly and in a tone of self - defence , ‘[92-lady ambrose] Of course [I]0-i know that there must be something more than the mere exclusion of [vulgar people]891-vulgar people , [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke . [We]878-we must have religion , and all that , and — ’ ‘[92-lady ambrose] Ah ! ’ exclaimed [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , interrupting [her]92-lady ambrose with a grand wave of the hand ; ‘[92-lady ambrose] [[my]0-i dear]892-my dear [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , let [us]878-we leave all that till by - and - by .
