Let [us]878-we be content to begin with simpler matters first . ’ ‘[878-we] Let [us]878-we begin with the flowers of life , ’ said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘[878-we] and when [we]878-we have chosen these , let [us]878-we trace them back to their roots . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i quite think , ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘[0-i] that in a really good society — one that was perfectly good even in the superficial sense of the word — [we]878-we should find , if [we]878-we only had eyes enough , religion lurking somewhere , and everything else [we]878-we want . ’ ‘[92-lady ambrose] And so that ’s [your]92-lady ambrose view , [[my]0-i dear]892-my dear , is it ? ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘[92-lady ambrose] Oh , then , [I]0-i suppose since [you]92-lady ambrose , [a Roman Catholic]1915-a roman catholic , think so , [I]0-i may also . ’ ‘[92-lady ambrose] Surely , too , ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘[92-lady ambrose] [we]878-we must all know that nothing can be so bad , either for [the pushers]895-the pushers or [the pushed]896-the pushed , as the struggle of [people]308-people to get into what [they]308-people think is good society , not in the least because [they]308-people care to be there , but merely because [they]308-people care to be known to be there . ’ [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , who perhaps felt unconsciously some small pricks of conscience here , again looked doubtful , and said , ‘[896-the pushed] Still , if [we]878-we really want to make a perfect state , this does not seem a very serious thing to begin with . ’ ‘[0-i] Listen , ’ exclaimed [Laurence]83-laurence ; ‘[0-i] let [me]0-i read [you]92-lady ambrose something [I]0-i have here — something of [[my]0-i uncle]2163-my uncle ’s , which [I]0-i have just thought of . It is a short adaptation of [Aristotle]154-aristotle ’s Ethics . ’ [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose started . Hearing two words , the one as long as [Aristotle]154-aristotle , and the other as unfamiliar as Ethics , [she]92-lady ambrose began to think that [she]92-lady ambrose had made the conversation serious with a vengeance . Indeed , [the whole party]591-the whole party , as well as [herself]92-lady ambrose , showed some signs of surprise . ‘[154-aristotle] It is very short , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[154-aristotle] and [I]0-i will only read a page or two . It is called “ A system of Ethics , adapted from Aristotle , for the use of [the English Nation]899-the english nation . ” It was suggested to [him]154-aristotle — ’ ( and this bewildered [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose still more , though at the same time it gave [her]92-lady ambrose some gleam of hope ) , ‘[900-a very rich vulgar family] by [a very rich vulgar family]900-a very rich vulgar family , who bought a place near here , and who much annoyed and amazed [him]154-aristotle by the great court [they]900-a very rich vulgar family paid to [him]154-aristotle . This is the first chapter ; it treats of “ The Summum Bonum , or The Moral End of Action . ” Listen — ‘ Ethics being the art and science of human action , as directed towards the chief good of life — that highest and final end , to which , if [we]2192-we think a little , [we]2192-we shall see all other ends are subordinate ; it is evident that [our]2192-we first task must be , as [[our]2192-we master]699-our master [Aristotle]154-aristotle well says , to form a clear conception of what this end , the chief good , is . ‘[154-aristotle] Now on this point [Aristotle]154-aristotle would seem to err . For [he]154-aristotle , following the common opinion of [men]1704-men , affirms the chief good to be happiness , holding the only question to be , in what does true happiness lie ? And if [he]154-aristotle had been philosophising for [savages]902-savages , [he]154-aristotle would indeed have been in the right . But because [savages]902-savages and [men in a state of nature]904-men in a state of nature have all one end of action , which is happiness , it by no means follows that the same is true of [civilised nations]905-civilised nations , and that these may not have ends that are far higher . It is indeed evident tliat [they]905-civilised nations have . And not this only , but that of such ends there is a very great variety . To describe and number these with anything like absolute accuracy is neither required nor admitted by the nature of the subject . But [we]906-we shall be sufficiently near the truth if [we]906-we say that there is a separate and characteristic chief good for [each civilised nation—(quot gentes]907-each civilised nation—(quot gentes tot summa bona)—and that it is by this in each case that the national character is determined . A glance at [the continent of [Europe]35-europe]908-the continent of europe will at once illustrate this , and suggest examples to [us]906-we of these national chief goods . [We]906-we shall see [the Germans]171-the germans , for instance , following what is called Thought to its inmost recesses , the French what is called Life . [We]906-we shall find accordingly that the chief good of [the former nation]909-the former nation , which is perhaps the highest of all , is the knowledge of the unknowable ; whilst that of the latter , which is next to it in dignity , is the practice of the unmentionable . And so on with all [the other nations]910-the other nations ; each will be found to have [its]911-its separate chief good ; and none of these to have the least connection with happiness . For [us]906-we , however , who are English , and writing for [English readers]912-english readers , it will be enough to concern [ourselves]906-we simply with the chief good of [the English]36-the english . ‘ [We]906-we shall discover this , in the same way as [we]906-we did that of [the French and Germans]2194-the french and germans , in an examination of [our]906-we own special national characteristic . First , however , [we]906-we must be clear what this characteristic is ; and here it will be well to take [[our]906-we neighbours]2097-our neighbours ’[906-we] opinions of [us]906-we as well as [our]906-we own . If [we]906-we inquire then in what light [we]906-we present [ourselves]906-we to [the other European nations]913-the other european nations , [we]906-we shall find that just as [the Germans]914-the germans are known mainly as [a profound nation]915-a profound nation , and [the French]172-the french as [a prurient nation]916-a prurient nation , so are [we]906-we , in like manner , now known as [a vulgar nation]917-a vulgar nation . And as this view of [us]906-we exactly tallies with [our]906-we own , it appears evident that the special national characteristic of [the English]36-the english is vulgarity , and that the chief good of [the English]36-the english is the final end that is aimed at by [the English vulgar classes]918-the english vulgar classes . ‘ This [we]906-we affirm to be social distinction , to [their]918-the english vulgar classes admiration and pursuit of which is due that cardinal moral quality which [they]918-the english vulgar classes call worldliness in [themselves]918-the english vulgar classes , and snobbishness in [[their]918-the english vulgar classes friends]2196-their friends and [enemies]1893-enemies . And if any object that to a great part of [the nation]1899-the nation social distinction in its true sense is a thing unknown , and that to another part it is a thing that comes without being struggled for , and so in neither case can be the end of moral action , [we]906-we shall answer [them]918-the english vulgar classes that to object this , is much the same as to argue that a peach - tree does not bear peaches because none are to be seen growing out of the roots ; or that there is no meaning in the Athanasian Creed because none is attached to it by [the only people who use it]2199-the only people who use it ; or that there is no meaning in the dogma of [the Pope]174-the pope 's infallibility because its only possible meaning is repudiated by [all those who defend it]2200-all those who defend it . For nothing will be found unless [we]906-we seek it in [its]2201-its right place . And for the ethics of [a nation]2202-a nation [we]906-we must look only in that part of [the nation]1899-the nation which is [their]918-the english vulgar classes proper sphere ; and that part is , as [we]906-we have already shown , the vulgar part . And should any still imagine that if [we]906-we thus limit the scope of [our]906-we observation , [we]906-we shall not be able to treat the subject exhaustively , [we]906-we shall remind [him]2204-him that [the vulgar classes]2205-the vulgar classes , though not yet co - extensive with [the nation]1899-the nation , are still rapidly becoming so , vulgarity ascending and descending with equal certainty ; since on the one hand it ruins all society into which it contrives to enter ; whilst it thrives [itself]2201-its , on the other hand , on [all society that contrives to enter into it]2207-all society that contrives to enter into it . To it therefore [our]906-we whole study may be confined . Nor lastly ( for it is well to anticipate every possible objection ) , is there any need that even thus [we]906-we should study those classes that naturally possess social distinction , that [we]906-we may so learn in what its real essence consists ; since , if [we]906-we do but observe facts , [we]906-we shall see that ignorance of the whole inner nature of [good society]452-good society is the chief characteristic of those who with most single - heartedness direct [their]918-the english vulgar classes lives towards getting into it . It will be enough then , without any further explanation , to lay it down that social distinction is the chief good , and the end of all moral action ; nor can [the Aristotelians]175-the aristotelians say that this is in reality a mediate end , and sought for only because it leads to happiness ; since so far are [men]1704-men from seeking social distinction for the sake of happiness , that [they]1704-men are perpetually renouncing happiness for the sake of social distinction . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Capital , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence ! ’[92-lady ambrose] exclaimed [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , breaking into a low silvery laugh , as soon as [Laurence]83-laurence had ended . ‘ And how true that is about [those people who really ruin the society into which [they]2210-those people who really ruin the society into which they contrive to push themselves contrive to push [themselves]2210-those people who really ruin the society into which they contrive to push themselves]2210-those people who really ruin the society into which they contrive to push themselves ! ’[92-lady ambrose] [Lord Allen]101-allen , who caught [Miss Merton]93-miss merton ’s eye at this moment , gave a very faint smile . ‘ So [you]92-lady ambrose see , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ that [you]92-lady ambrose were quite right , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , by instinctively beginning with exclusion . ’[83-laurence] ‘ Still , ’[101-allen] said [Allen]101-allen , ‘ [I]101-allen ’m[101-allen] afraid that all this is rather selfish . [These people who want to to be so smart]919-these people who want to to be so smart , are , [I]0-i dare say , not much the worse because of it . Indeed , [myself]0-i , [I]0-i rather like [a good snob now and then]920-a good snob now and then . ’ ‘[0-i] Well , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[0-i] let [me]0-i read a few more paragraphs , and [you]921-you will see . ‘ Such being the end , ’[0-i] [he]0-i goes on , ‘ of all moral action , virtue or morality is that state of mind which desires this end ; and virtuous or moral acts are those which help [us]2211-us on towards it , provided only that they are done with purpose . For acts done not with purpose , but by chance , are not to be held moral . Now the nature of purpose is well explained by [Aristotle]154-aristotle , when [he]154-aristotle says that its object is all such voluntary action as is the result of deliberation . And what then is the object of deliberation ? Let [us]2211-us consider that : for [men]1704-men , it is evident , do not deliberate about all matters alike ; since in addition to [their]1704-men continually not deliberating in cases when [they]1704-men ought , there are many matters about which deliberation is out of the question . Thus [no one]387-no one deliberates about what is in its nature immutable , as how to alter vulgarity of [a people ’s member of Parliament]2214-a people ’s member of parliament ; nor about necessary things , as how to alleviate the misery of [the starving poor]2215-the starving poor ; nor about things of chance , as how to prevent the dissemination of cholera ; nor , again , about remote things which do not concern [us]2211-us , as , to use a former instance , how to alleviate the misery of [the starving poor]2215-the starving poor ; nor does [anyone]354-anyone deliberate about impossible things , as how to check the poisonous adulteration of food ; nor about things that are past and lost , as how to do anything for the glory of [England]4-england ; nor , lastly , do [we]2211-us deliberate about things [we]2211-us do not care about , as how to get that lost glory back again . Deliberation , then , only takes place about such matters as [our]2211-us own agency can effect , and which [we]2211-us wish it should effect . Virtue , therefore , being thus based on deliberation , is manifestly not one of those things that come to [us]2211-us by nature whether [we]2211-us will or no ; but it is acquired by habit . The genus of moral virtue is a habit . But what special sort of habit ? and how does it differ from all other habits ? Let [us]2211-us consider this . ‘[0-i] [We]922-we must remember , first , that it is the office of every virtue to perfect that of which it is the virtue . Thus it is the virtue of [a modern [London]1-london house]923-a modern london house to be as badly built as possible and not be seen to be so ; it is the virtue of [an insured ship]924-an insured ship not to appear unseaworthy before [she]924-an insured ship does so to [the crew]925-the crew as [she]924-an insured ship is foundering ; and it is the virtue of [butcher]926-butcher ’s meat , groceries and so forth , not to appear unfit for human consumption . In the same way moral virtue , or the virtue of [a man]1770-a man , is that which makes [him]1770-a man appear to be one thing to [the world]406-the world , whilst in reality [he]1770-a man is another . Such being the case , it is plain that in trying to be virtuous , [we]922-we may , as in most other things , do too much , or too little ; and what is right will be a mean lying between these two extremes . Now of means there are two kinds , the absolute and the relative , either of which [we]922-we can find in anything that is continuous ; the former , as when [we]922-we take the bisecting point in a straight line , which is for [all men one and the same]929-all men one and the same ; the latter , as when [we]922-we take the mean point or thing with reference to [ourselves]922-we , in which case it will differ with [our]922-we different requirements . Thus , if three be too small a number , and seventy - five too great , simply as an arithmetical problem , [we]922-we take thirty - nine to be the mean , which exceeds three by as much as it is exceeded by seventy - five ; but with reference to [ourselves]922-we [we]922-we can not so decide . For thirty - nine articles of religion may be too few for [the present Archbishop of Westminster]930-the present archbishop of westminster , and three may be too many for the Dean . Or again between 100l . and 20l . , the mean with regard to the matter itself would be 60l . , but with regard to [ourselves]922-we , not so . For 60l . would be too little to offer to [a cook]931-a cook , and too much to offer to [a curate]932-a curate . So in like manner that equality which constitutes moral virtue is not the absolute , but the relative mean . Moral virtue , then , [we]922-we shall define to be a certain state , or habit of purpose , conforming in action to the relative mean , and adjusted to that mean as [the worldly or snobbish man]933-the worldly or snobbish man would adjust it . At this point [we]922-we shall pause a moment to make a very slight change in the accepted terminology of the subject . [We]922-we have hitherto spoken of the virtue of the vulgar classes as being a mean . [We]922-we consider , however , that [our]922-we language will be less ambiguous , if [we]922-we take another form of the same word , and agree to call it a meanness . Moral virtue , then , is a meanness lying between two vices , its extremes ; the one vice being that of excess , [the other that of defect]934-the other that of defect . Thus it is possible for a habit of mind to be so unrestrained and vehement , that the acts it produces at once betray [their]935-their motives and obtrude them on [the observer]936-the observer ; it is possible for [it]937-it , also , on the other hand , to be so weak and nerveless as never to produce any acts at all . For instance , the habit of thought in [a clergyman]938-a clergyman may be so strong and unrestrained as to lead [him]938-a clergyman to speak [his]938-a clergyman whole conclusions out , and so get deprived of [his]938-a clergyman living ; or on the other hand it may be so weak and undeveloped , that [he]938-a clergyman comes to no conclusions at all , and so dies in a curacy ; the meanness between these two extremes being what is called vagueness , or the absence of any defined opinions , which is a great merit , and leads , in [the Established Church]37-the established church , to high preferment . So also with habits of action , the general name given to the true meanness is worldliness , whereof the excess is snobbishness , and the defect independence : worldliness being in its essence the former of these , and in its aspect the latter . Whence it follows that [we]922-we may yet further generally define the moral meanness , as that which is inwardly one extreme , and which is outwardly the other . ’ ‘[939-the writer of this] Now , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[939-the writer of this] though [I]0-i do n’t suppose [the writer of this]939-the writer of this really cared two straws whether [the majority of [people]308-people]940-the majority of people were mean and vulgar or no , there is a great deal of truth in what [he]939-the writer of this says : and [I]0-i think in [our]922-we ideally good society one of the first things [we]922-we want is that it shall be unmixed and genuine ; [I]0-i mean , [all its members]942-all its members must be of it , as well as in it . [They]942-all its members must give it its prestige . [We]922-we must have none that merely get [their]942-all its members prestige from it . ’ ‘[942-all its members] Well , ’ said [Allen]101-allen , ‘[942-all its members] no doubt this exclusion is better , if it could be only managed . ’ ‘[942-all its members] Do n’t let [us]922-we think yet , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[942-all its members] about how to manage it . Let [us]922-we see what [we]922-we want first , and see what it costs afterwards . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i certainly believe , ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘[0-i] that what [I]0-i consider the extremely bad manners of [a great many very fine ladies]943-a great many very fine ladies would all go , if a stop were put to this jostling and scrambling that goes on about [them]943-a great many very fine ladies , as [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence proposes . ’ ‘[83-laurence] See , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[83-laurence] here is one good fruit of exclusion at once — the redemption of [our]922-we manners ; and a most important fruit too , [I]0-i think ; for [I]0-i hope [we]922-we all start with the understanding that [our]922-we society , ideally good as it is , is above none of those outward graces and refinements of behaviour and ways of living that give [us]922-we such pleasure now , when [we]922-we find [them]944-them . ’ ‘[83-laurence] And manner too , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , ’ broke in [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[83-laurence] as well as manners — Think what a charm there is in a really charming manner . ’ ‘[83-laurence] There is indeed , ’ exclaimed [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton . ‘[83-laurence] The dear Duchess of — — — for instance — why , there ’s a fascination even in the way in which [she]945-she says good morning . ’ ‘[945-she] Ah yes , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘[945-she] Now , there ’s what [I]0-i call a really perfect manner for [you]83-laurence . ’ ‘[0-i] Very well , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[0-i] and whatever is a really perfect manner , in [our]922-we ideal society [we]922-we must all have it . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i must confess , ’ said [Allen]101-allen , ‘[0-i] that [I]0-i get very sick sometimes of [our]922-we conventional society manners ; and [I]0-i often long to have [a good genuine savage]946-a good genuine savage to talk to . ’ ‘[946-a good genuine savage] That , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[946-a good genuine savage] is because of all the social shams that [we]922-we have just agreed to get rid of . And to call the manner of society conventional , conveys no greater blame than if [you]947-you were to call language conventional . For manner is but a second language , of which [the best society]948-the best society speaks the purest dialect — the Attic , in fact . And as with language , so with manner , the more uniformity there is in it in some ways , the nicer shades of individuality shall [we]922-we be able to express by it in others . ’ ‘[83-laurence] Well , ’ said [Allen]101-allen , shortly , ‘[83-laurence] perhaps it is so . [You]83-laurence are very likely right . ’ ‘[83-laurence] And in manner , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[83-laurence] [I]0-i include tone too — that special and indescribable way of looking at things , and speaking of things , which characterises good society , and distinguishes it from [the rest of [the world]406-the world]949-the rest of the world so completely , and yet by marks so subtle that they would utterly escape the notice of those who do n’t know [their]951-their meaning — that little extra stroke of polishing that brings to light such countless new delicate veins in the marble of life — the little extra stroke of the brush that puts a new refinement , and self - possession , into the face . As [Browning]112-mr. herbert says of a very different subject — Oh , the little more , and how much it is , And this is something quite independent of any special ability or special quality on the part of [the individual people]952-the individual people [themselves]952-the individual people ; though of course the more gifted and cultivated [they]952-the individual people are , the greater will its charm be . ’ ‘[0-i] Yes , ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton thoughtfully , and half to [herself]93-miss merton , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i think all that is quite true . ’ ‘[0-i] Of course , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i know that tone alone can only make society good in a very narrow sense of the word . [I]0-i merely mean that no amount of other qualities can make it really good , without tone . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t in the least object , ’ said [Allen]101-allen , ‘[0-i] to the marble being polished ; but what [I]0-i want first to be sure of is , that it is worth polishing . ’ ‘[0-i] Quite so , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘[0-i] What [we]953-we must now consider is , what are all those special qualities and accomplishments , which will make [a really perfect society]954-a really perfect society the best among the best — such things as wit , knowledge , experience , humour , and so on — the veins , in fact , in the marble , that can be brought out by the polish . ’ ‘[83-laurence] Ah , yes , [my]0-i dear [Laurence]83-laurence , ’ began [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘[83-laurence] this is the great thing that [we]953-we shall have to decide about ; and it is this very thing that [I]0-i am always telling [the world]406-the world is — ’ But [he]0-i was interrupted by the advent of [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , who , with the exception of [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks and [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , was [the only member of [the party not already there]2219-the party not already there]2218-the only member of the party not already there . [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert ’s whole aspect surprised [everyone]347-everyone . At luncheon , as [all remembered]2221-all remembered , [he]112-mr. herbert had been melancholy and desponding ; but [his]112-mr. herbert face now wore a bright smile , and there was something that was almost gaiety in [his]112-mr. herbert elastic step . [No one]387-no one , however , ventured to ask [him]112-mr. herbert the reason of this pleasing change ; but as [he]112-mr. herbert held an open newspaper in [his]112-mr. herbert hand , which [he]112-mr. herbert had apparently just received , it occurred to [most]2223-most that [he]112-mr. herbert must have seen in it ‘[0-i] something to [his]956-his advantage . ’ ‘[0-i] Well , ’ [he]112-mr. herbert exclaimed to [Laurence]83-laurence , in a manner quite in keeping with [his]112-mr. herbert look , ‘[0-i] and tell [me]0-i now how are [you]957-you getting on with [your]957-you new Republic ? [You]957-you ought to make a very beautiful thing out of it — all of [you]957-you together , with [so many charming ladies]958-so many charming ladies . ’ ‘[0-i] Do [you]0-i think so ? ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , in great surprise at this cheerful view of things . ‘[0-i] Yes , ’ answered [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , slowly and with decision . ‘[0-i] [Ladies]1708-ladies [I]0-i always think , so long as [they]1708-ladies are good and honest , have beautiful imaginations . And now , let [me]0-i ask [you]957-you how [you]957-you have set to work . ’ [Laurence]83-laurence explained to [him]112-mr. herbert that [they]2224-they had begun , on [Leslie]114-leslie ’s suggestion , with considering what society , or the life of [the highest classes]2225-the highest classes , would be at its best ; and that [they]2224-they were going to see afterwards what was implied in this . ‘[957-you] Indeed ! ’ said [Mr , Herbert]112-mr. herbert meditatively . ‘[957-you] Now , that is a really beautiful way of going about the business . And how far , let [me]0-i ask [you]957-you , have [you]957-you got with [your]957-you picture of [these highest classes]960-these highest classes ? [I]0-i trust at all events that [you]957-you have made a good beginning . ’ ‘[957-you] A beginning , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[957-you] is all that [we]961-we have made . [We]961-we have agreed that [our]961-we society is to have the utmost polish , ease , and grace of manner , and the completest savoir - vivre . It is , in fact , to be a sort of exemplar of human life at its highest conceivable completeness . ’ ‘[112-mr. herbert] Excuse [me]0-i , ’ said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘[112-mr. herbert] but the ways of polite life , and the manners of [fine ladies]962-fine ladies and [gentlemen]963-gentlemen , are beautiful only as the expression of a beautiful spirit ! [They]964-they are altogether hateful as the ornament or the covering of a vile one . ’ ‘[964-they] Yes , [Herbert]112-mr. herbert , yes , ’ exclaimed [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , with a long sigh . ‘[112-mr. herbert] And [I]0-i was just going to say this , when [you]957-you joined [us]961-we — that to make society really good — even really brilliant and entertaining — one thing is wanted , and that is true and genuine culture . Then let [us]961-we have the polish by all means ; but let it be a diamond [we]961-we polish , and not a pebble . [Our]961-we society must be [one that does not merely dance , and hunt , and shoot]965-one that does not merely dance , and hunt , and shoot . [It]966-it must think , and reason , and read . It must be familiar — the whole of it must be familiar — with the great thoughts of [the world]406-the world , the great facts of [the world]406-the world , and the great books of [the world]406-the world . [You]957-you want all this , if [you]957-you would be perfectly brilliant in [[your]957-you salons]970-your salons , as well as really profound in [your]957-you studies . ’ This was assented to by nearly all . [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose however looked a little uncomfortable , and not quite satisfied about something . ‘[957-you] Do n’t [you]957-you think , ’ [she]92-lady ambrose said at last , ‘[0-i] that if [everyone]347-everyone is to have so much culture , society will tend to become — well — just a little — ’ ‘[92-lady ambrose] Well , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose ? ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘[92-lady ambrose] Well , just a little bit blue . It will be all too bookish , if [you]92-lady ambrose understand what [I]0-i mean . Do n’t [you]92-lady ambrose know when [anyone]354-anyone comes to see [you]92-lady ambrose in [London]1-london , and will talk of nothing but books , [one]1681-one always fancies it is because [he]1681-one isn’t — it ’s very uncharitable to say so , but still it ’s true — because [he]1681-one is n’t very much in society and does n’t know many [people]308-people to talk about ? ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i always think it such a blessing , ’ said [Lord Allen]101-allen , ‘[0-i] to find [anyone who will talk about books]975-anyone who will talk about books , and will not be perpetually boring one with vulgar gossip and scandal . ’ ‘[0-i] Oh , so do [I]0-i , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose eagerly , ‘[0-i] but that was not what [I]0-i meant exactly . [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence knows what [I]0-i mean ; [I]0-i ’m sure [he]83-laurence does . [No one]387-no one can delight in a book more than [I]92-lady ambrose ; but still — ’[92-lady ambrose] [she]92-lady ambrose said , pausing to think how much of what [she]92-lady ambrose considered culture was to be found in [those [London]1-london drawing - rooms where [she]92-lady ambrose felt [her]92-lady ambrose own life]976-those london drawing - rooms where she felt her own life completest , ‘ still — somehow — ’[92-lady ambrose] [she]92-lady ambrose said with a faint smile , ‘ it is possible to be too literary , is n’t it , as well as too anything else ? ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Perfectly true , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke — [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose was delighted—‘people continually are too literary — to [my]0-i cost [I]0-i know it ; and that is because [the world at]977-the world at large — what is called [the reading world]978-the reading world even more than [the non - reading world]979-the non - reading world — are hopelessly at sea as to what books are , and what they really do for [us]980-us . In other words , if [you]981-you will forgive [my]0-i harping as [I]0-i do upon a single expression , [they]982-they lack culture . ’ ‘[981-you] Why , [I]0-i thought culture was books and literariness , and all that , ’ [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose murmured half aloud , with a look of bewilderment . [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert however suddenly came to [her]92-lady ambrose rescue . ‘[0-i] Now , all this , ’ [he]0-i said , ‘[0-i] is most interesting ; but [I]0-i feel [myself]0-i , something as [I]0-i imagine [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose does , that [I]0-i should like to know a little more clearly what culture is , and what [you]983-you mean by it , when [you]983-you call it the essence of good society . ’ ‘[983-you] Yes , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[983-you] this is just what [I]0-i like . Come , [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , suppose [you]99-mr. luke were to tell [us]984-us . ’ ‘[99-mr. luke] Suppose , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke with an august wave of [his]99-mr. luke hand , ‘[99-mr. luke] instead of that [we]984-us ask [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence to tell [us]984-us . [No one]387-no one can do so better than [he]83-laurence . [I]0-i , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , have perhaps grown something too much of [a specialist]986-a specialist to be able to put these things in a sufficiently popular way . ’ ‘[99-mr. luke] Ah , ’ said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ’[99-mr. luke] this is really nice . [I]0-i shall like to listen to this . But [you]99-mr. luke must allow [me]0-i to be merely [a listener]398-a listener , and not ask [me]0-i for instruction . [I]0-i assure [you]99-mr. luke [I]0-i am here altogether to be instructed . ’ [Laurence]83-laurence , with some diffidence , assented to what was asked of [him]83-laurence ; and there was a general rustling on all sides of [the party]1702-the party settling [themselves]1702-the party down more luxuriously on the grass . Every influence of the summer afternoon conspired to make all take kindly to the topic — the living airy whisper of the leaves overhead , the wandering scents of the flowers that the breeze just made perceptible , the musical splash of the fountain in its quiet restlessness , the luxury of the mossy turf as soft as sleep or rose - leaves , and a far faint murmur of church - bells that now and then invaded the ear gently , like a vague appealing dream . [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders even was caressed by [his]102-mr. saunders flattered senses into peacefulness ; the high and dry light of the intellect ceased to scintillate in [his]102-mr. saunders eyes ; the spirit of progress condescended to take a temporary doze . ‘[0-i] AND now , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[83-laurence] begin at the beginning , please , and do n’t do as [Lord Kennington]176-lord kennington did at [the Eton and Harrow]988-the eton and harrow match the other day — go talking to [me]0-i about “ overs , ” and “ long - stops , ” and things like that , before [I]0-i was even quite sure of the difference between “ out ” and “ in . ” ’ ‘[0-i] Of course , ’ [Laurence]83-laurence began , smiling with a little prefatory shyness , ‘[0-i] [we]989-we can all understand the difference between a coarse common rustic palate , like that of [the burly farmer]990-the burly farmer , for instance , who just enjoys food in a brute way when [he]990-the burly farmer is hungry , and drink so long as it is spirituous at all times ; and the palate of the true epicure , that is sensitive to taste as the nicest ear is to music , and can discriminate perfectly all the subtle semitones and chords of flavour . Well , transfer this image from the mouth to the mind , and there ’s the whole thing in a nutshell . There is culture and no culture . [A person]991-a person is really cultivated when [he]991-a person can taste not only the broad flavours of life — gulping its joys and sorrows down , either with a vulgar grimace of disgust , or an equally vulgar hearty voracity ; but when with a delicate self - possession [he]991-a person appreciates all the subtler taste of things , when [he]991-a person discriminates between joy and joy , between sorrow and sorrow , between love and love , between career and career ; discerning in all incidents and emotions [their]992-their beauty , [their]992-their pathos , [their]992-their absurdity , or [their]992-their tragedy , as the case may be . ’ ‘[993-you] [You]993-you mean , then , ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘[993-you] that [a man of the highest culture]994-a man of the highest culture is a sort of emotional bon vivant ? ’ ‘[993-you] That surely is hardly a fair way — ’ began [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘[993-you] Excuse [me]0-i , [[my]0-i dear]892-my dear [Laurence]83-laurence , ’ broke in [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , in [his]99-mr. luke most magnificent of manners , ‘[993-you] it is perfectly fair — it is admirably fair . [Emotional bon vivant]996-emotional bon vivant ! ’ [he]99-mr. luke exclaimed . ‘[996-emotional bon vivant] [I]0-i thank [Miss Merton]93-miss merton for teaching [me]0-i that word ! for it may remind [us]997-our all , ’ [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke continued , drawing out [his]99-mr. luke words slowly , as if [he]99-mr. luke liked the taste of them , ‘[996-emotional bon vivant] how near [our]997-our view of the matter is to that of [a certain Galilean peasant — of whom [Miss Merton]93-miss merton has perhaps heard]998-a certain galilean peasant — of whom miss merton has perhaps heard — who described the highest culture by just the same metaphor , as a hunger and a thirst after righteousness . [Our]997-our notion of it differs only from [his]998-a certain galilean peasant — of whom miss merton has perhaps heard , from [the Zeitgeist]177-the zeitgeist having made it somewhat wider . ’ [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , in [her]93-miss merton inmost soul , did anything but return [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke ’s compliment , and consider [his]99-mr. luke comment on [her]93-miss merton words as either admirably or perfectly fair . However , [she]93-miss merton held [her]93-miss merton peace . The thoughts of [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose had been flowing in a slightly different direction . ‘[177-the zeitgeist] But what [I]0-i want to ask , ’ [she]93-miss merton said , ‘[0-i] is this . [I]0-i want to know why it is that whenever [one]1681-one hears it said , “ Oh , So - and - so is [a very cultivated person , ” one]1000-a very cultivated person , ” one always expects to find [him]998-a certain galilean peasant — of whom miss merton has perhaps heard — well , almost half professional as it were , or at least able to talk of nothing but music , or painting , or books ? [I]0-i mean , [a man who ’s merely [a cultivated person]1002-a cultivated person does n’t seem ever to be quite [a man of [the world]406-the world]1003-a man of the world , or to be much good in society , except when one wants [him]998-a certain galilean peasant — of whom miss merton has perhaps heard to talk on [[his]998-a certain galilean peasant — of whom miss merton has perhaps heard own subjects]1005-his own subjects]1001-a man who ’s merely a cultivated person does n’t seem ever to be quite a man of the world , or to be much good in society , except when one wants him to talk on his own subjects — [I]0-i hate [[people]308-people [myself]0-i who have [subjects]1008-subjects]1007-people myself who have subjects — and then , ten to one , [he]998-a certain galilean peasant — of whom miss merton has perhaps heard does n’t know when to leave off . Now , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , [I]0-i see [you]83-laurence want to interrupt [me]0-i ; but do let [me]0-i say [my]0-i say . A right amount of culture is of course delightful , and personally , [I]0-i do n’t much care for [people who have n’t got it]1009-people who have n’t got it . But too much of it — [I’m]0-i sure , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , [you]83-laurence must agree with [me]0-i at heart — is a mistake . And that , [you]83-laurence know , is all [I]0-i mean about it ; nothing more than that . ’ ‘[0-i] Ah , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , smiling , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i think [I]0-i see what it is . [You]83-laurence will look on culture as some special kind of accomplishment or taste like music ; and [you]83-laurence think that in some special way it is bound up with books ; and books [you]83-laurence look upon as something special also , beginning and ending with [themselves]1010-themselves ; and , unless [I]0-i am much mistaken , [you]83-laurence think that the more books [a man]1770-a man has read , the more cultivated [you]83-laurence may safely call [him]1770-a man . ’ ‘[0-i] Not all books , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose in an injured tone . ‘[0-i] Of course [I]0-i do n’t mean trashy novels , and of course [I]0-i do n’t mean blue - books , or books of history . ’ ‘[0-i] But what [I]0-i want first of all to impress on [you]83-laurence , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[0-i] is that whatever its relation to books may be , culture is by no means a bookish thing , or a thing that ought to be less in place at [Hurlingham]38-hurlingham than at [the South Kensington Museum]1012-the south kensington museum . Nor is it in any sense a hobby , or a special taste , to be gratified at the expense of anything else . Instead of that , it is the education of all [our]1013-our tastes , of all [our]1013-our powers of enjoying life ; and , so far from its being a thing for [recluses]1014-recluses , and a substitute for society , it is only when naturalised in the best society that it can at all do itself justice in expressing itself outwardly , or even exist in any completeness inwardly . ’ [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose smiled , and looked more interested , and began to give [Laurence]83-laurence [her]92-lady ambrose most intelligent attention . ‘[1013-our] Still , ’ [Laurence]83-laurence went on , ‘[1013-our] culture and books have a good deal to do with one another ; and since they are so bound up together in [your]83-laurence mind , let [us]1013-our try to see at once what the relation really is . Let [us]1013-our begin , then , with that part of culture which in this sense is most bound up with books — most bound up because it can not be got without them ; the part of culture , [I]0-i mean , that comes from the knowledge of the past — from a knowledge of history , in short , or parts of history . ’ [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose here took [Laurence]83-laurence fairly aback by the way in which [she]92-lady ambrose repeated the word ‘[1813-the woman] History ! ’ ‘[1813-the woman] Well , judging from the results [I]0-i have seen , ’ [she]92-lady ambrose said , with an amount of decision in [her]92-lady ambrose voice that was positively startling , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i can not say , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , that [I]0-i agree with [you]83-laurence . And [I]0-i think that on this subject [I]0-i have a right to speak . ’ ‘[0-i] What on [earth]2155-earth can [the woman]1813-the woman be meaning ? ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke to [himself]99-mr. luke . ‘[1813-the woman] It is not a fortnight ago , ’ [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose went on , ‘[1813-the woman] that [I]0-i sat at dinner by [somebody]1017-somebody — [I]0-i wo n’t tell [you]83-laurence [his]1017-somebody name — who had not only read heaven knows how much history , but had written , [I]0-i believe , even more than [he]1017-somebody had read . And what do [you]83-laurence think [this good man]1018-this good man did during all the early part of dinner ? Why , [he]1018-this good man did nothing but fume , and fret , and bluster , so that [everyone]347-everyone was made uncomfortable , simply because [somebody]1017-somebody said that [King Harold]178-king harold was not quite so excellent a character as [the late Prince Consort]1021-the late prince consort ; and [I]0-i heard [him]1018-this good man muttering , “ What monstrous injustice ! What monstrous ignorance ! ” to [himself]1018-this good man for nearly half an hour . [I]0-i do n’t think [I]0-i ever saw such a — [I]0-i was going to say , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , laughing softly , ‘[0-i] such a beast — but [I]0-i wo n’t ; [I]0-i ’ll say a bear instead . At last , however — [I]0-i do n’t know how it came about — [he]1018-this good man said to [me]0-i , in a very solemn voice , “ What a terrible defeat that was which [we]1022-we had at [Bouvines]39-bouvines ! ” [I]0-i answered timidly — not thinking [we]1022-we were at war with [anyone]354-anyone — that [I]0-i had seen nothing about it in the papers . “ H’m ! ” [he]1018-this good man said , giving a sort of a grunt that made [me]0-i feel dreadfully ignorant , “ why , [I]0-i had an Excursus on it [myself]0-i in the ‘ Archæological Gazette , ’[1018-this good man] only last week . ” And , do [you]0-i know , it turned out that the Battle of [Bouvines]39-bouvines was fought in the thirteenth century , and had , as far as [I]0-i could make out , something to do with [Magna Charta]179-magna charta . Now , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , if that ’s the sort of culture [one]1024-one gets from studying history , [I]0-i ’m glad [I]92-lady ambrose ’ve forgotten even the names of [the twelve Cæsars]2228-the twelve cæsars , and the date of [the kings of [England]4-england]2229-the kings of england . Besides , ’[92-lady ambrose] [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose added , ‘ it makes [one]1681-one think what a serious thing it is to lose a battle , if [people]308-people are to be made so cross about it six hundred years afterwards . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ [I]83-laurence quite agree with [you]92-lady ambrose , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ that if that ’s the sort of culture one gets from history , [we]2232-we had better never open a history book again . But history , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , has very little to do with the Battle of [Bouvines]39-bouvines , and nothing with the character of [Harold]178-king harold . ’[83-laurence] ‘ Then what has it got to do with ? ’[92-lady ambrose] asked [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose incredulously . ‘ It certainly has to do with [kings]2233-kings , and wars , and facts , and dates , has n’t it ? ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ What [people]308-people call facts , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ are only the dry bones of history . It is quite true that [most professed historians]2235-most professed historians have hitherto , instead of painting the face of the past , simply made discrepant notes about the shape of its skull : everything that could give the shape of the skull the least significance [they]2235-most professed historians left unthought of , or dismissed it in an occasional chapter . But really the least important of all [the world]406-the world ’s events are those that [you]92-lady ambrose can localise exactly , and put an exact date to ; those which alone [most historians]2237-most historians see . ’[83-laurence] ‘ But , ’[93-miss merton] interposed [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘ do n’t [you]92-lady ambrose call such things as the events in [Caesar]180-caesar ’s life , for instance , or [Hildebrand]181-hildebrand ’s , history ? ’[93-miss merton] ‘ Looked on simply as events , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ [I]83-laurence call them biography , or [I]83-laurence call them illustrations of history ; but [I]83-laurence do not call them history . History , in its true sense , is a travelling in the past ; the best of histories would be but [the carriage]2238-the carriage or [the steamboat [you]92-lady ambrose travelled by]2239-the steamboat you travelled by ; [your]92-lady ambrose histories of dates and battles are at best but the Bradshaws and the railway - maps . [Our]2240-our past must be an extension of the present , or it is no real past . Now [I]83-laurence expect , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , that , in its true sense , [you]92-lady ambrose know a good deal more history than [you]92-lady ambrose are aware of . [I]83-laurence saw [you]92-lady ambrose reading [Saint - Simon]182-saint - simon yesterday evening , and [you]92-lady ambrose alluded to [Grammont]123-grammont ’s Memoirs at dinner . ’[83-laurence] ‘ Oh , of course , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘ books like that ! But , then , [they]2241-they really give [you]92-lady ambrose such a notion of the times , and quite take [you]92-lady ambrose back to [them]2241-they . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Nothing is history that does not , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘ Really , ’[92-lady ambrose] exclaimed [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , brightening . ‘ “ II y a plus de vingt ans que je dis de la prose , sans que j’en susse rien . ” And so it seems that [I]92-lady ambrose have known history without suspecting it , just as [M. Jourdain]183-m. jourdain talked prose . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Pardon [me]102-mr. saunders , ’[102-mr. saunders] cried [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ‘ if [I]102-mr. saunders interrupt [you]83-laurence for a moment ; but , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , though [I]102-mr. saunders admit that there is a great deal of truth in what [you]83-laurence say , [you]83-laurence have not even alluded to the great function of history , nor have [you]83-laurence even hinted at the great use of facts . However , perhaps [I]102-mr. saunders had better reserve what [I]102-mr. saunders have to say on this , as well as on certain other matters , till by - and - by . ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ Very well , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ if history , then , is a travelling in the past — what else it is , as [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders says , [we]2242-us can talk of afterwards — don’t [you]83-laurence see what it does for [us]2242-us , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , in the way of culture — does for [us]2242-us , not as [students]2243-students , but as [men]1704-men and [women of [the world]406-the world]2245-women of the world ? Just think for a moment what [our]2242-us own age would seem to [us]2242-us if all the past , beyond the memories of [[our]2242-us grandfathers]2247-our grandfathers , was a blank to [us]2242-us ; and then think how infinitely [our]2242-us minds are enlarged , how a freer air , as it were , seems to blow through them , even from that vague knowledge of the past afloat in [the world]406-the world , which [we]2242-us pick up here and there as [we]2242-us go along . Even that has an effect upon [us]2242-us . It prevents [us]2242-us being , as [we]2242-us else should be , merely [temporal people who are just as narrow - minded and dull as those merely local people — [the natives of [a neighbourhood]2251-a neighbourhood — who wear gorgeous ribands at flower - shows in [the country]1760-the country]2250-the natives of a neighbourhood — who wear gorgeous ribands at flower - shows in the country]2249-temporal people who are just as narrow - minded and dull as those merely local people — the natives of a neighbourhood — who wear gorgeous ribands at flower - shows in the country . Do n’t [you]92-lady ambrose remember last year , when [I]83-laurence was staying with [you]92-lady ambrose , how [you]92-lady ambrose pointed some of [them]2253-their out to [me]83-laurence , and how amused [you]92-lady ambrose were at [their]2253-their ways and [their]2253-their finery ? ’[83-laurence] [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose smiled and nodded . ‘ Go on , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence — [I]92-lady ambrose can understand all this , ’[92-lady ambrose] [she]92-lady ambrose said . ‘ But [I]92-lady ambrose want to hear a little more . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Well , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ [your]92-lady ambrose own knowledge of the history of [France]40-france and [England]4-england during the last two hundred years — [you]92-lady ambrose know well enough how that has made [you]92-lady ambrose , in a certain sense , more [a woman of [the world]406-the world]2254-a woman of the world . What would [you]92-lady ambrose be , for instance , if [you]92-lady ambrose never knew that there had been a French Revolution , or an English Revolution — [a Cromwell]2256-a cromwell , or a [Louis Quatorze]184-louis quatorze , or a [Mirabeau]185-mirabeau ? But [your]92-lady ambrose knowledge of history does not end here . [You]92-lady ambrose know something , at any rate , of the feudal times . [You]92-lady ambrose know what [a castle]2257-a castle was like , what [a knight]2258-a knight was like , what [a monk]2259-a monk was like . [You]92-lady ambrose know something , too , Of Roman and Greek history ; and , come — to go no farther — [you]92-lady ambrose know the Bible . ’[83-laurence] ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose hope , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , in a voice of reproving solemnity , ‘ that one would not call that history . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Certainly not , ’[102-mr. saunders] said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , with a small suppressed chuckle . ‘ At all events , ’[83-laurence] proceeded [Laurence]83-laurence , ignoring these interruptions , ‘ [you]92-lady ambrose know something of [Rome]41-rome , and [Greece]42-greece , and [Palestine]43-palestine , and [Egypt]44-egypt ; and each of these names is really a little aërial chariot which carries [your]92-lady ambrose imagination back as [you]92-lady ambrose pronounce it into some remote age , when life was different from what it is now . So is the mind widened by even a little vague history . Or , just repeat to [yourself]92-lady ambrose such words as [France]40-france and [Italy]45-italy , and think for a moment of the effect of them . They are not mere names — mere geographical expressions ; but they are spells which evoke , whether [you]92-lady ambrose will or no , hosts of subtle associations , rising up like spirits out of the past centuries , and hovering in the air round [you]92-lady ambrose with [their]2260-their unbidden influence , and mixing with all [your]92-lady ambrose notions of [Europe]35-europe as it is now . Or , would [you]92-lady ambrose feel the matter more strongly yet , think , when [you]92-lady ambrose are travelling , what but for history would [Venice]46-venice be , or [Athens]21-athens , or [Jerusalem]47-jerusalem ? If it were not for history , be it never so vaguely understood , would [you]92-lady ambrose find the same indescribable fascination in [Rome]41-rome ? ’[83-laurence] ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose never was at [Rome]41-rome , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘ [We]1025-us ’re[92-lady ambrose] going there next winter with [the Kenningtons]186-the kenningtons . ’ This piece of intelligence brought [Laurence]83-laurence to a stop . [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , however , whose imagination had been fired by all this talk about history , suddenly broke forth . ‘[92-lady ambrose] And also , ’ [he]100-mr. rose exclaimed , ‘[83-laurence] is it not by history alone that [we]1025-us can in [our]1025-us day learn anything of the more subtle and gorgeous dyes that life is capable of taking — how fair a thing it may be , how rich in harmonious freedom , and beauty of form , and love , and passionate friendship ? Why , but for history , what should [we]1025-us be now but [a flock of listless barbarians]1026-a flock of listless barbarians , ὀνειράτων ἀλίγκιοι μορφαισι φύρόντες εἰκη πάντα ? Would not all life ’s choicer and subtler pleasures be lost to [us]1025-us , if [Athens]21-athens did not still live to redeem [us]1025-us from the bondage of the middle age , and if [the Italian Renaissance]1027-the italian renaissance — [that strange child of Aphrodite and Tannhaüser]1028-that strange child of aphrodite and tannhaüser , did not still live to stimulate [us]1025-us out of the torpor of the present age ? What , but for history , should [we]1025-us know , ’ cried [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ‘[1025-us] of the χάρις of [Greece]42-greece , of the lust of [Rome]41-rome , of the strange secrets of [the Borgias]48-the borgias ? Consider , too , the bowers of quiet , full of sweet dreams , that history will always keep for [us]1025-us — how it surrounds [the house of the present]1029-the house of the present with [the boundless gardens of the past]1030-the boundless gardens of the past — [gardens rich in woods , and waters , and flowers]1031-gardens rich in woods , and waters , and flowers , and outlooks on [illimitable seas]1032-illimitable seas . Think of the immortal dramas which history sets before [us]1025-us ; of the keener and profounder passions which it shows in action , of the exquisite groups and figures it reveals to [us]1025-us , of nobler mould than [ours]1025-us — [Harmodius]187-harmodius and [Aristogeiton]188-aristogeiton , [Achilles]189-achilles and Patroclus , [David]190-david and [Jonathan]191-jonathan , [our]1025-us English [Edward]192-edward and [the fair Piers Gaveston]1033-the fair piers gaveston , ἅμα τ ’ ὠκύμορος καὶ ὀϊζυρὸς περὶ πάντων , or , above all , those two by the agnus castus and the plane - tree where [Ilyssus]193-ilyssus flowed,’—Mr . [Rose]100-mr. rose ’s voice gradually subsided,—‘and where the Attic grasshoppers chirped in shrill summer choir . ’[187-harmodius] ‘ At any rate , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ’[83-laurence] [Laurence]83-laurence resumed briskly , ‘ [you]92-lady ambrose now see something of the way in which history gives [us]1025-us culture ; and [you]92-lady ambrose see , too,—this is the chief point [I]83-laurence want to impress upon [you,—that]2261-you,—that in history , and many other things as well , books are only the telescopes through which [we]1025-us see distant facts ; and [we]1025-us no more become bookish by such a use of books than [you]92-lady ambrose became optical when [you]92-lady ambrose looked through [your]92-lady ambrose telescope in [Gloucestershire]13-gloucestershire , and saw [Captain Audley]194-captain audley , at [the bottom of [the park]2263-the park]2262-the bottom of the park , proposing to [[your]92-lady ambrose under - keeper ’s daughter]2264-your under - keeper ’s daughter . ’[83-laurence] ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose really do believe , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘ that [that man]1716-that man is a little off [his]1716-that man head . However , ’[92-lady ambrose] [she]92-lady ambrose went on laughing , ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose give up about the bookishness , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , and [I]92-lady ambrose dare say one really is the better for knowing something about history ; but still , [I]92-lady ambrose ca n’t help thinking that the chief thing to know about is , after all , the life about one , and that knowledge , just like charity , should begin at [home]2266-home . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ There , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ [we]2267-we quite agree ; and that , if [I]83-laurence managed to express [myself]83-laurence clearly , was the very thing that [I]83-laurence set out with saying . It is with the life about [us]2267-we that all [our]2267-we concern lies ; and culture ’s double end is simply this — to make [us]2267-we appreciate that life , and to make that life worth appreciating . [We]2267-we only study the past to adorn [our]2267-we present , or to make [our]2267-we view of it clearer . And now , since [we]2267-we have at any rate suggested how this is done , let [us]2267-we put the past , and the distant too — everything , in fact , to which books are only the telescopes — out of [our]2267-we minds altogether , and merely consider the real heart of the matter — culture and the present . [I]83-laurence tried to explain just now that [we]2267-we meant by [a man of culture one on whom none of the finer flavours of life]2268-a man of culture one on whom none of the finer flavours of life are lost — who can appreciate , sympathise with , criticise , all the scenes , situations , sayings , or actions around [him]2268-a man of culture one on whom none of the finer flavours of life — a sad or happy love - affair , a charm of manner and conversation , a beautiful sunset , or a social absurdity . [I]83-laurence declare , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ [I]83-laurence could tell better whether [a man]1770-a man was really cultivated , from the way in which [he]1770-a man talked gossip , or told a story ; than from the way in which [he]1770-a man discussed a poem or a picture . ’[83-laurence] ‘ Certainly , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie . ‘ [I]114-leslie do n’t call [a woman]1817-a woman cultivated who bothers [me]114-leslie at dinner first with discussing this book and then that — whose one perpetual question is , “ Have [you]114-leslie read So - and - so ? ” But [I]114-leslie call [a woman cultivated]2271-a woman cultivated who responds and who knows what [I]114-leslie mean as [we]2267-we pass naturally from subject to subject — who by a flash or a softness in [her]1817-a woman eyes , by a slight gesture of the hand , by a sigh , by a flush in the cheek , makes [me]114-leslie feel as [I]114-leslie talk of some lovely scene that [she]1817-a woman too could love it — as [I]114-leslie speak of love or sorrow , makes [me]114-leslie feel that [she]1817-a woman [herself]1817-a woman has known [them]2272-them ; as [I]114-leslie speak of ambition , or ennui or hope , or remorse , or loss of character , makes [me]114-leslie feel that all these are not mere names to [her]1817-a woman , but things . ’[114-leslie] ‘ Do [you]114-leslie call [me]106-mrs. sinclair cultivated , [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie ? ’[106-mrs. sinclair] whispered [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , in a soft parenthesis . ‘ [I]114-leslie mean , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie , finishing , ‘ [I]114-leslie like to hear each key [I]114-leslie touch make , not a dead thud as on a piece of wood , but strike a musical string . ’[114-leslie] ‘ Good , ’[100-mr. rose] murmured [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose ; ‘ that is good ! Yes , ’[100-mr. rose] [he]100-mr. rose continued , ‘ the aim of culture , if [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie will lend [me]100-mr. rose [his]114-leslie nice metaphor , is indeed to make the soul a musical instrument , which may yield music either to itself or to others , at any appulse from without ; and the more elaborate [a man]1770-a man ’s culture is , the richer and more composite can this music be . The minds of [some men]2274-some men are like a simple pastoral reed . Only single melodies , and these unaccompanied , can be played upon them — glad or sad ; whilst the minds of [others , who look at things from countless points of view]2275-others , who look at things from countless points of view , and realise , as [Shakespeare]195-shakespeare did , [their]2275-others , who look at things from countless points of view composite nature — [their]2275-others , who look at things from countless points of view minds become , as [Shakespeare]195-shakespeare ’s was , like a great orchestra . Or sometimes , ’[100-mr. rose] said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose dreamily , as if [his]100-mr. rose talk was lapsing into a soliloquy—‘when [he]100-mr. rose is [a mere passive observer of things]1034-a mere passive observer of things , letting impressions from without move [him]100-mr. rose as they will , [I]0-i would compare [the man of culture]1035-the man of culture to an Æolian harp , which the winds at will play through — a beautiful face , a rainbow , [a ruined temple]1036-a ruined temple , a death - bed , or a line of poetry , wandering in like a breath of air amongst the chords of [his]100-mr. rose soul , touching note after note into soft music , and at last gently dying away into silence . ’ ‘[2245-women of the world] Well , now , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , in a very matter - of - fact tone , for [he]83-laurence saw that [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose ’s dreamy manner always tended to confuse [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[2245-women of the world] since [we]1037-we are now clear that the aim of culture is to make [us]1037-we better company as [men]1704-men and [women of [the world]406-the world]2245-women of the world , let [us]1037-we consider a little farther how culture is attained . [We]1037-we have just spoken of histories and other books , which merely bring [us]1037-we face to face with facts that would else be out of [our]1037-we reach . [We]1037-we now come to two other things — the facts of the life about [us]1037-we , the facts which experience teaches [us]1037-we , and to which all other facts are secondary ; and , farther , to the way in which all this knowledge — the knowledge of [the living present]1041-the living present especially — is ( for [we]1037-we have really not talked of this at all yet ) turned into culture . Mere acquaintance with facts will not do it ; mere experience of facts will not do it . [A woman]1817-a woman , for instance may have had all kinds of experience — society , sorrow , love , travel , remorse , distraction — and yet [she]1817-a woman may not be cultivated . [She]1817-a woman may have gone through everything only half consciously . [She]1817-a woman may never have recognised what [her]1817-a woman life has been . What is needed to teach [her]1817-a woman — to turn this raw material into culture ? Here , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , [we]1037-we come to [[our]1037-we friends]1043-our friends the books again — not , however to such books as histories , but to books of art , to poetry , and books akin to poetry . The former do but enlarge [our]1037-we own common experience . The latter are an experience in [themselves]1044-themselves , and an experience that interprets all former experiences . The mind , if [I]0-i may borrow an illustration from photography , is a sensitised plate , always ready to receive the images made by experience on it . Poetry is the developing solution , which first makes these images visible . Or , to put it in another way , if some books are the telescopes with which [we]1037-we look at distant facts , poetry — [I]0-i use the word in its widest sense — is a magic mirror which shows [us]1037-we the facts about [us]1037-we reflected in it as no telescope or microscope could show them to [us]1037-we . Let [a person of experience look into this , and experience]1045-a person of experience look into this , and experience then becomes culture . For in that magic mirror [we]1037-we see [our]1037-we life surrounded with issues viewless to the common eye . [We]1037-we see it compassed about with chariots of fire and with horses of fire . Then [we]1037-we know the real aspect of [our]1037-we joys and sorrows . [We]1037-we see the lineaments , [we]1037-we look into the eyes of thoughts , and desires , and associations , which had been before unseen and scarcely suspected presences — dim swarms clustering around [our]1037-we every action . Then how all kinds of objects and of feelings begin to cling together in [our]1037-we minds ! A single sense or a single memory is touched , and a thrill runs through countless others . The smell of autumn woods , the colour of dying fern , may turn by a subtle transubstantiation into pleasures and faces that will never come again — a red sunset and a windy [sea - shore]1046-sea - shore into a last farewell , and the regret of a lifetime . ’ [Laurence]83-laurence had chosen these illustrations of [his]83-laurence quite at random ; but [he]83-laurence was fortunate in the last in a way which [he]83-laurence never dreamt of . [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , in [her]92-lady ambrose early and unwise days , had actually had a love - affair . [She]92-lady ambrose had been engaged to [a handsome young Guardsman]2276-a handsome young guardsman , with only eleven hundred a year , and no prospects but debts ; and though [she]92-lady ambrose had successfully exchanged [him]2276-a handsome young guardsman for [Sir George]122-sir george and [his]2276-a handsome young guardsman million of money , [she]92-lady ambrose still sometimes recalled [him]2276-a handsome young guardsman , and the wild September evening when [she]92-lady ambrose had seen [her]92-lady ambrose last of [him]2276-a handsome young guardsman upon [Worthing pier]49-worthing pier . ‘[1047-you] Ah , ’ [she]92-lady ambrose exclaimed , with some emotion in [her]92-lady ambrose voice , ‘[1047-you] [I]0-i know exactly what [you]1047-you mean now . Why , there have been poems at one time or another of one ’s life , that [one]1681-one could really hardly bear to hear repeated . Now , there ’s that of [Byron]169-byron ’s , “ When [we]1049-we two parted . ” [I]0-i do n’t even know if it is right to think it a good poem — but still , do [you]1050-you know , there was a time when , just because it was connected with something — it almost made [me]0-i cry if [anyone]354-anyone repeated or sang it — one of [[my]0-i brothers]1052-my brothers , [I]0-i know , who had a beautiful voice , was always — ’ [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose here grew conscious that [she]92-lady ambrose was showing more feeling than [she]92-lady ambrose thought at all becoming . [She]92-lady ambrose blushed , [she]92-lady ambrose stammered a little , and then , making a rush at another topic , ‘[1052-my brothers] But what is [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ’ [she]92-lady ambrose exclaimed , ‘[100-mr. rose] saying about [the Clock - tower]1053-the clock - tower and [the Thames Embankment]1054-the thames embankment ? ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i was merely thinking , ’ said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , who had been murmuring to [himself]100-mr. rose at intervals for some time , ‘[0-i] of a delicious walk [I]0-i took last week , by [the river side]1055-the river side , between [Charing Cross]50-charing cross and [Westminster]51-westminster . The great clock struck the chimes of midnight ; a cool wind blew ; and there went streaming on the wide wild waters with long vistas of reflected lights wavering and quivering in them ; and [I]0-i roamed about for hours , hoping [I]0-i might see some unfortunate cast [herself]1056-herself from [the Bridge of Sighs]1057-the bridge of sighs . It was a night [I]0-i thought well in harmony with despair . Fancy , ’ exclaimed [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ‘[0-i] the infinity of emotions which the sad sudden splash in [the dark river]1058-the dark river would awaken in [one]1681-one ’s mind — and all due to that one poem of [Hood]196-hood ’s ! ’ ‘[0-i] Yes , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , not having listened to [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , who spoke , indeed , somewhat low , ‘[0-i] Yes , ’ [he]0-i said , continuing the same train of thought [he]0-i had left off with , and looking first at [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose and then at [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘[0-i] is it not poetry that does all this for [the world]406-the world ? [I]0-i use poetry in its widest sense , and include in it all imaginative literature , and other art as well . Is it not the poet that gives [our]1061-we existence all its deepest colours , or enables [us]1061-we to give them to it [ourselves]1061-we ? Is it not — if [I]0-i may quote a translation of Goethe that [I]0-i made [myself]0-i — Is’t not the harmony that from [his]1062-his bosom springs , And back into itself the whole world brings ? When Nature round [her]1063-her spindle , cold and strong , Winds on and on the endless threads of things ; When all existences , a timeless throng , Make discord as with jangling strings , Whose life - breath bids the flux of blind creation Move to a rhythmic music of [his]1062-his own ? [Who calls each single thing to the common consecration , When rapturously it trembles into tone]1064-who calls each single thing to the common consecration , when rapturously it trembles into tone ? Who sets [our]1061-we wild moods and the storms in time ? [Our]1061-we sad moods , and the still eve ’s crimson glow ? Who showers down all the loveliest flowers of [June]197-june , Where [she]1065-she , the heart ’s beloved , will go ? Who , of a few green leaves in silly twine , Makes toil ’s immortal guerdon , art ’s reward , [Raises the mortal]1066-raises the mortal , draws down the divine ? And so , ’ [Laurence]83-laurence went on , ‘[1067-the bard] if it is to [the bard]1067-the bard that [we]1061-we owe all these fine things , [we]1061-we need surely not fear that [we]1061-we shall be thought bookish if [we]1061-we say that a society can not be really good that does not as a body draw a large amount of its nourishment from [the bard]1067-the bard ’s work . Of course in one sense poetry exists unwritten ; but in the general run of [people]308-people this will never properly awake itself , make itself available , but at the spell of written poetry . Nay , this is true even of [the poet]1070-the poet [himself]1070-the poet . Why else does [he]1070-the poet externalise [his]1070-the poet feelings — give [them]1071-them a body ? As [I]0-i say , however , the general catholic use of poetry is not to make [us]1061-we admire the poetry of poems but discern the poetry of life . [I]0-i [myself]0-i , ’ [Laurence]83-laurence went on , ‘[1070-the poet] am devoted to literature as literature , to poetry as poetry . [I]0-i value it not only because it makes [me]0-i appreciate the originals of the things it deals with , but for itself . [I]0-i often like the description of a sunset better than [I]0-i like a sunset ; [I]0-i do n’t care two straws about [Liberty]198-liberty , but [my]0-i mind is often set all aglow by a good ode to [her]198-liberty . [I]0-i delight in , [I]0-i can talk over , [I]0-i can brood over , the form of a stanza , the music of a line , the turn of a phrase , the flavour of an epithet . Few things give [me]0-i such pleasure for the moment as an apt quotation from [Horace]87-horace or [Shakespeare]195-shakespeare . But this , [I]0-i admit , is a hobby — a private hobby — this distinct literary taste , just as a taste for blue china is , and must certainly not be confused with culture in its deeper and wider sense . ’ ‘[1072-you] Ah , ’ said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose earnestly , ‘[1072-you] do n’t despise this merely literary culture , as [you]1072-you call it , or the pleasure it is to have at command a beautiful quotation . As [I]0-i have been lying on [the bank]1073-the bank here , this afternoon , and looking up into the trees , and watching the blue sky , glancing between the leaves of them — as [I]0-i have been listening to the hum of the insects , or looking out with half - shut eyes towards [the sea]300-the sea across the green rustling shrubs , and the red rose - blossoms , fragments of poetry have been murmuring in [my]0-i memory like a swarm of bees , and have been carrying [my]0-i fancy hither and thither in all manner of swift luxurious ways . The “ spreading favour , ” for instance , of these trees that [we]1075-we sit under , brought just now into [my]0-i mind those magical words of [Virgil]199-virgil ’s — O qui [me]0-i gelidis in vallibus Haemi What a picture there ! What a thrill it sent all through [me]0-i , like a rush of enchanted wind ! In another moment the verse that goes just before , also came to [me]0-i — Virginibus bacchata Lacaenis and into the delicious scene now around [me]0-i — [this beautiful modern garden]1076-this beautiful modern garden — mixed instantly visions of [Greek mountains]1077-greek mountains , and [ragged summits]1078-ragged summits , and choirs of [Laconian maidens maddened with a divine enthusiasm]1079-laconian maidens maddened with a divine enthusiasm , and with fair white vesture wildly floating . Again , another line from the same poem , from the same passage , touched [my]0-i memory , and changed , in a moment , the whole complexion of [my]0-i feelings — Felix qui potuit rerum cognoscere causas . Think of that ! The spirit is whirled away in a moment of time , and set amongst quite new images , quite other sources of excitement . But again , in an instant , the splash of the fountain caught [my]0-i ear , and awoke , [I]0-i scarcely know how , the memory of some lines in one of [Petrarch]200-petrarch ’s Epistles — Soporifero clausam qui murmure vallem and [my]0-i imagination , on the wings of the verses , was borne away floating towards [Vaucluse]52-vaucluse . Think , then , within the space of five minutes how many thoughts and sensations , composite and crowded , can , by the agency of mere literature , enrich the mind , and make life intenser . ’ ‘[0-i] And [I]0-i — ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , smiling,—‘do [you]2277-you see that far - away sail out — on the horizon line?—well , [I]0-i caught [myself]0-i murmuring over a scrap of [Milton]147-milton , only two minutes ago — As when afar at [sea]2278-sea [a fleet descried]2279-a fleet descried Hangs in the clouds , by equinoctial gales Why , [I]0-i could go on capping verses with [you]2277-you the whole afternoon , if [we]2280-us had nothing else to do . But besides this , a knowledge of books as books has got another use . How it enriches conversation , by enabling [us]2280-us to talk by hints and allusions , and to convey so many more meanings than [our]2280-us actual words express . [I]0-i came across an exquisite instance of this the other day , in a book of anecdotes about [the poet [Rogers]201-rogers]2281-the poet rogers , which shows how a familiarity with the scenes even of Greek poetry may give a brilliance to fashionable talk in the nineteenth century . One evening at [Miss Lydia White’s]202-miss lydia white’s — [she]202-miss lydia white’s was [a Tory]2282-a tory , and well known then in society — [a guest who was [a Whig]2284-a whig]2283-a guest who was a whig , said à propos of the depressed state of [[his]2283-a guest who was a whig own party]2285-his own party at the time , “ There is nothing left for [us]2280-us but to sacrifice [a Tory virgin]2286-a tory virgin . ” “ Yes , ” said [Miss Lydia White]203-miss lydia white , “ [I]0-i believe there ’s nothing [the Whigs]2287-the whigs would n’t do to raise the wind . ” But yet , after all , this is not the important thing , and [I]0-i hope [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose will forgive [us]2280-us for having talked so long about it . ’[0-i] ‘ And so [one]1681-one must read a great deal , after all , to be really cultivated , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , in a disappointed tone . ‘ [You]114-leslie ’ve made culture seem so nice , that [I]92-lady ambrose feel positively quite ashamed to think how seldom now [I]92-lady ambrose look at a line of poetry , except , of course , when anything new comes out , that [everybody]393-everybody must read . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ [I]114-leslie do n’t think [you]114-leslie need be afraid on that score , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie . ‘ If society is to be cultivated , [it]2290-it must , no doubt , read a good deal , as a body . But [all its members]942-all its members need not . With [women]492-women especially , nothing startles [me]114-leslie more than when [I]114-leslie find sometimes how very far , if [they]492-women have had any serious experience of [the world]406-the world and life , a very little poetry will go . ’[114-leslie] ‘ [I]93-miss merton expect , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘ that [we]2280-us are naturally more introspective than [men]1704-men , and so , in what concerns [ourselves]2280-us , a very little will make [us]2280-us cultivated ; although [we]2280-us do n’t certainly get so easily as [men]1704-men that indifferent way of looking on life as a whole , which [I]93-miss merton suppose is what [you]2296-you call the dramatic spirit , and which [people]308-people praise so in [Shakespeare]195-shakespeare . But as to what [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie says , [I]93-miss merton have so often [myself]93-miss merton noticed the same thing in [girls]2298-girls — especially at times when [they]2298-girls are passing into womanhood , without having made much of a success of youth . [I]93-miss merton remember [one poor friend of [mine]93-miss merton]2299-one poor friend of mine , whose whole life seemed to become clear to [her]2299-one poor friend of mine through just one line of [Tennyson]160-mr. tennyson ’s — [My]93-miss merton life has crept so long on a broken wing . [I]93-miss merton suppose it was a sort of magic mirror to [her]2299-one poor friend of mine as [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence was saying just now . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ [I]114-leslie , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘ once knew [some one at [Baden]53-baden]2300-some one at baden , who spent half [her]2299-one poor friend of mine time at the tables , as much the observed of [all observers]2301-all observers as [Worth]204-worth and [her]2299-one poor friend of mine own strange beauty could make [her]2299-one poor friend of mine — [she]2299-one poor friend of mine liked being stared at — and who was certainly not [a woman who gave much of [her]2299-one poor friend of mine time to reading]2302-a woman who gave much of her time to reading . [She]2299-one poor friend of mine was very wretched with [[her]2299-one poor friend of mine husband]1841-her husband , and [her]2299-one poor friend of mine name was far from being above the reach of gossip .
