Talking one day to [her]2299-one poor friend of mine in a hardish flippant sort of way — a tone of talk which [she]2299-one poor friend of mine affected to like — [I]114-leslie alluded by some chance to [Francesca di Rimini]205-francesca di rimini in [Dante]206-dante ; and [I]114-leslie shall never forget the tone in which [she]2299-one poor friend of mine exclaimed , “ [Poor Francesca!”—its]207-poor francesca!”—its passion and its pathos . [I]114-leslie was surprised that [she]2299-one poor friend of mine had even looked into [Dante]206-dante : but [she]2299-one poor friend of mine had ; and that one passage had lit up [her]2299-one poor friend of mine whole life for [her]2299-one poor friend of mine — that one picture of [the two lovers]2304-the two lovers “ going for ever on the accursed air . ” ’[114-leslie] ‘ How nice of [you]114-leslie , [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie , ’[106-mrs. sinclair] said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , ‘ to remember [my]106-mrs. sinclair poor verses ! ’[106-mrs. sinclair] ‘ Let [us]2305-us consider , too , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ that poetry does not only enable [us]2305-us to appreciate what [we]2305-us have already experienced , but it puts [us]2305-us in the way of getting new experiences . This was [Wordsworth]117-wordsworth ’s special claim for poetry , that it widened [our]2305-us sympathies — widened them in some new direction — that it was ever giving [us]2305-us , in fact , not new quotations , but new culture . ’[83-laurence] ‘ Ah , here , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘ is a thing that continually occurs to [me]114-leslie . Just consider for moment the wonderful social effect of even so partial a thing as the culture that [Wordsworth]117-wordsworth [himself]117-wordsworth gave [us]2305-us . Consider the effect of it on [a common worldly woman]2306-a common worldly woman — let [her]2306-a common worldly woman be [girl]2307-girl or [matron]2308-matron — who without it would be nothing but [a half mechanical creature]2309-a half mechanical creature , living , as far as [her]2306-a common worldly woman interests went , a wretched hand - to - mouth existence of thin distraction , or eager anxious scheming for [herself]2306-a common worldly woman or [[her]2306-a common worldly woman daughters]2310-her daughters . Cultivate [her]2306-a common worldly woman , [I]114-leslie say , just in this one direction — give [her]2306-a common worldly woman but this one fragment of culture , a love of Nature — and all the mean landscape of [her]2306-a common worldly woman mind will be lit up with a sudden beauty , as the beam of ideal sunshine breaks across it , with its “ light that never was on [sea or land]2311-sea or land . ” [I]114-leslie do n’t say that [such a woman]2312-such a woman will become better for this , but [she]2306-a common worldly woman will become more interesting . In [a girl]1940-a girl , however pretty , what is there to interest [a man]1770-a man if [he]1770-a man reads nothing in [her]1940-a girl face from night to night but that [she]1940-a girl is getting daily more worn and jaded in the search for [a rich husband]2315-a rich husband ? Or even , to go a step higher , in the unthinking , uncultivated flirt , so common in [every class of society]2316-every class of society — what is there in [her]2306-a common worldly woman that [a man]1770-a man will not soon discover to be insipid and wearying ? ’[114-leslie] ‘ Surely , ’[106-mrs. sinclair] remonstrated [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair plaintively , ‘ that rather depends on what [she]2306-a common worldly woman is like . [I]106-mrs. sinclair must stand up for [my]106-mrs. sinclair sex . ’[106-mrs. sinclair] ‘ But give [her]2306-a common worldly woman , ’[114-leslie] [Leslie]114-leslie went on , ‘ one genuine , one disinterested taste , and all is changed . If [I]114-leslie had an audience about [me]114-leslie of [young ladies]2318-young ladies , whom it was not too late to advise — [girls entering on]2319-girls entering on [the world]406-the world , determined to run the worldly course , and to satisfy all the expectations of [the most excellent and lowest - minded of [chaperons]2322-chaperons]2321-the most excellent and lowest - minded of chaperons , [I]114-leslie would say this to them:—I have no doubt [you]2323-you are all ignorant ; of course [you]2323-you are all vain . That to make a brilliant match is [your]2323-you great object , [you]2323-you all avow . A certain sort of flirting , of which the less said the better , is [your]2323-you most disinterested taste . [I]114-leslie know all this ( [I]114-leslie should say ) , and [I]114-leslie ca n’t help it ; nor do [I]114-leslie ask [you]2323-you to alter one of these points for the better . But this [I]114-leslie do ask [you]2323-you to do . Try to add something else to [them]2324-them . Try to win for [yourselves]2323-you one taste of a truer and deeper sort . Study [Wordsworth]117-wordsworth , and some parts of [Shelley]208-shelley ; open out [your]2323-you sympathies , by [their]2324-them aid , in just one direction . Learn to love [the sea]300-the sea , and [the woods]2326-the woods , and the wild flowers , with all their infinite changes of scent , and colour , and sound — [the purple moor]2327-the purple moor , the brown mountain stream , the rolling mists , the wild smell of the heather . Let these things grow to “ haunt [you]2323-you like a passion , ” learn in this way the art of desiring [You]2323-you ’ll perhaps find it a little dull at first ; but go on , and do n’t be disheartened ; and then — by - and - by — by - and - by , go and look in the looking - glass , and study [your]2323-you own face . Has n’t some new look , [child]1723-child , come into [your]2323-you eyes , and given [them]2324-them an expression — a something that [they]2324-them wanted before ? Smile . Has n’t [your]2323-you smile some strange meaning in it that it never used to have ? [You]2323-you are a little more melancholy , perhaps . But no matter . The melancholy is worth its cost . [You]2323-you are now a mystery . [Men]1704-men ca n’t see through [you]2323-you at a glance as [they]1704-men did ; and so , as [Sterne]209-sterne says , “ [you]2323-you have [their]1704-men curiosity on [your]2323-you side , ” and that alone — even that will have increased [your]2323-you value tenfold in [our]2330-our Babylonian marriage - market . ’[114-leslie] ‘ Well , [Mr. Leslie]114-leslie , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose with severe gravity , ‘ if that ’s the way [you]114-leslie ’d talk to [young ladies]2318-young ladies , [I]92-lady ambrose should be very careful [you]114-leslie never spoke to any that [I]92-lady ambrose had anything to do with . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ [Many people]2332-many people , [I]114-leslie know , ’[114-leslie] [Leslie]114-leslie went on , passing by the rebuke , ‘ think that books and culture are a kind of substitute for life , and that [the real masters in the art of living]2333-the real masters in the art of living have no need for [this poor pis - aller]2334-this poor pis - aller . [They]1080-the men of culture only drive four - in - hand , or shoot , or dance , or run away with [[their]1080-the men of culture friends]2196-their friends ’[114-leslie] wives . But no mistake can be greater . Culture is not a substitute for life , but the key to it . It is really to [the men of culture]1080-the men of culture , to [the men who have read and who have thought , that all exercise]1081-the men who have read and who have thought , that all exercise , all distractions , mental or bodily , moral or immoral , yield [their]1080-the men of culture finer keener pleasures . [They]1080-the men of culture are [the men that [husbands]1083-husbands dread for [their]1083-husbands wives]1082-the men that husbands dread for their wives , and [that fascinating people]1084-that fascinating people find fascinating . ’ [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose much disapproved of the tone of this speech ; but none the less , in a certain mysterious way , did it insidiously increase [her]92-lady ambrose appreciation of the value of culture ; and [she]92-lady ambrose felt that with [Laurence]83-laurence at any rate [she]92-lady ambrose most thoroughly agreed , when [he]0-i said by way of summing up , ‘[1080-the men of culture] And so now [I]0-i think [we]1085-we see what culture is , and the reason why it is essential to good society . [We]1085-we see that much as it depends on books , life is really the great thing it has to do with . It is the passions , the interests , the relations , the absurdities of life that it fits [us]1085-we to see into , to taste , to discriminate . And [I]0-i think [we]1085-we see , too , that not only is culture essential to good society , but good society also is essential to culture , and that there was therefore very good reason for the exclusiveness [we]1085-we began with . For in the first place [I]0-i expect it requires certain natural advantages of position to look at and overlook life in that sympathetic and yet self - possessed way , which alone can give [us]1085-we a complete view of it . And in [the next place]1086-the next place , the more [we]1085-we discern in life , the more social polish shall [we]1085-we want to do justice to [our]1085-we discernment ; and not polish only , but those far subtler things , tone and balance as well . [I]0-i think it was the late [Lord Lytton]210-lord lytton who remarked in one of [his]210-lord lytton books , what an offensive thing gaiety was sure to be in [any woman]1087-any woman except one of the most perfect breeding . So too with humour — the greater sense of humour [a well - bred man]1088-a well - bred man has , the more delightful [he]1088-a well - bred man is ; the greater sense of humour [a vulgar man]1089-a vulgar man has , the more intolerable [he]1088-a well - bred man is . ’ The measure of [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose ’s assent was now almost complete . It remained , however , for [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair to give the finishing touch . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i remember , ’ [she]106-mrs. sinclair said softly and regretfully , ‘[0-i] [a friend of [mine]0-i]485-a friend of mine — [he]485-a friend of mine was killed afterwards , [poor man , in a duel near [Dresden]54-dresden — who once , when [he]485-a friend of mine was down for some weeks in [the country fishing]1092-the country fishing]1091-poor man , in a duel near dresden — who once , when he was down for some weeks in the country fishing , fell desperately in love with [a certain rector ’s daughter , who sang , and painted , and read German]1093-a certain rector ’s daughter , who sang , and painted , and read german , and had [a beautiful figure as well]1094-a beautiful figure as well . [The mother]1095-the mother at once saw what was in the wind , and asked [him]485-a friend of mine directly to come and lunch at [the rectory]1096-the rectory . And there three things happened . First , [the mother]1095-the mother began telling [him]485-a friend of mine what very superior society there was in [the neighbouring local town]1098-the neighbouring local town ; “ In fact , [its]1099-its tone , ” [she]1095-the mother said , “ is almost like that of [a cathedral town]1100-a cathedral town . ” Then [the lovely daughter]1101-the lovely daughter asked [him]485-a friend of mine if [he]485-a friend of mine was partial to boiled chicken ; and then , a little later on — it was this that quite finished [him]485-a friend of mine , for the two first shocks [he]485-a friend of mine said [he]485-a friend of mine might have got over — in answer to some little common joke or other that [he]485-a friend of mine made , [she]1101-the lovely daughter told [him]485-a friend of mine , with a sort of arch smile — what do [you]485-a friend of mine think ? why , that [he]485-a friend of mine was saucy . ’ ‘[1101-the lovely daughter] [I]0-i confess , ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , laughing , ‘[1101-the lovely daughter] that it would take a very great deal of charm of some sort to make [one]1681-one get over that . At any rate , it ’s a comfort to think that [the young ladies in [[our]1104-we new Republic]890-our new republic]1103-the young ladies in our new republic wo n’t call [[their]1103-the young ladies in our new republic admirers]1106-their admirers “ saucy . ” ’ ‘[1103-the young ladies in our new republic] Well , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[1103-the young ladies in our new republic] and so [we]1104-we have got thus far — [we]1104-we have made [our]1104-we ideal society as highly bred , as highly educated , as polished , as sparkling , as graceful , as easy , as dignified , as [we]1104-we can possibly imagine it . And now , what next ? ’ There was a moment ’s pause . ‘[0-i] What [I]0-i should want in [a Utopia]1107-a utopia , ’ [Allen]101-allen broke in abruptly , ‘[0-i] would be something definite for [the people]350-the people to do , each in [his]350-the people own walk of life . What [I]0-i should want would be some honest , definite , straightforward , religious belief that [we]1104-we might all live by , and that would connect what [we]1104-we did and went through here with something more important elsewhere . Without this , to start with , ’ [he]0-i said , half sadly and half coldly , ‘[1109-you] all life seems to [me]0-i a mockery . ’ ‘[1109-you] And are [you]1109-you quite sure , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , with a slight sigh , ‘[1109-you] that it is not a mockery ? ’ [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke here saw an opening for which [he]83-laurence had long been waiting . ‘[83-laurence] [[MY]0-i dear]892-my dear [Laurence]83-laurence , ’ [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke began , ‘[83-laurence] of course human life is a mockery , if [you]83-laurence leave out the one thing in it that is of real importance . And it is because [you]83-laurence have done this , that [Lord Allen]101-allen thinks that culture is so little worth caring for , though [I]0-i doubt , by the way , if [he]101-allen expressed quite accurately what [I]0-i conclude [him]101-allen to have meant . However , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , clearing [his]99-mr. luke throat , and looking round at [the general company]2336-the general company , ‘[101-allen] what was said about culture just now was perfectly right — perfectly right , and really capitally illustrated — as far as it went . The only fault was that , as [I]0-i say , the most important point in the matter was entirely left out . It is quite true that culture is , as [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence observed so happily , the sensitising of the mental palate — the making it a good taster . But a taster of what ? Not only of social absurdities , or love affairs , or beautiful scenery , but of morality , of righteousness , of Christianity . The really profound work of culture is to make [us]1111-we judges of these — judges able to tell in an instant real righteousness and real Christianity from pseudo - righteousness and pseudo - Christianity , so that [we]1111-we may swallow the true like the healing water of life , and reject the false like a sample of bad claret — that [we]1111-we may have , in fact , just the same horror of any doctrine or dogma that is contrary to sweet reason ( such , for instance , ’ [he]83-laurence said confidentially to [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , ‘[93-miss merton] as that of eternal punishment ) that [we]1111-we have for [young ladies who call [[their]1112-their friends]2196-their friends “ saucy , ” or for [young ladies]2318-young ladies ’ mothers who look on [[a bishop]313-a bishop ’s palace]2339-a bishop ’s palace as a focus of the most polite society]2337-young ladies who call their friends “ saucy , ” or for young ladies ’ mothers who look on a bishop ’s palace as a focus of the most polite society . So [I]93-miss merton think , if [you]2340-you only all recognise this , that culture includes — in fact , essentially is — the discernment of true righteousness , of true morality , [you]2340-you need none of [you]2340-you fear that to [a really cultivated society]2341-a really cultivated society life will be in any danger of becoming a mockery . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ [I]93-miss merton was sorry , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton in a low tone to [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ to hear [you]83-laurence say that just now , because [I]93-miss merton know [you]83-laurence do n’t mean it . ’[93-miss merton] [Laurence]83-laurence , who had been sitting a little above [her]93-miss merton on [the bank]1073-the bank , moved quietly down , and placed [himself]83-laurence at [her]93-miss merton side . ‘ [You]93-miss merton make [me]83-laurence feel ashamed of [myself]83-laurence , ’[83-laurence] [he]83-laurence said to [her]93-miss merton , ‘ when [you]93-miss merton speak like this . ’[83-laurence] There was something in [his]83-laurence manner which a little embarrassed [Miss Merton]93-miss merton . [She]93-miss merton looked down , and said nothing for a moment ; and then , not having quite command of [her]93-miss merton voice , [she]93-miss merton answered [him]83-laurence in a tone rather louder than [she]93-miss merton intended . ‘ Well , ’[93-miss merton] [she]93-miss merton said , ‘ and do n’t [you]83-laurence think that some definite faith or other is needed by [the world]406-the world ? ’[93-miss merton] ‘ Yes , [I]1017-somebody think so ; [I]1017-somebody think so . [I]1017-somebody entirely agree with [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ’[1017-somebody] exclaimed [somebody]1017-somebody . But it was not [Laurence]83-laurence . To the surprise of [everyone]347-everyone , it was [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders . All eyes were turned on [him]102-mr. saunders . ‘ Will [you]102-mr. saunders allow [me]102-mr. saunders , ’[102-mr. saunders] [he]102-mr. saunders said , looking round [him]102-mr. saunders with a nervous eagerness , as though doubtful if [he]102-mr. saunders should gain a hearing , ‘ will [you]102-mr. saunders allow [me]102-mr. saunders to make a few observations here — it will only take a moment — to remind [you]102-mr. saunders of just a few things which [I]102-mr. saunders think ought not to be lost sight of ? Well , ’[102-mr. saunders] [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders went on , as [he]102-mr. saunders seemed to have secured the ear of [the house]1761-the house , ‘ in the first place as to history , just one word . The main use of history , which [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence forgot altogether to mention , is of course , as [Comte]211-comte has so well established , to teach [us]102-mr. saunders [his]211-comte philosophy of it — to show [us]102-mr. saunders , in other words , how entirely non compos mentis [the world]406-the world was till [our]102-mr. saunders time , and that it is only in the present century that [it]406-the world has acquired the power of passing a reasonable judgment . And next , as to facts ; mere facts , as facts , [I]102-mr. saunders think quite as useless as [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence does , except for one reason . And that reason is the way in which from every side [they]2344-they confute , give the lie to , annihilate , the pretensions of revealed religion , and of the myths which it calls its history . This , however , by the way . It was not the chief thing that [I]102-mr. saunders wanted to say to [you]102-mr. saunders . Now , [you]102-mr. saunders all , ’[102-mr. saunders] [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders went on , holding up [his]102-mr. saunders forefinger and addressing [the company]384-the company , ‘ propose to form a picture of what [the world]406-the world ought to be — what [I]102-mr. saunders suppose [you]102-mr. saunders hope it will be ; and [you]102-mr. saunders say , and very rightly , that the great secret is that it should appreciate properly the pleasures of human life . But , please mark this , [you]102-mr. saunders have quite ignored the most important thing of all — the vast change that all these pleasures are undergoing , that the whole aspect of life is undergoing , beneath the touch of modern thought and modern philosophy ; nay — and this indeed is the special point [I]102-mr. saunders want to lay stress upon — [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke just now even used those obsolete and misleading words , righteousness and morality , soiled by so many unworthy associations . By the way , ’[102-mr. saunders] [he]102-mr. saunders exclaimed , stopping suddenly and looking round [him]102-mr. saunders , ‘ [I]102-mr. saunders suppose [I]102-mr. saunders may speak the truth freely , as [I]102-mr. saunders know well enough that all to whom [my]102-mr. saunders vaticinations would be unwelcome are sure to mistake [me]102-mr. saunders for [a Cassandra]2346-a cassandra . ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ Mistake [him]99-mr. luke for a what ? ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , in a loud undertone . ‘ [She]2346-a cassandra was [a beautiful young unfortunate]2347-a beautiful young unfortunate , ’[106-mrs. sinclair] whispered [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair confidentially , ‘ who was betrayed by the god [Apollo]212-apollo . ’[106-mrs. sinclair] [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders was conscious [he]102-mr. saunders had raised a smile . [He]102-mr. saunders considered it a full licence to proceed . ‘ Well , ’[102-mr. saunders] [he]102-mr. saunders said , ‘ as [Miss Merton]93-miss merton remarked a moment ago , some definite faith is needed by [the world]406-the world ; and , as [I]102-mr. saunders now deliberately declare , some definite faith it will have — some one definite faith that will tolerate no dissent from it ; and it will have this before fifty years are over . ’[102-mr. saunders] [Everyone]347-everyone stared at [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , [everyone]347-everyone except [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , who simply smiled at the sky , and said , with an air of suppressed pleasantry , ‘ [I]99-mr. luke had imagined that [[our]2349-we young friend]526-our young friend ’s motto was freedom . ’[99-mr. luke] [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders was nettled at this beyond description . With a vindictive quickness [he]102-mr. saunders fixed [his]102-mr. saunders eyes upon [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke . ‘ Sight is free , ’[102-mr. saunders] [he]102-mr. saunders said , uttering [his]102-mr. saunders words very slowly , as if each one were a dagger in itself , and could give [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke a separate smart ; ‘ sight is free , ’[102-mr. saunders] [he]102-mr. saunders said , ‘ and yet the sight of [all healthy men]2351-all healthy men , [I]102-mr. saunders conceive , is in agreement . It differs , [I]102-mr. saunders admit , when [our]2349-we eyes are dim with tears of hysterical feeling ; or when [we]2349-we are drunk ; or when [we]2349-we are fighting — in this last case , [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , [I]102-mr. saunders am told [we]2349-we are often visited with illuminations of a truly celestial radiance — but it is surely not such exceptional vision as this that [you]99-mr. luke praise as free . And it is just the same , ’[102-mr. saunders] said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders triumphantly , ‘ with the mind . The minds of [men]1704-men will never have been so free as on that not - distant day when [they]1704-men shall all agree . And what will that agreement result in ? Why , in the utter banishment , the utter destruction — [I]102-mr. saunders know no word strong enough to express [my]102-mr. saunders meaning — of all mystery and of all mysticism , and consequently of that supposed inscrutable difference between right and wrong , which has been made , in the hands of [the priests]2353-the priests , one of the most hideous engines of terror that were ever employed to degrade and crush [mankind]696-mankind . Right and wrong , indeed ! Righteousness and morality ! There is something insidious in their very sound . No — “ useful , ” “ healthful , ” “ serviceable , ” “ pleasant”—these will be the words of the future . [Emancipated man]2355-emancipated man will know no wrong , save unhealthiness and unpleasantness . [That most treacherous handmaid of priestcraft]2356-that most treacherous handmaid of priestcraft , poetry , which , professing to heighten the lights of life , did , in reality , only deepen its shadows , will delude [him]2355-emancipated man no longer — [she]2356-that most treacherous handmaid of priestcraft will be gone — gone for ever . Science , [the liberator of humanity]2357-the liberator of humanity , will have cast its light upon [her]2356-that most treacherous handmaid of priestcraft ; and the lying vision will vanish . But why do [I]102-mr. saunders talk of poetry ? Is not that , and every other evil — reverence , faith , mysticism , humility , and [all the unclean company]2358-all the unclean company — comprised in this one word , Religion ? Well , let religion — [the ancien régime of [the world]406-the world]2359-the ancien régime of the world — retire , as it has done , to its Versailles , and fence itself round for a little with [[its]2359-the ancien régime of the world mercenary soldiers]2361-its mercenary soldiers ! [The Paris of [the world]406-the world]2362-the paris of the world is , at any rate , left free — and there the Revolution of Humanity is begun . Science leads [it]2359-the ancien régime of the world , and in another fifty years there will not be another religion left . Surely most here must know this , ’[102-mr. saunders] continued [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ‘ although [they]393-everybody may perhaps forget it sometimes . But the fact is notorious , and [I]102-mr. saunders really think — ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ Sir ! ’[102-mr. saunders] Where did that sudden , solemn exclamation come from — that single syllable at which the music of [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders ’s voice , ‘ like a fountain ’s sickening pulse , ’[102-mr. saunders] retired in a moment . Who had spoken ? The sound surprised [everybody]393-everybody . It was [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton — [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , with a face all aglow with feeling , beneath [his]110-mr. stockton picturesque wide - awake hat , and holding in [his]110-mr. stockton hand a white pocket - handkerchief bordered with pale blue . ‘ Perhaps , ’[110-mr. stockton] [he]110-mr. stockton continued , looking slowly round [him]110-mr. stockton , ‘ [I]110-mr. stockton , as [a man of science]2364-a man of science , who have been [a patient apprentice]2365-a patient apprentice at [my]110-mr. stockton work for six - and - twenty years , may be allowed to give some opinion on this matter . Destroy religion ! Destroy poetry ! ’[110-mr. stockton] [he]110-mr. stockton exclaimed , in [his]110-mr. stockton rich , bell - like voice , that was now resonant with an indignant melancholy . ‘ Will science destroy either of these precious and exquisite heritages of [the human race]1783-the human race ? Will it extinguish one profound , one ennobling , one devout feeling ? Will it blight that rich culture on which the present age so justly prides itself ? [I]110-mr. stockton have followed science for six - and - twenty years , [I]110-mr. stockton speak therefore from experience ; and [I]110-mr. stockton boldly answer “ No . ” How indeed should it ? [I]110-mr. stockton know , [I]110-mr. stockton deplore , and [I]110-mr. stockton trust also forgive , the common notion that it does . But how can that notion have arisen ? That is what puzzles [me]110-mr. stockton . Is not science essentially religious , essentially poetical — nay , does it not deepen quite boundlessly the religion and poetry already existing in [the world]406-the world , and fuse the two together , as they were never fused before ? Does it narrow [our]2368-we notions of life ’s wonder and dignity to peer into [the abyss of being]2369-the abyss of being , and learn something of the marvellous laws of things — to discover the same mysterious Something in a snow - flake , in the scent of a rose , in [the “ topmost star of unascended heaven]2370-the “ topmost star of unascended heaven , ” and in some prayer or aspiration in the soul of [man]1888-man ? True it is that this wondrous All is Matter , and that all matter is atoms in its last analysis . No idle metaphysics have clouded [my]110-mr. stockton brain , so [I]110-mr. stockton have been able to see these things clearly — ’[110-mr. stockton] ‘ Yes , yes , yes , ’[102-mr. saunders] cried [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , recovering [himself]102-mr. saunders , [his]102-mr. saunders voice tremulous with excitement , ‘ [I]102-mr. saunders know all that . [I]102-mr. saunders know that in [their]2372-their last analysis a pig and [a martyr , a prayer and a beef - steak]2373-a martyr , a prayer and a beef - steak , are just the same — atoms and atomic movement . [We]2368-we , [the younger generation of thinkers]2374-the younger generation of thinkers , accept all the premisses [you]102-mr. saunders give [us]2368-we without a moment ’s question . [We]2368-we only reason boldly and honestly on them , and [I]102-mr. saunders defy [you]102-mr. saunders to prove — [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , [sir]499-sir , if [you]102-mr. saunders will only listen to [me]102-mr. saunders — ’[102-mr. saunders] But there was little chance of that . Interrupted only for a moment , and whilst [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders was yet speaking , [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton ’s eloquence swept on . ‘ Consider [ourselves]2368-we , ’[110-mr. stockton] [he]110-mr. stockton said , ‘ consider the race of [men]1704-men , and note the truly celestial light that science throws on that . [We]2368-we have ascended , ’[110-mr. stockton] said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton ; ‘ noble thought ! [We]2368-we have not descended . [We]2368-we are rising towards heaven , [we]2368-we have not fallen from it . Yes — [we]2368-we , with attributes so like [an angel]2377-an angel ’s , with understanding so like [a God’s]2378-a god’s — to this height [we]2368-we have already risen . Who knows what future may not be in store for [us]2368-we ? And then , on the other hand , when the awestruck eye gazes , guided by science , through the “ dark backward and abysm of time , ” and sees that all that is has unfolded itself , unmoved and unbidden , ( astounding thought ! ) from a brainless , senseless , lifeless gas — the cosmic vapour , as [we]2368-we call it — and that it may , for aught [we]2368-we know , one day return to it — [I]110-mr. stockton say , when [we]2368-we realise , when [we]2368-we truly make [our]2368-we own , this stupendous truth , must not [our]2368-we feelings , ’[110-mr. stockton] said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , letting [his]110-mr. stockton eyes rest on [Miss Merton]93-miss merton ’s with an appealing melancholy—‘our feelings at such moments be religious ? Are [they]1123-they not Religion ? ’ ‘[110-mr. stockton] But , ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘[110-mr. stockton] there is nothing religious in a gas . [I]0-i do n’t see how anything religious can come out of it . ’ ‘[0-i] Perfectly right ! ’ chuckled [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , faintly clapping [his]102-mr. saunders hands . ‘[0-i] Nothing can come out of the sack but what ’s in it . [Miss Merton]93-miss merton ’s perfectly right . ’ ‘[93-miss merton] Ah , [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ’ [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton continued , ‘[93-miss merton] do n’t be frightened by the mere sound of the word matter . For who knows what matter is’—(‘Then , why talk about it ? ’ shrilled [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , unheeded)—‘that [great Alpha and Omega of [the Universe]55-the universe]2379-great alpha and omega of the universe ? ’[110-mr. stockton] [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton went on . ‘ And do n’t wrong [me]110-mr. stockton by thinking that [I]110-mr. stockton “ palter with [you]93-miss merton in a double sense , ” and that [I]110-mr. stockton am not using the word religion in its truest , its profoundest signification . Do [you]93-miss merton think , [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , for instance , that [I]110-mr. stockton can not feel with [you]93-miss merton , when , stirred to [your]93-miss merton inmost soul by some strain of [Mozart]213-mozart or [Beethoven]214-beethoven , [you]93-miss merton kneel before [your]93-miss merton sacrificial altar , whilst [the acolyte]2380-the acolyte exalts [the Host]2381-the host , and murmur with bowed head [your]93-miss merton litany to [[your]93-miss merton beautiful Virgin]2382-your beautiful virgin ? [His]110-mr. stockton acquaintance with Catholic ritual , and the fact of thus finding [herself]1124-she elected , without any merit of [her]1124-she own , as the special object of [so great a man]1125-so great a man ’s eloquence , produced in [Miss Merton]93-miss merton an unfortunate sense of absurdity , and in another moment [she]1124-she was conscious of nothing but a most inappropriate desire to laugh . [She]1124-she compromised with [her]1124-she facial muscles , however , and only gave a smile , which [she]1124-she trusted would pass muster as one of grave enquiry . [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton thought that it was so , and went on ; but , unknown to [himself]110-mr. stockton , [he]110-mr. stockton felt all the while that it was not so , and [his]110-mr. stockton enthusiasm , [he]110-mr. stockton could not tell why , became somewhat more polemical . ‘ Does science , then , ’[110-mr. stockton] [he]110-mr. stockton proceeded , ‘ rob [us]2384-us of one iota of religious feeling , or degrade [our]2384-us notions of life ’s measureless solemnity ? Nay , it is rather the flippant conceptions of theology that would do that , by connecting everything with an eternal Personality — a personality so degraded as to have some connection with [ourselves]2384-us . The prayer of [the theologian , “ cabined , cribbed , confined ” in spoken words]2385-the theologian , “ cabined , cribbed , confined ” in spoken words , is directed to [a Being that Science]2386-a being that science can make no room for , and would not want , if [she]2386-a being that science could . [He]110-mr. stockton is silent if [you]2388-you ask [him]110-mr. stockton , for [his]110-mr. stockton answer would be beyond the reach of words . Even to hint at its nature [he]110-mr. stockton would feel were a profanity . ’[110-mr. stockton] ‘ Do [you]110-mr. stockton know , [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , this time with a polite meekness , ‘ all this rather bewilders [me]93-miss merton . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ And so it does [me]110-mr. stockton , ’[110-mr. stockton] said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton much pleased with [Miss Merton]93-miss merton ’s manner ; ‘ and this august bewilderment , which gives fulness and tone to [our]2384-us existence , but which [we]2384-us can neither analyse nor comprehend — to [me]110-mr. stockton comes in one shape , to [you]2388-you in another , and is — religion . In the name , then , of all genuine science , and of [all serious scientific men]2389-all serious scientific men , let [man]1888-man keep , [I]110-mr. stockton say , ’[110-mr. stockton] said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , looking round [him]110-mr. stockton , ‘ this precious and ennobling heritage — let [him]1888-man keep it and shape it ever anew , to meet [his]1888-man ever - changing and deepening needs . In [my]110-mr. stockton dream of the future [I]110-mr. stockton see religions not diminished , but multiplied , growing more and more richly diverse , as they sink deeper into individual souls . Surely , science , then , is not come to destroy the past , but to fulfil it — and [I]110-mr. stockton confess [I]110-mr. stockton can [myself]110-mr. stockton see no better way of discovering what [we]2384-us desire in the future than by the charming analysis [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence has been giving [us]2384-us of what [we]2384-us most admire in the present . ’[110-mr. stockton] ‘ See , ’[103-donald gordon] said [Donald Gordon]103-donald gordon softly , ‘ here is science on the one side offering [us]2384-us all religions , and on the other none . ’[103-donald gordon] ‘ Heigho ! ’[99-mr. luke] sighed [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , very loud ; ‘ Let [us]1126-us agree about conduct first , and quarrel about theology afterwards . ’[99-mr. luke] ‘ Precisely , ’[110-mr. stockton] resumed [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , to [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke ’s extreme annoyance — [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke [himself]99-mr. luke having still much to say , and considering that [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton did but darken counsel by interrupting him—‘Mr . [Luke]99-mr. luke is perfectly right . ’ ( ‘[99-mr. luke] [I]0-i should like to know how [you]110-mr. stockton know that , ’ thought [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke . ) ‘[110-mr. stockton] Let [us]1126-us agree about conduct — morality , by - the - by , is the plainer word — that is the great thing . Let [us]1126-us agree about the noble and the beautiful . Let [us]1126-us agree heroically to follow truth — ay , truth ; let [us]1126-us follow that , [I]0-i say , picking [our]1126-us way step by step , and not look where [we]1126-us are going . Let [us]1126-us follow — what can [I]0-i add to this?—the incomparable life of [the great Founder of Christianity]1127-the great founder of christianity . Yes , [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , entertaining the views that [I]0-i do , [I]0-i say the incomparable life . Such is the message of science to [the world]406-the world ; such is the instinct of culture when enriched and quickened by science . ’ This was literally taking the bread out of [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke ’s mouth . Not only was it repeating what [he]99-mr. luke had said before , but it was anticipating , in a formless undisciplined way , the very thing that [he]99-mr. luke was going to say again And [the man who had robbed [him]99-mr. luke thus was [a mere Philistine]2392-a mere philistine — [a mere man of science who was without even a smattering of Greek or Hebrew]2393-a mere man of science who was without even a smattering of greek or hebrew , and who thought sensori - motor nerves and spontaneous generation more important subjects than [Marcion]215-marcion ’s Gospel or the Psalms of [David]190-david]2391-the man who had robbed him thus was a mere philistine — a mere man of science who was without even a smattering of greek or hebrew , and who thought sensori - motor nerves and spontaneous generation more important subjects than marcion ’s gospel or the psalms of david . For once in [his]99-mr. luke life [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke was for the moment completely silenced . [Laurence]83-laurence however somewhat soothed [him]99-mr. luke , by replying to [him]99-mr. luke , not to [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , ‘[0-i] Yes , [I]0-i believe [I]0-i was wrong after all ; and that true culture will really prevent [us]1129-we from looking on life as a mere mockery . ’ [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke was going to have answered ; but , worse even than [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton ’s , [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders ’s hated accents now got the start of [him]99-mr. luke . ‘[1130-you] One word more , ’ [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders exclaimed , ‘[1130-you] one plain word if [you]1130-you will allow [me]0-i . All this talk about Religion , Poetry , Morality , implies this — or it implies nothing — the recognition of some elements of inscrutable mystery in [our]1129-we lives and conduct ; and to every mystery , to all mystery , science is the sworn , [the deadly foe]1131-the deadly foe . What [she]1132-she is daily more and more branding into [man]1888-man ’s consciousness is , that nothing is inscrutable that can practically concern [man]1888-man . Use , pleasure , self - preservation — on these everything depends ; on these rocks of ages are all rules of conduct founded : and now that [we]1129-we have dug down to these foundations , what an entirely changed fabric of life shall [we]1129-we build upon them . Right and wrong , [I]0-i again say , are entirely misleading terms ; and the superstition that sees an unfathomable gulf yawning between them is the great bar to all healthful progress . ’ ‘[0-i] And [I]0-i say , on the contrary , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , replying very suavely to [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders ’s vehemence , ‘[0-i] that it is on the recognition of this mysterious and unfathomable gulf that the whole of the higher pleasures of life depend — and the higher vicious pleasures as much as , if not more than , the virtuous . ’ [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose started at this . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i am not vicious , ’ said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders snappishly . ‘[0-i] When [I]0-i call pleasure the one criterion of action , [I]0-i am thinking of very different pleasures from what [you]1130-you think [I]0-i mean . ’ ‘[0-i] What is [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders ’s notion of the most passionate pleasure ? ’ said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair bewitchingly . ‘[102-mr. saunders] [I]0-i agree with [my]0-i great forerunner [Hobbes]216-hobbes ’ said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ‘[216-hobbes] that the strongest of all pleasures are those arising from the gratification of curiosity ; and [he]216-hobbes is [the real ethical philosopher who subordinates all other appetites to this]1135-the real ethical philosopher who subordinates all other appetites to this , like [Bacon]217-bacon , who lost [his]217-bacon life through pursuing a scientific experiment , or ’ — [he]102-mr. saunders said pausing to think of another example — ‘[216-hobbes] Like [[Bluebeard]218-bluebeard ’s wives]1136-bluebeard ’s wives ? ’ enquired [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair naïvely . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i ’m afraid [I]1137-i never give [[my]1137-i husband]1791-my husband [his]1791-my husband highest pleasure ; for [I]1137-i never let [him]1791-my husband , ’[1137-i] [she]1137-i added in a regretful whisper , ‘ open [my]1137-i letters , although [I]1137-i read all [his]1791-my husband . But , [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ’[1137-i] [she]1137-i said , ‘ if [you]102-mr. saunders are so fond of curiosity , [you]102-mr. saunders must have some mystery to excite it . ’[1137-i] ‘ Yes , ’[102-mr. saunders] said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ‘ but mystery is a fox for [us]2395-us to hunt and shoot ; not [a God]1992-a god to hunt and shoot [us]2395-us . ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ Fancy , ’[92-lady ambrose] exclaimed [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose in horror , ‘ shooting a fox ! what sacrilege ! ’[92-lady ambrose] This remark , so entirely spontaneous , and so entirely unexpected , produced a general laugh , in which all joined but [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders [himself]102-mr. saunders , and [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert . ‘ Well , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence at length , when the chorus had subsided , ‘ may [I]83-laurence read a certain letter of [[my]83-laurence uncle]2163-my uncle ’s to [myself]83-laurence , which is printed in this very book [I]83-laurence have here ? It was running in [my]83-laurence mind just now , and is about the very matter [we]2395-us were speaking of — the connection of religions , of Christian morality , with all the higher pleasures of life . ’[83-laurence] ‘ Very good , ’[102-mr. saunders] said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders . ‘ Read what [you]2398-you please . [I]102-mr. saunders can only say that [I]102-mr. saunders have at this moment in [my]102-mr. saunders portmanteau an analysis [I]102-mr. saunders have made of all the Christian moral sentiments , in which [I]102-mr. saunders trace every one of them to such disgusting or paltry origins as shall at once rob [them]2399-them of all [their]2399-them pestilent prestige . [I]102-mr. saunders begin with the main root , [the great first parent of all these evils]2400-the great first parent of all these evils , the conception of [God]115-god , which [I]102-mr. saunders show may have arisen in seventy - three different ways , each one more commonplace than the other . By - and - by , if [you]2398-you will not fear to confront the document , [I]102-mr. saunders will show it to [you]2398-you . ’[102-mr. saunders] [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke meanwhile had seen [his]99-mr. luke way to bringing [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton ’s true ignorance home to [him]99-mr. luke , and had been regretting to [him]110-mr. stockton , in tones of insidious confidence , that hardly enough stress had been laid just now on the necessity of really wide reading—‘an intimacy , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘[99-mr. luke] with the great literatures of [the world]406-the world — a knowledge and comparison of the best things that have been said and thought , in all the various ages , on the great questions of life , without which , ’ [he]0-i added , ‘[99-mr. luke] as [you]110-mr. stockton and [I]0-i know , that discrimination between right and wrong that [we]1139-we were speaking of just now , can never be anything more than a make - believe . ’ Nor did [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke seem at all aware , as [he]99-mr. luke was thus proceeding , that [Laurence]83-laurence had found [his]0-i place , and had already begun to read , as follows : ‘[77-otho] As [I]0-i grow old , [[my]0-i dear]892-my dear [Otho]77-otho , [I]0-i am coming to think over many things that [I]0-i have hitherto thought too little about , and , amongst others , the great mystery of Christianity . ’ At this point , however , [Laurence]83-laurence and [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke were both interrupted by an entirely unforeseen event . [LAURENCE]83-laurence had just got to the end of the first sentence , and [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke at the same time was just reminding [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton with some unction how impossible it was for [us]1139-we to value properly that curious mixture of trumpery and elevation , the ‘[1141-you] Apocalypse ’ of [John]162-john , unless [we]1139-we compared it with a very kindred work , [the ‘[1141-you] Pastor ’ of [Hermas]56-hermas]2401-the ‘ pastor ’ of hermas , when [a servant]2402-a servant startled [Laurence]83-laurence by announcing in [his]2402-a servant ear the arrival of [the vicar of [the parish]2404-the parish]2403-the vicar of the parish . [Everyone in dismay]2405-everyone in dismay looked ; and there , standing a pace away in the background , [the stranger]2406-the stranger was . [He]2406-the stranger was [an old man , very tall and spare , with an ascetic aspect , but with a carriage dignified though slightly stooping , and with severe , piercing eyes]2407-an old man , very tall and spare , with an ascetic aspect , but with a carriage dignified though slightly stooping , and with severe , piercing eyes . [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose at once bought [himself]100-mr. rose golden opinions of [Lady Grace]89-lady grace by helping [[her]89-lady grace page]2410-her page , [a pretty boy with light curling hair , to arrange some tumblers on the grass]2411-a pretty boy with light curling hair , to arrange some tumblers on the grass . [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton felt [his]110-mr. stockton spirits suddenly rise , and began asking [Lady Violet]98-lady violet gresham what [she]98-lady violet gresham thought of [[their]2412-their new Republic]2413-their new republic as far as [they]2412-their had got with it . ‘[1141-you] [I]0-i do n’t know , ’ [she]98-lady violet gresham answered petulantly . ‘[1141-you] As far as [I]0-i can see , [you]1141-you want [everyone]347-everyone to read a great many books and to have only one opinion . For [my]0-i part , [I]0-i hate [people who do the one]1143-people who do the one , and a society that does the other . ’ ‘[1143-people who do the one] What [a charming girl]1144-a charming girl [Lady Violet]98-lady violet gresham is ! ’ said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton to [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , as [he]110-mr. stockton stood by the tea table . ‘[98-lady violet gresham] Such penetration ! such vivacity ! such originality ! ’ ‘[98-lady violet gresham] What beautiful sermons [he]1145-he does preach , to be sure ! ’ murmured [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘[1145-he] Who ? Who ? ’ enquired several voices . ‘[1145-he] Why , [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘[219-dr. seydon] Do n’t [you]219-dr. seydon know [him]1145-he ? See , [he]1145-he is coming back again to have some tea . ’ It was indeed but too true . [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke ’s face in especial grew very blank . [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders clenched [his]102-mr. saunders fist — a small one . [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon ’s face , on the contrary , wore what for it was a really gracious smile . [He]219-dr. seydon was mindful of how upon [his]219-dr. seydon arrival [he]219-dr. seydon had overheard the words ‘[1145-he] Apocalypse ’ and ‘[1145-he] mystery of Christianity . ’ As [Laurence]83-laurence introduced [him]219-dr. seydon into the circle [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose at once claimed acquaintance with [him]219-dr. seydon , and made room for [him]219-dr. seydon at [her]92-lady ambrose side . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i am sorry , ’ [he]0-i said , looking round [him]219-dr. seydon with a singularly dignified , almost condescending courteousness , ‘[0-i] to disturb in this way [your]83-laurence Sunday ’s reading . But [I]0-i can but stay a few moments . [I]0-i shall not interrupt [you]83-laurence long . ’ ‘[0-i] [We]1147-we have been talking a good deal , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[1147-we] about the signs of the times . ’ ‘[1147-we] And , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose eagerly , feeling [herself]92-lady ambrose near [a friend]2414-a friend , ‘[1147-we] about all this wicked infidelity and irreligion that is so much about in [the world]406-the world now . ’ ‘[1147-we] Ah , yes , ’ said [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon slowly , and with a sudden frown , ‘[1147-we] it is true , unhappily , that there is , or has been , much of that in [our]1147-we century . For [I]0-i fear [I]0-i can not deny that [we]1147-we , in this matter , are not wholly guiltless . [The Church]670-the church , [we]1147-we may depend upon it , has much to answer for . ’ ‘[670-the church] Perfectly true , [[my]0-i dear sir]461-my dear sir ! perfectly true , ’ exclaimed [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , who could never resist assenting to this sentiment . [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon darted a quick glance at [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , as if [he]219-dr. seydon were anything but pleased at finding [himself]219-dr. seydon so readily agreed with . ‘[670-the church] But , ’ [he]219-dr. seydon went on , ‘[670-the church] matters are fast assuming a more satisfactory appearance ; and the great advance made in true education , and the liberal spirit that this brings with it , can not fail to lead to that great change in [our]1147-we position that [we]1147-we so much desiderate . ’ ‘[670-the church] Quite so , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke . ‘[670-the church] The true reading of ecclesiastical history — ’ ‘[670-the church] Ah ! ’ exclaimed [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon , holding up [his]219-dr. seydon forefinger , ‘[670-the church] exactly so . [You]461-my dear sir have hit upon the right thing there . ’ ( ‘[461-my dear sir] Good gracious ! ’ thought [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , astounded at this patronising compliment , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i should think [I]0-i had . ’ ) ‘[0-i] Could [we]1147-we but get [both the parties]1154-both the parties , ’ [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon went on , addressing [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke across [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[0-i] to understand fairly the history of the important era , the matter would , [I]0-i think , be as good as settled . [You]461-my dear sir see , ’ [he]0-i said , turning to [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[461-my dear sir] if [the Easterns]1155-the easterns will merely face steadily the pregnant fact that [Michael Cerularius]220-michael cerularius , in [his]220-michael cerularius first letter to [Leo IX .]221-leo ix . , in 1053 , took absolutely no exception to any one point in Western doctrine , but simply to certain secondary points of discipline , [they]1155-the easterns will see that the gulf that separates [us]1147-we is very slight when viewed by the clearer light of modern thought . [I]0-i think , ’ [he]0-i added , ‘[0-i] that [I]0-i saw [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose ’s name amongst [the subscribers to [the Eastern Church Union Association]1157-the eastern church union association]1156-the subscribers to the eastern church union association . ’ ‘[92-lady ambrose] Oh yes , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[92-lady ambrose] certainly . [I]0-i do so wish that some union could be brought about . For [the Greek Church]1158-the greek church , [you]1159-you know , certainly have the Apostolical Succession ; and then , if [we]1147-we were only joined with [them]1158-the greek church , [the Roman Catholics]1160-the roman catholics could never deny [our]1147-we orders — not , ’ [she]92-lady ambrose added , with a most cordial smile to [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon , ‘[1160-the roman catholics] that [I]0-i do n’t [myself]0-i believe implicitly in [them]1158-the greek church , as it is . ’ A rapid frown gathered itself on [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon ’s brow . ‘[0-i] The denial of [them]1158-the greek church , ’ [he]219-dr. seydon said severely , ‘[0-i] hurts [the Romanists]1161-the romanists far more than it does [us]1147-we . As to [the Greeks]222-the greeks , what [I]0-i was going to say was this . Let [them]1158-the greek church just cast [their]1158-the greek church eyes so far as the tenth century , and [they]1158-the greek church will see — and pray mark this , all of [you]1162-you , ’ [he]0-i said , holding up [his]0-i forefinger , and shaking it several times , ‘[0-i] for this is very important — [I]0-i say [the Greeks]1163-the greeks will see , unless [they]1163-the greeks are determined to close [their]1163-the greeks eyes , that at the time of the great rupture with [the West]57-the west , [they]1163-the greeks did actually acknowledge the entire soundness of [our]1147-we confession of faith ; the main point [they]1163-the greeks objected to , and which [they]1163-the greeks thought fit ground then for separation , being that [the Western Church]1164-the western church did not sing Alleluiah in Lent , and that it used in [the Lord]325-the lord ’s Supper unleavened bread , which , [Nicetas Pectoratus]223-nicetas pectoratus contended in an elaborate treatise , was dead bread , and could not therefore be either supersubstantial or consubstantial to [us]1147-we . It has been the fault of [the Easterns]224-the easterns , in fact , to be ever over - subtle , and to fall into those excesses of human wisdom which are foolishness with [God]115-god . [Isaac the Armenian]225-isaac the armenian , for instance , wrote a book to prove [[his]225-isaac the armenian countrymen]1166-his countrymen in heresy for twenty - nine different reasons , of which the two most important are these — that [they]1166-his countrymen did not blow on [baptised persons]1167-baptised persons , and that [they]1166-his countrymen made [their]1166-his countrymen consecrated oils of rapeseed and not of olives . But two causes seem to [me]0-i to be now working together , under [God]115-god , to put [the Easterns]224-the easterns into a more becoming spirit , and to make [them]224-the easterns more heartily willing to join [us]1147-we . These are — [I]0-i have mentioned them in the third volume of [my]0-i “ History of the Filioque Clause”—first , that the genuine Greek blood is becoming daily more adulterated , and the Greek intellect losing therefore its old subtlety ; and secondly , that the political disturbance that now seems imminent in [the East]58-the east , will distract [them]224-the easterns from abusing such subtlety as [they]224-the easterns still possess . [We]1147-we shall therefore meet on the broad ground of [our]1147-we fundamental agreements ; and once let the moral influence of [the two churches]1168-the two churches , the Greek and English , be mutually augmented by an open union , in another five years , [I]0-i imagine , [we]1147-we shall have heard the last of infidelity , in [England]4-england at least , or indeed of Romanism either . ’ ‘[1169-the sort of man] Now , that ’s [the sort of man]1169-the sort of man , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , as soon as [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon had departed , ‘[1169-the sort of man] that [I]0-i should like to have for [[my]0-i clergyman]1170-my clergyman in [[our]1147-we new Republic]890-our new republic . ’ ‘[0-i] [Seydon]219-dr. seydon ! ’ exclaimed [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘[0-i] so that is [he]219-dr. seydon , is it ? [I]0-i thought [I]0-i remembered that face of [his]219-dr. seydon . Of course — [I]0-i remember now , seeing that [[his]219-dr. seydon college]1172-his college had given this living to [him]219-dr. seydon . ’ ‘[219-dr. seydon] It was [he]219-dr. seydon , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence to [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘[219-dr. seydon] who , some years ago , prevented [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson being made [a bishop]313-a bishop , which [he]219-dr. seydon said , though it might be a compliment to learning , would be a grievous insult to [God]115-god . ’ ‘[219-dr. seydon] And so , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ’ said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , ‘[92-lady ambrose] [you]92-lady ambrose would like [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon for [a clergyman]938-a clergyman ! Well , in [our]1175-us ideal society [you]92-lady ambrose would be able to have [any clergyman [you]92-lady ambrose chose]1176-any clergyman you chose — any religion [you]92-lady ambrose chose — any which most satisfied [your]92-lady ambrose own conscience . ’ ‘[1176-any clergyman you chose] Oh , very well , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[1176-any clergyman you chose] if it would not interfere with one ’s religion in any way , [I]0-i think all this culture and enlightenment most delightful . ’ ‘[0-i] It will bind [us]1175-us to nothing , ’ said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , ‘[0-i] except to a recognition of nobleness , of morality , of poetry . What [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence has offered to read to [us]1175-us is an account of how all of these are bound up in religion in [my]0-i sense of the word . ’ ‘[83-laurence] Come , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[83-laurence] please go on . It is wonderful , ’ [she]92-lady ambrose added in a solemn whisper , ‘[83-laurence] how [even bad men]1177-even bad men , like [old Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , know at heart how it is really best to be good , and to believe in true religion . ’ ‘[83-laurence] As [I]0-i grow old , [[my]0-i dear]892-my dear [Otho]77-otho , ’ [Laurence]83-laurence again began to read , ‘[77-otho] [I]0-i am coming to think over many things that [I]0-i have hitherto thought too little about , and , amongst others , the great mystery of Christianity . [I]0-i am coming to see that , from a too superficial way of looking at it , [I]0-i have done this religion a gross injustice , and have blindly failed to recognise how much of all that [we]1175-us hold most precious in life is dependent on its severe and unbending systems of theology and morals . It will perhaps strike [you]1179-you that it is rather late in the day for [me]0-i to pay [my]0-i tribute to these , now that [the world]406-the world at large is theoretically denying the former of them , and is practically forgetting the latter . But it is this very fact that induces [me]0-i to speak out — the growing licence and the growing scepticism of [modern society]1181-modern society . [I]0-i wish to raise [my]0-i voice against the present state of things , and to warn [the world]406-the world that if it goes on much longer as it is going on now , it will soon have irremediably ruined all the finer and more piquant flavours of life , and that soon there will be actually nothing left to give rational zest to this poor pitiful existence of [ours]1175-us . ‘ [You]1179-you know what an admirer [I]0-i have always been , in many ways , of [the ancients]2034-the ancients , and how , in many ways , [I]0-i think modern civilisation barbarous as compared with [theirs]2034-the ancients . [I]0-i have not changed this opinion . [I]0-i have only come lately to understand what it means . The charm of ancient life lies mainly in its form . In essence , the life open to [us]1175-us is , as [I]0-i fully see now , infinitely superior . And to what is this superiority due ? Simply to [Christianity]226-christianity . It came with Christianity , and it will also go with it . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i am not mad , [Otho]77-otho . Listen to [me]0-i a little longer , [[my]0-i boy]1183-my boy , and [you]1183-my boy will see [my]0-i meaning . ‘ To begin , then — just consider the one matter of humour . Compare [the ancient humourists]2416-the ancient humourists with [the modern]2417-the modern . Think for a moment of [Lucian]99-mr. luke , of [Aristophanes]227-aristophanes , of [Plautus]228-plautus , of [Petronius]84-petronius , of [Horace]87-horace ; then think of [Erasmus]229-erasmus , [Swift]230-swift , [Cervantes]126-cervantes , [Voltaire]231-voltaire , Sterne . Does not the mere memory of the two sets of names bring home to [you]1183-my boy what a gulf in this matter there is between [the ancient world]2072-the ancient world and [the modern]2417-the modern ? Is not the modern humour an altogether different thing from the ancient — broader and deeper beyond comparison or measurement ? The humour of [the ancients]2034-the ancients could raise a laugh ; true — that is just what it could raise , and a laugh could express all the feelings raised by it . Think of the intolerable vulgarity of [[Homers]232-homers gods]2421-homers gods , who “ laughed consumedly ” at [Vulcan]233-vulcan , as [he]232-homers waited on them,—why ? because [he]232-homers was lame . The sense of humour on [Olympus]148-olympus was about equal to what it would be now in [a country lawyer ’s Parlour]2422-a country lawyer ’s parlour . Think of [Horace]87-horace , who saw in a dull pun on two proper names , a joke so excellent that [he]87-horace wrote a whole satire in honour of it . It is true that [Juvenal]234-juvenal showed a somewhat finer sense , when [he]87-horace said that when [Fortune]235-fortune was pleased to be facetious , [she]2423-she made a nouveau riche ; [Petronius]84-petronius , perhaps , was even in advance of [Juvenal]234-juvenal . But ancient humour at its best was a shallow thing . It meant little . It was like the bright sparkle on a brawling stream , hardly ankle - deep But [our]2424-our modern humour is like the silent snake - like lights in a still water , that go coiling down into depths unfathomable , as it lures [our]2424-our thoughts onwards to the contemplation of endless issues . The twinkle in the eyes of [a Sterne]2425-a sterne or [a Cervantes]2426-a cervantes seems to hint to [us]2424-our of Eleusinian mysteries with a triumphant solemn treachery ; and wakes [our]2424-our souls , as [we]2424-our catch it , into a sudden , thrill of delicious furtive insight . Such humour as this may excite laughter ; but no laughter can ease [our]2424-our feelings fully — [they]2427-they also demand tears ; and even tears are not enough for [us]2424-our . Of such humour as this [the ancients]2034-the ancients had hardly a notion ; it differs from [theirs]2034-the ancients as [the man]1772-the man differs from [the baby]2430-the baby , and seems almost like a new sense , peculiar to the modern world . ‘[1183-my boy] Now , to what is this development of humour due — this new and exquisite source of pleasure ? Simply , as [you]1184-you must see , if [you]1184-you look into the matter , to that much maligned thing , [Christianity]226-christianity , and that marvellous system of moral laws and restraints which , although accredited through imposture , elaborated by barbarism , and received by credulity , has entirely changed the whole complexion of life . Think how it has done this . It has slowly permeated and penetrated [all man]1185-all man 's inner existence . It has given [him]1185-all man new unearthly aims ; it has given [him]1185-all man new unearthly standards by which to measure every action . It has cunningly associated everything with the most awful or the most glittering conceptions with which the imagination can scare or intoxicate itself — with Hell , Heaven , Judgment , and so forth : and thus there is scarcely a single choice or refusal that has been left indifferent , and not more or less nearly connected with the most stupendous issues . The infinitely beautiful , the infinitely terrible , the infinitely hateful meet [us]1186-us everywhere . Everything is enchanted , and seems to be what it is not . The enchantment quite deludes the vulgar ; it a little deludes [the wise]1187-the wise ; but [the wise]1187-the wise are for ever in various ways secretly undoing the spell , and getting glimpses of things as they really are . What a delight these glimpses are to [those that get them]1189-those that get them ! Here lies the sense of humour — in the detection of truth through revered and reigning falsehood . Think of the colloquies of [Erasmus]229-erasmus , and [his]229-erasmus Laus Stultitiæ — there is an instance for [you]1184-you . Think of [Don Quixote]127-don quixote — there is another . All its humour is due to Christian dreams of honour , duty and chivalry . Who , again , would have cared for [Swift]230-swift ’s showing [us]1186-us that [man]1888-man was hateful , if [Christ]134-christ had not bewitched [us]1186-us into thinking that [man]1888-man was loveable ? [Gulliver]236-gulliver owes [its]236-gulliver point to the Gospels . [Sterne]209-sterne sees everything “ big with infinite jest . ” But why ? Because Christianity has made everything big also with infinite solemnity . A possible moral meaning is secreted over the whole surface of life , like the scented oil in the cells on the surface of an orange skin , [The humourist]1192-the humourist catches the perfume of these volatile oils , as they are crushed out and wasted by [our]1186-us every action . ‘ Think , too , by the way , of the kindred subject of wit . [I]1192-the humourist was reading a play of Congreve ’s yesterday : and this made [me]1192-the humourist reflect how nearly all the brightest wit of [the modern world]2431-the modern world consists in showing [us]1186-us this one thing — that fidelity in marriage is ridiculous ; that is , in showing [us]1186-us what , but for [Christianity]226-christianity , [no one]387-no one would ever have doubted . Such wit is , as it were , the forbidden kiss [we]1186-us give to common sense , from which an angry religion has been bent on separating [us]1186-us . ‘[1192-the humourist] Think , too , of that flower of Christian civilisation , the innuendo . That is simply the adroit saying under difficulties of what , but for Christianity , [everyone]347-everyone would have taken for granted . ‘ Here , then , [you]2433-you see , are the wit , the innuendo , the humour of [the world]406-the world , all owing [their]2435-their existence , or , at any rate , [their]2435-their flavour , to Christianity . And what would life , what would [conversation]2436-conversation be without these ? But it is not these only that [we]1186-us owe to the same source . All [our]1186-us finer pleasures are indebted for [their]2435-their chief taste to it likewise . Love in itself , for instance , is , as [everyone]347-everyone knows who has felt it , the coarsest and most foolish of all [our]1186-us feelings . Leave it free to do what it pleases , and [we]1186-us soon cease to care what it does . But Christianity , with a miraculous ingenuity , has confined and cramped it into so grotesque and painful a posture , and set such vigilant guardians to keep it there , that any return to its natural freedom is a rapture , an adventure , and a truimph , which [none but the wisest and most skilful]2438-none but the wisest and most skilful can compass with grace or safety , and which [wise men]1896-wise men , therefore , think worth compassing . It is indeed the same with all the natural and true pleasures of life — poor tasteless things not worth living for , in [themselves]2435-their ; but they have been so hidden away from [us]1186-us , and have come to be in such bad odour with [the world]406-the world , that only [the wisest]2441-the wisest — for wisdom is but the detection of falsehood — see that [they]2435-their may be taken , and have the courage to take them ; and the wisdom [they]2435-their are conscious of in doing this , forms a delicious sauce piquante—(of which humour , wit , and so on , are some of the flavours)—to these same poor pleasures , that can give [us]1186-us a real zest for [them]2435-their . ‘[347-everyone] Such a life of wisdom is , of course , only for [the few]1194-the few . [The wise]1187-the wise must always be few , as [the rich]2099-the rich must . [The poor]2098-the poor must make fine food for [the rich]2099-the rich to eat . [The fools]1199-the fools must make fine follies for [the wise]1187-the wise to detect . [We]1201-we can not all be happy in a rational way . It is at least best that some of [us]1201-we should be . But what [I]0-i want to point out to [you]1202-you , [[my]0-i boy]1183-my boy , is , that if society goes on as it is going on now , [nobody]1902-nobody will be able soon to be rationally happy at all . It is true that [I]0-i do not now live much in [the world]406-the world ; but [I]0-i have sufficient means of seeing the course it is taking . [I]0-i , like [Hamlet]237-hamlet , have heard of its “ paintings , ” how it “ jigs and ambles and lisps , and nick - names [God]115-god ’s creatures . ” [I]0-i know how fast all Christian moral sentiment is silently dying out of it . Indeed , so rapid do [I]0-i imagine to be the way in which it is losing all proper feeling , that [I]0-i should not be surprised were society in another five years , if [I]0-i am not dead by that time , to receive [me]0-i back again . Now , as long as Christianity was firmly fixed as a faith , [we]1201-we might amuse [ourselves]1201-we by offending against [its]1206-its morals as much as [we]1201-we liked ; for [our]1201-we acts were in no danger of losing [their]1207-their forbidden character . There would always be a persecution , under which pleasure might thrive . But now , since faith is dead , [we]1201-we have only the moral sentiments left to [us]1201-we ; and if [we]1201-we once get rid of these by a too reckless violation of them , the whole work of Christianity , which [I]0-i have been trying to explain to [you]1208-you , will be undone . Wit and humour , love and poetry , will all alike have left [us]1201-we . Life will have lost its seasonings and its sauces : and served up to [us]1201-we au naturel it will only nauseate [us]1201-we . [Man]1888-man , indeed , will then be only separated from the animals by [his]1888-man capacity for ennui . ‘ [I]1888-man had once hoped that [the middle classes]2150-the middle classes — that vast and useless body , who have neither the skill that produces [their]2150-the middle classes wealth , nor [the taste that can enjoy it]2443-the taste that can enjoy it — might have proved [themselves]2150-the middle classes at least of some use , by preserving the traditions of a sound , respectable morality ; that [they]2150-the middle classes might have kept alive [the nation]1899-the nation ’s power of being shocked and scandalised at wit , or grace , or freedom . But no ; [they]2150-the middle classes too are changed . With awkward halting gait [they]2150-the middle classes are waddling in the footsteps of [[their]2150-the middle classes betters]2445-their betters , and [they]2150-the middle classes will soon have made vice as vulgar as [they]2150-the middle classes long ago made virtue . ‘[1888-man] To [me]0-i , of course , all this matters little . Such flavours as life has , have lasted [me]0-i this far ; nor will [the world]406-the world ’s growing blankness affect [me]0-i . [I]0-i shall never look into [a woman]1817-a woman ’s eyes again . One of [my]0-i own is blind now , and the other is so dim that [I]0-i doubt if [the best - paid beauty]1212-the best - paid beauty could contrive to look into it with more than an ironical tenderness . All this matters nothing to [me]0-i . But [you]1213-you , [[my]0-i boy]1183-my boy — what will be left for [you]1213-you , when [I]0-i am taken away from the evil that is to come ? [Your]1213-you prospect does not seem to [me]0-i a cheerful one . But alas ! [I]0-i can offer no remedy . [I]0-i can only beguile [my]0-i time by warning [you]1213-you . At any rate , it is always good to think a little about the roots of things : so [I]0-i trust [you]1213-you will be in some way profited by these patruæ verbera linguæ . ’ When [Laurence]83-laurence closed the book there was a silence of some moments , as if [no one]387-no one knew exactly how to take what had just been read . But at last [Donald Gordon]103-donald gordon exclaimed , in [his]103-donald gordon devoutest of soft whispers : ‘[0-i] Is [Saul]238-saul also among [the prophets]1215-the prophets ? ’ The words acted like a spell ; the ice was broken , and [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert [, who hitherto had hardly uttered a syllable the whole afternoon]2447-, who hitherto had hardly uttered a syllable the whole afternoon , now broke out suddenly in [his]112-mr. herbert most emphatic accents . ‘[0-i] Thank [you]1213-you , [[my]0-i dear]892-my dear [Laurence]83-laurence , ’ [he]112-mr. herbert exclaimed ; ‘[1213-you] thank [you]1213-you much , indeed . There is something in what [you]1213-you have just read [us]1217-us that seems to [me]0-i quite precious and peculiar . Nor do [I]0-i find any such honesty in any creed sung by [priests]1218-priests in [churches]1219-churches , as [I]0-i do in this sardonic confession of that great truth , which the present age as a whole is resolutely bent upon forgetting — that the grand knowledge for [a man]1770-a man to know is the essential and eternal difference between right and wrong , between base and noble ; that there is a right and [a noble to be striven for]1221-a noble to be striven for , not for the sake of its consequences , but in spite of [them]1222-them ; and that it is this fact alone which , under countless forms , is the one thing affirmed in all human art and implied in all serviceable learning , [[Your]1223-your Cervantes]1224-your cervantes smiles it to [you]1223-your ; [[your]1223-your Swift]1225-your swift curses it to [you]1223-your ; [[your]1223-your Bernard of [Morlaix]239-morlaix]1226-your bernard of morlaix hymns it to [you]1223-your ; [your]1223-your saddened [Shakespeare]195-shakespeare tells it to [you]1223-your in every way . Strange indeed is it , and mournful , that [we]1227-we see a time when the one truth that [we]1227-we live and die by not only needs to be pointed out to [us]1227-we , but asserted passionately in the teeth of [those whom [we]1227-we have elected as [[our]1227-we wisest teachers]1229-our wisest teachers]1228-those whom we have elected as our wisest teachers . ’ [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders at once took this to be a special allusion to [himself]102-mr. saunders , and [his]102-mr. saunders face involuntarily began to array itself in a smile of triumph . ‘[1230-you] However , ’ [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert went on benignantly , ‘[1230-you] [you]1230-you have truly gone the right way to work in constructing [an ideal society]1231-an ideal society , if [you]1230-you make it recognise this before all things , and see how witness is borne to it by every pleasure and every interest of life . ’ ‘[1230-you] Ah , yes , ’ exclaimed [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , ‘[1230-you] it is just this noble discrimination between right and wrong , [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , that modern enlightenment will so preeminently encourage and foster . Morality is quite indispensable to any dream of the future . And as to religion — the motto of the future is freedom — holy awful , individual freedom . [We]1227-we shall each be free to choose or evolve the religion most profoundly suited to [us]1227-we . ’ ‘[1233-she] Well , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[1233-she] as long as [I]0-i may keep [my]0-i own religion , [I]0-i shall be quite satisfied ; and about [other people]1232-other people , [I]0-i really do n’t think [I]0-i ’m bigoted — not as long , [you]1230-you know , as [they]1232-other people belong to [some church]2448-some church . But religion is the thing [I]1233-she want . Of course [we]1227-we must have morality . Must n’t [we]1227-we ? ’[1233-she] [she]1233-she added , with a half - puzzled expression , turning to [Lady Grace]89-lady grace . ‘ Must ! ’[1233-she] sighed [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair . ‘ It ’s very easy to say must . ’[106-mrs. sinclair] ‘ Of course [we]1227-we must , ’[89-lady grace] said [Lady Grace]89-lady grace cheerfully . ‘ [[My]1233-she dear]892-my dear , ’[1233-she] [she]1233-she went on , with a little kindly laugh towards [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ‘ [he]102-mr. saunders does n’t really doubt it . ’[1233-she] [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders sprang to [his]102-mr. saunders feet as if an adder had stung [him]102-mr. saunders . ‘ What ! ’[102-mr. saunders] [he]102-mr. saunders exclaimed , standing in the centre of [the group]537-the group , and looking round [him]102-mr. saunders , ‘ and do [I]102-mr. saunders not really doubt that the degrading practice of prayer , the fetish - worship of celibacy , of mortification , and so forth — do [I]102-mr. saunders not doubt that the foul faith in a future life , the grotesque conceptions of the theological virtues , and that preposterous idol of the marketplace , the sanctity of marriage,—do [you]2450-you think [I]102-mr. saunders do not really doubt that [we]1227-we must retain these ? Do [you]2450-you think , on the contrary , [I]102-mr. saunders do not know that [they]2451-they are already doomed ? However , ’[102-mr. saunders] here [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders paused suddenly and again sat down on the grass , ‘ there is no need for [me]102-mr. saunders at this moment to destroy any cherished illusions ; though [I]102-mr. saunders shall be happy to show [my]102-mr. saunders analysis of them that [I]102-mr. saunders spoke about just now to [anyone who is not afraid to inspect it]2452-anyone who is not afraid to inspect it . [I]102-mr. saunders hear much said about tolerance , as a characteristic of [[your]2450-you society]2453-your society .
