[[Your]2450-you new Republic]2454-your new republic may be full of illusions then . The great labour of destroying them will be positively delicious to [me]102-mr. saunders . ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ Well , ’[110-mr. stockton] said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , with a mixture of deference and patronage , ‘ and what does [Miss Merton]93-miss merton think ? ’[110-mr. stockton] ‘ Oh , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton with a slow smile , ‘ [I]93-miss merton am all in favour of toleration . [I]93-miss merton think that what [I]93-miss merton consider truth is quite good enough to stand on its own merits , if unprejudiced eyes can only be got to see them . And [I]93-miss merton honestly do think , that with really high - breeding , and with what [we]2455-we apparently mean by culture , [we]2455-we should have at least one part of [the world]406-the world as good as [we]2455-we could wish it . But yet — ’[93-miss merton] [she]93-miss merton added , hesitating a little , ‘ [we]2455-we have surely settled only half the question yet . [We]2455-we have said a good deal about this wide and discerning taste that is to guide [us]2455-we , [We]2455-we have not said much yet about the particular things — the occupations , the duties , the pleasures , that it will lead [us]2455-we to choose . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ No , ’[100-mr. rose] began [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ‘ [I]100-mr. rose should like [myself]100-mr. rose very much to say something as to that — as to the new pleasures that modern culture has made possible for [us]2455-we . ’[100-mr. rose] ‘ Suppose — ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose with one of [her]92-lady ambrose most beaming smiles , as [she]92-lady ambrose pushed [her]92-lady ambrose hat away over the back of [her]92-lady ambrose head , ‘ suppose [we]2455-we talk of this by - and - by — at dinner , or in the evening . Let [us]2455-we just enjoy a little now . The air now is so truly delicious . It seems quite like a sin , does n’t it , to think of going in to dinner by - and - by . ’[92-lady ambrose] A happy thought struck [Lady Grace]89-lady grace . ‘ Suppose [we]2455-we have dinner out of doors , [Otho]77-otho , ’[92-lady ambrose] [she]92-lady ambrose said , ‘ in [the pavilion with the roses round it that [you]77-otho used to call [the summer dining - room]2458-the summer dining - room]2457-the pavilion with the roses round it that you used to call the summer dining - room . ’[92-lady ambrose] This proposal was received with what was little short of rapture . ‘ That really would be too delightful ! ’[92-lady ambrose] exclaimed [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘ And what place could sound more perfect for [us]2455-we to finish [our]2455-we new Republic in ! ’[92-lady ambrose] It was arranged accordingly . ‘ And now , ’[92-lady ambrose] exclaimed [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose to [Laurence]77-otho confidentially , as the conversation ceased to be general , ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose want [you]77-otho to let [me]92-lady ambrose have a look at that book of [[your]77-otho uncle]2459-your uncle ’s . Listen , then , and please do n’t laugh at [me]92-lady ambrose . ’[92-lady ambrose] As [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose had read on , [her]92-lady ambrose voice had grown more and more disapproving , and several times [she]92-lady ambrose had shown symptoms of being on the point of stopping . ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose ’ve no doubt it ’s all very witty , ’[92-lady ambrose] [she]92-lady ambrose said , putting down the book , which was eagerly caught up by [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ‘ but — but that sort of thing , [you]77-otho know , ’[92-lady ambrose] [she]92-lady ambrose exclaimed at last , ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose think is rather better in [the smoking - room]2462-the smoking - room . [She]93-miss merton looked interested ; and [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , in slow , suave tones went on to read : — ( ‘[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t at all approve of this , ’ murmured [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ) ‘[0-i] Ah , they are sweet verses , ’ said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose ; ‘[0-i] a little too ascetic , perhaps , to be quite Greek . [NO proposal]2465-no proposal could have been happier than [Lady Grace]89-lady grace ’s , of the garden banquet in [the pavilion]862-the pavilion . It seemed to [the guests]1694-the guests , when [they]1694-the guests were all assembled [there]1691-there , that the lovely summer ’s day was going to close with a scene from fairyland . The table itself , with its flowers , and glowing fruit , and [its]1691-there many - coloured Venetian glass , shone and gleamed and sparkled , in the evening light , that was turning outside to a cool mellow amber ; and above , from the roof , in which the dusk was already darkness , hung china lamps , in the shape of green and purple grape - clusters , looking like luminous fruits stolen from [Aladdin ’s garden]2469-aladdin ’s garden . [The pavilion]862-the pavilion , open on all sides , was supported on marble pillars , that were almost hidden in red and white roses . Behind , the eye rested on great tree - trunks , and glades of rich foliage ; and before , it would pass over turf and flowers , till it reached [the sea beyond]2471-the sea beyond , on which , in another hour , the faint silver of the moonlight would begin to tremble . There was something in the whole scene that was at once calming and exhilarating ; and nearly all present seemed to feel in some measure this double effect of it . [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson had been quite restored by an afternoon ’s nap ; and [his]95-dr. jenkinson face was now all a - twinkle with a fresh benignity , that had however , like an early spring morning , just a faint suspicion of frost in it . [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks even was less severe than usual ; and as [he]113-mr. storks raised [his]113-mr. storks champagne to [his]113-mr. storks lips , [he]113-mr. storks would at times look very nearly conversational . ‘[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]892-my dear [Laurence]83-laurence , ’ exclaimed [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ‘[0-i] it really almost seems as if [your]83-laurence visions of the afternoon had come true , and that [we]1243-we actually were in [[your]83-laurence new Republic]2454-your new republic already . [I]0-i can only say that , if it is at all like this , it will be [an entirely charming place]1245-an entirely charming place — too charming , perhaps . But now , remember this — [you]83-laurence have but half got through the business to which [you]83-laurence first addressed [yourselves]83-laurence — that of forming a picture of [a perfect aristocracy]1246-a perfect aristocracy — [an aristocracy in the true and genuine sense of the word]1247-an aristocracy in the true and genuine sense of the word . [You]83-laurence are all to have culture , or taste . Very good , [you]83-laurence have talked a great deal about that , and [you]83-laurence have seen what [you]83-laurence mean by it ; and [you]83-laurence have recognised , above all , that it includes a discrimination between right and wrong . But now , [you]83-laurence with all this taste and culture — [[you]83-laurence gifted men]1248-you gifted men and [women of the nineteenth]1249-women of the nineteenth century,—what sort of things does [your]83-laurence taste teach [you]83-laurence to reach out towards ? In what actions and aims , in what affections and emotions , would [you]83-laurence place [your]83-laurence happiness ? That is what [I]0-i want to hear — the practical manifestations of this culture . ’ ‘[0-i] Ah , ’ said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i have at this moment a series of essays in the press , which would go far towards answering these questions of [yours]83-laurence . [They]1250-they do , indeed , deal with just this — the effect of the choicer culture of this century on the soul of [man]1888-man — the ways in which it endows [him]1888-man with new perceptions — how it has made [him]1888-man , in fact , [a being altogether more highly organised]1252-a being altogether more highly organised . All [I]0-i regret is , that these choicer souls , these χαρίεντες , are as yet like flowers that have not found a climate in which they can thrive properly . That mental climate will doubtless come with time . What [we]1253-we have been trying to do this afternoon is , [I]0-i imagine , nothing more than to anticipate it in imagination . ’ ‘[0-i] Well , ’ said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , with a little the tone of [an inquisitor]2472-an inquisitor , ‘[0-i] that is just what [I]0-i have been asking . What will this climate be like , and what will these flowers be like in this climate ? How would [your]83-laurence culture alter and better the present , if its powers were equal to [its]1254-its wishes ? ’ [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose ’s soft lulling tone harmonised well with the scene and hour , and [the whole party]591-the whole party seemed willing to listen to [him]100-mr. rose ; or at any rate [no one]387-no one felt any prompting to interrupt [him]100-mr. rose . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i can show [you]0-i an example , [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , ’ [he]0-i said , ‘[112-mr. herbert] of culture demanding a finer climate , in — if [you]0-i will excuse [my]0-i seeming egoism — in [myself]0-i . For instance , ( to take the widest matter [I]0-i can fix upon — the general outward surroundings of [our]1253-we lives ) , often , when [I]0-i walk about [London]1-london , and see how hideous [its]1-london whole external aspect is , and what [a dissonant population throng it]1255-a dissonant population throng it , a chill feeling of despair comes over [me]0-i . Consider how the human eye delights in form and colour , and the ear in tempered and harmonious sounds ; and then think for a moment of [a London street]1256-a london street ! Think of [the shapeless houses]1257-the shapeless houses , the forest of ghastly chimney - pots , of the hell of distracting noises made by [the carts]1258-the carts , [the cabs]1259-the cabs , [the carriages]1260-the carriages — think of the bustling , commonplace , careworn crowds that jostle [you]1261-you — think of [an omnibus]1262-an omnibus — think of [a four - wheeler]1263-a four - wheeler — ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i often ride in [an omnibus]1262-an omnibus , ’ said [Lord Allen]101-allen , with a slight smile to [Miss Merton]93-miss merton . ‘[0-i] It is true , ’ replied [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , only overhearing the tone in which these words were said , ‘[0-i] that one may ever and again catch some touch of sunlight that will for a moment make the meanest object beautiful with its furtive alchemy . But that is [Nature]121-nature ’s work , not [man]1888-man ’s ; and [we]1266-our must never confound the accidental beauty that Nature will bestow on [man]1888-man ’s work , even at its worst , with the rational and designed beauty of [man]1888-man ’s work at its best . It is this rational human beauty that [I]0-i say [our]1266-our modern city life is so completely wanting in ; nay , the look of out - of - door [London]1-london seems literally to stifle the very power of imagining such beauty possible . Indeed , as [I]0-i wander along [[our]1266-our streets]1269-our streets , pushing [my]0-i way among [the throngs of faces]1270-the throngs of faces — faces puckered with misdirected thought , or expressionless with none — barbarous faces set towards [Parliament]1271-parliament , or [Church]579-church , or [scientific lecture - rooms]1273-scientific lecture - rooms , or [Government offices]1274-government offices , or [counting - houses]1275-counting - houses — [I]0-i say , as [I]0-i push [my]0-i way amongst all the sights and sounds of [the streets of [our great city]1277-our great city]1276-the streets of our great city , only one thing ever catches [my]0-i eye , that breaks in upon [my]0-i mood , and warns [me]0-i [I]0-i need not despair . ’ ‘[1278-the shops] And what is that ? ’ asked [Allen]101-allen , with some curiosity . ‘[1278-the shops] [The shops]1278-the shops , ’ [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose answered , ‘[1278-the shops] of certain of [[our]1279-our upholsterers]1280-our upholsterers and [dealers in works of art]1281-dealers in works of art . [Their]1278-the shops windows , as [I]0-i look into them , act like a sudden charm on [me]0-i — like a splash of cold water dashed on [my]0-i forehead when [I]0-i am fainting . For [I]0-i seem there to have got a glimpse of the real heart of things ; and as [my]0-i eyes rest on the perfect pattern ( many of which are really quite delicious ; indeed , when [I]0-i go to [ugly houses]1282-ugly houses , [I]0-i often take a scrap of some artistic crétonne with [me]0-i in [my]0-i pocket as a kind of æsthetic smelling salts ) , [I]0-i say , when [I]0-i look in at [their]1278-the shops windows , and [my]0-i eyes rest on the perfect pattern of some new fabric for a chair or for a window - curtain , or on some new design for a wallpaper , or on some old china vase , [I]0-i become at once sharply conscious , [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , that , despite the ungenial mental climate of the present age , strange yearnings for , and knowledge of , true beauty , are beginning to show themselves like flowers above the weedy soil ; and [I]0-i remember , amidst the roar and clatter of [[our]1283-our streets]1269-our streets , and the mad noises of [our]1283-our own times , that there is amongst [us]1283-our [a growing number who have deliberately turned [their]1285-a growing number who have deliberately turned their backs on all these things , and have thrown their whole souls and sympathies into the happier art - ages of the past backs on all these things , and have thrown [their]1285-a growing number who have deliberately turned their backs on all these things , and have thrown their whole souls and sympathies into the happier art - ages of the past whole souls and sympathies into the happier art - ages of the past]1285-a growing number who have deliberately turned their backs on all these things , and have thrown their whole souls and sympathies into the happier art - ages of the past . [They]1285-a growing number who have deliberately turned their backs on all these things , and have thrown their whole souls and sympathies into the happier art - ages of the past have gone back , ’ said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , raising [his]100-mr. rose voice a little , ‘[1285-a growing number who have deliberately turned their backs on all these things , and have thrown their whole souls and sympathies into the happier art - ages of the past] to [Athens]21-athens and to [Italy]45-italy , to [the Italy of [Leo]221-leo ix .]61-the italy of leo and to [the Athens of [Pericles]243-pericles]62-the athens of pericles . To [such men]1286-such men the clamour , the interests , the struggles of [our]1283-our own times , become as meaningless as [they]1286-such men really are . [I]0-i know , indeed — and [I]0-i really do not blame [them]1286-such men — [several distinguished artists who , resolving to make [their]1288-several distinguished artists who , resolving to make their whole lives consistently perfect , will , on principle , never admit a newspaper into their houses that is of later date than the times of addison whole lives consistently perfect , will , on principle , never admit a newspaper into [[their]1288-several distinguished artists who , resolving to make their whole lives consistently perfect , will , on principle , never admit a newspaper into their houses that is of later date than the times of addison houses]1289-their houses that is of later date than the times of [Addison]64-addison]1288-several distinguished artists who , resolving to make their whole lives consistently perfect , will , on principle , never admit a newspaper into their houses that is of later date than the times of addison ; and [I]0-i have good trust that the number of [such men]1286-such men is on the increase — [men]1704-men [I]0-i mean , ’ said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , toying tenderly with an exquisite wine - glass of [Salviati]247-salviati ’s , ‘[1704-men] who with a steady and set purpose follow art for the sake of art , beauty for the sake of beauty , love for the sake of love , life for the sake of life . ’ [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose ’s slow gentle voice , which was apt at certain times to become peculiarly irritating , sounded now like the evening air grown articulate , and had secured [him]100-mr. rose hitherto a tranquil hearing , as if by a kind of spell . This however seemed here in sudden danger of snapping . ‘[100-mr. rose] What , [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose ! ’ exclaimed [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[100-mr. rose] do [you]100-mr. rose mean to say , then , that the number of [people]308-people is on the increase who wo n’t read the newspapers ? ’ ‘[100-mr. rose] Why , [the men]1293-the men must be [absolute idiots]1294-absolute idiots ! ’ said [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , shaking [her]89-lady grace grey curls , and putting on [her]89-lady grace spectacles to look at [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose . [I]0-i was merely speaking just now of the spirit of the movement . And of that [we]1296-we must all of [us]1296-we here have some knowledge . And even if [we]1296-we had not , [we]1296-we could not help seeing signs of it — signs of how true and earnest it is , in the enormous sums that are now given for really good objects . ’ ‘[115-god] That , ’ said [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , with some tartness , ‘[115-god] is true enough , thank [God]115-god ! ’ ‘[115-god] But [I]0-i ca n’t see , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , whose name often figured in the Times , in the subscription - lists of advertised charities — ‘[0-i] [I]0-i ca n’t see , [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , any reason in that why [we]1296-we should not read the newspapers . ’ ‘[100-mr. rose] The other day , for instance , ’ said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose reflectively , ‘[100-mr. rose] [I]0-i heard of eight [Chelsea]65-chelsea [shepherdesses]1298-shepherdesses , picked up by [a dealer]1299-a dealer , [I]0-i really forget where — in [some common cottage]1300-some common cottage , if [I]0-i recollect aright , covered with dirt , giving no pleasure to [anyone]354-anyone — and these were all sold in a single day , and not one of them fetched less than two hundred and twenty pounds . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i ca n’t help thinking [they]1298-shepherdesses must have come from [Cremorne]66-cremorne , ’ said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair softly . ‘[1298-shepherdesses] But why , ’ said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ‘[0-i] should [I]0-i speak of particular instances ? And [I]100-mr. rose was going to say , ’[100-mr. rose] [he]100-mr. rose went on , looking out dreamily towards the evening waves , ‘ that as the imagination is [a quick workman]2485-a quick workman , [I]100-mr. rose can at this moment see [[our]2476-our metropolis]2486-our metropolis already transplanted and rebuilt . [I]100-mr. rose seem to see [it]2486-our metropolis now as [it]2486-our metropolis were from a distance , with [[its]2486-our metropolis palaces]2487-its palaces , [its museums]2488-its museums , [its churches]2489-its churches , [[its]2486-our metropolis convents]2490-its convents , [[its]2486-our metropolis gardens]2491-its gardens , [[its]2486-our metropolis picture - galleries]2492-its picture - galleries — a cluster of domed and pillared marble , sparkling on a gray headland . The aloe - tree of beauty again blossoms there , under the azure stainless sky . ’[100-mr. rose] ‘ Do [you]100-mr. rose know , [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose in [her]92-lady ambrose most cordial manner , ‘ all this is very beautiful ; and certainly [no one]387-no one can think [London]1-london as it is more ugly than [I]92-lady ambrose do . [We]2496-our have many amongst [us]2496-our [who know what is beautiful , and who passionately desire it]2497-who know what is beautiful , and who passionately desire it ; and would [others]341-others only be led by these , it is quite conceivable that [we]2496-our might some day have a capital , the entire aspect of which should be the visible embodiment of [our]2496-our finest and most varied culture , [our]2496-our most sensitive taste , and [our]2496-our deepest æsthetic measure of things . [We]2496-our shall have [houses]1778-houses , [galleries]2503-galleries , [streets]2504-streets , [theatres]2505-theatres , such as [Giulio Romano]249-giulio romano or [Giorgio Vasari]250-giorgio vasari , or [Giulio Campi]251-giulio campi would have rejoiced to look at ; [we]2496-our shall have metal - work worthy of the hand of [Ghiberti]252-ghiberti and the praise of [Michel Angelo]253-michel angelo ; [we]2496-our shall rival [Domenico Beccafumi]254-domenico beccafumi with [[our]2496-our pavements]2506-our pavements . As [you]2507-you wander through [[our]2496-our thoroughfares]2508-our thoroughfares and [[our]2496-our gardens]2482-our gardens , [your]2507-you feelings will not be jarred by the presence of human vulgarity , or the desolating noise of traffic ; nor in every spare space will [your]2507-you eyes be caught by abominable advertisements of [excursion trains]2510-excursion trains to [Brighton]69-brighton , or of [Horniman]255-horniman ’s cheap tea . [Such a city]2514-such a city , ’[100-mr. rose] said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ‘ would be the externalisation of [the human spirit]2515-the human spirit in the highest state of development that [we]2496-our can conceive for it . [We]2496-our should there see expressed openly all [our]2496-our appreciations of all the beauty that [we]2496-our can detect in [the world]406-the world ’s whole history . The wind of the spirit that breathed there would blow to [us]2496-our from all the places of the past , and be charged with infinite odours . Every frieze on [our]2496-our walls , every clustered capital of a marble column , would be a garland or nosegay of associations . Indeed , [[our]2496-our whole city]2517-our whole city , as compared with [the [London]1-london that is now]2518-the london that is now , would be itself a nosegay as compared with a faggot ; and as related to the life that [I]100-mr. rose would see lived in [it]2514-such a city , it would be like a shell murmuring with all [the world]406-the world ’s memories , and held to the ear of [the two twins , Life and Love]2520-the two twins , life and love . ’[100-mr. rose] [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose had got so dreamy by this time that [he]100-mr. rose felt [himself]100-mr. rose the necessity of turning a little more matter - of - fact again . ‘ [You]2521-you will see what [I]100-mr. rose mean , plainly enough , ’[100-mr. rose] [he]100-mr. rose said , ‘ if [you]2521-you will just think of [our]2496-our architecture , and consider how that naturally will be — ’[100-mr. rose] ‘ Yes , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘ [I]99-mr. luke should be glad to hear about [our]2496-our architecture . ’[99-mr. luke] ‘ — How that naturally will be , ’[100-mr. rose] [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose went on , ‘ of no style in particular . ’[100-mr. rose] ‘ The deuce it wo n’t ! ’[99-mr. luke] exclaimed [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke . ‘ No , ’[100-mr. rose] continued [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , unmoved ; ‘ no style in particular , but a renaissance of all styles . [He]100-mr. rose then proceeded , turning again to [Miss Merton]93-miss merton as if nothing had happened . ‘ Let [me]100-mr. rose rather , ’[100-mr. rose] [he]100-mr. rose said , ‘ read a nice sonnet to [you]93-miss merton , which [I]100-mr. rose had sent to [me]100-mr. rose this morning , and which was in [my]100-mr. rose mind just now . Now , there , ’[100-mr. rose] [he]100-mr. rose said , ‘ [we]2534-we have a true and tender expression of the really Catholic spirit of modern æstheticism , which holds nothing common or unclean . Perhaps [you]100-mr. rose never go to All Saints ’[92-lady ambrose] ? ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i every now and then , ’ said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ‘[0-i] when [I]0-i am in the weary mood for it , attend the services of [[our]1306-our English Ritualists]1307-our english ritualists , and [I]0-i admire [[their]1307-our english ritualists churches]1308-their churches very much indeed . In some places the whole thing is really managed with surprising skill . The dim religious twilight , fragrant with the smoke of incense ; the tangled roofs that the music seems to cling to ; the tapers , the high altar , and the strange intonation of [the priests]2353-the priests , all produce a curious old - world effect , and seem to unite one with things that have been long dead . Indeed , it all seems to [me]0-i far more a part of the past than the services of [the Catholics]2089-the catholics . ’ [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose did not express [her]92-lady ambrose approbation of the last part of this sentiment , out of regard for [Miss Merton]93-miss merton ; but [she]92-lady ambrose gave a smile and a nod of pleased intelligence to [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose . ‘[2353-the priests] Yes , ’ [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose went on , ‘[2353-the priests] there is a regretful insincerity about it all , that is very nice , and that at once appeals to [me]0-i , “ Gleich einer alten halbverklungen Sage . ” [The priests]2353-the priests are only half in earnest ; [the congregations]1312-the congregations , even — ’ ‘[1312-the congregations] Then [I]0-i am quite sure , ’ interrupted [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose with vigour , ‘[1312-the congregations] that [you]0-i can never have heard [Mr. Cope]262-mr. cope preach . ’ ‘[262-mr. cope] [I]0-i do n’t know , ’ said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose languidly . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i never enquired , nor have [I]0-i ever heard [anyone]354-anyone so much as mention , the names of any of [them]1314-them . Now all that , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , were life really in the state it should be , [you]0-i would be able to keep . ’ ‘[0-i] Do [you]0-i seriously , and in sober earnest , mean , ’ [Allen]101-allen again broke in , ‘[0-i] that [you]0-i think it a good thing that all [our]1315-we art and architecture should be borrowed and insincere , and that [our]1315-we very religion should be nothing but a dilettante memory ? ’ ‘[0-i] The opinion , ’ said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ‘[0-i] which by the way [you]0-i slightly misrepresent , is not [mine]0-i only , but that of [all those of [our]1315-we own day who are really devoting [themselves]1316-all those of our own day who are really devoting themselves to art for its own sake to art for its own sake]1316-all those of our own day who are really devoting themselves to art for its own sake . [I]0-i will try to explain the reason of this . In [the world]406-the world ’s life , just as in the life of [a man]1770-a man , there are certain periods of eager and all - absorbing action , and these are followed by periods of memory and reflection . [We]1315-we then look back upon [our]1315-we past , and become for the first time conscious of what [we]1315-we are , and of what [we]1315-we have done . [We]1315-we then see the dignity of toil , and the grand results of it , the beauty and the strength of faith , and the fervent power of patriotism ; which , whilst [we]1315-we laboured , and believed , and loved , [we]1315-we were quite blind to . Upon such a reflective period has [the world]406-the world now entered . [It]406-the world has acted and believed already ; its task now is to learn to value action and belief — to feel and to be thrilled at the beauty of them . And the chief means by which it can learn this is art — the art of a renaissance . For by the power of such art , all that was beautiful , strong , heroic , or tender in the past — all the actions , passions , faiths , aspirations of [the world]406-the world , that lie so many fathom deep in the years — float upwards to the tranquil surface of the present , and make [our]1315-we lives like what seems to [me]0-i one of the loveliest things in nature , the iridescent film on the face of a stagnant water . Yes ; the past is not dead unless [we]1315-we choose that it shall be so . Christianity itself is not dead . There is “ nothing of it that doth fade , ” but turns “ into something rich and strange , ” for [us]1315-we to give a new tone to [our]1315-we lives with . And , believe [me]0-i , ’ [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose went on , gathering earnestness , ‘[0-i] that the happiness possible in such conscious periods is the only true happiness . Indeed , the active periods of [the world]406-the world were not really happy at all . [We]1315-we only fancy them to have been so by a pathetic fallacy . Is [the hero]1322-the hero happy during [his]1322-the hero heroism ? No , but after it , when [he]1322-the hero sees what [his]1322-the hero heroism was , and reads the glory of it in the eyes of [youth]1323-youth or [maiden]1324-maiden . ’ ‘[1322-the hero] this is very poor stuff — very poor stuff , ’ murmured [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , whose face had become gradually the very picture of crossness . ‘[1322-the hero] Do [you]0-i mean , [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , with a half humorous , half incredulous smile , ‘[0-i] that [we]1315-we never value religion till [we]1315-we have come to think it nonsense ? ’ ‘[0-i] Not nonsense — no , ’ exclaimed [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose in gentle horror ; ‘[0-i] [I]0-i only mean that it never lights [our]1315-we lives so beautifully as when it is leaving [them]1325-them like the evening sun . It is in such periods of [the world]406-the world ’s life that art springs into being in its greatest splendour . [[Your]100-mr. rose [Raphael]263-raphael]1327-your raphael , [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , who painted [you]100-mr. rose [your]100-mr. rose “ dear Madonnas , ” was a luminous cloud in the sunset sky of the Renaissance,—a cloud that took its fire from a faith that was sunk or sinking . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i ’m afraid that the faith is not quite sunk yet , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , with a slight sudden flush in [her]93-miss merton cheeks , and with just the faintest touch of suppressed anger . [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks , and [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke all raised [their]1328-their eyebrows . ‘ No , ’[100-mr. rose] said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ‘ such cyclic sunsets are happily apt to linger . ’[100-mr. rose] ‘ [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ’[92-lady ambrose] exclaimed [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , with [her]92-lady ambrose most gracious of smiles , ‘ of course [everyone who has ears]2541-everyone who has ears must know that all this is very beautiful , but [I]92-lady ambrose am positively so stupid that [I]92-lady ambrose have n’t been quite able to follow it all . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ [I]100-mr. rose will try to make [my]100-mr. rose meaning clearer , ’[100-mr. rose] [he]100-mr. rose said , in a brisker tone . ‘ [I]100-mr. rose often figure to [myself]100-mr. rose an unconscious period and a conscious one , as [two women]2542-two women — [one an untamed creature with embrowned limbs native to the air]2543-one an untamed creature with embrowned limbs native to the air and [the sea]300-the sea ; [the other marble - white and swan - soft]2545-the other marble - white and swan - soft , couched delicately on cushions before a mirror , and watching [her]92-lady ambrose own supple reflection gleaming in the depths of it . On the one is the sunshine and the sea - spray . The wind of Heaven and [her]92-lady ambrose unbound hair are playmates . The light of the sky is in [her]92-lady ambrose eyes ; on [her]92-lady ambrose lips is a free laughter . [We]2546-we look at [her]92-lady ambrose , and [we]2546-we know that [she]92-lady ambrose is happy . [We]2546-we know it , mark [me]100-mr. rose ; but [she]92-lady ambrose knows it not . Turn , however , to the other , and all is changed . Outwardly , there is no gladness there . [Her]92-lady ambrose dark , gleaming eyes open depth within depth upon [us]2546-we , like the circles of a new Inferno . There is a clear , shadowy pallor on [her]92-lady ambrose cheek . Only [her]92-lady ambrose lips are scarlet . There is a sadness — a languor , even in the grave tendrils of [her]92-lady ambrose heavy hair , and in each changing curve of [her]92-lady ambrose bosom as [she]92-lady ambrose breathes or sighs . ’[100-mr. rose] ‘ What [a very odd man]2547-a very odd man [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose is ! ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose in a loud whisper . ‘ [He]100-mr. rose always seems to talk of [everybody]393-everybody as if [they]393-everybody had no clothes on . And does [he]100-mr. rose mean by this that [we]2546-we ought to be always in the dumps ? ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Yes , ’[100-mr. rose] [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose was meanwhile proceeding , [his]100-mr. rose voice again growing visionary , ‘ there is no eagerness , no action there ; and yet all eagerness , all action is known to [her]92-lady ambrose as the writing on an open scroll ; only , as [she]92-lady ambrose reads , even in the reading of it , action turns into emotion , and eagerness into a sighing memory . Yet [such a woman]2312-such a woman really may stand symbolically for [us]2546-we as [the patroness]2550-the patroness and [the lady of all gladness]2551-the lady of all gladness , who makes [us]2546-we glad in the only way now left [us]2546-we . And not only in the only way , but in the best way — the way of ways . [Her]92-lady ambrose secret is self - consciousness . [She]92-lady ambrose knows that [she]92-lady ambrose is fair ; [she]92-lady ambrose knows , too , that [she]92-lady ambrose is sad ; but [she]92-lady ambrose sees that sadness is lovely , and so sadness turns to joy . [Such a woman]2312-such a woman may be taken as a symbol , not of [our]2546-we architecture only , but of all the eesthetic surroundings with which [we]2546-we shall shelter and express [our]2546-we life . [Such a woman]2312-such a woman do [I]100-mr. rose see whenever [I]100-mr. rose enter [a ritualistic church]2554-a ritualistic church — ’[100-mr. rose] ‘ [I]106-mrs. sinclair know , ’[106-mrs. sinclair] said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , ‘ that [very peculiar people]2555-very peculiar people do go to such places ; but , [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ’[106-mrs. sinclair] [she]106-mrs. sinclair said with a look of appealing enquiry , ‘ [I]106-mrs. sinclair thought [they]2555-very peculiar people were generally rather over - dressed than otherwise ? ’[106-mrs. sinclair] ‘ The imagination , ’[100-mr. rose] said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , opening [his]100-mr. rose eyes in grave wonder at [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , ‘ may give [her]2312-such a woman what garb it chooses . [Our whole city]2517-our whole city , then — [the city of our new Republic]2557-the city of our new republic — will be in keeping with this spirit . It will be the architectural and decorative embodiment of the most educated longings of [our]2546-we own times after order and loveliness and delight , whether of the senses or the imagination . It will be , as it were , a resurrection of the past , in response to the longing and the passionate regret of the present . [I]100-mr. rose said , if [you]100-mr. rose recollect , just now , that [the world]406-the world ’s ideal of the future must resemble in many ways [its]406-the world memory of the Italian Renaissance . But do n’t let that mislead [you]100-mr. rose . It may resemble that , but it will be something far in advance of it . During the last three hundred years — in fact , during the last sixty or seventy years , the soul of [man]1888-man has developed strangely in [its]406-the world sentiments and its powers of feeling ; in [its]406-the world powers , in fact , of enjoying life . As [I]100-mr. rose said , [I]100-mr. rose have a work in the press , devoted entirely to a description of this growth . [I]95-dr. jenkinson do n’t think so . ’[95-dr. jenkinson] Unfortunately , however , [the Doctor]376-the doctor found that , instead of putting down [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose by this , [he]376-the doctor had only raised up [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke . ‘ Ah , [Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , [I]99-mr. luke think [you]95-dr. jenkinson are wrong there , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke . ‘ As long as [we]2562-our recognise that this growth is at present confined to [a very small minority]2563-a very small minority , the fact of such growth is the most important , the most significant of all facts . Indeed , [[our]2562-our friend]2131-our friend [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose is quite right thus far , in the stress [he]100-mr. rose lays on [our]2562-our appreciation of the past , that [we]2562-our have certainly in these modern times acquired a new sense , by which alone the past can be appreciated truly , the sense which , if [I]99-mr. luke may invent a phrase for it , [I]99-mr. luke should call that of Historical Perspective ; so that now really for the first time the landscape of history is beginning to have some intelligible charm for [us]2562-our . And this , [you]95-dr. jenkinson know , is not all . [Our]2562-our whole views of things—(you , [Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , must know this as well as [I]99-mr. luke do)—the [Zeitgeist]177-the zeitgeist breathes upon [them]2565-they , and [they]2565-they do not die ; but [they]2565-they are changed — [they]2565-they are enlightened . ’[99-mr. luke] [The Doctor]376-the doctor was too much annoyed to make any audible answer to this ; but [he]376-the doctor murmured with some emphasis to [himself]376-the doctor , ‘ That ’s not what [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose was saying ; that ’s not what [I]376-the doctor was contradicting . ’[376-the doctor] ‘ [You]99-mr. luke take , [Luke]99-mr. luke , a rather more rose - coloured view of things than [you]99-mr. luke did last night , ’[113-mr. storks] said [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks . ‘ No , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , with a sigh , ‘ far from it . [I]99-mr. luke am not denying ( pray , [Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , remember this ) that [the majority of [us]2567-we]2566-the majority of us are at present either [Barbarians]264-barbarians or [Philistines]265-philistines ; and the ugliness of these is more glaring now than at any former time . But that any of [us]2567-we are able to see [them]2565-they thus distinctly in [their]2565-they true colours , itself shows that there must be a deal of light somewhere . Even to make darkness visible some light is needed . [We]2567-we should always recollect that . [We]2567-we are only discontented with [ourselves]2567-we when [we]2567-we are struggling to be better than [ourselves]2567-we . ’[99-mr. luke] ‘ And in many ways , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ [I]83-laurence think the struggle has been successful . Take , for instance , the pleasure [we]2567-we get now from the aspects of external nature , and the way in which these seem to mix themselves with [our]2567-we lives . This certainly is something distinctly modern . And nearly all [our]2567-we other feelings , it seems to [me]83-laurence , have changed just like this one , and have become more sensitive , and more highly organised . If [we]2567-we may judge by its expression in literature , love has , certainly ; and that [I]83-laurence suppose is the most important and comprehensive feeling in life . ’[83-laurence] ‘ Does [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence only suppose that ? ’[106-mrs. sinclair] sighed [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , casting down [her]106-mrs. sinclair eyes . ‘ Well , ’[95-dr. jenkinson] said [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , ‘ [our]2567-we feelings about these two things — about love and external nature — perhaps have changed somewhat . And [I]83-laurence think this is partly owing to the fusion in [our]2567-we minds of [our]2567-we sacred and secular ideas — which indeed [you]83-laurence were speaking of this morning in [your]83-laurence sermon . Thus , to find some rational purpose in life was once merely enjoined as a supernatural duty . In [our]2567-we times it has taken [our]2567-we common nature upon it , and become a natural longing — though , [I]83-laurence fear , ’[83-laurence] [he]83-laurence added softly , ‘ a fruitless one . ’[83-laurence] ‘ Yes , ’[89-lady grace] suddenly exclaimed [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , who had been listening intently to [[her]89-lady grace nephew]1341-her nephew ’s words ; ‘ and if [you]83-laurence are speaking of modern progress , [Otho]77-otho , [you]83-laurence should not leave out the diffusion of those grand ideas of justice , and right , and freedom , and humanity which are at work in [the great heart of [the nation]1899-the nation]2569-the great heart of the nation . And war too , ’[89-lady grace] [Lady Grace]89-lady grace went on , a glow mounting into [her]89-lady grace soft faded cheek , ‘ think how fast [we]2567-we are outgrowing that ! [England]4-england at any rate will never watch the outbreak of another war , with all its inevitable cruelties , without giving at least one sob that shall make all [Europe]35-europe pause and listen . Indeed , [we]2567-we must not forget how the entire substance of religion is ceasing to be a mass of dogmas , and is becoming embodied instead in practice and in action . ’[89-lady grace] ‘ Quite true , [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke . It is true that culture is at present but a little leaven hid in a barrel of meal ; but still it is doing its work slowly ; and in the matter of religion — indeed , in all matters , for religion rightly understood embraces all — ’[99-mr. luke] ( ‘ [I]89-lady grace do like to hear [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke talk sometimes , ’[89-lady grace] murmured [Lady Grace]89-lady grace ) , ‘ its effect is just this — to show [us]2567-we that religion in any civilised , any reasonable , any sweet sense , can never be found except embodied in action ; that it is , in fact , nothing but right action , pointed — winged , as it were — by right emotion , by a glow , an aspiration — an aspiration towards [God]115-god — ’[99-mr. luke] ( [Lady Grace]89-lady grace sighed with feeling ) — ‘ not of course , ’[99-mr. luke] [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke went on confidentially , ‘ [that petulant Pedant of [the theologians]2577-the theologians]2576-that petulant pedant of the theologians — [that irritable angry Father , with the very uncertain temper]2578-that irritable angry father , with the very uncertain temper — but towards — ’[99-mr. luke] ‘ [An infinite , inscrutable , loving Being]2579-an infinite , inscrutable , loving being , ’[89-lady grace] began [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , with a slight moisture in [her]89-lady grace eyes . ‘ Quite so , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , not waiting to listen , ‘ towards that great Law — that great verifiable tendency of things — that great stream whose flowing such of [us]2567-we as are able are now so anxiously trying to accelerate . It was soon found to have issued from [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , who had hardly spoken more than a few sentences during the whole of dinner . ‘[0-i] What can be the matter ? ‘ was enquired by several voices . ‘[0-i] [[My]0-i fool of [a servant]2402-a servant]1347-my fool of a servant , ’ said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders sullenly , ‘[0-i] has , [I]0-i find , in packing , wrapped up a small sponge of mine in [my]0-i disproof of [God]115-god ’s existence . ’ ‘[0-i] H’f , ’ shuddered [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , shrinking from [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders ’s somewhat piercing tones , and resting [his]0-i forehead on [his]0-i hand , ‘[0-i] [my]0-i head aches sadly . [I]0-i think [I]0-i will go down to [the sea]300-the sea , and join [the ladies]355-the ladies . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i , ’ said [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ‘[0-i] if [you]1351-you will excuse [me]0-i , must go and see in what state the document is , as [I]0-i left it drying , hung on the handle of [my]0-i jug . ’ No sooner had [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders and [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose departed than [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson began to recover [his]0-i equanimity somewhat . Seeing this , [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks , who had [himself]113-mr. storks [during dinner been first soothed and then ruffled into silence]2584-during dinner been first soothed and then ruffled into silence , found suddenly the strings of [his]113-mr. storks tongue loosed . ‘[1352-young fellows] Now , those are the sort of [young fellows]1352-young fellows , ’ [he]113-mr. storks said , looking after the retreating form of [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders , ‘[1352-young fellows] that really do a good deal to bring all solid knowledge into contempt in the minds of [the half - educated]1353-the half - educated . Do [I]112-mr. herbert understand that [Mr. Saunders]102-mr. saunders ’s arguments may be held , on the face of the thing , to disprove the existence of [God]115-god ? ’[112-mr. herbert] [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks and [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton both stared gravely on [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert ; and said nothing . [We]2592-we must be loyal to nature . [We]2592-we must do nothing per saltum . [We]2592-we must be patient . [We]2592-we must n’t leap at [Utopias]28-utopias , either religious or irreligious . [I]99-mr. luke was particularly anxious , ’[99-mr. luke] [he]99-mr. luke said in a whisper to [Laurence]83-laurence as [he]99-mr. luke drew [his]99-mr. luke chair forward , ‘ to speak of this when [[your]83-laurence Roman Catholic friend]2603-your roman catholic friend was [here]360-here ; as [she]2603-your roman catholic friend seems [a very intelligent young lady]2605-a very intelligent young lady , and is , [I]99-mr. luke have no doubt , fully alive to some of the grotesquenesses of what [she]2603-your roman catholic friend considers to be [her]2603-your roman catholic friend creed . ’[99-mr. luke] [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke resettled [himself]99-mr. luke . On one side of [him]99-mr. luke was [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , in a pale blue opera cloak , bordered with white fur , and embroidered with gold , something in [her]93-miss merton large eyes of a subdued sadness ; and on the other side was [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , all in white , who looked like a wood - anemone against a background of dark foliage . ‘ Now , ’[99-mr. luke] [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke continued , raising [his]99-mr. luke voice a little , but speaking with a more mellow persuasiveness than usual , ‘ [we]2606-we all of [us]2606-we feel , in a general way — [I]99-mr. luke think [I]99-mr. luke may say that [we]2606-we nearly all of [us]2606-we feel — that [the cultured minority of the present age]2607-the cultured minority of the present age is endowed with feelings , sentiments , and powers of insight , not only in advance of its common contemporaries , but in advance of all preceding times . [We]2606-we understand natural beauty , and natural affections , and above all moral beauty , in a new way , all [our]2606-we own . Now , to what is the advance due ? It is all due to culture in its highest connection — its connection with religion . [We]2606-we feel stronger emotions about natural scenery , for just the same reason that [we]2606-we feel stronger emotions about righteousness . And the reason is , that [our]2606-we emotions , in either case , no longer tempt [us]2606-we to draw grotesque inferences from [themselves]2607-the cultured minority of the present age . There ’s the whole heart of the matter . [We]2606-we rest gratefully content with the objects that excite [our]2606-we love ; [we]2606-we do n’t pass away beyond them , and forget them . [You]2608-you had an excellent instance of the old treatment [I]99-mr. luke condemn in those verses of [Euripides]241-euripides which [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence has translated with so much tenderness . There , [you]2608-you see , [you]2608-you have nature — flowers , meadows , and so forth ; and more important still , [you]2608-you have a high conception of virtue . But yet in that poem [you]2608-you have no real feeling for either the flowers or the virtue . The feeling only grazes these , so to speak , and glances off to a shadowy deity beyond , who was no more true , no more verifiable , than [any of the rest of [her]2610-her kind]2609-any of the rest of her kind , male or female , singular or triple . And now , ’[99-mr. luke] [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke went on , turning to [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘ here is another illustration of the whole thing — of the advance made by culture in [our]2606-we entire mental state , of which [I]99-mr. luke particularly wanted to talk to [you]93-miss merton ( for in one point at least [we]2606-we agree , even professedly — the doctrine of development ) , and this is an illustration of it that [you]93-miss merton in a special way will appreciate . [You]93-miss merton , of course , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘ know something more or less about [St. Augustine]158-augustine , [I]99-mr. luke suppose . ’[99-mr. luke] As it was with [her]93-miss merton reading that [Father]266-father ’s account of [his]266-father conversion that [Miss Merton]93-miss merton in a peculiar way associated [her]93-miss merton own , [she]93-miss merton looked at [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke with increased interest , feeling at the same time that [she]93-miss merton had certainly as much knowledge on the subject as [he]99-mr. luke so generously gave [her]93-miss merton credit for . ‘ Well , ’[99-mr. luke] [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke went on , ‘ [Augustine]158-augustine was on the whole , [you]93-miss merton know , the most cultured of all [the Fathers]2611-the fathers , and , considering the early date at which [he]158-augustine lived , had in some ways a real insight into Christianity ; so [we]2612-we may safely consider [him]158-augustine as the most favourable specimen of the results of the old system . Let [us]2612-we take then the purest and most elevating of all the pleasures of life , and enquire , through [him]158-augustine , how it is treated and looked upon by theological Christianity . The eyes , says [Augustine]158-augustine , love fair and various forms , and shining and lovely colours ; and all day long they are before [me]99-mr. luke , and solicit [my]99-mr. luke contemplation . “ For ” ( and this exquisite sentence [I]99-mr. luke remember in [his]158-augustine very words ) “ the Light , that queen of colours , bathing all that [we]2612-we can look upon , from morning till evening , let [me]99-mr. luke go where [I]99-mr. luke will , will still keep gliding by [me]99-mr. luke in unnumbered guises , and soothes [me]99-mr. luke whilst [I]99-mr. luke am busy at other things , and am thinking nothing of [her]93-miss merton . ’[99-mr. luke] ” [Miss Merton]93-miss merton was pleased at the appreciative tone in which [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke quoted . [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke noticed this , and [he]99-mr. luke was pleased also . ‘ And now , ’[99-mr. luke] [he]99-mr. luke continued , ‘ what return does [[our]2612-we gentleman]2613-our gentleman make to the light for its beautiful and constant service to [him]2613-our gentleman ? Does [he]2613-our gentleman thank [it]2613-our gentleman ? does [he]2613-our gentleman praise it ? does [he]2613-our gentleman seek it ? No — ’[99-mr. luke] [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke here gave a little laugh—‘not a bit of it ! [He]99-mr. luke prays to [[his]99-mr. luke God]1362-his god that [he]99-mr. luke may be delivered from its insidious snares ; [he]99-mr. luke envies the blindness of [Tobit]267-tobit , and describes [himself]99-mr. luke as “ earnestly groaning ” under the temptations of these eyes of [his]99-mr. luke flesh . That is all ! There , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , with a confident appeal to [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , whose expression was now slightly altering , ‘[99-mr. luke] [we]1363-we have in a most pointed form the barbarising results of the old theological religion . And now , put side by side with this , the following expression of the religion of sweet reason , such as culture reveals it to [us]1363-we . It deals with exactly the same sense , and the same pleasures : — What soul was [his]99-mr. luke , when , from the naked top Of [some bold headland]1364-some bold headland , [he]99-mr. luke beheld the sun Rise up , and bathe [the world]406-the world in light ! [He]99-mr. luke looked — [Ocean and earth]1366-ocean and earth , the solid frame of earth And [ocean]1367-ocean ’s liquid mass beneath [him]99-mr. luke lay In gladness and deep joy . The clouds were touched , And in [their]1366-ocean and earth silent faces could be read Unutterable love . Sound needed none , Nor any voice of joy ; [his]99-mr. luke spirit drank The spectacle : sensation , soul , and form , All melted into [him]99-mr. luke ; they swallowed up [His]99-mr. luke animal being ; in [them]1366-ocean and earth did [he]99-mr. luke live , And by [them]1366-ocean and earth did [he]99-mr. luke live ; [they]1366-ocean and earth were [his]99-mr. luke life . In such access of mind , in such high hour Of visitation from [the living God]1368-the living god , Thought was not ; in enjoyment it expired ; No thanks [he]99-mr. luke breathed , [he]99-mr. luke proffered no request . ’ A sudden sigh here escaped from some one . [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke looked round . ‘[99-mr. luke] Ah , ’ exclaimed [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , ‘[99-mr. luke] what a description of prayer ! What [a noble]1369-a noble , what a magnificent description ! ’ The fashion of [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke ’s countenance changed . [His]99-mr. luke whole quotation had been ruined , [he]99-mr. luke felt , by this odious interruption . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i never supposed , ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , who thought [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke pausing that [she]93-miss merton might give in [her]93-miss merton acquiescence , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i never supposed [St. Augustine]158-augustine ’s views quite final upon all matters . [I]0-i dare say there are some things that even [I]0-i could have taught [him]158-augustine . ’ [She]93-miss merton smiled as [she]93-miss merton said this ; but there was a little embarrassment in [her]93-miss merton tone which was perceived by [Laurence]83-laurence , and which brought [him]83-laurence at once to [her]93-miss merton rescue . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i , ’ [he]0-i said , ‘[0-i] think the contrast [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke has drawn even stronger than [he]158-augustine has made it . [I]0-i by no means think that [Augustine]158-augustine was afraid of the pleasures of light and sight as they were enjoyed by [Wordsworth]117-wordsworth ; for [I]0-i can hardly fancy that [he]158-augustine could have had the least conception of them . [They]1370-they seem to [me]0-i a new and peculiar heritage , which [we]1371-our may all more or less have part in ; but which by former ages were undreamt of , not rejected . [I]0-i often [myself]0-i look back on a certain early walk [I]0-i took one spring morning in [these gardens]2158-these gardens — amongst the very trees and flowerbeds [we]1371-our are now looking out upon . The fresh softness that was in the air , and all the wandering scents , like dreams or prophecies of summers gone or coming , and the wet light glistening on the dewy leaves , seemed to go at once to the soul — to “ melt into [me]0-i , ” as into [[Wordsworth]117-wordsworth ’s herdsman]1373-wordsworth ’s herdsman . Once [I]0-i surprised [myself]0-i stooping under a dripping bough , to look upwards at a yellow flower , and watch it lonely against a background of blue sky ; and once [I]0-i started to find [myself]0-i quite lost in staring at a red rock , gleaming amongst shrubs and ivy , which a plant of periwinkle spangled with a constellation of purple stars . The colour , the shape , the smell of every leaf and flower — each seemed to touch [me]0-i like a note of music ; and the bloom of morning mist was over everything . ’ ‘[0-i] Ah , ’ said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , [her]106-mrs. sinclair dark eyes gleaming in the moonlight , ‘[0-i] how those spring mornings sometimes make one sick with longing ! ’ ‘[0-i] Yes , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[0-i] with longing — with a vague longing ; not always , [I]0-i am afraid , with thanksgiving or with praise . But [I]0-i think the feeling in all its moods is the same in some ways . It is a mixing together of outward and inward things — [our]1371-our whole inward lives passing out of [us]1371-our into Nature ; Nature melting into [us]1371-our , and growing part of [our]1371-our inward lives , so that all [our]1371-our hopes and fears and memories become embodied things , touching [us]1371-our in scents of flowers , in the breath of the air , in the sparkle of water , or mixing , like [Hamadryads]268-hamadryads , [their]268-hamadryads beings with the trees . Now , could [I]0-i have described such feelings as these — [my]0-i own state of mind during [my]0-i morning walk — to [Saint Augustine]269-saint augustine , [he]269-saint augustine would not have understood [me]0-i . [He]269-saint augustine would have thought [me]0-i raving . And [my]0-i case is not peculiar . These feelings are no private things of [my]0-i own . They belong to [our]1371-our whole age . And of this , ’ [Laurence]83-laurence went on , ‘[1374-you] [you]1374-you may see a very curious proof in a part of [our]1371-our modern literature , which as literature is least successful . [I]0-i mean , a certain class of novels : not the works of [the greater novelists]1375-the greater novelists , still less the works of [the professional novel - manufacturers]1376-the professional novel - manufacturers ; not these , but a sort of production almost peculiar to [our]1371-our own time — the novels of [amateurs , who write perhaps but a single book]1377-amateurs , who write perhaps but a single book during [their]1377-amateurs , who write perhaps but a single book whole lives ; and that one , with the simple aim of pouring out [their]1377-amateurs , who write perhaps but a single book own feelings for [themselves]1377-amateurs , who write perhaps but a single book to contemplate , or of explaining to [themselves]1377-amateurs , who write perhaps but a single book or [others]341-others [their]1377-amateurs , who write perhaps but a single book own histories . ’ ‘[1374-you] And so , ’ said [Mr. Storks]113-mr. storks , ‘[1374-you] [you]1374-you would gauge the refinement of the age by its silliest novels ? ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i think [we]1371-our too often forget , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[0-i] that a very silly book may be evidently the work of [a very clever person]1379-a very clever person ; and may show [its author]1380-its author possessed of every gift , except that of literature . And in many of the poor novels [I]0-i am speaking of , the utter failure of the expression often only calls [our]1371-our attention more strongly to the depth , the delicacy , and the refinement of what [the writer]651-the writer has struggled to express . [I]0-i was reading [a girl]1940-a girl ’s novel in [the train]1383-the train the other day , called Love in a Life . Its long spasms of ungrammatical verbiage , its utter want of knowledge of [the world]406-the world , would have turned [the dullest reviewer]1385-the dullest reviewer , in spite of [himself]1385-the dullest reviewer , into a caustic wit . But there was a something all through it , that [its authoress]1386-its authoress was trying — trying to utter , that reminded [me]0-i of [Ariel]270-ariel trying to escape from [his]1387-his tree . What , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose ! Have [you]92-lady ambrose written a novel ? No ? Then why are [you]92-lady ambrose looking so mysterious , and so full of meaning ? ’ ‘[92-lady ambrose] Go on , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘[83-laurence] [I]0-i ’ll show [you]83-laurence by - and - by . ’ ‘[0-i] Well , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[0-i] take any one of these novels , and [you]92-lady ambrose will find [the writer]651-the writer looking on [Nature]121-nature in just that peculiar modern way that [we]1389-we have been talking of . [I]0-i do n’t say [you]92-lady ambrose will always find the sentiment in the books , but the books will show [you]92-lady ambrose that [you]92-lady ambrose would find it in [the writers]1390-the writers . And this feeling about Nature is but an example of others . Take , as [I]0-i said , the modern conception of love , and study that too , in these foolish novels . [You]92-lady ambrose will find half the folly comes from an attempt to express much , not from success in expressing little . ’ A pause followed this . It was broken at last by [Allen]101-allen . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i quite agree with [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , ’ [he]101-allen said diffidently . ‘[83-laurence] [I]0-i have not much right to judge , [I]0-i dare say . [I]0-i am not [a great reader]1391-a great reader ; and [I]0-i can only speak from books . But still [I]0-i know a little of the love poetry of this and of other times ; and the poetry of this has always seemed to [me]0-i far — far the highest . It has seemed to [me]0-i to give the passion so much more meaning , and such a much greater influence over all life . And this , [I]0-i suppose , must be because [men]1704-men , as [the world]406-the world goes on , are really learning to love in a higher way than perhaps [they]1704-men [themselves]1704-men are often conscious of . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i think [some philosopher]1394-some philosopher , ’ murmured [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair to [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘[0-i] says [we]1395-we feel that [we]1395-we are greater than [we]1395-we know . It must be a great comfort sometimes to know that [we]1395-we are greater than [we]1395-we feel . ’ ‘[271-novalis] Is it not [Novalis]271-novalis , ’ went on [Allen]101-allen , ‘[271-novalis] who says that if [all the human race]1396-all the human race were [a single pair of lovers]1397-a single pair of lovers , the difference between mysticism and non - mysticism would cease ? Would that have been understood even a hundred years ago ? But as to [poets]799-poets , [I]0-i was thinking of [two English poets of [our]1395-we own day]1399-two english poets of our own day especially . [Shakespeare]195-shakespeare may of course have exhibited the working of love more powerfully than [they]1399-two english poets of our own day ; yet [I]0-i am sure [he]195-shakespeare could never have conceived its meaning and its nature so deeply . [No heroine of [his]195-shakespeare]1400-no heroine of his could have understood [Mrs. Browning]272-mrs. browning ’s Sonnets from the Portuguese ; nor [any hero of [[his]195-shakespeare [her]272-mrs. browning husband]1402-his her husband ’s love lyrics]1401-any hero of his her husband ’s love lyrics . What seems to [me]0-i the thing so peculiarly modern , is this notion of love as something which , once truly attained , would , as [Browning]272-mrs. browning says , make Time break , Letting [us]1395-we pent - up creatures through Into Eternity , [our]1395-we due . ’ ‘[272-mrs. browning] Ah ! ’ murmured [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , ‘[272-mrs. browning] but suppose there is no eternity ! [I]0-i think [we]1395-we had better take what [we]1395-we can , and be thankful . Listen — listen again ! “ [The nightingales]1403-the nightingales , [the nightingales]1403-the nightingales ! ” There , [Lord Allen]101-allen , there is a bit of [your]101-allen [Mrs. Browning]272-mrs. browning for [you]101-allen . ’ ‘[272-mrs. browning] What , [Lord Allen]101-allen ! ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[101-allen] and is [Mr. Robert Browning]112-mr. herbert a better poet than [Shakespeare]195-shakespeare ? [I]0-i always thought [Shakespeare]195-shakespeare was quite [our]1395-we best . ’ ‘[0-i] It is not a question , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , as [Allen]101-allen did not speak , ‘[1405-different poets] of [different poets]1405-different poets , but of different ages . [I]0-i have often wondered [myself]0-i how far [Faust]151-faust would have appealed to [the author of [Hamlet]237-hamlet]1406-the author of hamlet , and whether all the spiritual action of the drama , in so far as it relates to [the heroine]1407-the heroine , might not be lost upon [him]1406-the author of hamlet . What a difference between [Margaret]273-margaret and [Ophelia]274-ophelia — not between [themselves]1408-themselves , but between the parts [they]1408-themselves play ! [Shakespeare]195-shakespeare [himself]195-shakespeare might have understood [Margaret]273-margaret ’s influence . [I]0-i doubt it . But even if [he]195-shakespeare had , that would prove little . [Shakespeare]195-shakespeare ’s was The prophetic soul Of [the wide world]1409-the wide world dreaming on things to come ; and the “ wide world ” of [his]195-shakespeare time would itself have understood nothing of it . But what strikes [me]0-i still more than the growth of particular feelings , is the infusion and the inter - penetration of all . Look at [Shakespeare]195-shakespeare ’s Sonnets . [He]195-shakespeare loved the objects [they]1410-they were addressed to ; [he]195-shakespeare loved flowers and Nature . But these two sets of things were connected only in [his]195-shakespeare mind , they were not fused . Take , however , that most typical of all modern poems — the celebrated love - song in [Maud]72-maud , and think of that : — The slender acacia would not shake One long milk - bloom on the tree ; The white lake - blossom fell into [the lake]1411-the lake . And the pimpernel dozed on [the lea]1412-the lea ; But the rose was awake all night for [your]1413-your sake , Knowing [your]1413-your promise to [me]0-i ; The lilies and roses were all awake , What a passion is here ! [We]1414-we almost hear [the lover]1415-the lover ’s pulses as they painfully beat quicker . [Our]1414-we breath catches with [his]195-shakespeare ; and [we]1414-we long and long with [his]195-shakespeare longing . And yet hardly a word about [his]195-shakespeare feelings is said directly . The secret is echoed back to [us]1414-we from the scene and from the summer night . It is the milk - bloom of the acacia , the musk of the roses , the stir of the morning breeze , that tells it all to [us]1414-we as if they were living things , and as if a human passion had passed into them for a soul . Now , would [the world]406-the world have understood this in any other times but [ours]1414-we ? [I]0-i do n’t think even [Shakespeare]195-shakespeare ’s [Jessica]275-jessica would , nor [Dante]206-dante ’s [Beatrice]276-beatrice , nor [Petrarch]200-petrarch ’s [Laura]277-laura , nor [Horace]87-horace ’s [Lydia]203-miss lydia white , nor [Plato]153-plato ’s Diotima , nor [Homer]278-homer ’s [Helen]279-helen . ’ ‘[279-helen] Listen ! ’ exclaimed [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose eagerly , as soon as [Laurence]83-laurence stopped ; ‘[1417-you] will [you]1417-you let [me]0-i read one passage out of [my]0-i work which bears upon this very point — in fact , sums up exactly what [you]1417-you have been saying ? [The goddess of this love]1419-the goddess of this love is no longer [the Aphrodite of [the Greeks]1163-the greeks]1420-the aphrodite of the greeks , or [the Mary of [the Christians]326-the christians]1422-the mary of the christians , [She]1419-the goddess of this love is [a mysterious hybrid being , in whose veins is the blood of both of [them]1425-them]1424-a mysterious hybrid being , in whose veins is the blood of both of them . All the joys , indeed , of the senses have fallen into it , like streams into [one sea]2617-one sea . And with the joys of the spirit it has been likewise . But whereas the senses have contributed [their]2618-their joys mainly , the spirit has contributed its sorrows and pains as well . Throughout this love , despite its fulness of life , there yet runs also a constant taint of death , of which it needs cleansing — grotesque troubles and misgivings of conscience , and cloistral meditations , and fantastic repentances . For this very reason , however , is it the more wholly expressive to [us]2619-us of [the man]1772-the man ’s inner development . It shows [us]2619-us how all [his]1772-the man desires , senses , and powers of feeling have been growing together , and coalescing into [a single organism , capable of quite new sets of pleasures , and responding to far finer movements from without]2621-a single organism , capable of quite new sets of pleasures , and responding to far finer movements from without . ” ’[100-mr. rose] ‘ H’m , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke slowly , in a tone of meditative commendation , ‘ there ’s a great deal of truth in that — a very great deal — if [the fellow]2622-the fellow , ’[99-mr. luke] [he]99-mr. luke added to [himself]99-mr. luke , ‘ would only put it a little better . ’[99-mr. luke] ‘ Are [you]100-mr. rose quite sure , ’[95-dr. jenkinson] said [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , looking round [him]100-mr. rose in an agony of suppressed irritation , ‘ that [anyone at all]2623-anyone at all feels all these things , beyond [the very few people who talk about them]2624-the very few people who talk about them ? ’[95-dr. jenkinson] ‘ Yes , ’[100-mr. rose] said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , smiling with a honeyed gravity , and wholly unconscious of [the Doctor]376-the doctor ’s animus , ‘ all feel thus who have any part or lot in [the world]406-the world ’s development . ’[100-mr. rose] ‘ [You]100-mr. rose , ’[376-the doctor] said [the Doctor]376-the doctor , turning sharply away from [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , ‘ think so , [Laurence]83-laurence , do n’t [you]100-mr. rose , because [you]100-mr. rose find some of the same sort of phrases in novels ? They are effeminate foolish books . ’[376-the doctor] ‘ Yes , ’[101-allen] said [Allen]101-allen with an assenting voice that much pleased [the Doctor]376-the doctor , ‘ a great deal of this increased depth and refinement of feeling , [I]101-allen know , is very good — all of it , [I]101-allen dare say , may be . But still , if left to itself , it must tend — indeed , [I]101-allen have often seen it tend — to make [men]1704-men effeminate , as [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson says , and unfit for work . Now , [I]101-allen dare say [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke will call [me]101-allen [a barbarian]2627-a barbarian , but [I]101-allen am going to venture to say that , in spite of all that is said against it , that barbarous thing sport — shooting , deer - stalking , hunting — is of great value , especially to [people who are not barbarians , as a kind of mental tonic]2628-people who are not barbarians , as a kind of mental tonic . It makes [them]2628-people who are not barbarians , as a kind of mental tonic active and spirited — it must do so : it gives [them]2628-people who are not barbarians , as a kind of mental tonic presence of mind , and a readiness to exert [themselves]2628-people who are not barbarians , as a kind of mental tonic ; and though sport may in one sense be a self - indulgence , it is a self - indulgence that is constantly teaching all sorts of self - denial . ’[101-allen] ‘ [[My]99-mr. luke dear]892-my dear [Lord Allen]101-allen , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘ [I]99-mr. luke most entirely agree with [you]101-allen . It does seem , [I]99-mr. luke admit , at first sight , a somewhat singular thing , that the result of the latest civilisation should be to give [men]1704-men leisure to return to the occupations of [their]1704-men earliest barbarism — and those too deprived of [their]1704-men one justification — necessity . But still these barbarous sports must , as [you]101-allen say , if not pursued too exclusively , give a valuable moral tone to [minds whose refinement might else become weakness]2631-minds whose refinement might else become weakness . Only the worst of the matter , as it actually stands , is this — that [the majority of [people who do follow sport]2633-people who do follow sport]2632-the majority of people who do follow sport , are [the very people who have no refinement that needs strengthening , but merely an idle aimless strength that needs refining]2634-the very people who have no refinement that needs strengthening , but merely an idle aimless strength that needs refining . And [you]101-allen must remember , [Lord Allen]101-allen , that [the man who is gluttonous of aimless bodily action]2635-the man who is gluttonous of aimless bodily action is no better than [the man who is an epicure in aimless mental emotion]2636-the man who is an epicure in aimless mental emotion . ’[99-mr. luke] ‘ And so , ’[103-donald gordon] said [Donald Gordon]103-donald gordon , with devout solemnity , ‘ this is what [we]2637-our must remedy in [[our]2637-our new Republic]890-our new republic . [[Our]2637-our gentlemen]2639-our gentlemen there must have both sides of [their]2639-our gentlemen nature developed equally ; and [they]2639-our gentlemen must be at once so intellectual and so manly , as to be content that partridges and foxes shall die exclusively for [them]2639-our gentlemen , without [their]2639-our gentlemen living exclusively for partridges and foxes . ’[103-donald gordon] ‘ Exactly so , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke drily . ‘ [Some one]551-some one observed this afternoon , ’[101-allen] said [Allen]101-allen , turning a little stiffly to [Donald Gordon]103-donald gordon , ‘ how one could see the expression of [a girl]1940-a girl ’s face changed by the influence of [a little genuine mental culture]2642-a little genuine mental culture . And [I]101-allen think [myself]101-allen that [the moors of [[your]103-donald gordon country]2645-your country]2644-the moors of your country , or [a river in [Norway]15-norway]2646-a river in norway , or a good cruise in [a yacht]2647-a yacht , may go — well , at least half as far towards making [a complete man]2648-a complete man , as the study of books , and art , and poetry , in an arm - chair , or in a picture - gallery . ’[101-allen] ‘ [I]93-miss merton think that is so true , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton softly to [him]103-donald gordon in a whisper , for [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson had begun to speak . ‘ But , ’[376-the doctor] [the Doctor]376-the doctor was saying , ‘ [you]103-donald gordon must want something besides looking at pretty scenery , and falling in love , and shooting .
