[I]99-mr. luke mean travelling , and the halving of [our]2650-we lives between [town and country]359-town and country . The completeness , the many - sidedness of such culture as there is amongst [us]2650-we , is in a great measure due to these ; but it is only slowly that [we]2650-we are learning to use them properly . Of course , [Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , [you]103-donald gordon understand all this — [no man]684-no man can do so better . It is simply the music and gymnastic of [the Greeks]222-the greeks . It is simply true education , which is but another name for culture . And in [the cultivated man]2655-the cultivated man , thought , and taste , and feeling , and spirit are really all one , and fused together . Could [we]2650-we but look forward to a time when all or even the greater part of [those one meets]2656-those one meets would unite these priceless gifts , there might then indeed be some satisfaction and some hope in life . ’[99-mr. luke] ‘ And do n’t [you]95-dr. jenkinson want goodness ? ’[95-dr. jenkinson] said [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , all [his]95-dr. jenkinson sharpness returning ; ‘ do [you]95-dr. jenkinson want no sense of duty , and right , and wrong ? ’[95-dr. jenkinson] ‘ Yes , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ but [we]2650-we have included that already . [We]2650-we have found that that is pre - supposed in every educated pleasure . It is that that gives even [our]2650-we lightest conversation its best sparkle , and beads its surface over with its bright , crisp foam of half - conscious irony . The moral ideal is a note , as it were , which [we]2650-we are always hearing , and with which [our]2650-we daily talk makes continual harmonies , because it is never pitched in unison with it . Thus [we]2650-we talk of killing time , and so on , as being the great end of [our]2650-we lives ; of money or position being the only thing to marry for ; and of marriage ties as if they were always a weariness , or a grotesque torture . ’[83-laurence] ‘ And thus , ’[114-leslie] said [Leslie]114-leslie , ‘ [we]2650-we say [a man]1770-a man has had , par excellence , a success , when [he]1770-a man has , for [his]1770-a man own selfish pleasure , done [a woman]1817-a woman the greatest injury possible . ’[114-leslie] ‘ And thus , ’[103-donald gordon] said [Donald Gordon]103-donald gordon softly , ‘ when [he]1770-a man does not tell all [the world]406-the world [he]1770-a man has done so , [we]2650-we say [he]1770-a man is [a perfect gentleman]2660-a perfect gentleman . ’[103-donald gordon] ‘ And do [you]99-mr. luke want no religion ? ’[95-dr. jenkinson] said [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , paying no attention to all this , but again turning to [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke . ‘ [[My]99-mr. luke dear]892-my dear [Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘ [you]95-dr. jenkinson and [I]99-mr. luke agree upon these matters so well , that [I]99-mr. luke think [you]95-dr. jenkinson must be trying to misunderstand [us]2650-we . Can religion and morals be separated ? and are not [they]2662-they both included in what [we]2650-we mean by culture ? Is it not in virtue of culture — of that nice and complex discrimination — that [we]2650-we can tell at once when [we]2650-we come across a genuine logion of [Jesus]283-jesus amongst the sayings vulgarly supposed to be most distinctive of [Him]283-jesus ? Think , for instance , ’[99-mr. luke] [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke continued , ‘ what a beautiful and profound harmony is at once made amongst [our]2650-we heartstrings , if culture have really tuned them , by such a story as that of [the woman taken in adultery]2663-the woman taken in adultery , or by the parable of [the Prodigal Son]2664-the prodigal son , or by such simple , pregnant sayings as , “ ὑπάγω καὶ ἔρχομαι πρὸς ” and then turn for a moment to the theological accounts of the Trinity ! Why , ’[99-mr. luke] exclaimed [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke with a sudden jauntiness , ‘ to sit on the key - board of an organ would make music compared to the discord , the jangling , the string - breaking that Church Catechisms , and Athanasian Creeds , and Episcopal speculations on the personality of [the Creator]1426-the creator , make on the musical instrument of the cultured mind . Ah , ’[99-mr. luke] [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke continued , ‘ could [the Founder of Christianity]2666-the founder of christianity only have found [men of more culture]2667-men of more culture as [[His]2666-the founder of christianity immediate disciples]2668-his immediate disciples and [reporters]2669-reporters — could [He]2666-the founder of christianity only have secured a biographer as simply honest as [poor Boswell]284-poor boswell was — Well , well , but it ’s no use speculating about what might have been . Religion has had bad times hitherto , but now at last [we]2650-we — some of [us]2650-we , at least — are seeing the way to make them better ; [you]2670-you [yourself]2670-you , [Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , amongst the number . And all this is due to that very thing which [we]2650-we say is the essence of the best human life — culture ; culture which is neither religion , nor morality , nor taste , nor intellect , nor knowledge , nor wide reading , but the single result of all — and this , ’[99-mr. luke] [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke added , ‘ showing itself to the full — doing itself complete justice , through — as [[our]2650-we friends]1043-our friends have already said — what [we]2650-we call polish and high - breeding , and refinement of manner , and of manners . ’[99-mr. luke] ‘ Surely [you]2670-you , ’[110-mr. stockton] said [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , turning to [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson with the most mollifying deference , ‘ must agree with [us]2650-we that the present century has seen the soul of [man]1888-man widening out , with all its marvellous powers , and displaying new riches of beauty like an unfolding flower . But whilst [we]2650-we value — and none can value more than [I]110-mr. stockton — [our]2650-we higher flights of imagination , [our]2650-we finer forms of love , and poetry , and worship , [I]110-mr. stockton am not blind to [the great agent that is at the bottom of all this change]2673-the great agent that is at the bottom of all this change . [I]110-mr. stockton mean the emancipated human intellect , with all its manifold apparatus of discovery and conquest — [that great liberator of life]2674-that great liberator of life , and thought , and religion . ’[110-mr. stockton] ‘ There is some truth in that , ’[95-dr. jenkinson] said [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , not ungraciously , ‘ but [I]95-dr. jenkinson think [you]2670-you are all putting it in a wrong way . Will this religion of [yours]99-mr. luke , as [you]99-mr. luke told [us]2650-we in the afternoon it was based on the discrimination between good and evil , also involve a discrimination between life and death ? Will it , [I]95-dr. jenkinson mean , point to any other life beyond this , or will it not ? Is whatever evil and sorrow [we]2650-we patiently suffer , a thing which , if it do not bring its reward to [us]2650-we here , will never bring [us]2650-we any reward at all ? And shall [we]2650-we call the death of [the noble sufferer blessed]2678-the noble sufferer blessed for no other reason than that [he]2678-the noble sufferer blessed rests from [his]2678-the noble sufferer blessed labours and [his]2678-the noble sufferer blessed works do not follow [him]2678-the noble sufferer blessed ? ’[95-dr. jenkinson] ‘ Dear [me]95-dr. jenkinson ! dear [me]95-dr. jenkinson ! ’[95-dr. jenkinson] said [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson petulantly to [himself]95-dr. jenkinson . ‘ These sort of questions ought never to be asked in that hard abrupt way . [You]99-mr. luke ca n’t answer them — [you]99-mr. luke ca n’t answer them . ’[95-dr. jenkinson] [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , however , found no difficulty with [his]110-mr. stockton answer . ‘ As to that , ’[110-mr. stockton] [he]110-mr. stockton said , ‘ [each man]2679-each man would think as [he]2679-each man pleased , and [his]2679-each man thoughts would shape themselves to meet the deepest needs of [his]2679-each man life . In the state of society [we]2680-we long for , the belief in a future life would be open to all to accept or to reject . The only thing to guard against would be any definite public opinion on the matter , one way or the other ; for in any definite public opinion , remember , there is the germ of all dogmatism and of all persecution . Public opinion , in society as it ought to be , would be a frictionless fluid , if [I]110-mr. stockton may borrow a metaphor from science , in which no adventitious obstacle from prejudice or otherwise would impede the progress of any view that its own merits set in motion . ’[110-mr. stockton] [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke was certainly [an unfortunate man]1431-an unfortunate man . [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton had again , in part at least , expressed the exact thing which in other words [he]110-mr. stockton was going to have said [himself]110-mr. stockton . [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , however , did not flinch . [He]99-mr. luke boldly took the bull by the horns . ‘ True , ’[99-mr. luke] [he]99-mr. luke said ; ‘ that metaphor is ingenious , and explains exactly what [we]2680-we want to explain . That is one of the great conditions of a truly cultivated society , what [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton calls a frictionless public opinion — a public opinion which shall let every system , every creed , every philosophy of life , stand or fall on its own practical verifiable merits ; and this [we]2680-we shall get , too , if [we]2680-we can only banish two things , prejudice and ignorance , of which last , ’[99-mr. luke] [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke added , looking studiously away from [Mr. Stockton]110-mr. stockton , ‘ by far the deadliest form is the fetish - worship of useless knowledge . ’[99-mr. luke] ‘ Well , ’[93-miss merton] said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton , ‘ [I]93-miss merton suppose that this is all that any of [us]2680-we would ask , who really and truly believe in what [we]2680-we profess to believe . ’[93-miss merton] ‘ Of course it is , ’[99-mr. luke] said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘ everything:—everything . ’[99-mr. luke] ‘ And [I]93-miss merton ’m[93-miss merton] quite sure , ’ said [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , ‘[99-mr. luke] that in a society where the tone is so nobly liberal , and where [all have such a true and burning admiration of the morally beautiful]1432-all have such a true and burning admiration of the morally beautiful , it will be quite impossible that [woman]496-woman ’s life shall not be seen to be what it really is — a thing as capable as [men ’s of high aims , and independent purposes]1434-men ’s of high aims , and independent purposes , and not , as it were , entirely sunk in [theirs]1435-theirs . [I]0-i , [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , in face of such a public opinion as [you]99-mr. luke speak of , should have little fear for [our]1436-us cause . [I]0-i think , under [God]115-god , it would prosper there . ’ ‘[0-i] Of course it would , ’ said [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke . ‘[0-i] If culture enables [us]1436-us to detect beauty and to prize it , what should it enable [us]1436-us to prize more than womanhood , with all its exquisite capabilities developed to [their]1437-their utmost ? Life has no greater ornament than cultured womanhood . ’ ‘[115-god] Except cultured manhood , ’ said [Lady Grace]89-lady grace , unconsciously giving [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke a slight wound by [her]89-lady grace generous and unexpected return of [his]99-mr. luke royal compliment . ‘[115-god] Ah , ’ [she]89-lady grace sighed to [herself]89-lady grace with a look at [Mr. Luke]99-mr. luke , ‘[99-mr. luke] and [he]99-mr. luke does not believe in [God]115-god — or thinks [he]99-mr. luke does not ! [I]0-i suppose it must needs be that offences come ; but [I]0-i wish [they]1438-their did not come by [such good men]1439-such good men . However — [I]0-i trust that it is all really for the best . And then — there is no such thing as eternal punishment . [One]1681-one may be thankful to feel sure of that . ’ ‘[1681-one] [I]0-i am afraid [you]1441-you will think [me]0-i very troublesome , ’ said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , who had been talking to [Laurence]83-laurence in a low tone for the last few minutes . ‘[1441-you] but there is one question more [I]0-i should like to ask [you]1441-you . [I]0-i want to know if [you]1441-you , who see the many delicate beauties of life , and the countless positions it may be viewed from,—I want to know if [you]1441-you will teach the lower , [the commoner classes]1442-the commoner classes , who look up to [you]1441-you as [models , to quote poetry]1443-models , to quote poetry , and to be enquiring and sceptical also ? ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i hope not , indeed , ’ broke in [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose with vigour ; ‘[0-i] and as to [our]1444-our being [[their]1438-their models]1445-their models , [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , [I]0-i ’m sure [you]112-mr. herbert ca n’t mean that . It seems to [me]0-i one of the very worst things in these times that [they]1438-their will take [us]1444-our for [their]1438-their models . However , [I]0-i think it is really a good deal [our]1444-our fault , and that it comes very much from [our]1444-our giving [[our]1444-our maids]2681-our maids so many of [our]1444-our old clothes to wear . That sort of thing puts notions into [their]1438-their heads . Now , here at any rate is one reform , that is implied in [our]1444-our Republic;—I do n’t like that word Republic , by the way — [we]1444-our must put a stop to all this imitation of [ourselves]1444-our . Is n’t that so , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence ? ’[0-i] ‘ Thank [you]0-i , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ’[112-mr. herbert] said [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , rising , ‘ thank [you]0-i . [I]112-mr. herbert think it altogether a wise — nay , more than wise , an essential thing , to keep these wide speculations from spreading beyond the only circles that they are really fitted for . [I]112-mr. herbert have to go [indoors]2682-indoors now , as [I]112-mr. herbert have a few matters to arrange to - night ; but [I]112-mr. herbert am much obliged to [you]0-i all for what [you]0-i have taught [me]112-mr. herbert about culture , and enlightenment , and society , as it ought to be . ’[112-mr. herbert] ‘ The difficulty is , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , as [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert was walking away , ‘ how to keep all this thought , and so forth , to [ourselves]1446-we . One thing [I]112-mr. herbert ’m[112-mr. herbert] quite certain of , that [we]1446-we really do a great deal of harm without thinking of it , by the way in which [we]1446-we speak [our]1446-we minds out before [servants]1447-servants , and [that sort of people]1448-that sort of people , without in the least considering what may come of it . Now , what do [you]1449-you think of this , as a plan for making [our]1446-we ideal state a really good and contented [place?—the upper classes]1450-place?—the upper classes should speak a different language from [the lower classes]1451-the lower classes . Of course [we]1446-we should be able to speak [theirs]1452-they , but [they]1452-they would not be able to speak [ours]1446-we . And then , [you]1449-you see , [they]1452-they would never hear [us]1446-we talk , or read [our]1446-we books , or get hold of [our]1446-we ideas ; which , after all , is what does all the mischief . And yet , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose with a sigh , ‘[1452-they] that ’s not the great difficulty . Now , are all of [us]1460-we ready to be let into the secrets of [a young lady]1461-a young lady ’s soul ? — ‘ “ [One]1681-one often feels a longing — [who has not felt it?—in the hurry and trouble of life]2684-who has not felt it?—in the hurry and trouble of life to pause for a little while and look back upon the past , which [we]1460-we too too often forget , and see what it is [we]1460-we have grown from . Turn over a page or two . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ “ How strangely do [they]2687-they come back to [me]83-laurence , those distant irrevocable days ! ” Will that do ? ’[83-laurence] asked [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘ Yes , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose think so — go on there . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ “ — those distant irrevocable days , when [the world]406-the world was all new to [me]83-laurence , and each experience was fresh and delightful , and [I]83-laurence knew nothing of what self - reproach could mean . Ah , [me]83-laurence ! how times have changed since then ! [I]83-laurence sometimes fancy that [I]83-laurence am hardly worthy now to look back upon [my]83-laurence own past . [I]83-laurence was gifted naturally with a curious warmth and sincerity of nature , that must have been very beautiful . But [my]83-laurence peculiar gift , [my]83-laurence own own gift , was a power of sympathy with [others]341-others , by which quite naturally [I]83-laurence used to throw [myself]83-laurence into [their]341-others places , understand [their]341-others difficulties , and excite [myself]83-laurence with [their]341-others interests . When [I]83-laurence was yet quite [a child]549-a child , that , [I]83-laurence know , is what [men]1704-men felt in [me]83-laurence — [I]83-laurence never cared for [boys]2692-boys — [one man]723-one man especially . It was then that life began for [me]83-laurence , and what it all meant broke on [me]83-laurence like a revelation . [I]83-laurence , in [my]83-laurence simplicity , never dreamt of [his]723-one man being more than [a friend]2414-a friend — [I]83-laurence am not sure even that [he]723-one man was [[my]83-laurence dearest friend]2695-my dearest friend . [I]83-laurence certainly never tried to charm [him]723-one man . But [I]83-laurence did charm [him]723-one man , nevertheless , quite unconsciously . And [he]723-one man loved [me]83-laurence passionately , devotedly , [child]1723-child as [I]83-laurence was . Ah , [God]115-god ! when will [another]2697-another ever feel the same for [me]83-laurence ? And [I—‘O]83-laurence , [my]83-laurence lost , [[my]83-laurence rejected friend]2698-my rejected friend ! come back to [me]83-laurence ’[83-laurence] , sometimes [I]0-i still cry in [my]0-i solitude ; ‘ poor , and obscurely connected as [you]1463-you are , come back to [me]0-i ! ’[0-i] [I]0-i shall never forget — poor little [me!—the]1462-me!—the solemn shock of the moment , how [my]0-i heart stood still , how all the blood came rushing into [my]0-i cheek , when all of a sudden , as it seemed to [me]0-i , and without any warning , [he]1463-you asked [me]0-i to be [[his]1463-you wife]2020-his wife . Everything seemed to grow dizzy before [me]0-i . It seemed to [me]0-i as if the day of judgment had come . ( Alas ! will there ever be a day of judgment at all ? is what [I]0-i now ask . ) [I]0-i do n’t know what [I]0-i said . [I]0-i only remember distinctly [my]0-i throwing [myself]0-i into [[my]0-i mother]1465-my mother ’s arms , and crying like [a child]549-a child — and [I]0-i was one — as if [my]0-i very heart would break . ‘ [I]0-i am only [a child]549-a child ! ’[0-i] that is what [I]0-i said . ‘ Oh , [mother]2700-mother , [I]0-i am such [a child]549-a child ! ’[0-i] The pathos of the scene often comes back to [me]0-i even now — a shadowy timid memory , wondering if [I]0-i shall give it harbour . [I]0-i remember , too , how [I]0-i said [my]0-i prayers that night , and how [I]0-i asked [God]115-god — ” ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i think [you]0-i need n’t read that , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[0-i] go on a page or two further . ’ ‘[0-i] “ [I]0-i spent much of [my]0-i time sketching . ” Shall [I]0-i go on [there]1691-there ? ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘[0-i] “ [I]0-i had always a curiously appreciative eye for natural beauty . ” Will that do ? Or shall [I]0-i go on here — [I]0-i think this is better — at the next paragraph?—“Oh the great waste of love in [this our world]1468-this our world . ” ’ ‘[0-i] Yes , go on there , ’ said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair and [several others]2702-several others . ‘[0-i] “ Oh the great waste of love in [this [our]1470-our world]1468-this our world ! How many a true heart would have given itself to [me]0-i , could [I]0-i only honestly and unreservedly have opened out to it all the depths of [mine]0-i , and received it ! And why did [I]0-i never do so ? It may be that [I]0-i have known none who could really understand [me]0-i — none that [I]0-i could really love . But does that excuse [me]0-i , not for not loving [them]1471-their , but for making as though [I]0-i did love [them]1471-their , and so ruining [their]1471-their lives and searing [my]0-i own ? sending [them]1471-their in the end to [their]1471-their brandy - bottles , and [their]1471-their gaming - hells , and [their]1471-their wild Cremornes , and [myself]0-i — to the mental state in which [I]0-i am now ! ‘ “ Have [I]0-i then lost it for ever — lost all hope of love ? and must [I]0-i quietly take up with [my]0-i unappreciated loneliness ? If it is so , if , indeed , it is so , surely [I]0-i have brought it on [myself]0-i . Was there not one — not [[my]0-i earliest lover]2703-my earliest lover — but another , who with a devotion [I]0-i understood far more fully , laid [himself]2704-his at [my]0-i feet , and offered [me]0-i all [[his]2704-his man]2705-his man ’s devotion , and [[his]2704-his man]2705-his man ’s sympathy ! Why , why in [my]0-i madness did [I]0-i send [him]2704-his from [me]0-i , penniless as [he]2704-his was — but what of that?—driving [him]2704-his to death , and leaving [myself]0-i to desolation ? How does the image of [his]2704-his pale still face upturned towards the Indian star - light , with eyes which no star - light could ever touch any more , rise before [me]0-i — [his]2704-his hand on [his]2704-his breast , and clasping with its last grasp a locket with [my]0-i picture in it ! Yes , [I]0-i see [him]2704-his there , though [I]0-i did not see [him]2704-his . [I]0-i know how [he]2704-his must have looked , with [his]2704-his heart bullet - pierced — noble , beautiful in death . Unworthy as [I]0-i was of [you]2707-you , [[my]0-i true - hearted one]2708-my true - hearted one , too late , too late , did [I]0-i learn [my]0-i own unworthiness . [I]0-i was sitting in the window of [[our]2709-our house at [Ventnor]73-ventnor]2710-our house at ventnor , when the letter came that told [me]0-i . It was evening ; and [I]0-i had been looking out through the summer twilight at [the sea]300-the sea and at the sunset . As [I]0-i read the letter , it dropped from [my]0-i hand . [I]0-i gave a gasp . [I]0-i repressed a shrill cry . [I]0-i felt a choking sensation in [my]0-i throat ; but [I]0-i was very proud , and [I]0-i even repressed a sob . [I]0-i only , with entire calmness , turned [my]0-i head towards [the sea]300-the sea , and sighed a sigh deep - drawn as if [my]0-i soul were in it . [My]0-i cheek was pale , [my]0-i eyes were wild and wistful — full of a solemn new earnestness . What the exact thoughts were that were busy in [me]0-i , [I]0-i can not tell . All [I]0-i am conscious of was this , that far , far off were the great crimson spaces of evening sky and a trail of rippled splendour on [the sea]300-the sea . One great violet cloud fringed with a border of living fire , that seemed to be eating into it , hung just above the place where the sun had gone down ; and over this , in a pale liquid solitude of hushed colour , was the evening star , trembling like a tear - drop . [I]0-i was always sensitive to colour ; and somehow or other this sunset relieved [me]0-i — went right to [my]0-i heart with a quiet sense of healing . That evening was , [I]0-i think , one of the great points in [my]0-i life . [I]0-i seemed ever after to see [my]0-i own character more clearly — how deep were [my]0-i own capacities for feeling , and also how strangely Nature could enter in and comfort [me]0-i , when all human sympathy would have seemed intrusive . That night , when [I]0-i went [upstairs]1696-upstairs , [I]0-i hardly knew [myself]0-i . There was a wild look in [my]0-i eyes — an inexpressible mournfulness and an inexpressible longing . Two or three long tendrils of hair had got loose , and hung over [my]0-i forehead with a kind of wild languor . ‘[0-i] What is there that [men]1704-men can see in [me]0-i to attract [them]1704-men ? ’ [I]1473-i had often said to [myself]1473-i . [I]1473-i think then a something of what it was began to dawn upon [me]1473-i . ‘[1473-i] And [he]1473-i — [he]1473-i , [the true]1474-the true , [the gallant]1475-the gallant , [the devoted]1476-the devoted , [he]1473-i has lost all this ’ , [I]1473-i gasped , turning away from the glass ; and , throwing [myself]1473-i on [my]1473-i knees by the bed , the sob [I]1473-i had so long suppressed broke forth , and [I]1473-i tried to pray — ” h’m — and so on , and so on , and so on — ’[1473-i] ‘ [You]1473-i need n’t read all those bits about the prayers , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose do n’t think it is quite reverent . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Well , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘ here ’s a new stage of [her]1477-the lady life . Let [us]2715-us go on here . “ And now , from the bleak desolation of [my]83-laurence present existence , [I]83-laurence peer wistfully out on all sides , and see if any will bring the love to [me]83-laurence that [I]83-laurence so much crave for . ” ’[83-laurence] ‘ Poor thing ! ’[106-mrs. sinclair] said [Mrs. Sinclair]106-mrs. sinclair , with a little sigh . ‘ [I]106-mrs. sinclair ’m[106-mrs. sinclair] afraid , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘[106-mrs. sinclair] [I]0-i must mention , by the way , that [the lady]1477-the lady is married , and remarkably well married too . ’ ‘[83-laurence] “ Here in [the old house]1478-the old house with [[its]1478-the old house quiet gables]1479-its quiet gables , ” [Laurence]83-laurence went on reading , “ [I]0-i sit in [[my]0-i own room]1480-my own room , and watch the sunset dying away over [the yellowing autumn woods]1481-the yellowing autumn woods , itself the colour of a belated autumn leaf . [I]0-i watch it alone — yes , thank heaven , alone . [I]0-i manage to steal for an hour or two away from [those people of whom [the house]1761-the house is full]1482-those people of whom the house is full . But ah ! the weariness , the far - offness of it all — ” ’ ‘[1484-you] It is entirely [her]1484-you own fault , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ’[1484-you] that [she]1484-you has [these people]1485-these people [here]360-here . In [London]1-london , [you]1493-you know , [she]1484-you is nearly always by [herself]1484-you . At least , ’ [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose added , ‘[1841-her husband] [he]1841-her husband ’s very rarely with [her]1484-you . ’ ‘[1841-her husband] A little further on , ’ said [Laurence]83-laurence , ‘[1841-her husband] it seems that [all the visitors]1494-all the visitors have gone ; and [she]1484-you has been to pay a visit to [[the parson]1495-the parson ’s wife]1496-the parson ’s wife . ’ ‘[1493-you] [You]1493-you may be sure [she]1484-you was quite by [herself]1484-you if [she]1484-you did that , ’ said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘[1484-you] Here , ’ [Laurence]83-laurence continued , ‘[1484-you] is a description of the visit . “ What sweet eyes [the little thing]1497-the little thing had ! What a look of trustfulness in [her]1484-you face ! A good and pure , and therefore [a happy woman]1498-a happy woman , if ever there was one . What a trust in those eyes of [hers]1484-you ! What an innocence ! What a sweet content ! There is no purple shadow of care under [her]1484-you eyes—(people say [I]0-i darken [mine]0-i artificially . Alas ! heaven knows there is little need for [me]0-i to do that ! ) There is no secret trouble discernible in [her]1484-you lips — no languor in [her]1484-you air ! What does [she]1484-you know of life , with its troubles , its distractions , its sins ? Ah ! were [I]0-i but like [her]1484-you — [I]0-i , [world - worn and world - weary , sickened with pomps , and vanities , and soiled affections , and hollow homage]1499-world - worn and world - weary , sickened with pomps , and vanities , and soiled affections , and hollow homage — were [I]0-i but worthy that [she]1484-you should talk to [me]0-i ! ‘ Do n’t talk to [me]0-i , ’[0-i] [I]0-i felt inclined to say . ‘ [You]1484-you would n’t if [you]1484-you knew — if [you]1484-you could know ! Oh , how far better are [you]1484-you than [I]0-i ! [You]1484-you little dream when [I]0-i show [myself]0-i demurely in [my]0-i seat in [the village church]2716-the village church , bowing at the Glorias , or kneeling with [my]0-i face hid in [my]0-i hands , [you]1484-you little imagine what [a woman]1817-a woman [you]1484-you see there . [You]1484-you little dream what strange thoughts unbidden mix themselves up for [me]0-i with the hymn - music ; what wild regrets , what bitter reveries , what strange scenes and figures , fill [my]0-i mind as [I]0-i kneel before the Communion - table . Why could [I]0-i not have been content like [you]1484-you with a quiet lot , [a toiling honest husband like [you]1484-you]2718-a toiling honest husband like you ? Is there not something holy , even in [his]2718-a toiling honest husband like you dull sermons , if [you]1484-you only look on them in the lovely light of duty ? Why does [my]0-i heart vibrate with the troubled wailing music of many sorrows , many longings , of which [you]1484-you do not even dream the existence ? Oh ! what [a far higher , far nobler woman]2719-a far higher , far nobler woman are [you]1484-you than [I]0-i , in every way ! ” ’[0-i] ‘ And now , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , seeing that [Laurence]83-laurence had shut the book , ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose want to know if all this is a specimen of culture , and if [you]83-laurence would call [the writer]651-the writer [a cultivated person]1002-a cultivated person ; because [she]651-the writer is really [one of the most delightful people [I]92-lady ambrose know to talk to]2722-one of the most delightful people i know to talk to ; and if this is what [you]83-laurence call culture — though [I]92-lady ambrose think , in [her]651-the writer case , it ’s a little bit affected , [you]83-laurence know — but then [she]651-the writer never lets [you]1484-you see all this when [you]1484-you talk to [her]651-the writer — [I]92-lady ambrose do quite from the bottom of [my]92-lady ambrose heart give up about culture being priggish , and bookish , and all that ; and since , as [you]83-laurence say , it really must include religion , [I]92-lady ambrose do n’t see what [we]2723-we could wish for more , to make life — humanly speaking — perfect . Of course [we]2723-we shall do good sometimes — [I]92-lady ambrose mean , not forget [the poor]2098-the poor — there ’s something so wretchedly heartless in that , [I]92-lady ambrose think . And then , too , politics — ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Yes , ’[101-allen] repeated [Allen]101-allen , ‘ politics — ’[101-allen] ‘ Of course , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘ it is necessary that [some of [us]2723-we]692-some of us should look after politics , because if [we]2723-we did not [somebody else]2726-somebody else would . But still—(are [you]101-allen [a Liberal]2727-a liberal , [Lord Allen?)—but]286-lord allen?)—but still , within a limit , [I]92-lady ambrose think the less [we]2723-we meddle the better . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Much , [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ’[100-mr. rose] said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , who had been somewhat put out by this digression , ‘ much is , no doubt , to be got over in [[your]92-lady ambrose friend]562-your friend ’s style ; nor do [I]100-mr. rose think the culture displayed in [her]562-your friend memoirs , even apart from that — ’[100-mr. rose] ‘ Oh , but [you]83-laurence must n’t judge [her]562-your friend only by [her]562-your friend writings , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose . ‘ When [you]83-laurence meet [her]562-your friend , [she]562-your friend is not a bit like [them]2729-them . ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ [Amateurs]2730-amateurs in writing rarely are , ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence . ‘ [Their]2730-amateurs writings are simply the foot - notes of [their]2730-amateurs lives , where [they]2730-amateurs tell [you]83-laurence what [they]2730-amateurs have not skill enough to bring into the text . ’[83-laurence] ‘ [She]562-your friend draws beautifully , ’[92-lady ambrose] [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose went on , ‘ and is really the brightest of creatures — so witty , and with such a sense of the ridiculous ! And really , to hear [her]562-your friend tell a bit of scandal — not that [I]92-lady ambrose at all approve of scandal [myself]92-lady ambrose — [I]92-lady ambrose always think it ’s so uncharitable — ’[92-lady ambrose] ‘ Ah , ’[103-donald gordon] said [Donald Gordon]103-donald gordon gently , ‘ [I]103-donald gordon have the very highest opinion of scandal . It is founded on the most sacred of things — that is , Truth , and it is built up by the most beautiful of things — that is , Imagination . ’[103-donald gordon] ‘ Well , [Mr. Gordon]287-mr. gordon , ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , smiling , ‘ [we]2731-us wo n’t talk about that now . But as for what [you]100-mr. rose say about style , [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , it is rather jerky , and so forth , [I]92-lady ambrose admit . However , that ’s the way with [[us]2731-us [women]492-women]2732-us women . Indeed , [I]92-lady ambrose often think that if [women]492-women had invented language , it would have consisted mainly of interjections , and that its only stop would have been a note of exclamation . ’[92-lady ambrose] [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose was much annoyed at these interruptions . ‘ [I]100-mr. rose wanted to say , ’[100-mr. rose] [he]100-mr. rose went on , as soon as [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose had ceased , ‘ that [I]100-mr. rose think [[your]100-mr. rose friend]562-your friend ’s memoirs more instructive from [their]2736-their very shortcomings , as showing how the human mind — even if not exceptionally gifted — has come to be an organism of increased delicacy and capacity , except when stunted by the necessity of work , or of occupation that is other than voluntary , and chosen for any object beyond itself . [You]100-mr. rose have here , [you]100-mr. rose see , that same modern sense of the blending together of the outer and inner worlds ; there is the same delicate discrimination between the aesthetic aspects of the different stages of life , and the nice gradation of moral colours : there is the same fine self - consciousness , and consequent endeavour to give tone and quality to [her]562-your friend memories as they pass by [her]562-your friend , in exquisite and complex ways . ’[100-mr. rose] ‘ Yes , ’[114-leslie] exclaimed [Leslie]114-leslie suddenly , who had spoken but little all the evening , ‘ here , [I]114-leslie think , is the crowning work of culture . It teaches each of [us]2731-us to look back upon [his]2737-his own life , with all its wants , its relations , and its possibilities , all its wasted hours and its affections trifled away or degraded — it teaches [us]2731-us to look back upon all this with quite a new kind of discrimination . The beauty of youth , with all its buoyancy and innocence , wakes in [us]2731-us of the modern world a more wistful and solemn regret ; [we]2731-us are more keenly alive to the pathos of failure ; to the sadness of the cold shadows that will often darken the whole inward landscape , and the ravage made by the storms that will sometimes break over it ; and to the gleams of sunshine fitfully reappearing , often only touching its distant wolds . And the charm of this is , ’[114-leslie] [Leslie]114-leslie went on , with a short laugh , ‘ that however disastrous [our]2731-us lives may have been , whatever shipwreck [we]2731-us may have made of [ourselves]2731-us or [others]341-others , let [us]2731-us only look back on this with the eyes of culture , whilst “ es wiederholt die Klage des Lebens labyrinthisch irren Lauf , ” and the whole retrospect becomes a delightful picture , the more impressive and suggestive from [its]2739-its landslips , [its]2739-its broken roads , and [[its]2739-its waste places]2740-its waste places . [I]114-leslie really think [one]1681-one is repaid for having made [oneself]1681-one quite lonely , and deserted , and friendless , by the pleasure [one]1681-one gets from contemplating [one]1681-one ’s own situation . ’[114-leslie] ‘ [I]92-lady ambrose can not bear [that man]1716-that man , ’[92-lady ambrose] whispered [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose to [Miss Merton]93-miss merton . ‘ Did n’t [you]93-miss merton notice the nasty way in which all that was said ? [We]2731-us have not half done yet . ’[83-laurence] [Laurence]83-laurence smiled , and looked a little shy , and murmured that [he]83-laurence did not think it was so late . ‘ [I]83-laurence do n’t know whether [you]93-miss merton ’ll mind , ’[83-laurence] [he]83-laurence said at last , ‘ but [[our]2731-us Rector]2746-our rector is going to give [us]2731-us a little evening service . What [rational man]2756-rational man believes in it ? ’[102-mr. saunders] ‘ before dinner , ’[100-mr. rose] said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose , who with [Laurence]83-laurence was bringing up the rear , ‘ at the books in [[[your]892-my dear uncle]2459-your uncle ’s pavilion]2758-your uncle ’s pavilion in [the garden]794-the garden ; and [I]100-mr. rose saw there , in a closed case , a copy of the “ Cultes secrets des [Dames Romaines]289-dames romaines . ” ’[100-mr. rose] ‘ Well ? ’[83-laurence] said [Laurence]83-laurence a little stiffly . ‘ It has been locked up for years . ’[83-laurence] ‘ [I]100-mr. rose conceived as much , ’[100-mr. rose] said [Mr. Rose]100-mr. rose gently . ‘ As [you]892-my dear do not seem to set much store by the work , [I]100-mr. rose will give [you]892-my dear thirty pounds for it . ’[100-mr. rose] ONCE more [the theatre]2077-the theatre was brightly lighted ; and once more [the congregation]599-the congregation was assembled in the tier of boxes . There was not so much excitement as there had been in the morning ; indeed , the reserved decorum that reigned might have been said to partake almost of the nature of apathy . When , however , [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon entered , [none]2026-none could deny that [he]219-dr. seydon did indeed look [a reverend man]1519-a reverend man ; and the very aspect of [the place]419-the place seemed to grow devotional at [his]219-dr. seydon presence . [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose perceived with a full heart that [he]219-dr. seydon was duly habited in a surplice ; and [her]92-lady ambrose bosom warmed with a sense of safety and of comfort as [he]219-dr. seydon took [his]219-dr. seydon place and solemnly produced [his]219-dr. seydon prayer - book . Nor was [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose alone in this sudden stir of feeling . There was another of [the worshippers]1521-the worshippers who was moved even more strongly , though in a slightly different way . Many starts had been given on the stage in [that theatre]1522-that theatre ; but none of these , it may be safely said , ever equalled one now given in the boxes , as [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , who had been kneeling with [his]95-dr. jenkinson face hid in [his]95-dr. jenkinson hands , raised [his]95-dr. jenkinson eyes , and saw for the first time who it was confronting [him]95-dr. jenkinson — [no obscure rural clergyman]1523-no obscure rural clergyman , as [he]95-dr. jenkinson had anticipated , but [that illiberal apologist of superstition , whose officious bigotry had robbed [the Upper House]1525-the upper house of [its most enlightened spiritual peer]1526-its most enlightened spiritual peer]1524-that illiberal apologist of superstition , whose officious bigotry had robbed the upper house of its most enlightened spiritual peer . [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , however , with the heroism of [a true martyr]1527-a true martyr , suffered bravely for [his]95-dr. jenkinson faith in the comprehensiveness of Christianity . [His]95-dr. jenkinson face assumed , in another moment , an expression of cherubic suavity ; in [his]95-dr. jenkinson gentlest and devoutest tones [he]95-dr. jenkinson was soon taking [his]95-dr. jenkinson part in the whole service , and that too with such an exquisite clearness of articulation , that , amongst the confused murmurs of [the rest]1528-the rest , the entire evening office sounded like a duet between [him]95-dr. jenkinson and [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon . It is true that there was something in the ring of this one audible voice that gave [the latter]388-the latter a sense of something being wrong somewhere ; but luckily , being a little shortsighted , [he]95-dr. jenkinson could not recognise [the owner of it]1530-the owner of it ; and [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , feeling no manner of call to endure the sermon , retired furtively as soon as the prayers were over . ‘ Were n’t [they]2760-they read beautifully ! ’[92-lady ambrose] said [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose to [Lady Grace]89-lady grace in a whisper . ‘ Oh , how glad [I]92-lady ambrose shall be to hear [him]219-dr. seydon preach once again ! ’[92-lady ambrose] [she]92-lady ambrose added , as [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon , having risen from [his]219-dr. seydon knees , retired , [his]219-dr. seydon hands clasped before [him]219-dr. seydon , through the side door . [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , however , was entirely alone in this gladness . [Most of [the others]1695-the others]1531-most of the others dreaded the sermon that was imminent , and some even meditated following [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson . But events were too quick for [them]1531-most of the others . Hardly , it seemed , had [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon left [the stalls]598-the stalls , than the curtain drew rapidly up , and displayed again the gorge in [the Indian Caucasus]1534-the indian caucasus , only with [a preacher in [it]1536-it]1535-a preacher in it very different from [the one who had stood there in the morning]1537-the one who had stood there in the morning . [The whole congregation]2110-the whole congregation gave a sudden gasp of surprise . It was not [Dr. Seydon]219-dr. seydon that [they]1531-most of the others saw . It was [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert . With a gracious gravity [he]112-mr. herbert advanced towards the footlights ; and made a slight bow to [the house]1761-the house — a bow of deprecation and apology . ‘ A little while ago , in [the garden]794-the garden , ’[112-mr. herbert] [he]112-mr. herbert said , ‘ [I]112-mr. herbert confessed to [[our]1531-most of the others kind host]2762-our kind host , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , that there were a few things that [I]112-mr. herbert should like quietly to say to [you]2762-our kind host ; and [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence has become sponsor for [you]2762-our kind host all , and has promised , in [your]2762-our kind host names , that [you]2762-our kind host would suffer [me]112-mr. herbert to say them here . It is true , ’[112-mr. herbert] [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert went on , with a smile and a wave of [his]112-mr. herbert hand , ‘ that when [I]112-mr. herbert look round [me]112-mr. herbert at this glittering semicircle , [I]112-mr. herbert begin to feel not a little shy of [you]2762-our kind host , and to repent of [my]112-mr. herbert own temerity . [You]2762-our kind host , however , have given [me]112-mr. herbert to - day so much good food for reflection , that [I]112-mr. herbert feel bound , in the commonest honesty , to make what poor return [I]112-mr. herbert can . So remember , that if [I]112-mr. herbert weary [you]1540-you , [you]1540-you have really brought it upon [yourselves]1540-you . ‘[112-mr. herbert] Well — to begin , then . [You]1540-you think [me]0-i — [you]1540-you need not deny it , for [I]0-i know [you]1540-you think [me]0-i — [a somewhat crotchety and melancholy individual , averse to modern knowledge and to modern progress]1541-a somewhat crotchety and melancholy individual , averse to modern knowledge and to modern progress , and seeing , as a rule , everything very yellow indeed , with [his]0-i jaundiced eyes . But [I]0-i think [myself]0-i that [I]0-i am not by any means so obstinate and so wrong - headed as [I]0-i am quite aware that [I]0-i appear to [you]1540-you ; nay , [my]0-i own opinion is that [I]0-i err , rather , in not being quite obstinate enough . It is true that [I]0-i have persistently pointed out that [England]4-england is at present given over wholly to ignoble pursuits , and is ruining [herself]4-england with deadly industries . But [I]0-i have never said hitherto , so far as [I]0-i know , that [we]1542-us might not rally , and that a brighter future might not be in store for [us]1542-us . Nay , [I]0-i hailed a piece of news to - day with the most unfeigned delight , which seemed an omen to [me]0-i that such a brighter future actually was in store for [us]1542-us . In a paper that reached [me]0-i this afternoon there was a letter on the prospects of the English iron trade ; and [I]0-i read in that letter that [[nineteen foundries]1543-nineteen foundries in [Middlesborough]74-middlesborough]1544-nineteen foundries in middlesborough have been closed within the last three months , and the Moloch fires in [their]1544-nineteen foundries in middlesborough blast - furnaces extinguished ; that ten more foundries in [the same place]1545-the same place are scarcely able to continue work , and must very shortly be closed likewise ; and that the dense smoke - cloud that so long has darkened [that whole country]1546-that whole country is beginning to clear away , and will open ere long upon astonished human eyes , that have never yet beheld it , the liquid melted blue of the deep wells of the sky . It is quite true that this indication of a reviving prosperity for [[our]1542-us country]1547-our country suggests more than it proves . But at any rate it put [me]0-i this afternoon , when [I]0-i joined [[your]1548-your party]1549-your party , into quite a right and hopeful mood for appreciating [your]1548-your conceptions of a better order of things . It is in fact simply to explain [my]0-i appreciation that [I]0-i am , in this most unconscionable way , now detaining [you]1548-your . ‘ Let [me]112-mr. herbert say in the first place , then , how profoundly right [I]112-mr. herbert consider the manner in which [you]1548-your set to work . For it is one of the most vital of all truths , that in a perfect state all the parts will be perfect ; and that if [the highest classes]2225-the highest classes be as good as [they]2225-the highest classes can be , so also will be [all the other classes]2764-all the other classes . And [I]112-mr. herbert want to tell [you]1548-your , in [the next place]1086-the next place , how entirely fair and lovely did all the elements seem to be , out of which [you]1548-your composed for [[your]1548-your higher classes]2766-your higher classes [their]2766-your higher classes ideal existence . For [you]1548-your gave [them]2766-your higher classes every outward grace that could adorn life , and every inward taste and emotion that could enrich it , and every species of intellectual activity that could stimulate it . [[Your]1548-your society]2453-your society was indeed to be truly the crème de la crème : it was to be made beautiful , and profound , and brilliant , by [lovers]2768-lovers , and [theologians]2769-theologians , and [wits]2770-wits , and [men of science]1882-men of science , and [poets]799-poets , and [philosophers]2773-philosophers , and [humourists]2774-humourists — [all men and women of [the world]406-the world]2775-all men and women of the world , and fit to live in [society]883-society , as well as to educate [it]883-society . This would indeed be , as was said at dinner , [Rome]41-rome and [Athens]21-athens and [Florence]68-florence , at [their]2775-all men and women of the world best , and let [me]112-mr. herbert add [Paris]60-paris also , united and reanimated , and enriched by the possession of yet wider knowledge , and the possibilities of freer speculation . That truly is a dazzling picture . But even that is not all . There was [[your]1548-your city]2778-your city itself too , of which a lovely glimpse was given [us]2779-our , with [its]2778-your city groves , [its]2778-your city gardens , [[its]2778-your city palaces]2487-its palaces , and [its]2778-your city exquisite reproductions of [the world]406-the world ’s noblest architectures ; and all this under [our]2779-our softest English skies , and by [[our]2779-our bluest English seas]2782-our bluest english seas . Ah , ’[112-mr. herbert] exclaimed [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , smiling , and clasping [his]112-mr. herbert hands gently , ‘ how [I]112-mr. herbert should like to live in [a city like that]2783-a city like that ! [I]112-mr. herbert can literally see [it]2778-your city now with [my]112-mr. herbert mind ’s eye , whilst [I]112-mr. herbert am talking . [I]112-mr. herbert see [[its]2778-your city private houses]2784-its private houses with [their]2784-its private houses wonders of wrought marble ; [I]112-mr. herbert see [its theatres]2785-its theatres , [[its]2778-your city museums]2488-its museums , [[its]2778-your city chapels and [churches of all denominations]2788-churches of all denominations]2787-its chapels and churches of all denominations , [[its]2778-your city scientific lecture rooms]2789-its scientific lecture rooms , and [[its]2778-your city convents]2490-its convents . For what strikes [me]112-mr. herbert more forcibly than anything is that all forms of faith and philosophy seem to find here an impartial home , and to unite in animating one harmonious social life . In fact , so vividly do [I]112-mr. herbert see this scene which [your]2791-your words have called up before [me]112-mr. herbert , that [I]112-mr. herbert want very much , if [you]2791-your will let [me]112-mr. herbert , to acid one small feature to it , [myself]112-mr. herbert . It is a very humble detail , this of [mine]112-mr. herbert . In the eyes of [the men of science , who lead modern thought]2792-the men of science , who lead modern thought , it is simply a sanitary matter . It relates to the way in which [you]2791-your shall dispose of [your]2791-your dead . Now in this , at least , [you]2791-your will be surprised to hear [I]112-mr. herbert quite keep pace with the times , being a sincere advocate for cremation ; and what [I]112-mr. herbert should want to do in [[your]2791-your city]2778-your city , would be to supply [it]2778-your city with [an establishment]2794-an establishment , hidden underground , where the bodies of the dead should be turned into gas , in properly devised retorts ; the gas from each body being received in a small separate gasometer . Above [these gasworks]2795-these gasworks , and amongst [[your]2791-your fair towers]2796-your fair towers and spires , and [[your]2791-your superb institutions]2797-your superb institutions , and art - galleries , [I]112-mr. herbert would build [a circular domed temple of umbred marble , blind and blank upon the face of [it]2798-a circular domed temple of umbred marble , blind and blank upon the face of it , without carved work , and without window , without carved work , and without window]2798-a circular domed temple of umbred marble , blind and blank upon the face of it , without carved work , and without window ; only there should be written above the portal , not as in [Dante]206-dante ’s vision , Per [me]112-mr. herbert si va nell ’[112-mr. herbert] eterno dolore , but one verse out of [our]1550-our English translation of the Bible , for [women]492-women and [little children]1552-little children to read ; and another verse out of [a Latin poet]1553-a latin poet , which is , [I]0-i believe , an equivalent for the original of that translation , for [men]1704-men and [scholars]1555-scholars to read . The first should be , “ Though after [my]0-i skin worms destroy this body , yet in [my]0-i flesh shall [I]0-i see [God]115-god . ” And the other : Quæris quo jaceas post obitum loco ? And within , around the dark walls , should be a number of separate shrines , like — to use the simile that [Dante]206-dante would have chosen — [the stalls in [a great stable]1557-a great stable]1556-the stalls in a great stable ; and to [each shrine]1558-each shrine there should be a separate gas - jet . And when the life of any was over , after the fire had done its work upon the dead body , [that man]1716-that man or [woman who felt most bitterly the loss of the one that had been]1560-woman who felt most bitterly the loss of the one that had been , should repair to [this temple]1561-this temple , to [an appointed shrine]1562-an appointed shrine , and there , in silence kneeling before it , should light the gas - jet ; and thus evoking for the last time that which was once so loved and loving , pass , with what thoughts might be , a brief vigil before it , till its flicker grew slowly faint upon [the watcher]1563-the watcher ’s face , and at length it went out and ended utterly and for ever . And above , over [these sanctuaries of bereavement]1564-these sanctuaries of bereavement and final leave - taking , there should hang from the domed roof one rude iron lamp , always burning — casting a pale flare upwards upon the darkness . This would be the common lamp of [the poor , for whose sake , dying]1565-the poor , for whose sake , dying , [no one]387-no one felt bereavement , or whom [no one at any rate could find time to say good - bye to]1567-no one at any rate could find time to say good - bye to ; but who thus united together , apart by [themselves]1565-the poor , for whose sake , dying , would do all that would be at all seemly in [them]1565-the poor , for whose sake , dying — would remind [you]1568-you mutely and unobtrusively by [their]1565-the poor , for whose sake , dying joint light , that one thing at least [they]1565-the poor , for whose sake , dying shared with [you]1568-you , namely death . It is not of [the poor]2098-the poor , however , that [I]0-i am mainly thinking now . It is of [[your]1568-you higher classes]2766-your higher classes , [who have leisure to feel sorrow and all its holy influences]1571-who have leisure to feel sorrow and all its holy influences . And these , [I]0-i say , would find in this simple funeral service one that would meet all [their]1565-the poor , for whose sake , dying diverse needs , and be in tune with all [their]1565-the poor , for whose sake , dying diverse feelings . It would suit all . For to some it would symbolise an absolute disbelief in any life beyond ; and to [all the rest]1572-all the rest it would symbolise a bewildered doubt about any life beyond . For in one or other of these states of mind [everyone]347-everyone would be . ‘ Do [you]112-mr. herbert deny it ? ’[112-mr. herbert] exclaimed [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , raising [his]112-mr. herbert voice suddenly , and looking round [the theatre]2077-the theatre with a passionate anger , at which [the whole audience]1575-the whole audience were literally electrified . ‘ Do [you]112-mr. herbert deny it ? ’[112-mr. herbert] [he]112-mr. herbert exclaimed . ‘ [I]112-mr. herbert tell [you]1568-you that it is so . [I]112-mr. herbert tell [you]1568-you too that that is [your]1568-you own case , and that in [your]1568-you Utopia [you]1568-you have aggravated the evil , and have not remedied it . [You]1568-you are [all deniers]2799-all deniers or [doubters]2800-doubters , [I]112-mr. herbert tell [you]1568-you , [every one of [you]1568-you]2801-every one of you . [The deniers]2802-the deniers , [I]112-mr. herbert know , will not contradict [me]112-mr. herbert ; so at present [I]112-mr. herbert need not speak to [them]2802-the deniers . It is to [you]1568-you — [the majority]1837-the majority , [you]1568-you who will contradict [me]112-mr. herbert ; [you]1568-you who are so busy with [your]1568-you various affirmations , with [your]1568-you prayers , [your]1568-you churches , [your]1568-you philosophies , [your]1568-you revivals of old Christianities , or [your]1568-you new improvements on [them]2802-the deniers ; with [your]1568-you love of justice , and humanity , and toleration ; it is to [you]1568-you that [I]112-mr. herbert speak . It is to [you]1568-you that [I]112-mr. herbert say that , however enlightened and however sure [you]1568-you may be about all other matters , [you]1568-you are darkened and uncertain as to this — whether there really is [any God]2804-any god at all who can hear all the prayers [you]1568-you utter to [Him]2804-any god , or whether there really is any other life at all , where the aspirations [you]1568-you are so proud of will be realised , and where the wrongs [you]1568-you are so pitiful over will be righted . There is not one amongst [you]1568-you who , watching [a dead friend]2805-a dead friend , flickering for the last time before [you]1568-you in the form of a gas - flame , and seeing how a little while and this flame was with [you]1568-you , and again a little while and it was not with [you]1568-you , would be at all sure whether this was really because , as [your]1568-you hearts would suggest to [you]1568-you , it went to [the Father]2806-the father , or because , as [[your]1568-you men of science]2807-your men of science would assert to [you]1568-you , it went simply — out . ‘[112-mr. herbert] Listen to [me]0-i for a moment , and [I]0-i can prove that this is so , to [you]1576-you . [You]1576-you are rich , and [you]1576-you have leisure to think of things in what light [you]1576-you will , and [your]1576-you life is to a great extent made easy for [you]1576-you by the labour of [others]341-others . [I]0-i do not complain of that . There can be no civilisation without order , and there can be no order without subordination . Outward goods must be apportioned unequally , or there would be no outward goods to apportion . But [[you]1576-you who have the larger share of these]1578-you who have the larger share of these are bound to do something for [those who have the less]1579-those who have the less . [I]0-i say [you]1576-you are bound to do so ; or else sooner or later that larger share will be taken away from [you]1576-you . Well , and what is it [you]1576-you propose to do ? [I]0-i know [your]1576-you answer — [I]0-i have heard it a thousand times . [You]1576-you will educate [them]1580-them — [you]1576-you will teach [them]1580-them . And truly , if [you]1576-you know how to do that properly , [you]1576-you will have done all [you]1576-you need do . But , ’ exclaimed [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , [his]0-i voice again rising , and quivering with excitement , ‘[0-i] that is just what [you]1576-you do not know . [I]0-i am not casting [my]0-i words at random . Out of [your]1576-you own mouths will [I]0-i judge [you]1576-you . There never was a time when [you]1576-you talked so much as now about teaching [the people]350-the people , and yet do not [you]1576-you [yourselves]1576-you confess that [you]1576-you can not agree together as to what to teach [them]350-the people ? [You]1576-you can agree about teaching [them]350-the people — [I]0-i know this too well — countless things that [you]1576-you think will throw light upon life ; but life itself [you]1576-you leave a blank darkness upon which no light can be thrown . [You]1576-you say nothing of what is good in it , and of what is evil . Does success in it lie in the enjoyment of bodily pleasures , or in the doing of spiritual duty ? Is there anything in it that is right for its own sake , or are all things right only because of their consequences ? And seeing that , if [we]1582-we struggle for virtue , [our]1582-we struggles can never be quite successful here , is there any other place where [they]350-the people may have , [I]0-i do not say [their]350-the people reward , but [their]350-the people consummation ? To these questions only two answers can be given , and one must be entirely true , and the other entirely false . But [you]1576-you — [you]1576-you dare not give either ; [you]1576-you are too enlightened . It is true that [you]1576-you can afford to be liberal about these matters ; [you]1576-you can afford to consider truth and falsehood equally tolerable . But for [the poor man]1583-the poor man surely it is not so . It must make some difference to [him]1583-the poor man what [you]1576-you teach [him]1583-the poor man , whether [your]1576-you teaching is to open [his]1583-the poor man eyes to [[his]1583-the poor man God]1362-his god and to [his]1583-the poor man duty , and so place [his]1583-the poor man noblest happiness in [his]1583-the poor man own hands , or whether it is to open [his]1583-the poor man eyes to those verified Utilitarian principles from which [he]1583-the poor man will learn that [his]1583-the poor man own life and labour are only not utterly contemptible , because they conduce to a material well - being in which [he]1583-the poor man [himself]1583-the poor man can have no share . If , with entire belief [yourselves]1576-you , [you]1576-you are prepared to give [him]1583-the poor man the former teaching , why then it is well and good both for [him]1583-the poor man and [you]1576-you . But if not , beware of teaching [him]1583-the poor man at all . [You]1576-you will but be removing a cataract from [his]1583-the poor man mind ’s eye that [he]1583-the poor man may stare aghast and piteous at [his]1583-the poor man own poverty and nakedness , or that [he]1583-the poor man may gaze with a wild beast ’s hunger at [your]1576-you own truly noble prosperity which [he]1583-the poor man can never taste , save in the wild beast ’s way . ‘ But enough of [the poor]2098-the poor ; enough of this division of happiness . Let [me]0-i ask [you]1576-you to consider now what sort of happiness there is to divide — [I]0-i say divide , meaning that [you]1576-you will get the whole of it . And as [I]0-i have said before , this happiness is very fair in seeming . Knowledge , and culture , and freedom , and toleration — [you]1576-you have told [us]2809-us what fine things all these can do for [you]1576-you . And [I]0-i admit it [myself]0-i too ; [I]0-i feel it [myself]0-i too . Lovely , indeed , to look upon are the faiths , the philosophies , the enthusiasms of [the world]406-the world — [the ancient products of the ages]2811-the ancient products of the ages — as the sunshine of the modern intellect falls on [them]2811-the ancient products of the ages . See , [they]2811-the ancient products of the ages look clearer , and brighter , and more transparent — see , they form themselves into more exquisite and lucid shapes , more aërial structures . But why ? Do not deceive [yourselves]1585-yourselves ; it is for a terrible reason . It is because , like a fabric of snow , they are one and all dissolving . ‘[0-i] Listen , and [I]0-i will show [you]1585-yourselves that this is so . [Aristotle]154-aristotle says that what is truly [a man]1770-a man ’s Self is the thinking part of [him]1770-a man . This sooner or later [all the other parts]1587-all the other parts obey — sooner or later , willingly or unwillingly ; and if [this Self]1588-this self be base , [the whole man]1589-the whole man will be base ; if [the Self]1590-the self be noble , [the whole man]1589-the whole man will be noble . And as it is with [the individual man]1592-the individual man , so it is with the ages and the generations . [They]1592-the individual man obey [[their]1592-the individual man several Selves]1593-their several selves , whatever [these Selves]1594-these selves may be . [The world]406-the world once had [a Self whose chief spokesman]1596-a self whose chief spokesman was [a Jewish peasant]1597-a jewish peasant called [Jesus]283-jesus ; and sooner or later [the world]406-the world followed [him]283-jesus . Later on , it had [a Self whose chief spokesmen]1599-a self whose chief spokesmen were [Dominics]290-dominics or [Luthers]291-luthers or [Loyolas]292-loyolas ; and in like manner [the world]406-the world followed [them]1599-a self whose chief spokesmen . Later still , it had got [another Self]1601-another self , and [the chief spokesmen of this]1602-the chief spokesmen of this were [Voltaires]293-voltaires and [Rousseaus]294-rousseaus , And in each case [the world]406-the world was convinced at heart , consciously or unconsciously , that the vital truths of life were to be sought for only where [these Selves]1594-these selves sought for [them]1594-these selves . With [Jesus]283-jesus and with [Luther]295-luther it sought [them]1594-these selves in duty and in a turning to [the true God]1605-the true god ; with [Voltaire]231-voltaire and [Rousseau]296-rousseau , in justice , and in a turning from [the false God]1606-the false god . And now , where do [you]1607-you seek [them]1594-these selves ? Where does [the Self of [your]1607-you age]1608-the self of your age seek [them]1594-these selves — [your]1607-you Self , that thinking part of [you]1607-you before which [you]1607-you all either quail or worship ? Does it seek [them]1594-these selves either in justice , or loving - kindness , or in the vision of [the most high God]1609-the most high god ! No — but in the rotting bodies of [dead men]1610-dead men , or in the writhing bodies of live cats . And in [your]1607-you perplexity , and [your]1607-you amazed despair , ever and again [you]1607-you cry to it , What shall [we]1611-us do to be saved ? Show [us]1611-us [the Father]2806-the father ! Show [us]1611-us the high and holy One that inhabiteth Eternity ! And what does [[your]1607-you Self]1613-your self answer [you]1607-you ? [It]1613-your self answers [you]1607-you with a laugh , “ There is [no high and holy One]1614-no high and holy one at all . How say [ye]1607-you then to [me]0-i , Show [us]1611-us [the Father]2806-the father ? For the Earth saith , [He]2806-the father is not with [me]0-i ; and the depth saith , [He]2806-the father is not with [me]0-i ; and [our]1611-us filthy phials of decaying animal matter say , [He]2806-the father is not with [us]1611-us . [Argal]75-argal , [[ye]1607-you poor foolish seekers]1616-ye poor foolish seekers , [He]2806-the father is nowhere . ” [You]1607-you may try to escape from [your]1607-you own Self , but [you]1607-you can not ; [you]1607-you may try to forget its answer , but [you]1607-you can not . Loudly [you]1607-you may affirm with [your]1607-you lips ; but the importunate denial is ever at [your]1607-you heart . Patriæ quis exsul se quoque fugit ? ‘ What do [you]1607-you do then in this perplexity — this halting between two opinions ? Why , [you]1607-you do this . [You]1607-you try to persuade [yourselves]1607-you that neither opinion is of much moment — that the question can not be decided absolutely — that it should not be decided absolutely — in fact , that it is one of [your]1607-you chief glories that [you]1607-you leave it undecided . But [I]1618-you tell [you]1607-you , in that case , that though [you]1607-you say [you]1607-you are rich , and increased with goods , and have need of nothing ; [you]1607-you are , in reality , wretched , and miserable , and poor , and blind , and naked . [I]1618-you am not casting [my]1618-you words at random . Again out of [your]1607-you own mouths will [I]1618-you judge [you]1607-you . All [your]1607-you culture , [you]1607-you say , is based ultimately upon this — a discrimination between right and wrong . True , profoundly true . But will [you]1607-you be able to say what is right and what is wrong any longer , if [you]1607-you do n’t know for whom anything is right and for whom anything is wrong — whether it is for [men with immortal souls , or only with mortal bodies]2812-men with immortal souls , or only with mortal bodies — who are only a little lower than [the angels , or only a little better than the pigs]2813-the angels , or only a little better than the pigs ? Whilst [you]1607-you can still contrive to doubt upon this matter , whilst the fabric of the old faith is still dissolving only , life still for [you]1607-you , [the enlightened few]2814-the enlightened few , may preserve what happiness it has now . But when the old fabric is all dissolved , what then ? When all divinity shall have gone from love and heroism , and only utility and pleasure shall be left , what then ? Then [you]1607-you will have to content [yourselves]1607-you with complete denial ; or build up again the faith that [you]1607-you have just pulled down — [you]1607-you will have to be born again , and to seek for [a new Self]2815-a new self . ‘[1618-you] But suppose [we]1617-we accept denial , [you]1618-you will say , what then ? [Many deniers]1619-many deniers have lived noble lives , though [they]1619-many deniers have looked neither for [a God]1992-a god nor for a heaven . Think of [Greece]42-greece , [you]1618-you will say to [me]0-i , and that will answer [you]1618-you . No — but that is not so , and that will not answer [me]0-i . [The Greeks]222-the greeks never , in [your]1618-you sense , denied [God]115-god ; [they]222-the greeks never , in [your]1618-you sense , denied eternal life — never , because [they]222-the greeks never knew [them]222-the greeks . [They]222-the greeks felt [God]115-god only ; [they]222-the greeks felt [him]115-god unconsciously ; and in denying the God [they]222-the greeks knew , [they]222-the greeks were really affirming the God [they]222-the greeks felt . But [you]1618-you — do not [you]1618-you deceive [yourselves]1618-you . Do not think [you]1618-you can ever again be as [the Greeks]222-the greeks . [The world]406-the world ’s progress has a twofold motion . History moves onwards round [some undiscovered centre]1622-some undiscovered centre , as well as round what [you]1618-you consider [its]1622-some undiscovered centre discovered axis ; and though it seems to repeat itself , it never can repeat itself . The Atheism of [the modern world]2431-the modern world is not the Atheism of [the ancient]1624-the ancient : the long black night of the winter is not the swift clear night of the vanished summer . [The Greek philosopher]1625-the greek philosopher could not darken [his]1625-the greek philosopher life , for [he]1625-the greek philosopher knew not from what mysterious source the light fell upon it . [The modern philosopher]1626-the modern philosopher does know , and [he]1626-the modern philosopher knows that it is called [God]115-god , and thus knowing the source of light [he]1626-the modern philosopher can at once quench it . ‘ What will be left [you]1618-you then if this light be quenched ? Will art , will painting , will poetry be any comfort to [you]1618-you ? [You]1618-you have said that these were magic mirrors which reflected back [your]1618-you life for [you]1618-you . Well — will they be any better than the glass mirrors in [[your]1618-you drawing - rooms]2816-your drawing - rooms , if they have nothing but the same listless orgy to reflect ? For that is all that will be at last in store for [you]1618-you ; nay , that is the best thing that possibly can be in store for [you]1618-you ; the only alternative being not a listless orgy for the few , but an undreamed of anarchy for all . [I]1626-the modern philosopher do not fear that , however . [Some]1684-some will be always strong , and some will be always weak ; and though , if there is [no God]2818-no god , no divine and fatherly source of order , there will be , trust [me]1626-the modern philosopher , [no aristocracies]2819-no aristocracies , there will still be tyrannies . There will still be [rich and poor]2820-rich and poor ; and that will then mean happy and miserable ; and [the poor]2098-the poor will be — as [I]1626-the modern philosopher sometimes think [they]2098-the poor are already — but a mass of groaning machinery , without even the semblance of rationality ; and the rich , with only the semblance of it , but a set of gaudy , dancing marionettes , which it is the machinery ’s one work to keep in motion . ‘[1626-the modern philosopher] What , then , shall [you]1627-you do to be saved ? Rend [your]1627-you hearts , [I]0-i say , and do not mend [your]1627-you garments . Seek [God]115-god earnestly , and peradventure [you]1627-you still may find [Him]115-god — and [I]0-i — even [I]0-i may find [Him]115-god also . For [I]0-i — who am [I]0-i that speak to [you]1627-you ? Am [I]0-i [a believer]1628-a believer ? No , [I]0-i am [a doubter]1629-a doubter too . Once [I]0-i could pray every morning , and go forth to [my]0-i day ’s labour stayed and comforted . But now [I]0-i can pray no longer . [You]1627-you have taken [[my]0-i God]1630-my god away from [me]0-i , and [I]0-i know not where [you]1627-you have laid [Him]115-god . [My]0-i only consolation in [my]0-i misery is that at least [I]0-i am inconsolable for [His]115-god loss . Yes , ’ cried [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert , [his]112-mr. herbert voice rising into a kind of threatening wail , ‘[1627-you] though [you]1627-you have made [me]0-i miserable , [I]0-i am not yet content with [my]0-i misery . And though [I]0-i too have said in [my]0-i heart that there is [no God]2818-no god , and that there is no more profit in wisdom than in folly , yet there is one folly that [I]0-i will not give tongue to . [I]0-i will not say Peace , peace , when there is no peace . [I]0-i will not say [we]1632-we are still [Christians]2028-christians , when [we]1632-we can sip [our]1632-we wine smilingly after dinner , and talk about some day defining [the Father]2806-the father ; and [I]0-i will only pray that if [such a Father]1635-such a father be , [He]1635-such a father may have mercy alike upon those that hate [Him]1635-such a father , because [they]1636-they will not see [Him]1635-such a father ; and on [those who love and long for]1637-those who love and long for [Him]1635-such a father , although [they]1637-those who love and long for no longer can see [Him]1635-such a father . ’ [Mr. Herbert]112-mr. herbert ’s voice ceased . The curtain fell . The whirlwind was over ; the fire was over ; and after the fire , from one of the side boxes came a still small voice . ‘[1635-such a father] Very poor taste — very poor taste . ’ It was perceived that [Dr. Jenkinson]95-dr. jenkinson , having discovered almost immediately who was really to be [the preacher]2122-the preacher , had stolen back silently into [the theatre]2077-the theatre . THE following morning [Miss Merton]93-miss merton had risen early , and was sauntering slowly before breakfast up and down [the broad terrace in front of [the house]1761-the house]2824-the broad terrace in front of the house . [She]93-miss merton inhaled the fresh delightful air ; [she]93-miss merton looked out over [the breezy sea]2826-the breezy sea ; [she]93-miss merton scanned [the splendid villa]2827-the splendid villa , now shining in the sunlight , with [its]2827-the splendid villa marble porticoes , and [its]2827-the splendid villa long rows of windows ; and [she]93-miss merton thought over yesterday with all its conversations and incidents . In especial , [she]93-miss merton thought of [Laurence]83-laurence . [She]93-miss merton thought of [him]83-laurence as [he]83-laurence was now , and as [he]83-laurence had been in former times , when [they]2828-they had known [each other]1699-each other so well ; and as [she]93-miss merton thought of [him]83-laurence , [she]93-miss merton sighed . ‘[1635-such a father] And [he]1638-he might do so much , ’ [she]93-miss merton said to [herself]93-miss merton , ‘[1638-he] and yet [he]1638-he is so weak and so irresolute ; wasting [his]1638-he time in [Paris]60-paris and in [London]1-london , reading poetry and buying pictures , and talking philosophy [he]1638-he does n’t believe in with [[his]1638-he dilettante friends]1639-his dilettante friends . And [this place]2166-this place — [this lovely place]1641-this lovely place — how often does [he]1638-he come [here]360-here ? What does [he]1638-he do for [[his]1638-he tenants]409-his tenants and [dependants]1644-dependants — for [all who ought to look for help to [him]1638-he]1645-all who ought to look for help to him ? [I]0-i have no patience with [a man who keeps moaning about religion as [he]1638-he does]1646-a man who keeps moaning about religion as he does , and yet wo n’t act up to the light which [he]1638-he must have . ’ Whilst [she]2830-she was thus meditating , the subject of [her]2830-she meditations appeared upon [the terrace]491-the terrace . ‘[0-i] [You]0-i are out early , ’ [he]0-i said . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i have been just seeing [Herbert]112-mr. herbert off . [He]114-leslie never fancies [he]114-leslie feels anything ; but what [he]114-leslie wo n’t admit to [himself]114-leslie , [his]114-leslie manner , [I]0-i am sure admitted to [me]0-i , and [I]0-i dare say to [you]1654-you too . ’ ‘[0-i] Yes , ’ said [Miss Merton]93-miss merton thoughtfully , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i felt sure it must be something of that kind . [I]0-i was thinking of [our]1655-we culture and [our]1655-we enlightenment . [I]0-i was thinking of — [God]115-god knows what ; and why should [I]0-i tell [you]1654-you ? [I]0-i do n’t know what [I]0-i shall do . [I]0-i ca n’t stop here ; [I]0-i sha n’t go to [London]1-london — [I]0-i hate [London]1-london . [[We]1655-we both of [us]1655-we]1659-we both of us want to pray , and [we]1655-we neither of [us]1655-we can . ’ There was a long pause . At last [Miss Merton]93-miss merton said with some embarrassment , stooping as [she]93-miss merton did so to smell a red geranium : ‘[0-i] [I]0-i ’m sure [I]0-i wish [I]0-i could be of any use to [you]83-laurence ; but really [I]0-i do n’t quite see how [I]0-i can . ’[0-i] There was another pause . At last [Laurence]83-laurence said in a very low tone : ‘ [I]83-laurence can not pray , because [I]83-laurence do not believe in [God]115-god . Will [you]93-miss merton pray for [me]83-laurence ? ’[83-laurence] [Miss Merton]93-miss merton turned and looked at [him]83-laurence with a soft , serious smile . ‘ [I]93-miss merton did last night , if [you]83-laurence wish very much to know , ’[93-miss merton] [she]93-miss merton said , and [her]93-miss merton cheek grew slowly tinted with an unconscious blush . ‘ Did [you]93-miss merton ? ’[83-laurence] exclaimed [Laurence]83-laurence with a sudden eagerness . ‘ Then , if [you]93-miss merton cared enough for [me]83-laurence to do that , will [you]93-miss merton care enough for [me]83-laurence to do something far better than praying for [me]83-laurence ? Will [you]93-miss merton — ’[83-laurence] [he]83-laurence said , pausing and looking at [her]93-miss merton ; ‘ will [you]93-miss merton — ’[83-laurence] But at that instant the gong for breakfast sounded , and the sentence died unfinished . Both [he]83-laurence and [she]93-miss merton were perhaps a little grateful for this interruption . It relieved a sudden sense of shyness that had become painful , and to all intents and purposes [their]1660-their looks had already said all that need be said . It might , both felt , be securely left to find its way into words at a more convenient season . In another moment [they]1660-their were in the midst of that most matter - of - fact bustle that precedes in [country - houses]1661-country - houses the settling down to breakfast of [a large party]1662-a large party . ‘ Well , [Mr. Laurence]83-laurence , ’[92-lady ambrose] exclaimed [Lady Ambrose]92-lady ambrose , ‘ all pleasant things come to an end at last . But this visit to [you]83-laurence has really been positively delightful .
